(lp0
S'Photos: Someone Smashed The Hell Out Of Dozens Of LinkNYC Kiosks : Gothamist\nSupport Us\nNYPR Network\nNYPR Network\nGothamist is a website about New York\nView Pretty | Blog\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nNews\nPopular\nWe The Commuters\nAdvertising\nContact\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nPhotos: Someone Smashed The Hell Out Of Dozens Of LinkNYC Kiosks\nby Jake Offenhartz in News\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\ton Apr 22, 2019 1:52 pm\nfullscreen\ncontinue\nview fullscreen\nclose\nThe war between man and machine is heating up, and this time it has nothing to do with Mister Softee.\nIn the last few days, an unidentified vandal and/or Blade Runner has smashed at least 30 LinkNYC kiosks in the West Village and Chelsea, leaving a trail of destruction along 6th and 8th Avenues and across 14th Street. Several of the screens remained black as of Monday morning, while a few others continued to display their standard programming\xe2\x80\x94ads for North Face, #LinkNYCfacts, ads for CitiBank, etc.\xe2\x80\x94through concentric circles of shattered glass.\nObserves Gothamist Editor-In-Chief John Del Signore: "This is why we can\'t have nice dystopian capitalist data harvesting things."\nyikes, somebody went around the village smashing all of the @LinkNYC screens pic.twitter.com/swdtWL82TI\xe2\x80\x94 Josh Machiz (@Machiz) April 20, 2019\nAfter several New Yorkers took note of the rampage online, a spokesperson for LinkNYC said the company was aware of the damage and looking into it. "LinkNYC provides a valuable public service to many of the city\'s most vulnerable," they wrote on Twitter. "When people vandalize Links, they impede on its ability to fund and deliver these services."\nBut not everyone sees it that way. Mark Thomas\xe2\x80\x94a Queens resident who for years has been protesting the company by transforming the structures into ad-hoc noise machines\xe2\x80\x94told Gothamist that it felt like LinkNYC was "using the poor as pawns [to say] \'please don\'t smash our ads.\'"\n"They didn\'t get into the business to serve the poor and vulnerable," he added. "They did it to sell ads and make lots of money."\nHave not seen a @LinkNYC vandalized this blatantly before. Both sides, on 14th between 7th & 8th pic.twitter.com/QOy5L1q187\xe2\x80\x94 Dave Temkin (@dtemkin) April 22, 2019\nSince launching in 2016, the hulking tablets\xe2\x80\x94which now number roughly 1,700 citywide\xe2\x80\x94have faced scrutiny from privacy experts and civil liberties groups over their business model\'s potential for surveillance overreach. The kiosks are effectively underwritten by Google through a subsidiary called Sidewalk Labs, which is headed by former deputy mayor and Hudson Yards-booster Dan Doctoroff. Privately, Doctoroff has described the company\'s plans to track pedestrians and serve them targeted ads, with the goal of "replicating the digital experience in physical space."\nIn addition to offering free gigabit-speed wi-fi and domestic calling, each kiosk includes thirty sensors and three security cameras. According to LinkNYC, footage from the cameras may be shared with law enforcement "to protect your safety, including during an emergency involving potential harm," and in instances of vandalism.\nOn Monday, a spokesperson for the company told Gothamist that the vandal had been spotted on one of the security cameras, and that the footage was shown to the NYPD. The police department did not have any information about LinkNYC-bashing related arrests.\nAccording to Thomas, the prolific spree does seem "a bit scary," considering it likely means a very determined and possibly angry individual is walking around the city with a sledgehammer (or whatever tool of destruction was used).\nAt the same time, he noted, "I did see some beautiful things in the carnage. Somebody\'s really got something to say, and this is their way of saying it." We will keep an eye on our inbox for a manifesto.\nGothamist is now part of WNYC, a nonprofit organization that relies on its members for support. You can help us by making a donation today!\nYour contribution supports more local, New York coverage from Gothamist. Thank you!\nContact the author of this article or email tips@gothamist.com with further questions, comments or tips.\ntwitter\nfacebook\nreddit\nprint\nhuman uprising linknyc vandalism\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\nbest of gothamist\nThe 10 Best Parm Sandwich Spots In NYC The 8 Best Eat-In Movie Theaters In NYCThe Best Of Gothamist 2018The Best Bites Of 2018The 14 Best New Burgers In NYC\n\xc2\xa9 2003-2019 WNYC. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use & Privacy Policy.'

It's easy to spot lines out the door, but some underlying trends are harder to see.Healthy, Homemade Recipes To Save Money And Keep Your Dog FitKeeping your dog healthy and fit is important for a long and happy life.\xc2\xa0Chef Wenford Simpson Cooks Up Island-Themed Easter FoodEaster is a time of year that's deeply connected with food traditions.\xc2\xa0The holiday is an occasion for feasting and the meals usually have a symbolic meaning.\xc2\xa0Furry Friend Finder: Manny And Ralph Are Looking For Forever HomesManny is a 4-year-old, housebroken, Maltipoo mix.\nRalph is 18-months-old, housebroken, 35 pounds and from Brazil.\nMore\nStation Info\nWCBS-TVWLNY-TVContact UsAdvertiseContestsStation Events\nTravel\nFinal Four Guide: Top 10 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Downtown MinneapolisWith thousands of Final Four fans heading to downtown Minneapolis in the coming days, you better believe the Instagram filters will be flying.\nCBS Entertainment\nCBS Entertainment\nLatest Photos\nVisiting The Armour-Stiner (Octagon) HouseHidden along the Hudson River is an eight-sided house that fascinates people who admire odd architecture.\nIcons & Disruptors Podcast\nCBSN New YorkWatch Now\nVandal Smashes 30 LinkNYC Screens At Wi-Fi Kiosks Across\xc2\xa0City\nApril 23, 2019 at 12:44 pmFiled Under:Aundrea Cline-Thomas, Chelsea, LinkNYC, Local TV, Manhattan, New York, West Village\nNEW YORK (CBSNewYork) \xe2\x80\x94 More than two dozen LinkNYC kiosks have been vandalized across the city.\nThe kiosks replaced phone booths and provide free Wi-Fi and calling services, CBS2\xe2\x80\x99s Aundrea Cline-Thomas reported Tuesday.\nAn NYPD officer took pictures of the shattered glass of a kiosk on West 14th Street near 7th Avenue. Caution tape covered another damaged one further down the street.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? Why would you do that? I mean, they\xe2\x80\x99re spending a lot of money to put those out there and it\xe2\x80\x99s kind of convenient,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sandra Brathwait, who works in the area.\nMore than two dozen @LinkNYC kiosks have been vandalized within the last week. More on why #LinkNYC says it impacts the most vulnerable residents: https://t.co/wfcP9DbD8s @CBSNewYork pic.twitter.com/IGoM2kA3JN\n\xe2\x80\x94 Aundrea Cline-Thomas (@AClineThomas) April 23, 2019\nAccording to LinkNYC, there have been 30 kiosks targeted, mainly in this West Village neighborhood and in Chelsea within the last week.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems like an unnecessary form of anger, so it bothers me, definitely,\xe2\x80\x9d West Village resident David Hutchings said.\nOn Friday, Mohammed Islam was at his fruit stand at the corner of 14th Street and 5th Avenue when he said he heard a loud crash at the kiosk just steps away. He said he saw the suspect, a man, throw a large stone at the screen in broad daylight.\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lot of people see \xe2\x80\xa6 he broke the other one and then go,\xe2\x80\x9d Islam said.\nIslam said the screen in question has since been fixed.\nWitnesses called police who then discovered the string of vandalism. The units were installed to replace pay phones and give access to city services.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt gives you free public Wi-Fi. I gives you 311, 911, charge your phone,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Ponessa, who works in Chelsea.\nyikes, somebody went around the village smashing all of the @LinkNYC screens pic.twitter.com/swdtWL82TI\n\xe2\x80\x94 Josh Machiz (@Machiz) April 20, 2019\nThe kiosks have received backlash for being a place where the homeless camp out and where others use the Wi-Fi to watch pornography. Police have not linked those concerns to this string of vandalism, Cline-Thomas reported.\nAuthorities said surveillance video captured the vandalism at certain locations and witnesses were able to take a picture of the suspect.\nOfficials said while the glass is shattered, many of the kiosks still work.\nComments (2)\nTerry Mi says:\nApril 23, 2019 at 8:16 am\nBig mistake to not realize something like this might happen.\nThis type of vandalise can be prevent by protecting the screens with thick plexiglass.\nReply\nboosdiet says:\nApril 23, 2019 at 7:29 am\nGreat\nReply\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nEnter your comment here...\nPlease log in using one of these methods to post your comment:\nEmail (required) (Address never made public)\nName (required)\nWebsite\nYou are commenting using your Google account.\n(\xc2\xa0Log\xc2\xa0Out\xc2\xa0/\nChange\xc2\xa0)\nYou are commenting using your Twitter account.\n(\xc2\xa0Log\xc2\xa0Out\xc2\xa0/\nChange\xc2\xa0)\nYou are commenting using your Facebook account.\n(\xc2\xa0Log\xc2\xa0Out\xc2\xa0/\nChange\xc2\xa0)\nCancel\nConnecting to %s\nNotify me of new comments via email. aS'Man smashes LinkNYC kiosks in Manhattan | WPIX 11 New York\nGoSearch\nWatch Now: PIX11 News at 5\nPIX11 TV Schedule\nWatch CW Shows\nSearch\nContact Us\nWPIX 11 New York\nMenu\nLocal News\nVideos\nMorning\nTraffic\nTransit\nTeam\nContests\nApps\nEvents\nWeather\n68\xc2\xb0\n68\xc2\xb0\nLow 57\xc2\xb0\nHigh 72\xc2\xb0\nWed\n49\xc2\xb0\n68\xc2\xb0\nThu\n53\xc2\xb0\n63\xc2\xb0\nFri\n50\xc2\xb0\n65\xc2\xb0\nSee complete forecast\nSevere weather alert\nMan smashes LinkNYC kiosks in\xc2\xa0Manhattan\nPosted 10:19 PM, April 22, 2019, by Henry Rosoff, Updated at 10:22PM, April 22, 2019\nShare this:FacebookTwitterRedditPinterestEmail\nPlease enable Javascript to watch this video\nCHELSEA, Manhattan\xe2\x80\x94Several of the 9.5-foot-tall LinkNYC kiosks along 6th Ave, 8th Ave and 14th Street were smashed over the weekend.\nEach screen was hit in the same way: a solid blow to both sides using an object seemingly similar to a baseball bat. The charging, phone, Wi-Fi and other functions of the kiosks appear to be unaffected.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Twitter account talked about how the kiosks help the homeless and those with low income writing:\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC provides a valuable public service to many of the city\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable. When people vandalize Links, they impede on its ability to fund and deliver these services.\xe2\x80\x9d\nHowever, the telecom companies that operate the roughly 1,700 kiosks are not exactly hurting for cash. The ads are expected to generate about a billion dollars over 12 years; the city gets half that money.\nThe NYPD may also soon be arresting the screen cracking culprit. He was caught on the security cameras of one of the kiosks.\nSubmit tips to police by calling Crime Stoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477), visiting http://www.nypdcrimestoppers.com, or texting 274637 (CRIMES) then entering TIP577. Spanish-speaking callers are asked to dial 1-888-57-PISTA (74782).\nFiled in: Manhattan, News\nSuggest a correction\n\xc3\x97\nSuggest A Correction\nYour name\nYour email\nReport a typo or grammatical error\nCancel\nShare this:FacebookTwitterRedditPinterestEmail\nPIX11\xe2\x80\x99s Fuel My School\xc2\xa0Campaign\nTell us how your school makes a difference and you could win $11,000 for school supplies for your NY or NJ classroom!\nPopular\nChanel Lewis sentenced to life in prison for murder of Queens jogger Karina\xc2\xa0Vetrano\nBrenda Jackson, mother of Dale Earnhardt Jr., dies at\xc2\xa065\nWoman, 21, dies on Manhattan subway\xc2\xa0tracks\nMan arrested in Brooklyn hacking rampage; PIX11 News spoke exclusively with suspect before\xc2\xa0arrest\nLatest News\nLong Island mourns for local Marine killed by a roadside bomb in\xc2\xa0Afghanistan\nWoman dies after falling into meat grinder at Pennsylvania\xc2\xa0plant\nWinner of $768.4 million Powerball jackpot is 24-year-old Wisconsin\xc2\xa0man\nTraffic stop leads to capture of fake cab driver, woman locked inside van with stolen license plate:\xc2\xa0NYSP\nLocal Stories News\nNYPD cracks down on lockboxes being used to store drugs on NYC phone\xc2\xa0kiosks\nExtra Manhattan Morning\n\xe2\x80\x98Original Soupman\xe2\x80\x99 made famous by \xe2\x80\x98Seinfeld\xe2\x80\x99 opens kiosk in moves closer to\xc2\xa0reality\nNews\nTreasurer of police charity stole $400K meant for families of fallen NYPD officers:\xc2\xa0prosecutors\nNews\n\xe2\x80\x98Bad Girls Club\xe2\x80\x99 star Shannade aS"Vandal Smashes 30 LinkNYC Kiosk Screens, Spokesperson Says\n- NBC New YorkHomeNewsLocalTop Video U.S. & WorldHealthWeirdWeatherTechSportsWeatherForecastMaps & RadarWeather AlertsSchool Closing AlertsWeather NewsInvestigationsI-TeamBetter Get BaqueroEntertainmentEntertainment NewsThe SceneIn The WingsNY LiveYour Guide 4 NYOpen HouseBreakfast With Open HouseGeorge to the Rescue1st LookCOZI TVTrafficCommunityContact UsContestsTV ListingsLIVE TVLIVE TVON NOWNews 4 NY at 5:30ON DEMANDNBC on DemandWatch the latest full episodes of your favorite NBC series anytime and anywhere.Click for full schedule66\xc2\xb0ConnectSocial MediaOur ProductsNewsletters\nSend us Videos and Pictures\nSend Tips\nSubmit a Complaint\nSubmit TipsSend FeedbackTerms of ServicePrivacy PolicyVisit our partner siteWATCH LIVENews 4 NY at 5:30Vandal Smashes 30 LinkNYC Kiosk Screens, Spokesperson SaysThe vandal damaged a total of 30 kiosks, the spokesperson saidPublished Apr 22, 2019 at 4:18 PM | Updated at 7:33 PM EDT on Apr 22, 2019 NEWSLETTERS Receive the latest local\nupdates in your inboxEmailPrivacy policy | More Newsletters UP NEXT XVandal Smashes 30 LinkNYC Kiosk ScreensLinkEmbedCopyClose Link to this video //www.nbcnewyork.com/on-air/as-seen-on/Vandal-Smashes-30-LinkNYC-Kiosk-Screens_New-York-508914412.htmlCopyClose Embed this video Replay More videos (1 of 9)\xc2\xab\xc2\xbbVandal Smashes 30 LinkNYC Kiosk ScreensA vandal smashed the screens on more than two dozen LinkNYC kiosks in Manhattan, a spokesperson for the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 operators said. Michael George reports. (Published Monday, April 22, 2019)What to KnowA vandal smashed the screens on more than two dozen LinkNYC kiosks in Manhattan, a spokesperson for the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 operators saidThe vandal damaged a total of 30 kiosks, the spokesperson saidThe NYPD is aware of the vandalism and investigating, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s spokesperson saidA vandal smashed the screens on more than two dozen LinkNYC kiosks in Manhattan, a spokesperson for the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 operators said.The vandal damaged a total of 30 kiosks, the spokesperson said.All of the damaged kiosks are located in Chelsea and the West Village, according to Gothamist.The NYPD is aware of the vandalism and investigating, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s spokesperson said.Top Tri-State News PhotosAP\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC provides a valuable public service to many of the city\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable,\xe2\x80\x9d the spokesperson said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen people vandalize Links, they impede on its ability to fund and deliver these services.\xe2\x80\x9dThe number people call the most using the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 tablet phone app is the EBT \xe2\x80\x94 Electronic Benefits Transfer \xe2\x80\x94 customer service line, according to the spokesperson.\xc2\xa0When LinkNYC surveyed kiosk users recently, 15 percent of people who responded said the kiosks were \xe2\x80\x9ctheir only high speed internet connection,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the spokesperson.MTA Probes 'Horrible, Uncommon' Death of Subway Rider in NYC\xe2\x80\x9cThat number goes up to 29 percent in some areas of the city,\xe2\x80\x9d the spokesperson added.It wasn't immediately clear how many users were surveyed.Get the latest from NBC 4 New York anywhere, anytimeDownload the App\nAvailable for IOS and AndroidFollow NBC New York Calendar\nNew Yorker of the Week\nScholar Athlete\nOur Journalists\nWEATHER ALERTView full list of weather alerts\nCLOSINGS ALERTView full list of closures\nPolice Investigating Smashed LinkNYC Kiosk Screens\nBy\nSpectrum News Staff\nPUBLISHED 7:10 AM ET Apr. 23, 2019\nPUBLISHED 7:10 AM EDT Apr. 23, 2019\nSHARE\nNEW YORK -\xc2\xa0Police are trying to track down the person who destroyed dozens of LinkNYC kiosks throughout the city.\nThe electronic kiosks provide free WiFi, phone calls and device charging.\nOn Friday, someone filed a complaint to police, saying a rock was thrown at a kiosk near Union Square.\nLinkNYC says 30 kiosks were smashed, and that security cameras captured the person they believe is responsible.\nAnyone with information on the case should contact the Crime Stoppers hotline at 1-800-577-8477, or text CRIMES and then enter TIP577, or visit\xc2\xa0www.nypdcrimestoppers.com.\nREAD MORE\nLATEST NEWS\nCHANGE aS'At least 30 LinkNYC kiosks vandalized in Chelsea, West Village | abc7ny.com\nWATCH LIVENew York CityNew JerseyLong IslandNorthern SuburbsConnecticutEDITLog InVideoPhotosLocal News New York CityNew JerseyLong IslandNorthern SuburbsConnecticutCategories WeatherTrafficLocalish7 On Your Side7 On Your Side InvestigatesU.S. & WorldPoliticsSportsWeatherEntertainmentBackstage with Sandy KenyonNeighborhood EatsNeighborhood TreatsIn Our BackyardGlam LabStation Info About ABC 7Meet the News TeamABC 7 In Your CommunitySweepstakes and RulesTV ListingsJobsshows Live with Kelly and RyanABC 7 Shows & SpecialsLive Well NetworkSend photos/videos here or use #abc7NYFollow Us:Welcome, Your AccountLog OutShareTweetEmailAt least 30 LinkNYC kiosks vandalized in ManhattanShare:ShareTweetEmailEMBED <>More Videos <iframe width="476" height="267" src="https://abc7ny.com/video/embed/?pid=5265460" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>Tim Fleischer reports on LinkNYC kiosks vandalized in Manhattan.Share:ShareTweetEmailWABC WEST VILLAGE, Manhattan (WABC) -- Police are investigating after more than two dozen LinkNYC kiosks were vandalized in Manhattan.\nA spokesperson with LinkNYC says at least 30 kiosks have been smashed in the West Village and Chelsea, leaving a trail of destruction along 6th and 8th avenues and across 14th Street.\nThe first incident was reported April 19 at 15th Street and 5th Ave just after noon. A rock was used to smash the kiosk.\nSeveral of the screens remained black as of Monday morning, while a few others continued to display their standard programming.\nSecurity footage captured the person causing the damage and several good Samaritans called police to provide a suspect description.\nNo arrests have been made, but a witness described the vandal as a white male who was last seen wearing a black shirt, jeans and was carrying an "I Love NY" bag.\nLinkNYC provides a way to access the internet, a public service that for some is their only way to get internet service. A company spokesperson released the following statement:\n"LinkNYC provides a valuable public service to many of the city\'s most vulnerable. The most dialed number using the tablet phone app is the EBT customer service line; and in a recent survey of LinkNYC users, 15% of respondents from New York said it is their only high speed internet connection. That number goes up to 29% in some areas of the city. When people vandalize Links, they impede on its ability to fund and deliver these services."\nHave not seen a @LinkNYC vandalized this blatantly before. Both sides, on 14th between 7th & 8th pic.twitter.com/QOy5L1q187\xe2\x80\x94 Dave Temkin (@dtemkin) April 22, 2019\n----------\n* More Manhattan news\n* Send us a news tip\n* Download the abc7NY app for breaking news alerts\n*Follow us on YouTube\n*\nReport a correction or typo\nRelated topics:chelseawest villagemanhattannew york citycrimenypdvandalismsurveillance videoShare:ShareTweetEmailCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 WABC-TV. aS"A lost iPhone | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n68\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n68\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nOpinionColumnistsMark Chiusano\nA lost iPhone\nAn iPhone lost in Manhattan, and how some people use those LinkNYC kiosks.\nAn iPhone lost in Manhattan, and how some people use those LinkNYC kiosks.\nPhoto Credit: Colter Hettich\nBy Mark Chiusano mark.chiusano@amny.com\n@mjchiusano\nApril 16, 2019 6:02 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nMore than an addictive device\nI was leaving the office the other day and already staring down at my phone. The usual addictions \xe2\x80\x93\xc2\xa0a quick email check, as if the elevator ride since the last one had been more than 30 seconds. Then Google Maps to see when the next train was coming, as if I could do anything but get on. Given my neck-bent focus I didn\xe2\x80\x99t notice the woman at the LinkNYC kiosk until I was a few feet in front of her. She was hunched over even more than I was, talking into the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s screen.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYeah, I\xe2\x80\x99m calling you from the kiosk,\xe2\x80\x9d the woman was saying,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cbecause I lost my iPhone.\xe2\x80\x9d The man on the other end sounded confused. You could hear his voice because the woman didn\xe2\x80\x99t have headphones, so her call wasn\xe2\x80\x99t private.\nShe was wearing just a white T-shirt even though it was cold and drizzling. She was carrying some belongings in plastic bags. She sounded distressed but not acutely distressed, more like losing a cell phone was one more in a line of things to be distressed about.\nMaybe I got that impression because of the other people standing on the corner near the kiosk. Someone charging their phone, two guys doing the lean-stagger that tends to mean you\xe2\x80\x99re high on something. An infamous midtown McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s is a block away, where people go to buy Klonopin or sleep through their Methadone.\nMaybe I got that impression due to assumptions about the people who often use the shiny kiosks, which were basically meant to replace\xc2\xa0payphones. Now the kiosk advertisement screens tell us to buy cars or perfume or go vote. Then there\xe2\x80\x99s the little tablet embedded\xc2\xa0on the side that was the subject of horror and glee a couple years ago when homeless people (or a homeless person or two) figured out how to watch pornography out there on the streets.\nIntersection, the company provider for the kiosks, has moved beyond the porn problem but added other tools for people who might not have a phone or laptop or an unlimited data plan\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x93\xc2\xa0a problem in stark contrast to the phone addiction of all those zombies you see walking with their heads on emails or Instagram.\nThe company says it sees 9,000 tablet searches per month on the social service directory Aunt Bertha.\nSign up for amExpress, the conversation starter for New Yorkers.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\nOf the 600,000 monthly calls facilitated by the kiosks, Intersection says the state EBT line is the most dialed, where callers can get questions answered about food stamps and similar services.\nMaybe the woman in the white T-shirt who\xe2\x80\x99d lost her phone was someone who might use\xc2\xa0the kiosks for urgent reasons. Maybe a phone meant something more to her than an addictive device. Maybe she had a story to tell. This occurred to me just after I swiped into the subway station for my ride home and saw that the train whose arrival I\xe2\x80\x99d been checking had just left. My eyes had been on the phone almost the whole time. I put my phone and its screen back in my pocket and reality returned.\nI went back through the turnstile and jogged up the stairs into the drizzle, rounded the corner past the lean-stagger men to the kiosk to see whether\xc2\xa0the woman would talk to me.\nBut by the time I got there, she was gone.\nBy Mark Chiusano mark.chiusano@amny.com\n@mjchiusano\nMark Chiusano has been a columnist and editorial writer for amNewYork and Newsday since 2015.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nKarina Vetrano's killer\xc2\xa0sentenced to life in prison Your MetroCard could win you a 7-day trip to Hawaii What we know about the Karina Vetrano case Subway rider killed in 'horrible' dragging incident A rich revival of 'All My Sons'\nTop columns\nThis is what happens when rules are followed\nWhat if there were no Facebook?\nLessons and tragic loss in Sri Lanka\nJimmy Margulies cartoons\nUnifying power of 'Star Wars'\nAct on the message of Earth Day\nTop News stories\nRanked Choice Voting proposed for NYC\nKarina Vetrano's killer\xc2\xa0sentenced to life in prison\nWhat we know about the Karina Vetrano case\nWhat to know about the\xc2\xa0Karina Vetrano murder retrial\nMan arrested in connection with\xc2\xa0murder at\xc2\xa0Bushwick Houses\nMTA conductor stabbed on Bronx subway platform\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. All rights reserved."

aS"LinkNYC's 6 million users have used 8.6 terabytes of data | VentureBeat\nCHANNELS l\nl\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nAI\nAR/VR\nBig Data\nBusiness\nCloud\nCommerce\nDev\nEnterprise\nEntrepreneur\nEsports\nHeartland Tech\nMarketing\nMedia\nMobile\nPC Gaming\nSecurity\nSocial\nTransportation\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nWebinars\nAdvertise\nVB Lab\nEVENTS l\nl\nVB EVENTS\nUpcoming Events\nGET INVOLVED\nSponsor\nMedia Partner\nVolunteer\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nWebinars\nAdvertise\nVB Lab\nNEWSLETTERS\nJOB BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nCHANNELS\n\xe2\x80\xba\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nEsports\nAI\nHeartland Tech\nAR/VR\nMarketing\nBig Data\nMedia\nBusiness\nMobile\nCloud\nPC Gaming\nCommerce\nSecurity\nDev\nSocial\nEnterprise\nTransportation\nEntrepreneur\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nEVENTS\n\xe2\x80\xba\nVB EVENTS\nUpcoming Events\nGET INVOLVED\nSponsor\nMedia Partner\nVolunteer\nNEWSLETTERS\nJOB BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nVENTUREBEAT\n\xe2\x80\xba\nAbout\nAdvertise\nCareers\nContact\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nVB Lab\nWebinars\nPrivacy Policy\nMOBILE\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 6 million users have used 8.6 terabytes of data\nKyle Wiggers@Kyle_L_Wiggers March 28, 2019 6:15 AM\nImage Credit: LinkNYC\nMOST READ\nGoogle Maps will now show real-time availability of electric vehicle charging stations\nTesla plans to launch driverless taxi service in 2020\nGoogle\xe2\x80\x99s SpecAugment achieves state-of-the-art speech recognition without a language model\nTesla claims its latest self-driving chip is 7 times more powerful than its rivals\xe2\x80\x99\nFortnite teams up with Avengers: Endgame for another tie-in on April 25\nUPCOMING EVENTS\nGamesBeat Summit:\nApr. 23 - 24\nTransform:\nJul. 10 - 11\nWhat better way to replace New York City\xe2\x80\x99s thousands of aging pay phones than with 9.5-foot-tall kiosks outfitted with 55-inch HD displays, gigabit internet, and Android tablets preloaded with informational apps? So went the thinking back in 2014, when then-mayor Michael Bloomberg launched a competition \xe2\x80\x94 the Reinvent Payphones initiative \xe2\x80\x94 calling on private enterprises, residents, and nonprofits to submit designs for spruced-up, publicly accessible hubs that would provide advertising-subsidized services to the public.\nCityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC beat out piezoelectric pressure plates, EV charging stations, and other competing proposals for a contract, and the consortium wasted no time in getting to work. Intersection \xe2\x80\x94 which with Qualcomm and CIVIQ Smartscapes manages the kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 said it plans to spend $200 million laying down 400 miles of new communication cables and installing as many as 10,000 Links that supply free Wi-Fi to passersby within a 150-foot radius. The first kiosk went online in January, though the project has quite a ways to go \xe2\x80\x94 1,780 Links are active currently, short of the initial goal of 4,500 kiosks by July of this year. But many promised features \xe2\x80\x94 like buttons that link directly to 911 and New York\xe2\x80\x99s 311 service, USB chargers, backup batteries, and a VoIP service that allows free calls to all 50 states and Washington, D.C. \xe2\x80\x94 made their way into the final design.\nAnd the initial kiosks have really taken off. According to Intersection, the LinkNYC network now has more than 6 million unique users who have used 8.597 terabytes of data collectively \xe2\x80\x94 equivalent to about 1.3 billion songs or 292 billion WhatsApp messages. And the project facilitates 600,000 phone calls every month, up from 500,000 in September of last year.\nPeople using the Links\xe2\x80\x99 tethered tablets complete about 9,000 searches per month on the built-in social services directory and 311 app, Intersection says, with the most common search terms being: \xe2\x80\x9cwork,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chousing health,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cpublic benefits.\xe2\x80\x9d Almost 3 times the numbers of searches \xe2\x80\x94 36,000 per month \xe2\x80\x94 are performed in the Maps app, the bulk of which are for \xe2\x80\x9cmidnight run,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfood/clothing delivery,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBest Buy,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmovie theaters.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe mishmash of metrics underscores the fact that for some New Yorkers, the Link hubs aren\xe2\x80\x99t just a convenience \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re a lifeline.\nA 2015 study by the New York City Bureau of Policy and Research found that 25 percent of NYC residents don\xe2\x80\x99t have home broadband internet, including 32 percent of unemployed residents. And according to a 2015 survey published by the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Consumer Affairs, 44.5 percent of residents without an income didn\xe2\x80\x99t own a cell phone or a service plan. It\xe2\x80\x99s perhaps unsurprising, then, that the most-dialed number on Link hubs is the New York State Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) helpline, through which families can access Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits and other social support.\nFour years ago, Mayor Bill De Blasio touted the Links as a sign of progress in the fight for a democratized internet. \xe2\x80\x9c[They\xe2\x80\x99re] the fastest and largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9c[and] a critical step toward a more equal, open, and connected city for every New Yorker, in every borough.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt bears mentioning that LinkNYC isn\xe2\x80\x99t a philanthropic effort \xe2\x80\x94 investors extended $150 million in financing to Intersection in 2017. Moreover, despite the fact that revenue fell short of expectations in the first two years \xe2\x80\x94 the city collected $43.4 million in payments, narrowly beating the $42.5 million minimum CityBridge guaranteed \xe2\x80\x94 display ads, sponsorships, and partnerships on the Links are expected to generate between $500 million and a billion dollars over the next 12 years. (CityBridge and the city split the ad revenue equally; under an amended deal, CityBridge will delay paying the city its share of revenues above the minimum payments until the last year of the contract, when they\xe2\x80\x99ll be due with 10 percent interest.)\nThat said, Intersection contends it\xe2\x80\x99s doing its part to promote art, culture, and political participation through its army of kiosks. When the Links\xe2\x80\x99 screens aren\xe2\x80\x99t showing real-time bus arrivals and local maps, programming consists of rotating regular, seasonal, and limited-time content collaborations with organizations, publications, and government agencies. That includes headlines from the Associated Press, comics, weather info, and real-time alerts from the Office of Emergency Management, along with hundreds of hyperlocal factoids \xe2\x80\x94 dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cNYC Fun Facts\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThis Day in New York\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 about people, places, and things.\nTo date, Intersection says it has showed 40 local artists, 2,000 local events, and 750 NYC Facts \xe2\x80\x94 oh, and seven marriage proposals.\nOn the civic engagement side of the equation, Intersection last April teamed up with the New York City Council to roll out Participatory Budgeting New York City, which let residents as young as 11 vote via the tablets on how the city will allocate a $1-million-per-neighborhood public budget. (This weekend marks the launch of its second year.) Intersection also launched an awareness campaign to get New Yorkers registered to vote in advance of the November 2018 general elections, and it circulates Community Board meeting notices and local road closures through its LinkLocal program, which lets small businesses advertise for free on select Links around the city.\nIntersection says there were 14,473 tablet app sessions to access voter registration and voter information this past election cycle and that over 150 board meeting notices are on LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s regular content rotation.\nEncouraging as those stats might be, they\xe2\x80\x99re unlikely to assuage Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s loudest critics, some of whom \xe2\x80\x94 including the Intercept, the American Civil Liberties Union, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Stop LinkNYC, and ReThink LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x94 have brought attention to the hubs\xe2\x80\x99 potential for mass surveillance. Each Link is equipped with three cameras capable of, among other things, \xe2\x80\x9cmonitor[ing] pedestrian, bike, and car traffic; track[ing] passing wireless devices; listen[ing] to street noise; and \xe2\x80\xa6 identify[ing] abandoned packages.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIntersection says it makes clear in its privacy policy that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t collect information about users\xe2\x80\x99 precise locations. In response to allegations that it intends to track Wi-Fi users\xe2\x80\x99 real-time positions, Intersection says it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t collect their clickstream data or browsing history. It also says that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t share data with third parties freely and makes \xe2\x80\x9creasonable attempts\xe2\x80\x9d to notify affected users in the event it receives a data-pull request from a government agency.\nIntersection added vision-assistance tools after the National Federation of the Blind sued the City of New York and LinkNYC, arguing that the tablets lacked basic accessibility features. (They\xe2\x80\x99re now are fully compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.) And some advocacy groups have levied nuisance complaints against Intersection, claiming that the Links encourage loitering. The tablets initially had an internet browser, but engineers disabled it in response to complaints about users browsing pornographic material.\nFor better or worse, those bumps in the road haven\xe2\x80\x99t dissuaded expansion. Beginning in 2017, in collaboration with British telecommunications company BT and British advertising agency Primesight, Intersection began installing hundreds of hubs in the U.K., including in London, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, where they\xe2\x80\x99re branded LinkUK. Elsewhere, kiosks have been installed in the New Jersey city of Newark (LinkNWK), across the Hudson River from Manhattan, and on the busiest street corners in Philadelphia (LinkPHL).\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99ll definitely be a combination of lessons learned and ensuring we add a little local flavor [to our programing],\xe2\x80\x9d Amanda Giddon, senior consumer marketing manager at Intersection, told VentureBeat in an earlier interview. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have research teams in New York and Philadelphia who\xe2\x80\x99ve conducted some preliminary focus group testing to understand how to best serve the community. We\xe2\x80\x99re really open to feedback, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve done a lot of work here and look forward to seeing how it\xe2\x80\x99s received.\xe2\x80\x9d"
p9
aS'Are LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Tracking Your Movements?\nTheIntercept_EnglishPortugu\xc3\xaasPoliticsJusticeNational SecurityWorldTechnologyEnvironmentSpecial InvestigationsVoicesPodcastsVideosDocumentsAboutEditorial PoliciesBecome a SourceJoin NewsletterBecome A Member\xc2\xa9 First Look Media. All rights reservedTerms of usePrivacySitemapTheIntercept_Photo illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesPhoto illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesAre New York\xe2\x80\x99s Free LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Tracking Your Movements?Ava KofmanAva KofmanSeptember 8 2018, 1:00\xc2\xa0p.m.Photo illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesPhoto illustration: Soohee Cho/The Intercept, Getty ImagesLinkNYC kiosks have become a familiar eyesore to New Yorkers. Over 1,600 of these towering, nine-and-a-half-foot monoliths \xe2\x80\x94 their double-sided screens\xc2\xa0festooned with ads and fun facts \xe2\x80\x94 have been installed across the city since early 2016. Mayor Bill de Blasio has celebrated their ability to provide \xe2\x80\x9cthe fastest and largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world\xe2\x80\x9d as \xe2\x80\x9ca critical step toward a more equal, open, and connected city for every New Yorker, in every borough.\xe2\x80\x9d Anyone can use the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 Android tablets to search for directions and services; they are also equipped with charging stations, 911 buttons, and phones for free domestic calls.\nBut even as the kiosks have provided important services to connect New Yorkers, they\xc2\xa0may\xc2\xa0also\xc2\xa0represent\xc2\xa0a troubling expansion of the city\xe2\x80\x99s surveillance network,\xc2\xa0potentially connecting every borough to a new level of invasive monitoring. Each kiosk has three cameras,\xc2\xa030 sensors, and heightened sight lines for viewing above crowds.\nSince plans for LinkNYC were first unveiled, journalists, residents, and civil liberties experts have raised concerns that\xc2\xa0the internet kiosks might be storing sensitive data about its users and possibly tracking their movements. For the last two years, the American Civil Liberties Union, Electronic Frontier Foundation, and a small but vocal group of activists \xe2\x80\x94 including ReThink LinkNYC, a grassroots anti-surveillance group, and the anonymous Stop LinkNYC coalition \xe2\x80\x94 have highlighted the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s potential to track locations, collect personal information, and fuel mass surveillance.\nNow an undergraduate researcher has discovered indications in LinkNYC code\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 accidentally made public on the internet\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0that LinkNYC may be actively planning to track users\xe2\x80\x99 locations.\nMayor Bill de Blasio speaks at\xc2\xa0a press conference next to\xc2\xa0a LinkNYC public internet\xc2\xa0kiosk on Feb 18, 2016.\nPhoto: Albin Lohr-Jones/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re the Product\nPlans to replace the city\xe2\x80\x99s payphone booth network with Wi-Fi-enabled kiosks were first announced by de Blasio in 2014. Less than a year later, the city awarded a contract to a chameleon-like consortium of private companies known as CityBridge. It was an attractive deal: LinkNYC kiosks, at no cost to the city, would provide free internet coverage to anyone walking by. CityBridge, in turn, would be responsible for the installation, ownership, and construction of the devices, with plans to earn back its expenses through advertising. The twin 55-inch displays will eventually carry targeted ads derived from the information collected about kiosk users.\nThese terms raised alarms among internet researchers and privacy experts, who were quick to point out that nothing in life is truly free. \xe2\x80\x9cAs we know,\xe2\x80\x9d Benjamin Dean, a technology policy analyst, told attendees at a New York hacking conference in 2016, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you\xe2\x80\x99re not paying, you\xe2\x80\x99re not the customer \xe2\x80\x94 you\xe2\x80\x99re the product.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe key player in CityBridge is known as Intersection, and one of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s largest investors is Sidewalk Labs, with whom it also shares the same offices and staff. Sidewalk Labs CEO Daniel Doctoroff is the chair of Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s board. Sidewalk Labs is owned by Google\xe2\x80\x99s holding company, Alphabet Inc. In other words, the\xc2\xa0plan to blanket New York City with 7,500 camera-equipped obelisks has been largely underwritten by the company formerly known as Google \xe2\x80\x94 a corporation whose business model depends on selling your personal information to advertisers. As Doctoroff, who was also the city\xe2\x80\x99s former deputy mayor of economic development, has said of the kiosks: \xe2\x80\x9cBy having access to the browsing activity of people using the Wi-Fi \xe2\x80\x94 all anonymized and aggregated \xe2\x80\x94 we can actually then target ads to people in proximity and then obviously over time, track them through lots of different things, like beacons and location services, as well as their browsing activity. So in effect, what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing is replicating the digital experience in physical space.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn March 2016, the New York Civil Liberties Union raised multiple concerns with the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s vast and indefinite data retention and the possibilities for unwarranted NYPD surveillance. The NYCLU asked whether environmental sensors and cameras would be hooked up to NYPD systems, including the Domain Awareness System (built by Microsoft). LinkNYC has since updated its policy to state that it will take reasonable efforts to notify users if their information is being shared with law enforcement.\nIn May of this year, Charles Meyers, an undergraduate at New York City College of Technology, came across folders in LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s public library on GitHub, a platform for managing files and software, that appear to raise further questions about location tracking and the platform\xe2\x80\x99s protection of its users\xe2\x80\x99 data. Meyers made copies of the codebases in question \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC Mobile Observation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and shared both folders with The Intercept.\nAccording to Meyers, the \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC Mobile Observation\xe2\x80\x9d code collects the user\xe2\x80\x99s longitude and latitude, as well as the user\xe2\x80\x99s browser type, operating system, device type, device identifiers, and full URL clickstreams (including date and time) and aggregates this information into a database. In Meyers\xe2\x80\x99s view, this code \xe2\x80\x94 along with the functions of the \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d codebase \xe2\x80\x94 suggests that the company is interested in tracking the locations of Wi-Fi users in real time.\xc2\xa0If such code were run on a mobile app or kiosk, he said, the company would be able\xc2\xa0to make advertisements available in real time based on where and who someone was, and that this would constitute a potential violation of the company\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy.\xc2\xa0In 2016, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy made it clear that it did not collect information about users\xe2\x80\x99 precise locations. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d it states, \xe2\x80\x9cwe know where we provide WiFi services, so when you use the services we can determine your general location.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLinkNYC disputes these speculations. David Mitchell, Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s chief technology officer, told the Intercept that the code was never intended to be released and was part of a longer-term research and development process. \xe2\x80\x9cIn this instance,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained over email, \xe2\x80\x9cIntersection was prototyping and testing some ideas internally, using employee data only, and mistakenly made source code public on Github. This code is not in use on the LinkNYC network.\xe2\x80\x9d An Intersection spokesperson added that LinkNYC does not collect users\xe2\x80\x99 clickstream data or browsing history, and that it has not used the \xe2\x80\x9cRxLocation\xe2\x80\x9d codebase to collect user data. LinkNYC did not respond to repeated questions about the function or purpose of the code.\nThe Intercept asked four technologists, including a computer forensics investigator and an expert on Wi-Fi location tracking, to independently review the code. Each confirmed that the code could execute commands as Meyers had described, but they emphasized that it was not possible to determine the purpose of the code and whether it was actually running on any kiosks or devices\xc2\xa0based on the information given. They concluded that it was unlikely that\xc2\xa0the code\xc2\xa0was currently in use, as its unfinished security features pointed to the fact that\xc2\xa0it appeared to be in progress, possibly for a mobile product. \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t know why it exists, but the fact that it exists is creepy,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Surya Mattu, a research scientist and artist. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no way properly to interrogate this further as a third party.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor many researchers and privacy experts, this lack of third party oversight represents the\xc2\xa0most significant issue. Privacy experts told The Intercept that the lack of clarity surrounding LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s leaked code points to the larger lack of transparency surrounding the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s operations. Despite their omnipresence in the city\xe2\x80\x99s major public spaces, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s pervasive data collection is not constrained by any auditing mechanisms, explained Daniel Schwarz, a technology fellow at the NYCLU. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout transparency and external auditing of the source code, as well as what data is collected, for what purpose, and how it is being monetized by the company,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no way to verify whether the privacy policy is working to protect users\xe2\x80\x99 data.\xe2\x80\x9d\nA few hours after The Intercept contacted LinkNYC for comment, the company demanded that Github remove Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s copy of its code due to copyright violations.\nPedestrians pass one of the new Wi-Fi kiosks that offer free web surfing, phone calls and a charging station on August 24, 2016 in New York City.\nPhoto: Spencer Platt/Getty Images\nConnecting \xe2\x80\x94 and Controlling \xe2\x80\x94 Communities\nAs LinkNYC expands across the globe \xe2\x80\x94 Intersection has unveiled plans for kiosks in Philadelphia, Toronto, and the U.K. \xe2\x80\x94 so too does the scope of the concerns surrounding it. Shahid Buttar, the EFF\xe2\x80\x99s director of grassroots advocacy, has warned of the possibility of mission creep \xe2\x80\x94 that is, the expansion of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s uses beyond its stated purpose to provide free Wi-Fi. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no reason to presume that a current statement of policy will constrain the consortium of the future,\xe2\x80\x9d Buttar said.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s current privacy policy already shows that the company sweeps up enormous amounts of sensitive data\xc2\xa0from all users, such as \xe2\x80\x9cMAC address (anonymized), IP address, browser type and version, time zone setting, browser plug-in types and versions, operating system and platform, device type, and device identifiers.\xe2\x80\x9d LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy classifies this information as technical, rather than personal, data.\xc2\xa0It may occasionally \xe2\x80\x9csupplement anonymized Technical Information we collect from you with information collected by third parties. Third parties may include advertising partners or other providers that help us understand our users.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThis distinction, privacy experts say, ignores the fact that device identifiers \xe2\x80\x94 even when anonymized \xe2\x80\x94 provide more than enough information to tell advertisers, law enforcement, or malefactors who we are, since most phones and computers are used by the individuals who own them. Knowing\xc2\xa0that a device has been in multiple locations, along with\xc2\xa0the history of the Wi-Fi networks it has visited,\xc2\xa0can provide enough information for someone to find out where individuals live, work, commute, shop, and so on.\xc2\xa0A recent Associated Press investigation found that many Google services for Android devices and iPhones were storing location data even if when users had turned on a privacy setting to prevent Google from doing so.\nAccording to privacy watchdogs, the rollout of the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s cameras have shown how the mission has already expanded beyond its initial purview. In 2016, LinkNYC disclosed that the kiosks \xe2\x80\x9cmay\xe2\x80\x9d contain cameras; by 2017, the cameras were operational. LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy states that cameras do not keep video records for more than seven days and that the camera footage is used to \xe2\x80\x9cimprove the services.\xe2\x80\x9d But opting out is not an option: Just by walking down the block, it is possible to be swept into its audio or video feeds, which can capture a nearly 360-degree view of their surroundings. Civil liberties experts have concerns about the circumstances under which CityBridge will share its ongoing taping with law enforcement. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, according to documents obtained by ReCode, Sidewalk Labs is selling kiosks to other cities that will be able to \xe2\x80\x9cmonitor pedestrian, bike and car traffic, track passing wireless devices, listen to street noise and use the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 built-in video cameras to identify abandoned packages.\xe2\x80\x9d Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s chief innovation officer told MIT Tech Review that it was considering upgrading kiosks to support augmented reality and autonomous vehicles.\nJoin Our NewsletterOriginal reporting. Fearless journalism. Delivered to you.I\xe2\x80\x99m in\nThe NYCLU and EFF stated that the ambiguity surrounding Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s discovery of the code underscores the need for community-driven initiatives to protect the privacy and civil liberties of users. As EFF has noted, there are no means for New Yorkers to participate in decisions about how data from LinkNYC kiosks will be used, with whom they will be shared, for how long they will be retained, or whether the parameters under which they\xc2\xa0are initially collected might expand in the future. In response to Meyer\xe2\x80\x99s findings, ReThink LinkNYC is calling for third-party oversight to confirm that the company\xe2\x80\x99s software does what it says it does.\nThe New York City Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office did not respond to a request for comment on the calls for auditing and stronger oversight. Samir Saini, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT),\xc2\xa0wrote in an email to The Intercept following the publication of the story that \xe2\x80\x9cas a public project, LinkNYC can only exist if it conforms to the City\xe2\x80\x99s unambiguous commitment to user privacy. That means the City does not, and will never, allow the network operator \xe2\x80\x94 CityBridge \xe2\x80\x94 to exploit individual identifiers or precise location of LinkNYC users. If, at any time during our careful oversight of CityBridge, we discover practices that violate the Privacy Policy, we will direct CityBridge to immediately cease and desist from that practice. It is unfortunate that CityBridge inadvertently posted code on Github for an R&D project they were working on. CityBridge is not permitted to use code that tracks the precise location of users on the LinkNYC network.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn a follow-up email to The Intercept, Saini explained that city\xe2\x80\x99s audits will be \xe2\x80\x9ctriggered when DoITT feels that an investigation of specific franchisee practices is necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0At present there are no regular audits of the CityBridge agreement to determine whether LinkNYC is violating users\xe2\x80\x99 privacy.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t know if it\xe2\x80\x99s being held to its standards because there is so much opacity and not enough transparency surrounding the system,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Buttar. \xe2\x80\x9cThere needs to be some designated processes with public accountability and participation before the kiosk system and private organizations that constitute the consortium can propose changes unilaterally on millions of users.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCorrection: September 18, 2018\nThis article has been updated with comments from Samir Saini, commissioner\xc2\xa0of the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, who contacted The Intercept after publication. Saini clarified the LinkNYC privacy policy and explained that CityBridge does not retain the right to collect information about the specific websites users visit on their own devices.\nUpdate: September 10, 2018\nCharles Meyers filed a counter notice with Github, challenging LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s takedown demand, and he has made the code he found available again here.\nWe depend on the support of readers like you to help keep our nonprofit newsroom strong and independent. Join\xc2\xa0Us\xc2\xa0Contact the author:Ava Kofmankofman.ava@\xe2\x80\x8bgmail.com@eyywa\nLeave a commentTheIntercept_Join Our NewsletterWeekly editor\xe2\x80\x99s picksBreaking stories and exclusives2020 election coverageEmail list managed by MailChimp\nFilters SVG'

aS"LinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York - Archpaper.com\nLinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York\nMenu\nAwards\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nContact\nAbout\nPrivacy Policy\nMap\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nTopics\nRegions\nInternational\nEast\nSoutheast\nMidwest\nWest\nSouthwest\nTopics\nAN Interior\nArchitecture\nArt\nDesign\nDevelopment\nPreservation\nTransportation\nUrbanism\nNewsletters\nFacades+\nSpec Sheet\nCity Terrain\nLate Edition: East\nLate Edition: West\nLate Edition: Midwest\nLate Edition: Southwest\nConferences\nFacades+ Conference\nFacades+ AM\nTech+\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nConferences\nConferences\nFacades+ Conferences\nTech+ Expo\nAwards\nSubscribe\nKubrick Takeover\nLinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York\nBy\nSelina Cheah\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nJune 19, 2018\nShare:\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\n(Courtesy LinkNYC, Museum of the City of New York)\nBeginning this Thursday, LinkNYC kiosks around the city will feature images from the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s (MCNY) extensive photography archive.\nThe aptly named campaign, Summer in the City, is a partnership between the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications (DoITT), LinkNYC, the city\xe2\x80\x99s free Wi-Fi kiosk system, and MCNY. Images will be displayed from the Museum\xe2\x80\x99s current exhibition, Through a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs.\nPasserby on the street will be able to catch a glimpse of the old New York through the lens of the iconic film director. Kubrick\xe2\x80\x99s photographs highlight his formative years as a photographer (before he became a film director) for Look magazine in New York City between 1945-1950. The photographs focus on and capture the pathos of everyday life of the city, from street scenes to sporting events.\nThe LinkNYC kiosks can be found dotted all over the city. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio launched the program in 2016, more than 1,650 Links are active across all five boroughs and have replaced the old pay phones with sleek kiosks that feature free Wi-Fi, phone chargers, and digital displays for advertisements and in this case, art.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not the first time that LinkNYC has featured art on its kiosks from MCNY. Previous \xe2\x80\x9cexhibitions\xe2\x80\x9d on the kiosks include historic photos of women who influenced New York\xe2\x80\x99s political history for Women\xe2\x80\x99s History Month and \xe2\x80\x9cOn This Day in NYC History\xe2\x80\x9d information. The MCNY and LinkNYC partnership is one of many programs that disseminate New York City\xe2\x80\x99s history; others include the NYC Space/Time Directory from the New York Public Library, an app from Urban Archive that made more than 2,500 images of old New York available on-the-go, and a Civil Rights & Social Justice Map from the Greenwich Village Society.\nLinkNYC\nMCNY\nPublic Art\nRelated Stories\nApril 17, 2019\nWhere There's a Willis\nHank Willis Thomas creates 25-foot-tall Afro pick for 5th Avenue\nApril 11, 2019\nTwo Become One\nTwo major art and design fabricators merge into new plastic next spring\nTrending\nMost Popular\nMost Recent\nFoster + Partners pitches new Notre Dame spire as competition heats up\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what saved the Notre Dame Cathedral from total destruction\nThe Cursed Architecture Twitter feed showcases the best of the worst\nFrance launches an international competition to rebuild Notre Dame\xe2\x80\x99s spire\nAlbright-Knox Art Gallery reveals new expansion renderings\nFoster + Partners pitches new Notre Dame spire as competition heats up\nOCEANIX and BIG unveil a floating city of the future at the United Nations\nPhotographs document the Italian Fascist architecture of Eritrea\nA leaning Manhattan tower draws blame from both sides\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what saved the Notre Dame Cathedral from total destruction\nIs Windsor, Florida, peak New Urbanism?\nChicago\xe2\x80\x99s Graham Foundation spotlights Arakawa and Madeline Gins\nDe Blasio cracks down on glass towers as part of Green New Deal\nPepsi denies plans to advertise in space\nLA-M\xc3\xa1s designs colorful accessory dwelling units for Los Angeles\nCopyright 2019The Architect's Newspaper, LLCAll rights aS'LinkNYC kiosks improving quality of life in the Big Apple | Retail Customer ExperienceTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS Assisted SellingAutomated Retail / VendingBill Payment KiosksCONNECT: The Mobile CX SummitConsumer BehaviorCustomer ServiceData SecurityDigital MerchandisingDigital SignageDisplay TechnologyEmployee TrainingICX SummitIn-Store MediaInteractive / TouchscreenKiosk BrandingKiosks / Self-ServiceLoyalty ProgramsMarketingMerchandisingMultifunction KiosksOmnichannel / MultichannelOnline RetailingPaymentsPCI CompliancePoint-of-Purchase / POPPOSRFID TechnologyRobotics / AISelf-CheckoutSocial MediaSpecialty StoresStore Design & LayoutSupermarkets & Grocery StoresTechnologyTop 100 RetailView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbFeatured Topic - Bill Payment KiosksRetail kiosk outlook: 2019 expected to surpass 2018Kiosk industry observers are upbeat for 2019 as retailers are recognizing the need for in-store technology to assist their overburdened sales associates, a client base that better understands the marketing muscle and operating data kiosks can offer, and declining technology costs.How self-serve kiosks are helping cash-paying utility customersAlabama Power Company recognized the need to make payments easier for its cash-paying customers. Self-serve kiosks have proven helpful, and automatic payments have been rising.Utility Bill Pay Kiosks Benefit All PlayersWhile offering bill pay kiosks may allow a utility company to improve customer experience, they also offer benefits throughout the payment chain.Sponsored by: U.S. PaymentsSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESVIDEOSWEBINARSEVENTS June 4-6, 2019 | DallasView Agenda View SpeakersJune 4-6, 2019 | DallasView Agenda View SpeakersView Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesNewsBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggersStore\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nLinkNYC kiosks improving quality of life in the Big AppleJuly 26, 2018 | by Bradley CooperPhoto courtesy of Link.Editor\'s Note: An earlier version of this story ran on Digital Signage Today, a sister publication of Retail Customer Experience.Ruth Fasoltd cites numerous benefits that the LinkNYC kiosks have provided New Yorkers.In 2016, New York City went through a major smart city upgrade, as Intersection deployed multiple Link kiosks. The city replaced older phone booths with these kiosks, which offer free Wi-Fi to the public, as well as advertising and wayfinding.The kiosks also allow customers to make free nationwide calls\xc2\xa0or report emergencies. There are now more than 1,600 kiosks in all five boroughs of the city. Digital Signage Today spoke with Ruth Fasoldt, director of community affairs for Link, to see how these devices are transforming the city and improving lives.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What are the main features the kiosks offer?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next several years.In addition to free Wi-Fi, Links offer free nationwide phone calls, a dedicated 911 button, device charging, and a tablet to access maps and city services. Link\'s services come at no cost to users or taxpayers because Link generates its own revenue through advertising on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of kiosks.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How do they improve the lives of residents?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC provides so many benefits to New Yorkers and visitors. More than 4 million people \xe2\x80\x94 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas\xc2\xa0or San Diego \xe2\x80\x94 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of users joining the network each week. The network also sees more than 250,000 free phone calls made every month. Using the tablet, people can access maps and directions on the go.Along with ads that keep LinkNYC\'s services 100 percent free for users and taxpayers, the digital displays feature useful and enriching content, including community board meeting updates, real-time transit and weather information so people can make more informed decisions about their day on the go, PSAs, fun facts about NYC, historic photos\xc2\xa0and more. The screens are also used for emergency messaging, for instance, in an extreme weather event. We see tweets and Instagram posts all the time of people capturing our content and sharing it with others.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0How does LinkNYC deal with issues such as people loitering by the kiosks or watching inappropriate content in public?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0Back in 2016, there was an issue with some kiosks having long-term users. The LinkNYC tablet is meant to be an on-the-go resource, so the web browser was removed from Link tablets in September 2016, in exchange for curated content on the tablet, and loitering complaints dropped 96 percent immediately.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0What type of ads do the kiosks display?Fasoldt:\xc2\xa0LinkNYC has a very high caliber of advertisers across categories \xe2\x80\x94 from Samsung to Delta to The Gap and The Met.Utilizing DOOH\xc2\xa0to its fullest and breaking from the norm of basic, static ads, Link kiosks offer the ability for advertisers to display unique, dynamic ads. From weather and transit, to sporting events, movie times and more, Link ads can change based on real-time information and updates, keeping advertisements relevant and consumers engaged.During the 2018 Winter Olympics in PeyongChang, for example, NBC partnered with Intersection to display Olympics content and coverage on LinkNYC screens, highlights, prime time previews, real-time medal counts, athlete bios and more. This digital OOH content campaign was the first of its kind for the U.S. Olympics broadcaster.More recently, Intersection pioneered another first-of-its-kind campaign, partnering with Disney and Marvel to promote "The Avengers: Infinity War." On the movie\'s launch weekend, LinkNYC screens displayed ads for the blockbuster, as well as the closest theater location to each kiosk and the next show time, so that passersby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do the kiosks use any analytics?Fasoltd:\xc2\xa0We have stats on usership, how often different services are used, the busiest Links and more. We have also made strategic use of our network capabilities like dayparting (for example, we increase transit info on our displays during peak commuting hours), geotargeting (playing historical photos in their place of original capture), and network flexibility (during Women\'s History month, we displayed facts about women\'s suffrage along the route of the women\'s march).Digital Signage Today:\xc2\xa0Do you think smart cities will start to pop up everywhere? Why?Fastold:\xc2\xa0Cities around the world are looking for ways to better deliver services to residents and visitors, increase broadband connectivity, and adapt to the needs of the digital age. Many are looking to New York and LinkNYC in particular as a model. In addition to New York, a Link network is live in the U.K.\xc2\xa0We have planned expansions into Philadelphia and Newark, with many more cities on the way.Topics: Kiosk Branding, Kiosk ROI, Kiosks, Kiosks / Self-Service, Technology Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentAn inside view to Toyota\'s unified enterprise customer experienceHow to create a customer experience that keeps bringing people backHow location intelligence enhances the customer experienceBrick-and-mortar retail isn\'t dead, it\'s just evolvingLatest ContentHow to create deeper customer connections by going \'direct to user\'Target talks digital signage, using Big Data to deliver a personalized experienceShare A Coke: How a personalized promotion became an e-commerce platformPrinter friction marathon: A strange way to end the Adobe SummitGet the latest news & insightsSubscribeLinkedIn Twitter Facebook RSSNewsWhole Foods opens fast casual inside West Palm Beach storeMastercard offers enhanced data to Amazon Business commercial card usersSimon Property Group pilots online shopping platformJCPenney shelves Apple Pay after April EMV deadline passesAlbertsons jumps on IBM Food Trust Network for blockchain trackingSmartphone go-to digital banking tool for US adultsBest Buy CFO moving into CEO come JuneSee More \xc2\xbbResources[WEBINAR]: The impact of the employee experience on the hourly workforceDelivering on the Brand Promise with Video-based IntelligenceReinventing the Customer ExperienceImproving the Retail Experience with Business Intelligence10 Ways to Drive Word of Mouth MarketingSee More \xc2\xbbTrendingRite Aid leader shares insight on its successful e-commerce strategyRetail isn\'t dead. It\'s changing3 ways IoT is impacting retailAn inside view to Toyota\'s unified enterprise customer experienceSurvive a retail apocalypse: Innovate the in-store customer experienceONLINE STORE2019 aS'Creepy Mister Softee Mystery Solved: Meet The Man Who Uses LinkNYC To Freak Out NYers: Gothamist\nSupport Us\nNYPR Network\nNYPR Network\nGothamist is a website about New York\nView Pretty | Blog\nArts & Entertainment\nFood\nNews\nPopular\nWe The Commuters\nAdvertising\nContact\nNewsletter\nRSS Feed\nStaff\nCreepy Mister Softee Mystery Solved: Meet The Man Who Uses LinkNYC To Freak Out NYers\nby Jake Offenhartz in Arts & Entertainment\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\ton Dec 13, 2018 1:25 pm\n(Jennifer Hsu / Gothamist)\nOn the day before Halloween, nearly six months after we were first puzzled by the slo-mo Mister Softee jingle invading the sidewalk Wi-Fi tablets of New York City, I received a cryptic email that began as follows: "I\'m the one who\'s been making the LinkNYC kiosks blast Mister Softee, and other noises and sounds. I\'m contacting you through a burner email address, because I don\'t think I want to identify myself as the culprit. You might understand my indecision better if you knew who I am. Or maybe not. I don\'t know."\nThe email was unsigned, delivered only under the moniker "stupid city." It contained a 2,000 word manifesto outlining the motives and methods for the writer\'s ongoing manipulation of the ubiquitous kiosks. It was neither a prank nor a hack, he clarified, but something he deemed street theater \xe2\x80\x94 "an ephemeral kind of performance art that subverts a repugnant piece of street furniture (LinkNYC)."\nI quickly responded to the email to ask for proof of his handiwork, and he suggested we meet in person for a live rendition. After a period of contemplation, "stupid city" agreed to let us share his identity, so long his face wasn\'t visible in any photos. Likewise, I only briefly considered the possibility that I was living out a Stephen King horror novel, soon to find myself locked in the freezer of an ice cream truck, my final cries blotted out by the somnolent jingle.\nFrom the moment the nine-a-half-foot tall screens began springing up on city sidewalks in early 2016, promising free gigabit speed Wi-Fi and domestic calls, Mark Thomas said he saw their alternative application as a broadcast platform. In the years since, he\'s conceived dozens of soundscapes, including his own experimental noise pieces, spoken word poetry and spooky piano compositions. He observed MLK Day by playing the "I have a dream" speech along Broadway in Astoria, and once held a curbside memorial honoring the passing of radio legend Joe Frank through four machines at once.\nBut it wasn\'t until earlier this year that Thomas hit on sonic gold, with his eerily slowed-down take on the familiar Mister Softee theme song. "It sounded irritating and bad," he explained. "I decided to stick with it." As time went on, he added air horns and numbers sequences that offered clues to his identity.\nThroughout the summer, befuddled pedestrians shared videos of the howling tablets online, some testifying to having witnessed the creepy tune blaring "seemingly in unison" from up to ten hotspots at once. A few people speculated that it was the result of hackers, possibly the Russians, or else yet another intrusive guerilla marketing campaign. A spokesperson for LinkNYC tried to downplay the development, insisting that it was merely "an old fashioned phone prank."\nMaybe so. But the strange missive that had landed in my inbox touched on something else behind the haunting broadcasts. "I have what I guess you\'d call a set of grievances about the kiosks, and how the company behind them has failed to do anything particularly innovative with the unearned municipal privilege they enjoy with their monopoly franchise," Thomas wrote.\n"I have never understood the fundamental premise of LinkNYC, that every single outdoor payphone should be routed and replaced with this unproven alternative, or how such a broad decision affecting the public interest was reached without a single call for public input." (Representatives for LinkNYC disputes this characterization of the community feedback process).\nLong before he began tormenting the auditory cortices of unsuspecting New Yorkers, Thomas loved payphones. A self-described "phone phreak," his obsession began in high school, when he\'d spend hours in his bedroom dialing a booth on a seedy Tampa Bay street, then playing piano for whatever stranger picked up. As an adult, in the 1990s and early 2000s, he maintained the largest database of payphone numbers and addresses in the world, which he made public on his website in the hopes that others would pick up his teenage hobby.\nWhen the New York Times profiled Thomas in 2004, they found that his Payphone Project had grown into a practical tool for desperate people across the world\xe2\x80\x94a parent searching for her runaway daughter, detectives seeking a predator, etc.\xe2\x80\x94while staying true to its goal of forging "whimsical acts of contact" between strangers. \'\'Pay phones are lifelines for the down and out; their booths are rainy-day cocoons,\'\' he\'d told the newspaper. \'\'You lose those, and you lose a lot of windows onto the human condition.\'\'\nSo it makes an obvious sense that Mayor Bill de Blasio\'s decision to rip out most of the city\'s 7,500 payphones and replace them with decidedly less-cocoonish digital obelisks would inspire a very specific grudge in Thomas. The fact that LinkNYC is effectively underwritten by Google, through its subsidiary Sidewalk Labs, which was founded by former deputy mayor and "smart city"-booster Dan Doctoroff, likely did not cushion the blow for the self-identified artist.\nBut when we finally meet in midtown on a Tuesday afternoon, the 50-year-old Thomas does not appear overly preoccupied with nostalgia or vengeance. He\'s far more interested in demonstrating his process, which involves using the kiosk\'s free domestic calling feature to dial one of the countless conference call numbers he\'s rigged with various pieces. He then cranks up the volume on the device, clicks back to the home screen, and walks away.\nEach of his recordings begins with sixty seconds of silence, a detail he added after discovering that people in certain areas, particularly Murray Hill and the Upper East Side, "really hated when the serenity of their neighborhoods were disrupted by noise blasting out of these things." This "magic minute," as he\'s dubbed it, helps Thomas to avoid detection, while also allowing him to program several machines at once.\nOur chosen intersection, 42nd Street and Third Avenue, places us within a one-block radius of eight different machines. I watch as he punches a number into the keypad, then blends into the stream of office workers and emerges at another machine fifty yards away. The spontaneous jingle draws a few gaping expressions and exaggerated double-takes. Mostly, New Yorkers react to the song by stealing only a momentary glance at their surroundings, seeming to acknowledge and then accept the oddity without breaking stride. The reaction is a bit better over the summer, Thomas points out, because sound carries further in heat.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s true. All along third ave they are playing the Mr. Softee song. Was this truly not intentional? Wow. It feels like a psychological experiment. pic.twitter.com/LBJKHaWWBD\xe2\x80\x94 Steve Burges (@stevenatschool) May 23, 2018\nThroughout the demonstration, Thomas, a trained classical pianist and former web developer, seems quietly pleased by his symphony. Ears tuned forward like antennae, he observes how his favorites pieces "tangle in with the rest of the street noise and fill those little washes of silence that come in when traffic has moved on." While there are advantages to the built-in audience of Midtown, he\'s partial to lonelier kiosks in Sunset Park, and one in particular located under the 7 train in Corona.\nIf there is an apparent contradiction in the project\xe2\x80\x94his beaming pride in the pieces and simultaneous gripes with the devices themselves\xe2\x80\x94Thomas is not worried about it. He\'s not particularly focused on fears raised by watchdog groups about illicit data-mining and surveillance overreach either. His core beef with LinkNYC is rooted in the singular fact that they claim to be "the payphone of the future," when their primary purpose seems to be serving up digital advertisements to non-consenting pedestrians.\n"I consider the kiosks themselves to be unwanted, unasked for irritants, and to express that sentiment I turned the kiosks themselves into irritants," Thomas explains. But he\'s also quick to emphasize that he considers his work not as a protest but as a sort of one-man outsider art project, and that he views LinkNYC as "less of a threat than an opportunity." He\'d be happy for others to take up the mantle of street theater as well.\nIs there a deeper meaning behind his taunting Mister Softee remix? A dissonant clapback at the techno-utopian delusions of the smart city, perhaps? A winking reference to one of the extant targets of Mayor Bloomberg\'s city-sanitizing campaign?\nNo, not really. He was just messing around on his laptop one day and inadvertently played the jingle at half speed, he says.\nEventually, I ask Thomas whether LinkNYC is aware of his efforts. He believes that they are, and that the company may have even gone through the trouble of rewiring the network because of him. While users were once able to place uninterrupted calls for four hours at a time, the kiosks now require you to confirm that you\'re still there after 10 (or sometimes three) minutes. It wouldn\'t be particularly hard for them to find him, he notes, waving to one of the tablet\'s three cameras.\nLinkNYC would not comment directly on Thomas\'s work, though a spokesperson for the NYC Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications told Gothamist: "Considering that more than five million people have used LinkNYC because it\xe2\x80\x99s fast, free, safe, and useful, it makes sense that among them there\xe2\x80\x99s a prankster."\nFor now, Thomas plans to continue staging his unique brand of street theater, spreading false hope to ice cream lovers, and pumping countless other works of noise through the towering monoliths across the city. He has many reasons for doing this, but chief among them is that it brings him joy.\n"For as long as I can remember, I have wanted to feel invisible yet present, and this is as close as I think I\'ve come to reaching that goal," he wrote in that mysterious introduction. "I feel like a ghost, but at the same time I am hiding in plain sight."\nGothamist is now part of WNYC, a nonprofit organization that relies on its members for support. You can help us by making a donation today!\nYour contribution supports more local, New York coverage from Gothamist. Thank you!\nContact the author of this article or email tips@gothamist.com with further questions, comments or tips.\ntwitter\nfacebook\nreddit\nprint\nlinknyc mister softee mystery solved phone phreak phone phreaking\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\nbest of gothamist\nThe 10 Best Parm Sandwich Spots In NYC The 8 Best Eat-In Movie Theaters In NYCThe Best Of Gothamist 2018The Best Bites Of 2018The 14 Best New Burgers In NYC\n\xc2\xa9 2003-2019 WNYC. All rights reserved.\nTerms of Use & Privacy Policy.'
