aS"LinkNYC's 5 million users make 500,000 phone calls each month | VentureBeat\nCHANNELS l\nl\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nAI\nAR/VR\nBig Data\nBusiness\nCloud\nCommerce\nDev\nEnterprise\nEntrepreneur\nEsports\nHeartland Tech\nMarketing\nMedia\nMobile\nPC Gaming\nSecurity\nSocial\nTransportation\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nWebinars\nAdvertise\nVB Lab\nEVENTS l\nl\nVB EVENTS\nUpcoming Events\nGET INVOLVED\nSponsor\nMedia Partner\nVolunteer\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nWebinars\nAdvertise\nVB Lab\nNEWSLETTERS\nJOB BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nCHANNELS\n\xe2\x80\xba\nCHANNELS\nGamesBeat\nEsports\nAI\nHeartland Tech\nAR/VR\nMarketing\nBig Data\nMedia\nBusiness\nMobile\nCloud\nPC Gaming\nCommerce\nSecurity\nDev\nSocial\nEnterprise\nTransportation\nEntrepreneur\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nEVENTS\n\xe2\x80\xba\nVB EVENTS\nUpcoming Events\nGET INVOLVED\nSponsor\nMedia Partner\nVolunteer\nNEWSLETTERS\nJOB BOARD\n\xe2\x80\xb9\nVENTUREBEAT\n\xe2\x80\xba\nAbout\nAdvertise\nCareers\nContact\nGot a news tip?\nPress Releases\nVB Lab\nWebinars\nPrivacy Policy\nMOBILE\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 5 million users make 500,000 phone calls each month\nKyle Wiggers@Kyle_L_Wiggers September 29, 2018 4:15 AM\nImage Credit: LinkNYC\nMOST READ\nGoogle Maps will now show real-time availability of electric vehicle charging stations\nTesla plans to launch driverless taxi service in 2020\nGoogle\xe2\x80\x99s SpecAugment achieves state-of-the-art speech recognition without a language model\nTesla claims its latest self-driving chip is 7 times more powerful than its rivals\xe2\x80\x99\nFortnite teams up with Avengers: Endgame for another tie-in on April 25\nUPCOMING EVENTS\nGamesBeat Summit:\nApr. 23 - 24\nTransform:\nJul. 10 - 11\nIn 2014, in a bid to replace the more than 11,000 aging payphones scattered across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s pedestrian walkways with more functional fixtures, Mayor Bill de Blasio launched a competition \xe2\x80\x94 the Reinvent Payphones initiative \xe2\x80\x94 calling on private enterprises, residents, and nonprofits to submit designs for replacements.\nIn the end, LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x94 a plan proposed by consortium CityBridge \xe2\x80\x94 secured a contract from the city, beating out competing proposals with electricity-generating piezoelectric pressure plates and EV charging stations. The plan was to spend $200 million installing as many as 10,000 kiosks, or Links, that would supply free, encrypted gigabit Wi-Fi to passers-by within 150 feet. They would have buttons that link directly to 911 and New York\xe2\x80\x99s 311 service and free USB charging stations for smartphones, plus wired handsets that would allow free calls to all 50 states and Washington, D.C. And perhaps best of all, they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t cost the city a dime; advertising would subsidize expansion and ongoing maintenance.\nThe\xc2\xa0Links wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t just get urbanites\xc2\xa0online and let them juice their phones, though. The idea was to engage users, too, principally with twin 55-inch high-definition displays and tethered Android tablets with map functions. Mike Gamaroff, head of innovation at Kinetic, characterized the Links in 2016 as \xe2\x80\x9cfirst and foremost a utility for the people of the city, that also doubles up as an advertising network.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTwo years after the deployment of prototypical kiosks in Manhattan, Intersection \xe2\x80\x94 a part of the aforementioned CityBridge, which with Qualcomm and CIVIQ Smartscapes manages the kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 is ready to declare them a success. The roughly 1,600 Links recently hit three milestones: 1 billion sessions, 5 million users, and 500,000 phone calls a month.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have an opportunity to communicate with people as they navigate their day,\xe2\x80\x9d Intersection senior consumer marketing manager Amanda Giddon told VentureBeat in a phone interview. \xe2\x80\x9cMy mandate is to help make Link a part of the community through content and content strategy \xe2\x80\x94 really, anything that [makes] New Yorkers feel like tourists in their own city [or] even help tourists feel like New Yorkers through useful, actionable information.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCreative content\nAt any given time, the Link kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 screens host news headlines from the Associated Press, comics, weather info, real-time alerts from the Office of Emergency Management, and creative from a mix of roughly 50 other campaigns. Also on tap are hundreds of hyperlocal factoids\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cNYC Fun Facts\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThis Day in New York\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 about people (\xe2\x80\x9cMartin Hildebrandt opened the United States\xe2\x80\x99 first tattoo business in New York City in 1870\xe2\x80\x9d), places (\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a superhero supply store in Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x9d), and things (\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City gets 15 times more snow than the South Pole each year\xe2\x80\x9d). There are close to 400 trivia tidbits in all, with new ones joining the collection each week.\nGibbon researches the facts herself, typically spending a few hours a week\xc2\xa0poring through a range of sources, including Broadway.org, Grow NYC, Time Magazine, FiveThirtyEight, and the\xc2\xa0National History Museum. She dutifully fact-checks them and copies them to a master spreadsheet before deciding which ones will make the cut.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been really great to see people writing in about the content they see.\xc2\xa0We\xe2\x80\x99ve created some moments of awe for people, and if I can create a moment of awe for someone on a daily basis, then I\xe2\x80\x99m doing my job right,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Giddon said.\nWhen the kiosks aren\xe2\x80\x99t alerting pedestrians to, say, the percentage of New Yorkers riding elevators at any time, they display real-time bus arrivals and local maps. But the bulk of their programming consists of rotating regular, seasonal, and limited-time content collaborations with organizations, publications, and government agencies.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe survey our users quite frequently [for ideas] \xe2\x80\xa6 and we go to great lengths to make sure our [content] is contextually relevant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Giddon. \xe2\x80\x9c[We\xe2\x80\x99re] pioneering this publishing approach and public space and are really eager to get feedback and adjust as we continue to expand.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOne recent example is a partnership with the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT) that showcased the work of local artists. Another is \xe2\x80\x9cPopular Places Near You,\xe2\x80\x9d a Foursquare-powered feature that shows top restaurants and entertainment hubs within walking distance.\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the tip of the iceberg. Intersection worked with the Museum of the City of New York\xe2\x80\x99s Beyond Suffrage exhibit to feature NYC women in politics, with the NYC Department of Records to curate historical photography (localized at a neighborhood level), and with Silicon Harlem and Global Kids to showcase legendary\xc2\xa0African Americans\xc2\xa0during Black History Month.\nSocial services\nIntersection\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0also leveraging the kiosks to promote civic engagement.\nIn April, it teamed up with the New York City Council to roll out Participatory Budgeting New York City, which let residents as young as 11 vote via the kiosk tablets on how the city will allocate its $40 million public budget. And it launched an awareness campaign to get New Yorkers registered to vote in advance of the November 2018 general elections. (The latter integrated with the city\xe2\x80\x99s voter registration data to show a real-time count of the number of people signed up.) It also posts Community Board meeting notices and local road closures and through its LinkLocal program lets small businesses advertise for free on select kiosks around the city.\nIntersection has experimented with social services, too. In January, users were able to browse and enroll in health plans through New York State of Health insurance marketplace.\nFor some New Yorkers, the Link hubs aren\xe2\x80\x99t just a convenience \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re a lifeline. A 2014 study by the Office of the New York City Comptroller found that 27 percent of NYC residents surveyed \xe2\x80\x94 40 percent of whom had less than a high school education \xe2\x80\x94 lacked broadband internet at home.\nWithout a reliable internet connection, students can\xe2\x80\x99t access online classroom resources, out-of-work adults can\xe2\x80\x99t submit job applications, and families struggling to make ends meet can\xe2\x80\x99t take advantage of social services. As the New York Times wrote in August 2016:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIn urban areas, rural areas, and everywhere in between, students who lack internet service at home have difficulty doing their nightly schoolwork. Many of them cobble together whatever connectivity they can, picking up free Wi-Fi signals in front of libraries, in school parking lots, and at fast-food restaurants.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFour years ago, De Blasio\xc2\xa0touted the Links as a sign of progress in the fight for unimpeded internet access. \xe2\x80\x9c[They\xe2\x80\x99re] the fastest and largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0he said, \xe2\x80\x9c[and] a critical step toward a more equal, open, and connected city for every New Yorker, in every borough.\xe2\x80\x9d\nControversy\nBut the accolades tend to ignore the fact that LinkNYC isn\xe2\x80\x99t strictly a philanthropic effort. Advertisements that run alongside Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s programming were expected to generate between $500 million and a billion dollars over the next 12 years. (CityBridge and the city split the ad revenue equally.)\nAnd the kiosks themselves aren\xe2\x80\x99t without controversy.\nThe connected tablets initially had an internet browser, but Intersection disabled it in response to complaints about users browsing pornographic material. It also added vision-assistance tools after the National Federation of the Blind sued the City of New York and LinkNYC, arguing that the tablets lacked basic accessibility features.\nRevenue, meanwhile, has missed expectations.\xc2\xa0Over the first two years, the city collected $43.4 million in payments, narrowly beating the $42.5 million minimum CityBridge guaranteed. Under an amended deal, CityBridge will delay paying the city its share of revenues (above the minimum payments) until the last year of the contract, when they\xe2\x80\x99ll be due with 10 percent interest.\nAnd as The Intercept recently pointed out, consumer advocacy groups and activists, including the American Civil Liberties Union, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Stop LinkNYC, and ReThink LinkNYC, have brought attention to the hubs\xe2\x80\x99 potential for mass surveillance.\nEach hub is equipped with three cameras and sensors capable of, among other things, \xe2\x80\x9cmonitor[ing] pedestrian, bike, and car traffic; track[ing] passing wireless devices; listen[ing] to street noise; and \xe2\x80\xa6 identify[ing] abandoned packages.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNone of this has scared away investors, who extended $150 million in financing to Intersection last year.\nIntersection makes clear in its privacy policy that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t collect information about users\xe2\x80\x99 precise locations. And in response to recent allegations that it intends to track Wi-Fi users\xe2\x80\x99 real-time positions, it said it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\xc2\xa0collect their clickstream data or browsing history.\nAs Intersection and CityBridge eye expansion to new markets, Giddon said, they\xe2\x80\x99ll take into account feedback they\xe2\x80\x99ve received so far.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99ll definitely be a combination of lessons learned and ensuring we add a little local flavor [to our programing],\xe2\x80\x9d Giddon said.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWe have research teams in New York and Philadelphia who\xe2\x80\x99ve conducted some preliminary focus group testing to understand how to best serve the community. We\xe2\x80\x99re really open to feedback, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve done a lot of work here and look forward to seeing how it\xe2\x80\x99s received.\nIntersection hopes to install 7,500 Link kiosks by 2026, when its contract with the city expires. In June, it launched InLinkUK, a partnership with telecom provider BT and outdoor advertising agency Primesight to replace over 1,000 pay phones in major U.K. cities with kiosks. In September, 100 kiosks\xc2\xa0hit the sidewalks of Philadelphia as part of its LinkPHL program. And by the end of this year, 45 will come to Newark."
p16
aS'LinkNYC, DoITT Announce Content Partnership With The Museum Of The City Of New York\nBreaking\nBREAKING: Outer Critics Circle Awards Nominees Announced! Cara Joy David\nSocial Analytics\nGrosses\nBroadway Leader Board\nTheater Report\nWhat\'s Playing Around the World\nUpdate BWW\'s Database\nLinkNYC, DoITT Announce Content Partnership With The Museum Of The City Of New York\nby BWW News Desk\nBroadwayWorld.com\nJun. 19, 2018\nTweet\nShare\nLinkNYC and the Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications (DoITT) today announced a content partnership with the Museum of the City of New York, extending the Museum\'s extensive archive of photography and historic moments to the streets of New York through the Link network. A new campaign called Summer in the City to launch June 21st will feature images from the Museum\'s current exhibition, Through a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs, which highlights the iconic film director\'s formative years in New York City as a photographer for Look magazine between 1945-1950.\n"We\'re proud to partner with MCNY to serve both residents and visitors by extending the Museum\'s rich archive of photography to the streets of New York," said Samir Saini, Commissioner for the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications. "New Yorkers in all five boroughs will catch a glimpse of history, art and culture just by passing by a LinkNYC kiosk. What better way to start the summer!"\n"In addition to providing super-fast, free Wi-Fi to four million New Yorkers and visitors, LinkNYC is fundamentally changing the way information is delivered on the go. Through the content on our digital displays, we have brought useful and enriching information to the streets of New York, including in partnership with great local organizations that have made Link a beloved member of the community," said Jen Hensley, President of Link. "We are so thrilled to partner with the Museum of the City of New York, a great New York City institution, to bring their incredible content to our five-borough network."\n"Partnering with LinkNYC and DoITT is the perfect opportunity to both extend our content beyond the walls of the Museum as well as reinforce the Museum\'s mission as an institution that captures the inclusive urban experience by spotlighting relevant contemporary issues important to New Yorkers," said Whitney Donhauser, Ronay Menschel Director of the Museum of the City of New York. "The Summer in the City campaign, featuring the photography of Stanley Kubrick encompasses the rich, diverse history of the city while giving you a glimpse into the iconic director\'s future work as an artist who continues to be celebrated globally."\nLinkNYC has partnered with the Museum on multiple campaigns, ranging from highlighting historic photos of women who influenced New York political history for Women\'s History Month from the Museum\'s exhibition, Beyond Suffrage: A Century of New York Women in Politics, to surfacing new \'On This Day In NYC History\' (#OTDNYC) information every day. The programs aim to increase access to city history and delight New Yorkers and visitors while on the go.\nThrough a Different Lens: Stanley Kubrick Photographs is made possible in part by Ann G. Tenenbaum and Thomas H. Lee, Nancy and Mitchell Steir, The Hilaria and Alec Baldwin Foundation, The Andrew and Marina Lewin Foundation, Daryl Brown Uber/William E. Weiss Foundation, and George A. Kellner.\nThis exhibition is organized by the Museum of the City of New York in collaboration with SK Film Archives LLC.\nDigitization of the Stanley Kubrick Photographs from the Look magazine collection was made possible in part by the Charina Endowment Fund, Bloomberg Philanthropies, Daryl Brown Uber/William E. Weiss Foundation, and other generous donors.\nDoITT is the technology core of New York City government, working with over 100 city agencies and entities to deliver the tech they need to serve and empower New Yorkers. DoITT\'s technology solutions help keep the five boroughs safe, strong, and vibrant. For more information, visit nyc.gov/DoITT or visit us on Facebook or Twitter.\nLinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,650 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next few years.\nMore than 4 million people - more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas, or San Diego - have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of new users joining the network each week.\nIn addition to free Wi-Fi, each Link offers free phone calls, device charging, and a tablet to access maps, 311, the social services platform Aunt Bertha, and access to 911. All of Link\'s services are 100% free for users and come at no cost to taxpayers.\nFor more information and to find a Link near you, visit link.nyc.\nFounded in 1923 as a private, nonprofit corporation, the Museum of the City of New York celebrates and interprets the city, educating the public about its distinctive character, especially its heritage of diversity, opportunity, and perpetual transformation. The Museum connects the past, present, and future of New York City, and serves the people of the city as well as visitors from around the world through exhibitions, school and public programs, publications, and collections. To connect with the Museum on social media, follow us on Instagram and Twitter at @MuseumofCityNY and visit our Facebook page at Facebook.com/MuseumofCityNY. For more information please visit www.mcny.org.\nRelated Articles\nTV: Broadway Struts the Red Carpet at TOOTSIE- Live at 5:45pm!\nVIDEO: Todrick Hall Will Lead Regional Premiere of KINKY BOOTS\nTV: Watch Highlights from ALL MY SONS on Broadway!\nTV: Watch Highlights of Carvel, Miller & More in INK on Broadway!\nMore Hot Stories For You\nJeremy Jordan & Ashley Spencer Welcome Beautiful Baby Girl to the Family\nBroadway Actor Quentin Mar\xc3\xa9 Passes Away Age 49\nBreaking: HADESTOWN, TOOTSIE & More Earn 2019 Outer Critics Circle Nominations!\nThe Ratings Are In For FOSSE/VERDON! aS"Pranksters Are Making LinkNYC Booths Play Ice Cream Van Music - Motherboard\ngotcha|by Joseph Cox|Jul 3 2018, 3:05pmPranksters Are Making LinkNYC Booths Play Ice Cream Van MusicLinkNYC's Wi-Fi and communication booths are taunting New Yorkers during a heatwave thanks to a clever prankster.SHARETWEETby Joseph Cox|Jul 3 2018, 3:05pmImage: ShutterstockSHARETWEETNew York City is insanely hot right now, which makes a recent prank even more cruel, or ingenious, depending on your perspective. Someone is going around New York, fiddling with the city\xe2\x80\x99s public LinkNYC internet booths, and making them blare out ice cream van music according to social media posts and LinkNYC. \xe2\x80\x9cSomeone hacked the internet kiosk in front of my apartment and it\xe2\x80\x99s been playing the ice cream truck song for hours,\xe2\x80\x9d Chelsea Hassler, vice president and editorial director at communications agency Zeno Group, tweeted on Monday. LinkNYC confirmed the incident to Motherboard, but noted that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a hack in a technical sense.Instead, LinkNYC told Motherboard in an email, people are using a booth\xe2\x80\x99s phone app to call a number\xe2\x80\x94where the person on the other end presumably plays their ice cream van music of choice\xe2\x80\x94and then pressing the home button on the booth to hide the call in progress.Got a tip? You can contact this reporter securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, OTR chat on jfcox@jabber.ccc.de, or email joseph.cox@vice.com.LinkNYC has installed over a thousand of its booths across New York, which offer free Wi-Fi and other communication services. Critics have pointed to these devices\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99s potential for snooping because they include, with cameras and Bbluetooth beacons. Notably, LinkNYC added that it has deployed a feature that disables a call after 10 minutes if callers don\xe2\x80\x99t confirm they are present and using the booth. So, if the booths have been blasting out the music for hours as reported, perhaps someone is walking up and down New York making sure the devices don\xe2\x80\x99t hang up. Hassler added in another tweet that several booths were affected. LinkNYC told Motherboard that free access to its services does not mean that everyone is going to use the booths responsibly.SHARETWEETTagged:Ice CreamNew YorkHackingheatwavePrankstersphreakingLinkNYCWhere we're going, we don't need email.Sign up for Motherboard Premium.subscribeReadWatchTopicsMoveableHackingEnvironmentSpaceGamingHealthTechScienceInfluenceVICE ElsewhereVICE AppsVICE on TVVICE MagazineEditionenUnited StatesptBrasilfrFrancedeGermanyitItalynlNetherlandsesSpainenUnited StatesAboutTerms of UseContent Funding on VICEPrivacy Policy\xc2\xa9 2019 VICE Media LLC"

aS'Free Municipal Wi-Fi May Be the Next Front In the War Against Privacy - Slashdot\nSlashdot\nStories\nFirehose\nAll\nPopular\nPolls\nDeals\nSubmit\nSearch Slashdot\nLogin\nor\nSign up\nTopics:\nDevices\nBuild\nEntertainment\nTechnology\nOpen Source\nScience\nYRO\nFollow us:\nRSS\nFacebook\nGoogle+\nTwitter\nNewsletter\nWant to read Slashdot from your mobile device? Point it at m.slashdot.org and keep reading!\nNickname:\nPassword:\nPublic Terminal\nForgot your password?\nClose\nbinspamdupenotthebestofftopicslownewsdaystalestupid\nfreshfunnyinsightfulinterestingmaybe\nofftopicflamebaittrollredundantoverrated\ninsightfulinterestinginformativefunnyunderrated\ndescriptive\ntypodupeerror\nCheck out Slashdot on Minds! | Migrate from GitHub to SourceForge quickly and easily with this tool. Check out all of SourceForge\xe2\x80\x99s recent improvements.\n\xc3\x97\n102710250\nstory\nFree Municipal Wi-Fi May Be the Next Front In the War Against Privacy\n(theintercept.com)\n76\nPosted\nby\nBeauHD\non Monday September 10, 2018 @10:05PM\nfrom the you\'re-the-product dept.\nTuballoyThunder writes: According to The Intercept, it appears that the LinkNYC free Wi-Fi might be designed to track users. This and other concerns were raised during a 2015 discussion on Slashdot. While many people are comfortable in trading their privacy for ostensibly free services, it is disheartening when municipalities collaborate with business to make it happen. "In May of this year, Charles Meyers, an undergraduate at New York City College of Technology, came across folders in LinkNYC\'s public library on GitHub, a platform for managing files and software, that appear to raise further questions about location tracking and the platform\'s protection of its users\' data," reports The Intercept. "Meyers made copies of the codebases in question -- \'LinkNYC Mobile Observation\' and \'RxLocation\' -- and shared both folders with The Intercept."\nMeyers says the "LinkNYC Mobile Observation" code collects the user\'s longitude and latitude, browser type, OS, device type, device identifiers, and full URL clickstreams (including data and time) and "aggregates this information into a database," the report says. Meyer\'s believes the company is interested in tracking the location of Wi-Fi users in real time. "If such code were run on a mobile app or kiosk, he said, the company would be able to make advertisements available in real time based on where and who someone was, and that this would constitute a potential violation of the company\'s privacy policy," reports The Intercept.\nFollowing the revelations, LinkNYC said the code was never intended to be released and was part of a longer-term R&D process. "In this instance, David Mitchell, Intersection\'s CTO, told the Intercept in an email. "Intersection was prototyping and testing some ideas internally, using employee data only, and mistakenly made source code public on Github. This code is not in use on the LinkNYC network." [Intersection is the "key player" in CityBridge, "a chameleon-like consortium of private companies" that New York City contracted to turn the city\'s payphone booth network into Wi-Fi-enabled kiosks.]\nbusiness\ndata\nprivacy\n\xe2\x86\x90\nRelated Links\n\xe2\x86\x92\nMIT Machine Vision System Figures Out What It\'s Looking At By Itself\nSubmission: Free municipal WiFi may be the next front in the war against privacyNew York\'s Free LinkNYC Internet Kiosks Are Now Used By 5 Million Users, Who Have Participated in 1 Billion Sessions and Make 500,000 Phone Calls a MonthLinkNYC\'s 6 Million Users Have Used 8.6 Terabytes of Data\nCryptocurrency Wipeout Deepens To $640 Billion As Ether Leads Declines\nThis discussion has been archived.\nNo new comments can be posted.\nFree Concepts that nature doesn\'t have and doesn\'t need. Privacy can be had through legislation. Pick your country according to taste, or at least the right politicians.\nRe:\n(Score:3)\nby mikael ( 484 ) writes:\nPrairie dogs maintain lookouts and give out warning calls if they see a predator. threshold.\nUse a random MAC address.\n(Score:2)\nby b0s0z0ku ( 752509 ) writes:\nUse a random MAC address and create a script that passes a random email address to the captive authentication portal.\nLinkNYC doesn\'t check validity of email addresses used in their authentication portal, so you can use any random gibberish ending in a TLD.\nNo valid account or info needed.\nRe:\n(Score:1)\nby tummetott ( 1505019 ) writes:\nhow to use a random MAC address this on fedora: https://fedoramagazine.org/ran... Alphabet.\nThe CTO is Craig Nevill-Manning [wikipedia.org] a former Google employee (and the CEO is Dan Doctoroff [wikipedia.org]... a buddy of Michael Bloomberg who was in his administration and served as CEO of Bloomberg until Bloomberg took back the reigns).The whole thing is a Google project setup not to look like a Google project.\n1 reply beneath your current threshold.\nMy business offers 100% free, shit-free wi-fi\n(Score:2)\nby DogDude ( 805747 ) writes:\nMy business offers the public 100% free, untracked wi-fi.\nI think it\'s my moral obligation to offer a relatively untraceable public Internet connection.\nPrognostication\n(Score:3, Interesting)\nby Anonymous Coward writes:\non Tuesday September 11, 2018 @05:17AM (#57288940)\nI am usually loath to spout off about future trends. Basically because it\'s so easy to get one thing wrong which causes the whole to be shot down.\nBut keep this in mind for the next decade or so, and when you see things turn out like this, remember you read it somewhere.\nI see like never before in my lifetime or the recent past a concerted effort to push the world in a certain direction it would not be going otherwise. I fear that the end result of this is to create a world population that is grey and identityless and is simply a good source of taxes and labor, similar to how a flock of sheep is a good source of wool, and can be moved, sold, bred, and culled at the whim of the owner.\nTech being developed like ubiquitous surveillance, mammoth data centers, and application of AI, is starting to make the treating of the human population of Earth like large herds of chattel feasible.\nAll the different trends you\'ve been seeing developing since 9/11 play into it: muslims against the west, China vs USA, religion vs secularism, feminists against males, the absolutely vileness that political debate has stooped to in the US and Europe (and elsewhere), forced immigration to and assimilation in Europe, racial division like never before, economic trends, rise of supernational governing bodies and regional blocks, change of politics to become more autocratic, the erosion of private ownership, free speech, and privacy itself. The ironic twist is that most of us stand one one side or the other on at least one of these issues, feeling extremely righteous and virtuous about it, having no compunction even wishing for, or calling for the death of, opposing sides.\nMost will probably hail the new overlords that will put an end to this emerging chaos by application of autocratic force. But you or the next generation will probably be told what work to do and how much, what to be entertained by, where to live, what to wear, whom to breed with and how much, what language to speak, what to worship, when to die, etc. And take heart, it won\'t be that dystopic, most will even like it...\nShare\ntwitter\nfacebook\nlinkedin\n1 reply beneath your current threshold.\nshould we believe them?\n(Score:2)\nby sad_ ( 7868 ) writes:\nshould we take their word for it and believe them, there isn\'t really a way to find out.when in doubt, it\'s always better to presume the worst.\nVPN\n(Score:3)\nby Karmashock ( 2415832 ) writes:\non Tuesday September 11, 2018 @07:04AM (#57289158)\nAnyone that cares can use a VPN and probably should be using a VPN anyway. There are VPNs selling subscriptions for less than a dollar a month.Just get a VPN and move on.\nShare\ntwitter\nfacebook\nlinkedin\nRe:VPN\n(Score:5, Informative)\nby DaMattster ( 977781 ) writes:\non Tuesday September 11, 2018 @07:46AM (#57289280)\nAnyone that cares can use a VPN and probably should be using a VPN anyway. There are VPNs selling subscriptions for less than a dollar a month.Just get a VPN and move on.I am starting to notice that at some public WiFi hotspots, the high port numbers are being blocked precisely to prevent things like this from happening. Of course they claim it is for the "safety" of the network but we know that\'s not the *real* reason.\nParent Share\ntwitter\nfacebook\nlinkedin\nRe:\n(Score:2)\nby SuricouRaven ( 1897204 ) writes:\nI would guess it\'s less about VPNs than about stopping people running bittorrent.\nRe:\n(Score:2)\nby mea2214 ( 935585 ) writes:\nExactly, which is why I block all those ports on my open wifi.\nThe determined can still work around it but it deters the casual bittorrent user.\nRe:\n(Score:3)\nby Karmashock ( 2415832 ) writes:\nThat will just cause an arm\'s race between the Wifi\'s block list and the VPN\'s aggressiveness.The banning of VPNs in places like China and Russia is great for the industry because it will force people that need vpns to come up with tech that the Russians and chinese will neither stop nor even detect.And that can be applied generally there after.The tech is inherently uncontrollable. It is hubris on the part of the networks to think they can stop connections from occurring.But that\'s fine. I like their hubri\n1 reply beneath your current threshold.\nRe:\n(Score:1)\nby Anonymous Coward writes:\n"Meyers says the "LinkNYC Mobile Observation" code collects the user\'s longitude and latitude, browser type, OS, device type, device identifiers, and full URL clickstreams (including data and time)"so the vpn might mask the urls and the browser type, but it really isnt going to stop the rest as that is typically tracked through the connection its self.\nRe:\n(Score:2)\nby Karmashock ( 2415832 ) writes:\nThey\'ll know which device connected at which time... where that device is... but they won\'t know what you\'re doing on it.The big problem with tracking everyone is that you don\'t want to track everyone. You want to track specific subsets of the population and classify those to create useful patterns.Absent that... the tracking isn\'t useful.What is more, theoretically, the identifiers could be altered in software. I\'m fairly certain you can do it with a rooted phone already.But the real point is that the tech\n1 reply beneath your current threshold.\n1 reply beneath your current threshold.\nVPN might be a possibility\n(Score:2)\nby DaMattster ( 977781 ) writes:\nIt might be possible to use a VPN like OpenVPN to thwart this tracking but I\'ll bet the LinkNYC folks that about people doing it and probably block high port numbers or some other shady shit.\nIf it is free.....\n(Score:1)\nby gbkersey ( 649921 ) writes:\n....you are the product\n16 replies beneath your current threshold.\nThere may be more comments in this discussion. aS'LinkNYC kiosks will display fantastical, never-built NYC structures - Curbed NY\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nNew York\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nNeighborhoods\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nCurbed.com\nDetroit\nHamptons\nLos Angeles\nMiami\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nFor Sale in New York\nFor Rent in New York\nDevelopment\nNews\nHouse Calls\nArchitecture\nMaps\nTransportation\nAffordable Housing\nCelebrity Homes\nNeighborhoods\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nNews\nLinkNYC kiosks will display fantastical, never-built NYC structures\nNew,\n4\ncomments\nFrom I.M. Pei\xe2\x80\x99s Grand Central-replacing colossus to Buckminster Fuller\xe2\x80\x99s Dodgers Dome in Brooklyn, it\xe2\x80\x99s all in here\nBy\nTanay Warerkar@TanayWarerkar\nJul 10, 2018,\n3:38pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nLinkNYC kiosks will display fantastical, never-built NYC structures\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nVia LinkNYC\nFor its latest campaign, LinkNYC has teamed up with authors Greg Goldin and Sam Lubell to highlight New York structures that were never built. This digital exhibit is a follow up to the release of their book, \xe2\x80\x98Never Built New York,\xe2\x80\x99 which came out in 2016, and their subsequent exhibition at the Queens Museum last fall.\nIn the LinkNYC partnership, these never built projects will be displayed as close as possible to their would be locations in the city. Take for instance I.M. Pei\xe2\x80\x99s Hyperboloid, a 102-story circular tower that would have replaced Grand Central Terminal, and would have been the tallest structure in the world\xe2\x80\x94that will be visible on LinkNYC kiosks near the station.\nOther never built structures that have received recognition on LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s digital billboards include Moshe Safdie\xe2\x80\x99s Habitat New York 1, an origami-like luxury residence and shopping complex proposed to rise north of Gracie Mansion, on the Upper East Side; and the domed stadium designed by Buckminster Fuller, that would have kept the Dodgers in Brooklyn. Peek at some of the others below.\nThis is LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s latest collaboration following ones with the Museum of the City of New York in March, to honor women activists; and the one with the Department of Records and Information Services (DORIS) last year to show off historic photos of NYC neighborhoods.\nThe New York City transit projects that never were\nHelp bring a \xe2\x80\x98Never Built New York\xe2\x80\x99 exhibit to life at the Queens Museum\nNext Up In\nNews\nCity may demolish and rebuild two NYCHA buildings in Chelsea: report\nEverything you need to know about NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Easter Parade\nPart of Broadway will be car-free on April 27 for Earth Day\nNetflix will grow NYC presence with Brooklyn soundstages\nAby Rosen scraps hotel plan for iconic Chrysler Building\nNoguchi Museum plans major expansion in Long Island City\nMost Read\nFirst look at the TWA Hotel\xe2\x80\x99s rooftop infinity pool with runway views\nThe 10,000-square-foot pool observation deck will overlook the Jamaica Bay and bustling JFK runways\nWhat $5,000 rents in NYC\nSee what $5,000/month rents in five NYC neighborhoods, including Dumbo and Soho\nIn the West Village, rare 197-year-old wood-frame home seeks $12M\nThe house at 17 Grove Street is one of the neighborhood\xe2\x80\x99s few remaining wood-frame homes\nCity may demolish and rebuild two NYCHA buildings in Chelsea: report\nThe project, part of the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s ten-year plan to resolve $24 billion in repairs, would bring profit to the embattled agency\nNYC passes its own \xe2\x80\x98Green New Deal\xe2\x80\x99 in landmark vote\n"You cannot overstate how big a deal this is," said one advocate\nCurbed NY Newsletter\nEnter your email address\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nThis Article has a component height of 33. The sidebar size is long.\nLoading comments...\nThe Latest\nMost New Yorkers support homeless shelters in their neighborhood: poll\nSome six in ten New Yorkers say they would actually support a shelter opening in their community\nBy\nCaroline Spivack\nIs NYC ready for the L train \xe2\x80\x98slowdown\xe2\x80\x99? Transit advocates weigh in\nThe short answer? Not really.\nBy\nAmy Plitt\nStaten Island\xe2\x80\x99s Bay Street rezoning approved by City Planning Commission\nThe Staten Island BP calls the rezoning a "boondoggle" while activists say it is "irresponsible"\nBy\nCaroline Spivack\n2\ncomments\n/\nnew\nFirst look at the TWA Hotel\xe2\x80\x99s rooftop infinity pool with runway views\nThe 10,000-square-foot pool observation deck will overlook the Jamaica Bay and bustling JFK runways\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n6\ncomments\n/\nnew\nIn City Island, a Colonial-style house near the beach seeks $1.4M\nThis lovely blue house has stunning views to the Long Island Sound\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\nStately Clinton Hill landmark transforms into a shared co-living space\nCommon, a co-living startup, remade a historic townhouse into one of its shared homes\nBy\nAmy Plitt\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. aS'LinkNYC delivers better quality of life with digital signage, Wi-Fi | Digital Signage TodayTest LinkCONTINUE TO SITE \xc2\xbb or wait 15 seconds\xc3\x97Toggle navigation\nTOPICS 3D Digital Signage4K Ultra HDAdvertisingAudience MeasurementBanks / FinancialCellular SignageCloud-Based Digital SignageContentContent ManagementCorporate CommunicationCustomer ExperienceDigital BillboardsDisplay TechnologyDistributors / ResellersDOOH AdvertisingEducation / SchoolsEntertainment VenuesHardwareHealthcare / HospitalsHotelsICX SummitInstallation / IntegrationInteractive / TouchscreenLED SignsMenu BoardsMobile InteractivityOutdoor SignageRestaurantsRetailSoftwareTrends / StatisticsWayfindingView all Topic Centers \xc2\xbbSUPPLIERS Companies by NameCompanies by CategoryProducts & ServicesRequest Information from SuppliersPROJECT HELPRESOURCESVIDEOSWEBINARSEVENTS June 4-6, 2019 | DallasView Agenda View SpeakersView Industry Event Calendar >>MORE VideosWebinarsEventsPodcastsPhotosArticlesNewsBlogsPress ReleasesJob ListingsProject HelpMedia Kit / Editorial CalendarBloggersStore\nGet the latest news & insightsSubscribe\nLinkNYC delivers better quality of life with digital signage, Wi-FiJune 22, 2018 | by Bradley CooperIn 2016, New York City went through a major smart city upgrade, as Intersection deployed multiple Link kiosks. The city replaced older phone booths with these kiosks, which offer free Wi-Fi to the public, as well as advertising and wayfinding.The kiosks also allow customers to make free nationwide calls, or report emergencies. There are now more than 1,600 kiosks in all five boroughs of the city. Digital Signage Today spoke with Ruth Fasoldt, director of community affairs for Link, to see how these devices are transforming the city and improving lives.Q. What are the main features the kiosks offer?A. LinkNYC is the first-of-its-kind communications network replacing the city\'s payphones to build the world\'s fastest and largest free public Wi-Fi network. Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the public launch of LinkNYC in early 2016, more than 1,600 Links are active across all five boroughs, with thousands more set to be deployed over the next several years.In addition to free Wi-Fi, Links offer free nationwide phone calls, a dedicated 911 button, device charging, and a tablet to access maps and city services. Link\'s services come at no cost to users or taxpayers because Link generates its own revenue through advertising on the 55-inch digital displays on the sides of kiosks.Q. How do they improve the lives of residents?A. LinkNYC provides so many benefits to New Yorkers and visitors. More than 4 million people \xe2\x80\x94 more than the populations of the cities of Chicago, Phoenix, Philadelphia, Dallas\xc2\xa0or San Diego \xe2\x80\x94 have used the free gigabit Wi-Fi service, with tens of thousands of users joining the network each week. The network also sees more than 250,000 free phone calls made every month. Using the tablet, people can access maps and directions on the go.Along with ads that keep LinkNYC\'s services 100 percent free for users and taxpayers, the digital displays feature useful and enriching content, including community board meeting updates, real-time transit and weather information so people can make more informed decisions about their day on the go, PSAs, fun facts about NYC, historic photos\xc2\xa0and more. The screens are also used for emergency messaging, for instance, in an extreme weather event. We see tweets and Instagram posts all the time of people capturing our content and sharing it with others.Q. How does LinkNYC deal with issues such as people loitering by the kiosks or watching inappropriate content in public?A. Back in 2016, there was an issue with some kiosks having long-term users. The LinkNYC tablet is meant to be an on-the-go resource, so the web browser was removed from Link tablets in September 2016, in exchange for curated content on the tablet, and loitering complaints dropped 96 percent immediately.Q. What type of ads do the kiosks display?A. LinkNYC has a very high caliber of advertisers across categories \xe2\x80\x94 from Samsung to Delta to The Gap and The Met.Utilizing DOOH\xc2\xa0to its fullest and breaking from the norm of basic, static ads, Link kiosks offer the ability for advertisers to display unique, dynamic ads. From weather and transit, to sporting events, movie times and more, Link ads can change based on real-time information and updates, keeping advertisements relevant and consumers engaged.During the 2018 Winter Olympics in PeyongChang, for example, NBC partnered with Intersection to display Olympics content and coverage on LinkNYC screens, highlights, prime time previews, real-time medal counts, athlete bios and more. This digital OOH content campaign was the first of its kind for the U.S. Olympics broadcaster.More recently, Intersection pioneered another first-of-its-kind campaign, partnering with Disney and Marvel to promote "The Avengers: Infinity War." On the movie\'s launch weekend, LinkNYC screens displayed ads for the blockbuster, as well as the closest theater location to each kiosk and the next show time, so that passersby, if inspired by the ad, could easily catch the next showing.Q. Do the kiosks use any analytics?A. We have stats on usership, how often different services are used, the busiest Links and more. We have also made strategic use of our network capabilities like dayparting (for example, we increase transit info on our displays during peak commuting hours), geotargeting (playing historical photos in their place of original capture), and network flexibility (during Women\'s History month, we displayed facts about women\'s suffrage along the route of the women\'s march).Q. Do you think smart cities will start to pop up everywhere? Why?A.\xc2\xa0Cities around the world are looking for ways to better deliver services to residents and visitors, increase broadband connectivity, and adapt to the needs of the digital age. Many are looking to New York and LinkNYC in particular as a model. In addition to New York, a Link network is live in the U.K.\xc2\xa0We have planned expansions into Philadelphia and Newark, with many more cities on the way.Image via Link.Topics: Advertising, Audience Measurement, Content, Customer Experience, Display Technology, DOOH Advertising, Outdoor Signage Bradley CooperBradley Cooper is a Technology Editor for DigitalSignageToday.com and BlockchainTechNews.com. His background is in information technology, advertising, and writing. wwwFollow @DigSignageTodaySponsored Links:Related ContentTarget marketer, digital signage leaders discuss how to use big data without creeping out the customerAR, AI claim top read spots for MarchHow to deliver effective dynamic DOOH campaignsHow window digital signage can draw in retail customersLatest ContentWhat\'s driving the DOOH market?Eye tracking tech delivers DOOH ads, prizes3 tips for successful indoor digital signageHow to successfully use digital signage in K-12 educationGet the latest news & insightsSubscribeLinkedIn Twitter Facebook RSSNewsK4Connect partners with Lenbrook for smart senior livingPeerless-AV deploys video wall at TCL Chinese TheatreVisix shipping AxisTV Alert for digital signageIBASE launches Ryzen R-1000 solutions for digital signageKey Digital expands line of HDMI switchersTrendnet expands PoE line with 90W supportD-Link adds 2 products to PoE lineSee More aS'NYC Mayor on City\'s Warp-Speed Wifi: "You Won\'t Need to Insert a Quarter in the Slot" | InverseExploreFollowInnovationDataShareSubscribeNYC Mayor on City\'s Warp-Speed Wifi: "You Won\'t Need to Insert a Quarter in the Slot"Mayor Bill de Blasio just officially rolled out LinkNYC: free, gigabit internet across the city.By Joe Carmichael on February 18, 2016Filed Under Fighting & SmartphonesNext time you\xe2\x80\x99re in New York, you won\xe2\x80\x99t have to slip into a ubiquitous Starbucks for your free wifi. On Thursday, Mayor Bill de Blasio cut the virtual ribbon for the city\xe2\x80\x99s new program: LinkNYC. LinkNYC has plans to bring free, warp-speed wifi to all five boroughs, but for now, the kiosks, or \xe2\x80\x9clinks\xe2\x80\x9d are in Manhattan. This internet is faster than most anything you\xe2\x80\x99ve ever experienced, and it\xe2\x80\x99ll soon be all over the city. The program officially launched on January 19 in Manhattan, but in a sort of beta mode: the only enabled feature, until now, was the crazy-fast wifi. Starting Thursday, the Links also replace public payphones, offering free domestic calling in addition to \xe2\x80\x9ctwo USB charging ports, a tablet for accessing the internet, and a red 911 button to contact emergency services,\xe2\x80\x9d the press release announces. And more and more Links will be popping up across the city: by the end of July, there will be over 500 kiosks in all five boroughs; by mid-2019, there will be over 4,500 of them.Mayor de Blasio speaking to the press at the public unveiling of LinkNYC on Thursday.This program melds beautifully with one of De Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s passions: fighting for social and economic equality. Counsel to the Mayor Maya Wiley echoed this sentiment: \xe2\x80\x9cWe know that low income New Yorkers, particularly African American and Latino residents, rely on their smartphones to get online. And now New Yorkers can reduce some of that broadband bill, no matter their zip code, at no cost to taxpayers.\xe2\x80\x9dGetting free wifi 2 all is best boss @BilldeBlasio & best partners @colin_odonnell @ScottGoldsmith3 #LinkNYC pic.twitter.com/Xmr5BEahJD\xe2\x80\x94 Maya Wiley (@mayawiley) February 18, 2016\nThe rest of the city\xe2\x80\x99s press release was, naturally, filled with trumpeters and trumpet echoes, the redundancies of which are too amusing to exclude \xe2\x80\x94 plus, they do go some ways to tell you a bit more about what the program provides to both New Yorkers and tourists.Mayor de Blasio:LinkNYC is the Wi-Fi network New Yorkers deserve: the largest, fastest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world \xe2\x80\x94 and you won\xe2\x80\x99t need to insert a quarter in the slot, because it\xe2\x80\x99s completely free.\nCouncil Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito:LinkNYC takes another step by providing Wi-Fi hotspots all across the five boroughs to make internet accessibility more inclusive for all.\nBrooklyn Borough President Eric L. Adams:By expanding access to the Internet from thousands of sites in our city, LinkNYC will keep New Yorkers connected.\nQueens Borough President Melinda Katz.:Folks are thrilled that free, citywide public Wi-Fi is well on its way.\nChief Technology Officer for the City of New York Minerva Tantoco:Just like the smartphone, we\xe2\x80\x99ll look back on the world before LinkNYC and wonder how we ever lived without it.\nUnion Square Partnership Executive Director Jennifer Falk:LinkNYC brings our public spaces into the 21st century, giving access to all and strengthening our great city\xe2\x80\x99s place as a global leader in technology, communication and media.\nSponsoredWHAT\'S THE GREENEST ROUTE FROM LA TO NYC??Join Shell for The Great Travel Hack, an energy conscious roadtrip across the country.Watch More \xc2\xbbCouncil Member James Vacca, Chair of the Committee on Technology:Who could argue with free Wi-Fi? LinkNYC is going to save New Yorkers a bundle when it comes to data plans. I know I plan on taking advantage of the service!\nWho could argue with free wifi, James? Not me.Not me.(Especially not if you agree to plop a kiosk right outside my apartment.)Source for main photograph is this gem of an extended moment:#LinkNYC @BilldeBlasio @NYCMayorsOffice demos new free wi-fi & help kiosk at 16th St & 3rd Ave @fox5ny @FOX5DESK pic.twitter.com/tL4rw6k3pn\xe2\x80\x94 Lisa Evers (@LisaEvers) February 18, 2016\nMedia via Twitter, Flickr (New York City Mayor\'s Office)Related StoriesThis Google Map Says a Lot About How One Country Val...Nutritionist Explains Links Between Eggs, Cholestero...In Earth\'s Vanishing Cloud Forests, "Many Species Ar...Does 5G Internet Really Give You Cancer? aS'Mystery behind mysterious LinkNYC ice cream jingle explained\nQueens\nQueens\nToggle navigation\nLog In\nWatch Live\nLatest News\nHeadlines\nPublic Safety\nEducation\nHealth\nNY1 Minute\nIn The Papers\nMornings on 1\nIn Focus with Cheryl Wills\nNY1 Live at Ten\nWeather\nNYC Weather\n7 Day Forecast\nInteractive Radar\nWatches and Warnings\nWeather Blog\nTransit\nTransit News\nInteractive Traffic Map\nPolitics\nNew York Politics\nInside City Hall\nOff Topic/On Politics Podcast\nYou Decide with Errol Louis\nWashington DC Bureau\nPolitical ItCH\nNY State of Politics Blog\nState Government Guide\nArts+Culture\nArts\nStyle\nTheater Reviews\nSpotlight NY\nOn Stage\n1 More Thing\nCommunity+Neighborhoods\nManhattan\nBrooklyn\nThe Bronx\nQueens\nStaten Island\nHuman Interest\nCommunity Calendar\nNew Yorker of the Week\nScholar Athlete\nOur Journalists\nLatest News\nHeadlines\nPublic Safety\nEducation\nHealth\nNY1 Minute\nIn The Papers\nMornings on 1\nIn Focus with Cheryl Wills\nNY1 Live at Ten\nWeather\nNYC Weather\n7 Day Forecast\nInteractive Radar\nWatches and Warnings\nWeather Blog\nTransit\nTransit News\nInteractive Traffic Map\nPolitics\nNew York Politics\nInside City Hall\nOff Topic/On Politics Podcast\nYou Decide with Errol Louis\nWashington DC Bureau\nPolitical ItCH\nNY State of Politics Blog\nState Government Guide\nArts+Culture\nArts\nStyle\nTheater Reviews\nSpotlight NY\nOn Stage\n1 More Thing\nCommunity+Neighborhoods\nManhattan\nBrooklyn\nThe Bronx\nQueens\nStaten Island\nHuman Interest\nCommunity Calendar\nNew Yorker of the Week\nScholar Athlete\nOur Journalists\nWEATHER ALERTView full list of weather alerts\nCLOSINGS ALERTView full list of closures\n0 videos remaining. Log in for unlimited access.\nLog In\nPLAY VIDEO\nLOG IN\nLinkNYC explains mystery behind ice cream jingle heard on kiosks\nBy\nSpectrum News NY1\nPUBLISHED 6:07 PM ET Jul. 02, 2018\nPUBLISHED July 2, 2018 @6:07 PM\nSHARE\nWith scorching heat plaguing New Yorkers this week, ice cream sure sounds good, but the sound of the ice cream truck rounding the corner turned out to be a cruel prank on a Queens boulevard.\nTwitter user, Chelsea Hassler, tweeted video on Sunday of a LinkNYC kiosk near her Long Island City apartment blasting a creepy, slowed-down version of the recognizable tune that tells children sweet treats are near.\nHassler said the ice cream jingle was playing on all of the LinkNYC kiosks on Vernon Boulevard between 47th and 50th Avenues earlier this week.\nThis isn\'t the first time LinkNYC towers have seemed to be possessed by the ghost of Mister Softee.\nNew Yorkers have reported hearing the music coming from the kiosks in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens over the past few months.\nNY1 reached out to LinkNYC and officals claimed it wasn\'t the work of hackers. They said, people are dialing a number that for some odd reason, plays the jingle, and they leave it on speaker. Since the first crop of these prank calls, LinkNYC has blocked the number, and added an automatic 10-minute hang-up feature.\nOfficials pointed out that\xc2\xa0out of the 460,000 free calls made from LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s phone app every month, the most dialed number is the customer service line for the New York State Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) card.\nIn a statement, they said, "We hope New Yorkers will allow their neighbors to access Links for these important services and not continue to misuse them for pranks.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNY1 asked for the alleged number that plays the jingle. LinkNYC has not provided it.\nREAD MORE\nLATEST NEWS\nCHANGE REGION\nCONTACT\nABOUT\nRSS\nFAQ\nSITEMAP\nCAREERS\nTERMS\nPRIVACY\nADVERTISE WITH US\n\xc2\xa9 1999-2019 Charter Communications. All Rights Reserved. Reproduction in whole or in part without permission is prohibited.'

aS'The long view for DoITT and LinkNYC | CSNY\nSkip to main content\nSupport Local Journalism\nSearch\nLatest\nPolitics\nPolicy\nPersonality\nOpinion\nPower Lists\nFirst Read\nFirst Read Tech\nEvents\nMagazine\nPhotos\nJob Board\nResource Directory\nLegal & Public Notices\nSubscription AdvertiseAbout Us StaffNewsletter ContactPrivacy Policy Terms of Use(C) 2019\xc2\xa0City and State NY LLC\nCHANNELS\nThe long view for DoITT and LinkNYC\nMichael Appleton/Mayoral Photography OfficeTechnologyThe long view for DoITT and LinkNYCA Q&A with Samir Saini, commissioner of the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications.By REBECCA C. LEWISMay 17, 2018\nSHARE:\nNew York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications Commissioner Samir Saini is just two months into his new job, but he already has big plans for his department. In an interview with City & State, Saini described how he plans to reshape the department while continuing to meet Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s goal of providing broadband for all New Yorkers, from free public Wi-Fi to home broadband service. Saini also weighed in on cybersecurity in the city and his own transition from his previous role as Atlanta\xe2\x80\x99s chief information officer.C&S: How is the OneNYC initiative to bring broadband to all New Yorkers going?SS: It\xe2\x80\x99s going well. There are different parts to the program. The first part is the effort to bring broadband on our streets, which is the public Wi-Fi, the high-speed public Wi-Fi strategy. And that is largely tied to the LinkNYC kiosks. So the Link deployments, things are going very well. We just briefed the City Council on this and we have another briefing as part of a budget hearing next week on it. But we have, as of today, about 1,500 Links, active Links deployed delivering, from what I\xe2\x80\x99m getting on average, about 300-350 megabit per second up and down with a 200-foot radius range from each Link. So we have 1,500 Links deployed, scattered across the boroughs and that\xe2\x80\x99s going quite well. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s 3.5 million active subscribers using free, high-speed public Wi-Fi from the Links. And I think the other metric I just saw is we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing double-digit growth in the number of subscribers every year since we deployed the Links. So Link is going well. That\xe2\x80\x99s one piece.C&S: And the other pieces?SS: The other piece is broadband in the home. That\xe2\x80\x99s also moving forward. So broadband in the home is largely driven by DoITT\xe2\x80\x99s role to administer a set of franchise agreements. There are eight franchise agreements with cable providers. I guess the big issue there is broadband in the home, but it\xe2\x80\x99s really largely provided by two suppliers in the city: Verizon Fios and Charter/Spectrum. And what I think what you\xe2\x80\x99re going to be seeing from DoITT as part of a strategic plan we\xe2\x80\x99re going to launch very soon, before July 1, is new strategies we\xe2\x80\x99re going to deploy to help accelerate the deployment of affordable broadband in the home, and the equitable distribution of it because there are parts of the city that don\xe2\x80\x99t have broadband. The Mayor\'s Office of the Chief Technology Officer just issued a broadband report two weeks ago that\xe2\x80\x99s actually quite enlightening. Some of the highlights over here are that, No. 1, roughly 31 percent of New Yorkers don\xe2\x80\x99t have broadband in the home today, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the equivalent to the entire population of the city of Houston. So that\xe2\x80\x99s a problem. There\xe2\x80\x99s also issues around affordability for the current broadband services that are offered. And I think the obvious issue is there is a minimal level of choice for broadband. So all these things we\xe2\x80\x99re tackling, and I think you\xe2\x80\x99re going to see this in the strategic plan, ways in which we\xe2\x80\x99re going to change this game to deliver more equitable, affordable broadband to more New Yorkers to really hit the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s commitment of broadband for all New Yorkers by 2025.\nsamir-saini-headshot-submitted.jpg\nAlt Text:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiTitle Text:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiCaption:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiDescription:\xc2\xa0Samir SainiImage Credit:\xc2\xa0Submitted\nC&S: What can you tell me about ongoing difficulties with Charter/Spectrum? In what ways are they possibly violating their franchise agreement with the city?SS: There were two audits that we conducted against Spectrum. One was an audit that was financially related around evaluating how revenue was being calculated and generated. And the second audit was more on labor. And really the audits were meant to ensure and validate that Charter was in fact complying to the letter of the franchise agreement we have in place with them. So that\xe2\x80\x99s all public knowledge. On the financial audit, we asked for a bunch of financial data from Charter. They provided it ... and we\xe2\x80\x99re analyzing it. So that\xe2\x80\x99s in process. On the audit regarding whether they violated any labor issues, we made some initial findings, however there\xe2\x80\x99s other concerns from other entities around whether this is a violation of labor provisions within the franchise agreement that are still pending a final determination.C&S: You\xe2\x80\x99re fairly new to the job. What has your transition been like and what do you consider to be your most important role?SS: I\xe2\x80\x99m still two months in. But really, I\xe2\x80\x99ve broken down our core objectives into three parts. The first is going all-in into achieving digital equity for all New Yorkers. Digital equity implying equitably distributed, affordable broadband in every home, on every street, in every borough. The second one is really a focus on DoITT as a shared services provider. DoITT provides a set of IT services to serve our internal agencies. We have over 100 agencies that we support in different ways. So the first objective I\xe2\x80\x99ll have for our agency is to really transform ourselves more fully and entirely into operating like an external service company. Less a call center, internal service order taker. So it\xe2\x80\x99s a big cultural shift for us, but the idea is to really start transforming how we interact with agencies: treat them like customers, have a menu of services that are really easily understood and explainable and measurable. So it\xe2\x80\x99s really running our internal shop better than we do today and then transforming ourselves from order taker to a service management orientation.\nThe second objective is really around relooking at the services we provide to the agencies. We provide about 60 high-level services today \xe2\x80\x93 relooking at these 60, asking our customers, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat services do you want from us?\xe2\x80\x9d And then optimizing the service portfolio to align to the needs of the agencies today and what they\xe2\x80\x99ll need over the foreseeable future. This hasn\xe2\x80\x99t happened in a long time. Up to this point, DoITT has built its service portfolio based on random requests from different agencies. If you wanted a pizza, DoITT would figure out how to make a pizza and give you a pizza. If you wanted a hamburger, we\xe2\x80\x99d figure that out and give you a hamburger. If you wanted a steak, we did that. Now we have a kitchen and a bunch of chefs that can make all sorts of stuff. But the question is, should we? Or do we want to be a pizza joint? What do we actually want to be? It\xe2\x80\x99s a good problem to have because we\xe2\x80\x99ve built a lot of relationships and we have a wide menu, but it\xe2\x80\x99s now becoming a point where we want to be more strategic about what we want to put on our menu based on what really our customers want from us \xe2\x80\x93 especially if people aren\xe2\x80\x99t ordering burgers anymore.C&S: Cybersecurity has been a very large concern recently, especially with the upcoming elections. What is the city doing to shore up its defenses against cyberattacks?SS: There was a press release from the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office announcing the preliminary budget that\xe2\x80\x99s going to the City Council for review over the next few weeks. In that budget is an inclusion for over $40 million dedicated for Geoff Brown and the new cyber command unit that\xe2\x80\x99s been set up. The cyber command unit, we call C3 under the citywide (chief information security officer) Geoff Brown, reports directly into the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office, the deputy mayor of operations, not to me. And that\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing because security is such a huge world these days that it requires its own agency, its own dedicated focus and that\xe2\x80\x99s where that lives. So the biggest thing we\xe2\x80\x99ve done is put money to it, and the money is really for staff and for tools to strengthen the city\xe2\x80\x99s ability to detect, to respond, to prevent threats from happening in the first place. It also is investments to ensure that we can continuously proactively check to find holes in the environment if any exist and close them before they\xe2\x80\x99re ever exploited by a bad actor externally. And so we\xe2\x80\x99re feeling really good about it. It takes investment and the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s proposed budget provides exactly that.C&S: Is that different than other cities?SS: It is. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know of any other city that has that structure. Coming from me, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s a very good thing because New York City isn\xe2\x80\x99t like any other city. The sheer complexity of what we do and how visible we are externally warrants that cybersecurity be its own entity and have its own separate investment and funding and resources. So I think the executive order Mayor de Blasio issued to create this organization last summer was absolutely the right move. And I think New York should feel really good that we\xe2\x80\x99re not doing what other cities do. We\xe2\x80\x99re taking cybersecurity so seriously, we created a whole agency, and incremental new funding dedicated to it to ensure that we\xe2\x80\x99re safe.C&S: A couple months ago, there was a huge cyberattack that crippled Atlanta. Do you think that having a New York City approach to cybersecurity could have prevented or at minimized the damage of that attack?SS: I don\xe2\x80\x99t. I mean, the reality of what happened in Atlanta and also what\xe2\x80\x99s happening in other cities is just not being, it\xe2\x80\x99s not hitting the news unless you\xe2\x80\x99re in the CIO circuit, is that those kinds of threats, especially that one ... can\xe2\x80\x99t be prevented. (Editor\'s note: After this interview was published, the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications clarified that Saini meant\xc2\xa0that such threats are "very hard to prevent.")\xc2\xa0The key is to have an administration that prioritizes cybersecurity. I\xe2\x80\x99ll put it that way. And investments in cybersecurity in particular are really critical regardless of how it\xe2\x80\x99s structured. In Atlanta, I think Mayor (Keisha Lance) Bottoms publicly said that she had not made cybersecurity a priority. That\xe2\x80\x99s her words. But now, after the attack, it is her No. 1 priority. So I think the mayor is doing absolutely the right thing, which is way before, this is last year, before the Atlanta attack and actually several other attacks that occurred in other cities affecting critical infrastructure, public safety infrastructure, transportation infrastructure. California got affected. He saw the writing on the wall and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do this differently,\xe2\x80\x9d which is where C3 was born.C&S: You were CIO in Atlanta before coming to New York City. How different has it been to come from a place where, as you said, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t initially a priority to a place where it is?SS: Part of why I had left is first off, I\xe2\x80\x99m actually from New Jersey. So, in part, this was a move home. But the other is, there was a leadership change happening in Atlanta, there was a new mayor coming it. It was a logical time for me to depart. But also, there was minimal \xe2\x80\x93 I felt like Atlanta had hit a point where they were not investing as much as I would have wanted them to in moving on a number of areas, scaling out smart city initiatives we had, but also in the cyber space. So it was really a mixed bag of reasons, but moving here to New York, it\xe2\x80\x99s been a real blessing because I think this city and this mayor really understands and values IT. Not to say they didn\xe2\x80\x99t in Atlanta, but certainly, it\xe2\x80\x99s a big deal here. In large part I think it\xe2\x80\x99s because the operations of New York City are so complex and affect so many people that technology plays an even more critical role in the delivery of the services to the 8.7 million people that live here, less so the 500,000 people that live in Atlanta. So I think there\xe2\x80\x99s just a lot more focus and dependence on it, and a lot more investment and appreciation for IT and our services.C&S: And you said the kind of attack that happened in Atlanta isn\xe2\x80\x99t really preventable. Is it a concern that it could happen in New York City?SS: Yes. There\xe2\x80\x99s multiple types of cyberattacks that occur all the time. So I would be the first to tell you, and no one could disagree with this, no city, no state, no private sector entity is immune from any of these. Period. If anyone thinks they\xe2\x80\x99re well-protected, well, they shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t say that publicly because they\xe2\x80\x99re just going to be a target. If you talk to the cybersecurity experts out there, they\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you the same thing \xe2\x80\x93 that the game now, it\xe2\x80\x99s not about investing in services to protect yourself from ever having an attack. Everyone needs to accept that there will be an attack. It\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of when. It\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of how bad. And the question really will be, how ready are you, as a city or as a private sector company, to detect it and remediate it, and to strengthen your defenses so if it happens again, it won\xe2\x80\x99t be as bad, or that kind of attack won\xe2\x80\x99t happen again. It\xe2\x80\x99s about containment and response and then strengthening your defenses next time. No one is immune. It just so happens that Atlanta got hit, but when was the last time Atlanta was hit? Never. Because we did several other things, at least over the course of my time there, where we could have gotten hit 10 times because we had legacy infrastructure and all sorts of holes. That\xe2\x80\x99s why it\xe2\x80\x99s just one of those things where you\xe2\x80\x99re never 100 percent safe. Nobody is 100 percent safe from a cyberattack. Anyone who says they are, I would worry about.\nRelated Stories\nNew York CityA look at DoITT\'s new Text-to-911 emergency response initiativeBy GRACE SEGERS\nTechnologyThe next frontier: A Q&A with DoITT Commissioner Anne RoestBy FRANK G. McMahon is a go-to expert on budget plans and policy proposals. His organization promotes greater transparency, accountability and fiscal responsibility in state government, which often puts him at odds with lawmakers and the governor. McMahon previously worked as a journalist in Albany, as an Assembly Republican staffer and a budget adviser for almost 30 years, giving him great insight into the goings-on in the Capitol.\n20190423'

aS'Greenpoint LinkNYC Kiosk Acts As \'Drug Den\' Concierge: Neighbors\n- Greenpoint - New York - DNAinfo\nThe DNAinfo archives brought to you by WNYC.Read the press release here.New Midtown East\nUpper East Side & Roosevelt Island\nUpper West Side & Morningside Heights\nWashington Heights & Inwood\nBrooklyn\nBedford-Stuyvesant\nCobble Hill, Carroll Gardens & Red Hook\nCrown Heights, Prospect Heights & Prospect-Lefferts Gardens\nFort Greene & DUMBO\nPark Slope, Windsor Terrace & Gowanus\nWilliamsburg, Greenpoint & Bushwick\nQueens\nAstoria & Long Island City\nFlushing & Whitestone\nForest Hills, Rego Park & Jamaica\nJackson Heights & Elmhurst\nMaspeth, Middle Village & Ridgewood\nThe Rockaways\nThe Bronx\nFordham & Tremont\nNorwood & Bedford Park\nRiverdale & Kingsbridge\nSouth Bronx\nWoodlawn & Wakefield\nStaten Island\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nCrime & Mayhem\nEducation\nFood & Drink\nHealth & Wellness\nParenting & Schools\nPolitics\nReal Week\nThis Is New York\nHolidays in the Neighborhood\nNeighborhood PartnersAdvertise With UsOur TeamTerms of UsePrivacy Policy\xc2\xa9 2018 DNAinfoSearchSearch\nWilliamsburg, Greenpoint & BushwickCrime & Mayhem\nGreenpoint LinkNYC Kiosk Acts As \'Drug Den\' Concierge: Neighbors\nBy Gwynne Hogan\n|&nbspSeptember 22, 2017 5:30pm |\xc2\xa0Updated on September 25, 2017 7:23am@gwynnefitz\nTwitter\nFacebook\nEmail\nMore\nThe kiosks went up along Manhattan Avenue the end of July.\nView Full Caption\nDNAinfo/Gwynne Hogan\nGREENPOINT \xe2\x80\x94 A municipal wireless internet kiosk\xc2\xa0that went up on Manhattan Avenue in late July has become an electronic concierge for a neighborhood "drug den," allowing people\xc2\xa0to schedule drug purchases and warn each other about approaching police, locals say.\nDrug users can be seen and heard at the LinkNYC terminal, located on Manhattan between\xc2\xa0Huron and India streets, arranging meet ups then disappear into a building known to be a drug spot around the corner and reappear\xc2\xa0after visibly drugged out, business owners and residents said.\n"It is a crime magnet. It is creating and enabling it." said Heather Letzkus\xc2\xa0who has a birds-eye view of the kiosk from her apartment window above and has overheard countless meet ups, and watched callers return to linger at the kiosk visibly drugged out.\nThe kiosk is located about half a block from 177 Huron St. a house that\'s been on the radar of local authorities for months, according to Councilman Stephen Levin\'s office.\n"It seems to be a drug den of some kind," said Ben Solotaire, a staffer at Levin\'s office.\nPolice have logged eight complaints since March at 177 Huron St, records show. They\'ve made five arrests at the address for criminal possession\xc2\xa0of controlled substance, assault, strangulation, menacing, records show.\nMost recently,\xc2\xa0Emil Slevin, 54, whose family owns the house according to property records,\xc2\xa0was cuffed on Sept. 9 for pouring acid on another man, prosecutors said.\nSlevin was being held on Rikers Island on $5,000 which he hadn\'t posted and was due back in court on Oct. 12. His Legal Aid Attorney declined to comment on the charges immediately.\nArlene Mocko, 47, who was arrested there in March for drug possession, was re-arrested on Aug. 25 after she pushed into\xc2\xa0Letzkus\' building demanding to use the bathroom, Letzkus said. Mocko\xc2\xa0had been making a loud call at the wireless kiosk warning the person on the other line about a police car on the block before the incident, Letzkus said.\nPolice found\xc2\xa0Mocko\xc2\xa0with a crack pipe with cocaine in it, prosecutors said. She\'s now\xc2\xa0facing trespassing, drug possession and harassment charges. She was released on her own recognizance and is due back in court on Oct. 19.\nMocko, who couldn\'t be reached for comment immediately is raising $5,000 on GoFundMe to buy a car and leave the city and describes struggling with addiction.\nLevin\'s office has received several complaints about other LinkNYC\xc2\xa0kiosks along Manhattan Avenue residents have said become flashpoints\xc2\xa0for\xc2\xa0loitering, loud behavior, catcalling, and arranging drug deals, Solotaire\xc2\xa0said.\nSince their July installation, the LinkNYC\xc2\xa0kiosks are the latest\xc2\xa0flashpoint along Manhattan Avenue, where citywide and nationwide issues of homelessness and opioid addition\xc2\xa0have manifested themselves on a very local level.\nClay Street nearby has two homeless shelters, and the director has\xc2\xa0voiced concerns about how easy access to heroin in the area has caused residents who hadn\'t used in years to relapse.\nBusiness owners along the block worry that the kiosks have brought with them a host of unintended consequences.\n"It\'s becoming a\xc2\xa0physical mess to clean up," said Adam Saucy, the owner of Odd Fox Coffee said daily he has to sweep up, "McDonald\'s meals, bottles, cans, paper, bags...half-eaten turned over pizza."\n"If I had it my way this thing\xc2\xa0would be gone," he said, declining to give his age.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do understand the public good of having these things,\xe2\x80\x9d Saucy said, but he added,\xc2\xa0"it\xe2\x80\x99s causing problems that I don\xe2\x80\x99t think people anticipated or were very prepared to deal with.\xe2\x80\x9d\nRecord Grouch co-owner Brian Gempp\xc2\xa0wrote they often hear\xc2\xa0loud arguments between people waiting to use the kiosk and keeps customers from browsing their records out front.\nSince LinkNYC\xc2\xa0kiosks\xc2\xa0were debuted in Manhattan neighborhoods starting in early 2016, Manhattan residents have complained the kiosks were being used as a place for people to post up and drink and use drugs\xc2\xa0or\xc2\xa0organize drug deals.\nLinkNYC was forced to disable the\xc2\xa0wireless browsing capabilities in September of 2016\xc2\xa0after numerous complaints about people using them to watch pornography.\xc2\xa0Loitering complaints dropped by 96 percent after that, according to LinkNYC spokeswoman\xc2\xa0Ruth Fasoldt.\n"In Greenpoint alone, there were more than 163,000 wi-fi sessions in August and Link has worked with\xc2\xa0local businesses to offer affordable advertising on the Links\xe2\x80\x99 55-inch digital displays,\xe2\x80\x9d Fasoldt said.\n"Anyone who sees illegal activity on their street should call 911," she added.\nIn early 2016 more than 1,000 kiosks have been installed across the city with thousands more coming, the company said.\nTwitter\nFacebook\nEmail\nMore\nNext in Williamsburg, Greenpoint & Bushwick48,000 Students With Disabilities Not Getting Help They Need, DOE AdmitsNext aS"More LinkNYC Kiosks May Come To Upper West Side | Upper West Side, NY Patch\nToggle navigation\nUpper West Side\n{{ user.display_name }}\nPost\nManage posts\nMembership\nProfile settings\nEmail settings\nHelp\nContact\nLog out\nAdvertise\nSign up\nLog in\nUpper West Side\nHome\n75\xc2\xb0F\nPost\nAdvertise\nNearby\nNew York City, NY\nCentral Park, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nChelsea, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nHoboken, NJ\nLocal News\nWeather\nPolice & Fire\nObituaries\nSchools\nTraffic & Transit\nSports\nPolitics & Government\nBusiness\nCommunity\nLocalStream\nJobs\nLocal Directory\nNeighbor Posts\nLifestyle\nHome & Garden\nRestaurants & Bars\nPets\nKids & Family\nHealth\nArts & Entertainment\nTravel\nCalendar\nReal Estate\nTown Info\nNew York City\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nGet Tickets\nSee All Places\nNearby Places\nNew York City, NY\nCentral Park, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nChelsea, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nHoboken, NJ\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\nThis Mother's Day Gift Will Last A Lifetime\ncommunity corner\nMore LinkNYC Kiosks May Come To Upper West Side\nThe city has five new Upper West Side locations in mind for LinkNYC Kiosks.\nBy Brendan Krisel, Patch National Staff |\nApr 10, 2018 2:52 pm ET | Updated Apr 10, 2018 2:53 pm ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nUPPER WEST SIDE, NY \xe2\x80\x94 The Upper West Side may get new LinkNYC kiosks at five new locations, according to a Community Board 7 agenda. The city Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and Citybridge \xe2\x80\x94 the organization that will install new LinkNYC kiosks \xe2\x80\x94 are applying to continue deployment of the multi-use terminals on the Upper West Side. The targeted locations are: 2 Columbus Avenue between West 59th and 60th streets;111 West 60 Street on the corner of Columbus Avenue;40 Columbus Avenue near West 61st Street;322 Columbus Avenue between West 75th and 76th streets;100 West 77th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus avenues.Thousands of LinkNYC kiosks have been installed across New York City, many of them on the Upper West Side, in a venture to replace outdated payphones. The terminals provide free wi-fi access, phone charging and assistance with directions. The terminals have also been deployed for more creative uses such as sending Valentines Day messages and functioning as bus countdown clocks.\nWhile the kiosks have their uses, there has been some negative backlash. Some people simply don't like how they look, and internet browsing was removed from the terminals because some New Yorkers were using them to watch porn in public.
