aS'LinkNYC kiosks will now display historic photos of NYC neighborhoods - Curbed NY\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nNew York\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nNeighborhoods\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nCurbed.com\nDetroit\nHamptons\nLos Angeles\nMiami\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nFor Sale in New York\nFor Rent in New York\nDevelopment\nNews\nHouse Calls\nArchitecture\nMaps\nTransportation\nAffordable Housing\nCelebrity Homes\nNeighborhoods\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nNews\nLinkNYC kiosks will now display historic photos of NYC neighborhoods\nNew,\n1\ncomment\nIn some cases, kiosks will display historic images of the very street they\xe2\x80\x99re on\nBy\nTanay Warerkar@TanayWarerkar\nOct 25, 2017,\n3:42pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nLinkNYC kiosks will now display historic photos of NYC\xc2\xa0neighborhoods\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nVia LinkNYC\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC kiosk serve many functions; you can browse the internet (through your device), make free phone calls, charge your phone, and access various city services and maps. Now, these kiosks will serve a new function: they will act as a repository of the neighborhoods\xe2\x80\x99 pasts.\nLinkNYC has teamed up with the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Records and Information Services (DORIS) to show off historic photos from NYC neighborhoods on Link\xe2\x80\x99s 55-inch digital screens. While these images will be specific to the link kiosks in the neighborhood, in some instances they may be images from the very same block where the kiosk is installed.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC now allows you to travel back in time with localized historic photos, bringing the Department of Records and Information Services\xe2\x80\x99 rich digital collections to the streets for everyone to enjoy,\xe2\x80\x9d Jen Hensley, the general manager of LinkNYC, said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cWe hope New Yorkers and visitors alike will delight in seeing snapshots of New York City history and feel more connected to the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSince its launch in early 2016, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s kiosks have expanded to all five boroughs. Currently there are more than 1,100 kiosks throughout the city, and many more are set to follow in the coming years. Together they\xe2\x80\x99ve served over 2.6 million people so far.\nThe Pay Phone of the Future Will Have Wi-Fi, Charging Stations [Curbed]\nWith Official Launch, LinkNYC Set to Bring Wi-Fi, Directions to NYers [Curbed]\nHigh Line spur, LinkNYC among city\xe2\x80\x99s most important new public projects [Curbed]\nNext Up In\nNews\nCity may demolish and rebuild two NYCHA buildings in Chelsea: report\nEverything you need to know about NYC\xe2\x80\x99s Easter Parade\nPart of Broadway will be car-free on April 27 for Earth Day\nNetflix will grow NYC presence with Brooklyn soundstages\nAby Rosen scraps hotel plan for iconic Chrysler Building\nNoguchi Museum plans major expansion in Long Island City\nMost Read\nFirst look at the TWA Hotel\xe2\x80\x99s rooftop infinity pool with runway views\nThe 10,000-square-foot pool observation deck will overlook the Jamaica Bay and bustling JFK runways\nWhat $5,000 rents in NYC\nSee what $5,000/month rents in five NYC neighborhoods, including Dumbo and Soho\nIn the West Village, rare 197-year-old wood-frame home seeks $12M\nThe house at 17 Grove Street is one of the neighborhood\xe2\x80\x99s few remaining wood-frame homes\nCity may demolish and rebuild two NYCHA buildings in Chelsea: report\nThe project, part of the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s ten-year plan to resolve $24 billion in repairs, would bring profit to the embattled agency\nNYC passes its own \xe2\x80\x98Green New Deal\xe2\x80\x99 in landmark vote\n"You cannot overstate how big a deal this is," said one advocate\nCurbed NY Newsletter\nEnter your email address\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nThis Article has a component height of 18. Not really.\nBy\nAmy Plitt\nStaten Island\xe2\x80\x99s Bay Street rezoning approved by City Planning Commission\nThe Staten Island BP calls the rezoning a "boondoggle" while activists say it is "irresponsible"\nBy\nCaroline Spivack\n2\ncomments\n/\nnew\nFirst look at the TWA Hotel\xe2\x80\x99s rooftop infinity pool with runway views\nThe 10,000-square-foot pool observation deck will overlook the Jamaica Bay and bustling JFK runways\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n6\ncomments\n/\nnew\nIn City Island, a Colonial-style house near the beach seeks $1.4M\nThis lovely blue house has stunning views to the Long Island Sound\nBy\nValeria Ricciulli\n4\ncomments\n/\nnew\nStately Clinton Hill landmark transforms into a shared co-living space\nCommon, a co-living startup, remade a historic townhouse into one of its shared homes\nBy\nAmy Plitt\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. aS"What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York? - The New York Times\nSectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexNew YorkSubscribeLog InLog InToday\xe2\x80\x99s PaperNew York|What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York?AdvertisementSupported byF.Y.I.What are those tall kiosks that have replaced pay phones in New York?ImageSince the system launched in early 2016, around 1,250 Links have been erected throughout all five boroughs. The company is aiming for a total of 7,500 Links by 2026.CreditCreditCole Wilson for The New York TimesBy Keith WilliamsJan. 11, 2018Q. Tall kiosks labeled \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x9d are replacing phone booths, offering free Wi-Fi and nationwide phone calls. The thing is, I have never seen anybody using one. What gives?A. Compared with the pay phones they often replace, LinkNYC kiosks, known as Links, get plenty of use, even if no one is standing next to them.According to CityBridge, the consortium that operates LinkNYC, over 3.2 million people have registered for the system\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi service, with 600,000 users each week. The Wi-Fi operates at gigabit speed, meaning it can be up to 100 times faster than cellular LTE networks. The range of a Link is about 150 feet in any direction.Links are a critical piece in the city\xe2\x80\x99s goal to bring broadband internet access to all New Yorkers, but the system\xe2\x80\x99s community-first approach provides other social benefits, as well.Each Link has an interactive screen, which offers everyday information you might expect, like weather, local maps, and transit updates, as well as a connection to the city\xe2\x80\x99s 311 service. Through a partnership with the software program Aunt Bertha, however, users can anonymously search for nonprofit and social services.Links also offer free phone calls anywhere in the country; the system registers around 200,000 calls each month. The number dialed most frequently? The state\xe2\x80\x99s hotline for its Electronic Benefits Transfer program, commonly known as food stamps.Since the system launched in early 2016, around 1,250 Links have been erected throughout all five boroughs. The company is aiming for a total of 7,500 Links by 2026, when its contract with the city is scheduled to expire.As the first system of its kind, LinkNYC has faced unforeseen difficulties. When the system was introduced, each Link offered an internet browser. But a slew of complaints of users camping out in front of the units and, in some cases, viewing inappropriate content, caused the system to remove that functionality.The system\xe2\x80\x99s biggest challenge is finding new locations, said Jen Hensley, the general manager of LinkNYC. The system is building a new fiber-optic network, but not every pay phone site is close enough to a manhole to connect to it.Links generate revenue through advertisements, which appear on the 55-inch screens on the sides of each kiosk. These ads are interspersed with in-house content like \xe2\x80\x9cNYC Fun Facts\xe2\x80\x9d and historical photos of nearby locations. LinkNYC and the city split the ad revenue equally, subject to an annual minimum.The idea is expanding to other cities: Links have begun appearing in the United Kingdom, and are set to arrive in Philadelphia this summer.The system is in a constant state of refinement, with temporary options ranging from time-sensitive to whimsical. Through Jan. 31, for example, users can browse and enroll in health care plans; in December, each Link offered a direct line to Santa\xe2\x80\x99s voice mail.EMAIL fyi@nytimes.com A version of this article appears in print on , on Page MB3 of the New York edition. Order Reprints | Today\xe2\x80\x99s Paper | SubscribeAdvertisementOpen in the appSite IndexGo to Home Page \xc2\xbbnewshome pageworldU.S.politicsNew Yorkbusinesstechscienceclimatesportsobituariesthe upshottoday's papercorrectionsopiniontoday's opinionop-ed columnistseditorialsop-ed Contributorsletterssunday reviewvideo: opinionartstoday's artsart & designbooksdancemoviesmusicPop Culturetelevisiontheaterwatchingvideo: artslivingautomobilescrosswordfoodCookingeducationstylehealthjobsmagazinereal estatet magazinetravelweddingslistings & moreReader CenterWirecutterLive EventsThe Learning Networktools & servicesN.Y.C. events guidemultimediaphotographyvideoNewslettersNYT storetimes journeysmanage my accountnewshome pageworldU.S.politicsNew Yorkbusinesstechscienceclimatesportsobituariesthe upshottoday's papercorrectionsopiniontoday's opinionop-ed columnistseditorialsop-ed Contributorsletterssunday reviewvideo: opinionartstoday's artsart & designbooksdancemoviesmusicPop Culturetelevisiontheaterwatchingvideo: artslivingautomobilescrosswordfoodCookingeducationstylehealthjobsmagazinereal estatet magazinetravelweddingsmoreReader CenterWirecutterLive EventsThe Learning Networktools & servicesN.Y.C. events guidemultimediaphotographyvideoNewslettersNYT storetimes journeysmanage my accountSubscribehome deliverydigital subscriptionsCrosswordCookingemail newsletterscorporate subscriptionseducation ratemobile applicationsreplica editionSite Information Navigation\xc2\xa9\xc2\xa02019\xc2\xa0The New York Times CompanyContact UsWork with usAdvertiseYour Ad ChoicesPrivacyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapHelpHelpSubscriptions"
p31
aS'403 Forbidden\n403 Forbidden\nnginx'
p32
aS"LinkNYC Kiosks Adopt Aunt Bertha Social Services App - CityLab\nSkip to content\nDesign Transportation Environment Equity Life\nLinkNYC's new Aunt Bertha app connects users with information about food pantries, emergency housing, and other social services. LinkNYC\nNew York City's Wi-Fi Kiosks Now Include a 'Yelp for Social Services'\nLaura Bliss\nApr 13, 2017\nThe move targets New Yorkers who stand to benefit most from the LinkNYC network in the first place. Share Tweet LinkedInEmailPrint\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s no blueprint for how to roll out the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest free public wi-fi network\xe2\x80\x94especially one with hundreds of web-beaming, touch-screen towers spread across five boroughs. So a little more than a year after LinkNYC installed its first kiosks around New York City, some questions are still hazy. How are they supposed to be used? Who are they really meant for?\nToday LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s purpose takes a slightly clearer shape, with the addition of Aunt Bertha, an existing app modeled as a Yelp for social safety-net services run by an Austin-based benefit corporation. LinkNYC kiosks are already equipped with access to 911 and 311, a portal to apply for government benefits, interactive maps, free phone-call capabilities, and a USB charger. Through a simple search from one of the kiosk tablets, New Yorkers can now tap into Aunt Bertha\xe2\x80\x99s robust database of food pantries, emergency housing, childcare, healthcare, transportation assistance, and financial aid programs located within that zip code.\nRecommended\nTo Court a Skeptical Public, New York Sends Wi-Fi Ambassadors\nEillie Anzilotti Aug 12, 2016\nA Portland Startup Is Smashing Barriers to Affordable Housing Laura Bliss Jan 27, 2017\nNew Place Names Lift M\xc4\x81ori Culture in New Zealand\xe2\x80\x99s Capital Chris Fitch 8:00 AM ET\nThe app targets the New Yorkers who stand the most to gain from LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s services in the first place. A 2015 study by the city comptroller\xe2\x80\x99s office found that roughly 813,000 households (nearly 26 percent, citywide) lacked broadband access at home; 510,000 don\xe2\x80\x99t have a computer.\nThe majority of these disconnected households are surviving below the poverty line, and may benefit from the resources Aunt Bertha is designed to catalogue and serve up with ease. Founded in 2012, the platform has connected more than 280,000 people around the U.S. with services from all tiers of government, large nonprofit agencies, and neighborhood groups\xe2\x80\x94the sorts of resources otherwise buried across thousands of websites and pamphlets that can require hours or days of sifting to find.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople in need are almost always grappling with interrelated problems\xe2\x80\xa6 so easily accessible powerful technology tools that provide useful options in one place are key,\xe2\x80\x9d Steve Lee, a managing director at Robin Hood, a New York City anti-poverty agency, said in a statement.\nWhether New Yorkers will bite, of course, is the big-ticket question. LinkNYC has logged more than a million registered users on its wi-fi network since the kiosks first rolled out in February 2016. However, the offerings have shifted substantially: Initially, the touch-screens offered unfettered web-browsing, but that feature quickly got axed when the lure of YouTube (and porn sites) proved too disruptive to sidewalk life. And not all New Yorkers have taken enthusiastically to the 2001 Space Odyssey-like monoliths, which are owned and operated by a consortium of public and private entities with Alphabet at the center. Data privacy concerns, especially in low-income neighborhoods already experiencing disproportionate levels of police surveillance, have held plenty of users back.\nRepresentatives for LinkNYC say that the kiosks themselves don\xe2\x80\x99t require log-ins (though the wi-fi network does), and wipe any personal information entered at the end of each session. Usage data from the Aunt Bertha app, they say, will be aggregated to guide searchers to services that might be the most in-demand where they are. LinkNYC also continues to work with community groups, local libraries, youth groups, and seniors organizations to reach groups that could benefit from the services. Meanwhile, the network will continue to expand. Currently, there are a little over 800 kiosks around the city; LinkNYC expects 7,500 total by 2025.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmart\xe2\x80\x9d technology will never solve wicked problems like urban poverty, hunger, transportation gaps, and healthcare divides on its own\xe2\x80\x94focused policies and targeted investments have to work in tandem. But if the yank-back of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s web browsing access was a case study in unintended consequences of overly broad ambitions, a move to connect more New Yorkers with specific services is a step in a helpful direction.\nAbout the Author\nLaura Bliss\n@mslaurabliss\nFeed Laura Bliss is CityLab\xe2\x80\x99s west coast bureau chief, covering transportation and technology. She also authors MapLab, a biweekly newsletter about maps (subscribe here). Her work has appeared in the New York Times, The Atlantic, Los Angeles magazine, and beyond.\nExpand Comments +\nMost Popular\nEnvironment No, Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s New Climate-Change Law Is Not a \xe2\x80\x98Green New Deal\xe2\x80\x99 Puerto Rico just adopted legislation that commits it to generating all its power from renewable sources. Here\xe2\x80\x99s what separates that from what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in D.C.\nBrentin Mock\nApr 22, 2019\nLife When Your Neighborhood Gets a Corporate Rebrand From National Landing to SoHa, neighborhoods often find themselves renamed by forces outside the community, from big companies to real estate firms.\nRaechel A. Portelli\n11:57 AM ET\nLife Who\xe2\x80\x99s Really Buying Property in San Francisco? A lot of software developers, according to an unprecedented new analysis.\nAlexis C. Madrigal\nApr 19, 2019\nEquity What the Supreme Court Said About the 2020 Census Citizenship Question In oral arguments, conservative justices asked about data science, while liberals asked what the citizenship question was really for.\nKriston Capps\n3:48 PM ET\nEquity The Hidden Horror of Hudson Yards Is How It Was Financed Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s new luxury mega-project was partially bankrolled by an investor visa program called EB-5, which was meant to help poverty-stricken areas.\nKriston Capps\nApr 12, 2019\nMapsClick Here\nNewslettersClick Here\nFacebookClick Here\nSkip to content\nShare Tweet\nNext Story in Life \xc2\xbb\nSpecial\xc2\xa0Reports FAQ Masthead Solutions Store Atlantic\xc2\xa0Media Jobs Media\xc2\xa0Kit Partner Solutions Contact\xc2\xa0Us Privacy Terms\xc2\xa0&\xc2\xa0Conditions\nSign up for CityLab Daily:\nSign Up\nLoading...\nSubscribe to our other newsletters here.\nCityLab is committed to telling the story of the world\xe2\x80\x99s cities: how they work, the challenges they face, and the solutions they need.Citylab.com \xc2\xa9 2019 The Atlantic Monthly Group"

aS"LinkNYC kiosks will now show photos of old New York - Archpaper.com\nLinkNYC kiosks will now show photos of old New York\nMenu\nAwards\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nContact\nAbout\nPrivacy Policy\nMap\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nTopics\nRegions\nInternational\nEast\nSoutheast\nMidwest\nWest\nSouthwest\nTopics\nAN Interior\nArchitecture\nArt\nDesign\nDevelopment\nPreservation\nTransportation\nUrbanism\nNewsletters\nFacades+\nSpec Sheet\nCity Terrain\nLate Edition: East\nLate Edition: West\nLate Edition: Midwest\nLate Edition: Southwest\nConferences\nFacades+ Conference\nFacades+ AM\nTech+\nEvents\nCompetitions\nProducts\nJobs\nConferences\nConferences\nFacades+ Conferences\nTech+ Expo\nAwards\nSubscribe\nFrom the Archives\nInstead of ads and porn, LinkNYC kiosks will now show photos of old New York\nBy\nAudrey Wachs\n(@gridwachs)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nOctober 30, 2017\nCity Terrain\nEast\nInstead of ads and porn, LinkNYC kiosks will now show photos of old New York. Pictured here: The Battery, 1960. (Image via NYPL)\nShare:\nBeginning last Friday, select wifi kiosks in New York now feature scintillating pictures of the city from decades past. It\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC porn, but for buildings.\nIn partnership with LinkNYC, the city\xe2\x80\x99s wifi kiosk system, the Department of Records and Information Services is displaying dozens of historic photos on LinkNYC screens in the five boroughs. The images correspond to the blocks where they\xe2\x80\x99re displayed, so a person at Henry and Clark streets, for example, would see a black-and-white picture of the port in what is now Brooklyn Bridge Park. The New York Times reports that most of the photographs on display date from the 1890s through the 1970s, and the project will be up through the end of the year.\nLinkNYC is taking residents\xe2\x80\x99 suggestions for where the archival images should be displayed; readers can tweet @LinkNYC to have their voices heard.\nNYC Archive takes us back to the 1940s #inBrooklyn to Roulstons grocery on 4th Ave & 28th St. #NYCThenandNow @nycrecords pic.twitter.com/Qr5kpGpgOI\n\xe2\x80\x94 NYC IT & Telecomm (@NYCDoITT) October 26, 2017\nThe program is the latest in a slate of apps and maps that disseminate New York City history online. This year,\xc2\xa0Urban Archive geotagged and released over 2,500 images of old New York that users can access on the go. Built in collaboration with\xc2\xa0Brooklyn Historical Society, the\xc2\xa0New York Public Library\xc2\xa0(NYPL), and\xc2\xa0the Museum of the City of New York, the app pings users with archival images when they\xe2\x80\x99re near a historic site in the database, prompting reflection on the changing city. Separately, the NYPL launched the\xc2\xa0NYC Space/Time Directory, a\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99digital time-travel service\xe2\x80\x99 that combines\xc2\xa0the library\xe2\x80\x99s map collection with geospatial tools to illuminate the city\xe2\x80\x99s messy and beautiful development over more than\xc2\xa0a century.\xe2\x80\x9d Downtown, the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation (GVSHP) debuted its\xc2\xa0Civil Rights & Social Justice Map, an interactive tool that reveals key downtown sites where marginalized people have\xc2\xa0fought for equity, dignity, and representation.\nBeyond the archive, urbanists can now access maps to\xc2\xa0prepare for L-mageddon,\xc2\xa0discover the city\xe2\x80\x99s noisiest neighborhoods, learn about\xc2\xa0future skyscrapers, and find the internet\xe2\x80\x99s favorite kind of architecture.\nAbout the author\nAudrey Wachs\n(@gridwachs)\nAssociate Editor, The Architect's Newspaper\nLinkNYC\nMaps\nRelated Stories\nJanuary 2, 2019\nMeet the artist who hand-paints ski maps for resorts around the world\nDecember 31, 2018\nThis map depicts the population density of world cities in stunning detail\nJuly 13, 2018\nLinkNYC brings never-built megaprojects to the streets of New York\nJune 19, 2018\nLinkNYC kiosks will display iconic film director\xe2\x80\x99s photos of old New York\nTrending\nMost Twitter feed showcases the best of the worst\nFrance launches an international competition to rebuild Notre Dame\xe2\x80\x99s spire\nAlbright-Knox Art Gallery reveals new expansion renderings\nFoster + Partners pitches new Notre Dame spire as competition heats up\nOCEANIX and BIG unveil a floating city of the future at the United Nations\nPhotographs document the Italian Fascist architecture of Eritrea\nA leaning Manhattan tower draws blame from both sides\nHere\xe2\x80\x99s what saved the Notre Dame Cathedral from total destruction\nIs Windsor, Florida, peak New Urbanism?\nChicago\xe2\x80\x99s Graham Foundation spotlights Arakawa and Madeline Gins\nDe Blasio cracks down on glass towers as part of Green New Deal\nPepsi denies plans to advertise in space\nLA-M\xc3\xa1s designs colorful accessory dwelling units for Los Angeles\nCopyright 2019The Architect's Newspaper, LLCAll rights aS"LinkNYCs will show bus arrival time info | Metro US\nNews\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nHealth\nSports\nGames\nMetro Bet\nMetro Play\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nMore Social\nFOLLOW US\nSUBSCRIBE TO US\nCONTACT US\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nGoogle Plus\nLinkedIn\nInstagram\nSearch form\nSearchSearch\nSearch form\nSearchSearch\nNewsThe Big StoriesToday\xe2\x80\x99s DebatePresident TrumpLocal NewsNew YorkPhiladelphiaPoliticsEntertainmentMoviesTVCelebritiesLifestyleCareer & EducationJobsFood and DrinksHomeRelationshipsSex and DatingStyle and BeautyTravelThings to DoNew YorkBostonPhiladelphiaSportsNew YorkBostonPhiladelphiaBody & MindHealthWeight LossFitnessGamesCrosswordSudokuMore GamesHoroscopeQuizSweepstakesMetroAbout UsContact UsAdvertiseGrumblePrint EditionNew YorkBostonPhiladelphiaSpecialsInfoTerms and ConditionsCommenting GuidelinesSitemapSweepstakesMetro BetMetro Play\nFollow Metro on\nFacebook\nTwitter\nGoogle Plus\nInstagram\nLinkedIn\nContact Us Email\nNew York\nLinkNYCs will show bus arrival time info\nThe pilot program for LinkNYC kiosks to show bus arrival time info kicks off in Brooklyn and will expand through all five boroughs in the upcoming weeks.\nBy Kristin Toussaint\nPublished : April 04, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nStarting in Brooklyn and expanding soon throughout the city, LinkNYC kiosks will show bus arrival time information. Photo: Wikimedia Commons\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nNext time you need to know when your bus will arrive, you can look to some LinkNYC kiosks.\nCity Council Member Brad Lander, who represents Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s 39th District (covering Carroll Gardens, Gowanus, Park Slope and more) announced on Wednesday the launch of a bus time arrival pilot program for 29 Links within those areas.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s 55-inch screens in those Brooklyn neighborhoods will now show arrival info for buses that are a short walk away from a particular kiosk.\nRecommended Slideshows\n22 PicturesPHOTOS: Celebrities attend 'Avengers: Endgame' premiere in Los Angeles22 Pictures\n14 PicturesPHOTOS: Memorial spotlights the man behind Nipsey Hussle rap persona14 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked\n36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n2 Pictures5 fun things to do in Grand Central Terminal this May2 Pictures\n4 PicturesGet away to Florida\xe2\x80\x99s Captiva Island4 Pictures\nIn the coming weeks, the same bus arrival time feature will launch on Links throughout all five boroughs.\nThe pilot is a collaboration between LinkNYC, the New York City Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications and Lander.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98real-time passenger information\xe2\x80\x99 bus clocks we\xe2\x80\x99ve installed in our district and across the city prove that knowing when the next bus is coming is a real quality-of-life improvement for NYC\xe2\x80\x99s bus riders,\xe2\x80\x9d Lander said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, thanks to LinkNYC and DoITT, riders will have access to that information on thousands of LinkNYC consoles along bus routes citywide, within just a couple of weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThere are more than 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks across the city, which already show subway status updates, weather, sports scores, information about community meetings, street closures and more.Related ArticlesCar Free Day coming to New York Saturday for the fourth year in a rowMayor de Blasio rolls out New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Green New DealSwish Ally Fund is hosting another exciting benefit concert to benefit LGBTQ communit...\nTo city leaders, incorporating real-time data on buses is a logical next step and also a necessity for residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCity buses need deep interventions before they will function adequately, and part of the path to turning around our failing bus service is to get more information into the hands of bus riders, in as many ways as possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Raskin, executive director of the Riders Alliance, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cAdding bus arrival times to LinkNYC kiosks is a smart and creative way to help bus riders save time, and it will help make the bus a more modern, convenient option for New Yorkers to choose.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTags:New York CityTransportation\nLoading...\nLatest From ...\nNews\nShare Now\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsApp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nBusiness schools, aS"LinkNYC continues rapid public Wi-Fi expansion in Brooklyn, Queens | am New York\nMenu\nLATEST PAPER\nSEARCH\nNews\nPolitics\nThings To Do\nEAT & DRINK\nEntertainment\nReal Estate\nTransit\nOpinion\nLATEST PAPER\n68\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nHome\nNews\nPolitics\nElections\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nPets\nSecrets of NY\nReal Estate\nCity Living\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nStaten Island\nTransit\nSports\nOpinion\nJim Marguiles\nCartoon roundup\nWeather\n68\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nNews\nLinkNYC continues rapid public Wi-Fi expansion in Brooklyn, Queens\nWashington Heights resident Anthony Ramos charges his mobile phone at a\nLinkNYC kiosk on Third Avenue at East 43rd Street in Manhattan on Wednesday, March 29, 2017. LinkNYC kiosks are replacing almost all of\nNew York City's 6,000 remaining pay phones.\nPhoto Credit: Charles Eckert\nBy Ivan Pereira and Laura Figueroa ivan.pereira@amny.com, laura.figueroa@newsday.com\n@IvanPer4\nMarch 29, 2017 8:30 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nAn influx of outerboro communities will be linked in this year.\nThe city is on track to meet the 7,500 installation benchmark of its public kiosks, LinkNYC, by 2023 and the majority of the 150 confirmed to go online this spring and summer are in Brooklyn and Queens neighborhoods including Astoria, Park Slope, Long Island City and Flatbush, according to the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunication (DoITT).\nThe addition comes as a relief to city leaders and residents who have called for more equity in distribution of the new technology, which offers\xc2\xa0free phone service, WiFi, charging ports and has been replacing traditional payphones since its launch last year.\nrecommended reading\nCity: LinkNYC kiosks surpass 1 million users\nThey\xe2\x80\x99re excited for the expansion even though the service has been at times beset by controversies ranging from the kiosks being monopolized by individuals looking at pornography and privacy concerns related to user data.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think to date there\xe2\x80\x99s been a concentration in Manhattan, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve said we have to get the outer boroughs equally served, that is the aim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bronx City Councilman James Vacca, the chair of the Council\xe2\x80\x99s Committee on Technology, after receiving an update on LinkNYC Wednesday.\nThere have been roughly 150 new kiosks recently installed throughout the city, and they will be activated in the near future, according to CityBridge, the consortium behind the hot spots.\nAs of Wednesday, 667 Links were up and running in all five boroughs, the operator said.\nGet the Top Stories newsletter\nEditors' picks of our best stories, right to your inbox.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have helped more than 1.3 million New Yorkers and visitors get online at the fastest speeds available in New York City, for free,\xe2\x80\x9d Jen Hensley, LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s general manager, said in a statement.\nThe kiosks initially launched with a tablet that allowed users to browse the internet, but that capability has since been turned off due to complaints from residents. Now, visitors must have their own devices to access the free WiFi.\nLinkNYC has generated $37.3 million in advertising revenue since they launched and they\xe2\x80\x99re expected to generate $25 million in the upcoming year, according to DoITT Commissioner Anne M. Roest, who testified at Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s hearing.\nrecommended reading\nOfficial: Porn viewers are hogging free web kiosks\nVacca is optimistic that the service will straighten itself out after a first-year rife with difficulties.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not going back,\xe2\x80\x9d Vacca said after the hearing. \xe2\x80\x9cWe learned from the experience when the city initially rolled it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\nSome New Yorkers and civil rights groups such as the NYCLU expressed concern over users\xe2\x80\x99 data mining and privacy issues. Two weeks ago, CityBridge updated its privacy policy and sought to ensure users that the kiosks don\xe2\x80\x99t store or share personal information.\nLast September, the city disabled the use of the stations\xe2\x80\x99 web browsers after fielding a number of complaints about people monopolizing the kiosks and spending hours surfing the internet, often for inappropriate material.\nIrene Meisel, a member of the group RethinkLinkNYC who attended the City Council hearing, argued that the kiosks do not go far enough to achieve their primary goal, as stated by city officials: to close the \xe2\x80\x9cdigital divide\xe2\x80\x9d faced by low-income New Yorkers without web access at home.\nMeisel said her group would like to see the city direct some of the LinkNYC revenue to programs that increase digital access to underserved communities.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe city has said that the Links were put up to address the digital divide. As they\xe2\x80\x99re currently configured now we don\xe2\x80\x99t see that they\xe2\x80\x99re doing that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\nAbout 150 new LinkNYC kiosks will go online in the coming months. Here is where you can find them.Queens: Astoria, Long Island City, Rego Park, Elmhurst, Sunnyside, Forest Hills.Brooklyn: Flatbush, Ditmas Park, Park Slope, Greenwood, Greenpoint, Bed Stuy and Crown Heights.The Bronx: Melrose, Fordham HeightsManhattan: Harlem, Midtown\nBy Ivan Pereira and Laura Figueroa ivan.pereira@amny.com, laura.figueroa@newsday.com\n@IvanPer4\nIvan has been a staff reporter with amNewYork since May 2012 and covers breaking news, politics and enterprise stories.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost popular\nKarina Vetrano's killer\xc2\xa0sentenced to life in prison Your MetroCard could win you a 7-day trip to Hawaii What we know about the Karina Vetrano case Subway rider killed in 'horrible' dragging incident A rich revival of 'All My Sons'\nTop News stories\nRanked Choice Voting proposed for NYC\nKarina Vetrano's killer\xc2\xa0sentenced to life in prison\nWhat we know about the Karina Vetrano case\nWhat to know about the\xc2\xa0Karina Vetrano murder retrial\nMan arrested in connection with\xc2\xa0murder at\xc2\xa0Bushwick Houses\nMTA conductor stabbed on Bronx subway platform\nNews photos & videos\nBiden set to announce 2020 presidential bid: Source\nEaster parade and bonnet festival in NYC\nBunnies and bonnets: Must-see Easter parade photos\nCop shot in confrontation, suspect dead: NYPD\nNYPD officer shot in Manhattan released from hospital\nThese 9 photos will help you relax on Stress Awareness Day\nQuick Links\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nNewsletters\nSecrets of New York\nEvents this week\nWeekend Best Bets\nStaff & Bios\nSitemap\nPartners\nNewsday\nNews 12\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nSections\nNews\nTransit\nPolitics\nElections\nEntertainment\nCelebrities\nThings To Do\nEat & Drink\nContact us | Jobs at amnewyork | PRIVACY\nPOLICY | TERMS OF SERVICE\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\n240 W 35TH ST., 9TH FLOOR NY, NY 10001 646.293.9499 FAX: 212.239.2828 | Newsday. aS'New York adds bus info to LinkNYC kiosks, starting in Brooklyn | StateScoop\nSubscribe\nAbout\nRSS\nBrought to you by\nSpecial Reports\nState\nCity\nCounty & Local\nWatch\nListen\nAttend\nContent Studio\nNew York adds bus info to LinkNYC kiosks, starting in Brooklyn\nShare\nWritten by Benjamin Freed\nApr 5, 2018 | STATESCOOP\nSince early 2016, New York City has installed about 1,700 LinkNYC kiosks\xc2\xa0offering free Wi-Fi, mobile-device charging stations, and access to city services where now-antiquated phone booths once stood. As of this week, 29 kiosks in Brooklyn will now display real-time\xc2\xa0bus schedules, city officials announced Wednesday, with the updates spreading to the rest of the city not long after.\nThe bus-information upgrade was announced by LinkNYC, which is privately operated and managed by the Citybridge consortium;\xc2\xa0the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of\xc2\xa0Information Technology and Telecommunications;\xc2\xa0and City Council member Brad Lander, who\xc2\xa0represents neighborhoods like Park Slope and Cobble Hill. The initial 29\xc2\xa0kiosks getting the bus information are all in\xc2\xa0Lander\xe2\x80\x99s district.\nKiosks will show pedestrians which bus lines they\xe2\x80\x99re on, and how many stops away the nearest bus is, with the relevant information being dowloaded from the Metropolitan Transit Authority. The arrival times will be shown on the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 55-inch digital screens. Citybridge, a group\xc2\xa0of advertising and communications companies, also sells ads on the displays.\nCity officials boast of LinkNYC having one of the quickest internet connections in New York, with the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 broadcasting gigabit-speed Wi-Fi that\xe2\x80\x99s 100 times faster than typical public wireless and 40 times faster than the average home connection, according to the service\xe2\x80\x99s website.\nThe\xc2\xa0Android tablet computers implanted in each kiosk already allowed users to access city maps and social services. The kiosks also support phones that offer free domestic phone calls. Along with the free wireless internet and device charging, city officials estimate LinkNYC has already been used 3.5 million times since the first kiosks were installed, with Wi-Fi users going through more than 3,625 terabytes of data. CIVIQ, which\xc2\xa0manufactures the kiosks,\xc2\xa0has also\xc2\xa0deployed them in\xc2\xa0London, and similar\xc2\xa0systems are being planned in Chicago and Miami.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom voter registration to healthcare enrollment, and now with real-time bus information on Brooklyn kiosks, LinkNYC has once again proven to be more than just fast and free Wi-Fi,\xe2\x80\x9d DoITT Commissioner Samir Saini says in a press release.\nLander may have more of a rooting interest in getting the real-time bus information on the kiosks. Many of his\xc2\xa0constituents might soon be familiarizing themselves with their local bus schedules in preparation for next year\xe2\x80\x99s scheduled shutdown of the subway\xe2\x80\x99s L train, a vital link for Brooklynites headed into Manhattan.\nCity officials do not expect the Brooklyn pilot to last more than a few weeks before the real-time bus information spreads to the rest of the kiosk network. The pilot is mostly to make sure the bus schedules are functioning properly and meeting user-experience requirements. LinkNYC also\xc2\xa0plans to collect direct\xc2\xa0feedback from users who are frequent bus passengers.\n-In this Story-\nCivic Tech, Digital Services, LinkNYC, New York, New York City, Samir Saini, State & Local News, States, Tech News, Transportation\nRelated news\nCity\nNew York City hires Obama administration tech adviser as CTO\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 1 min ago\nCity\nWhy local governments should lead multi-jurisdiction disaster response\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 3 hours ago\nCity\nSt. Louis IT agency revised security policies after audit, CIO says\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 1 day ago\nAd Specs\nSponsor\nRSS\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Scoop News Group\n|\nAll Rights Reserved\nSearch for:\nThe latest state and local government tech news, delivered straight to your inbox.\nSign up for our daily newsletter.\nPrivacy Policy\nWe use cookies to provide you with the best experience across all Scoop News Group websites. By using Scoop News Group websites, you consent to the use of cookies. Learn more\nGOT IT!'

aS'Post Your Valentine On LinkNYC Kiosks Once Famous For Public Porn | New York City, NY Patch\nToggle navigation\nNew York City\n{{ user.display_name }}\nPost\nManage posts\nMembership\nProfile settings\nEmail settings\nHelp\nContact\nLog out\nAdvertise\nSign up\nLog in\nNew York City\nHome\n75\xc2\xb0F\nPost\nAdvertise\nNearby\nCentral Park, NY\nUpper West Side, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nChelsea, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nEast Village, NY\nLocal News\nWeather\nPolice & Fire\nObituaries\nSchools\nTraffic & Transit\nSports\nPolitics & Government\nBusiness\nCommunity\nLocalStream\nJobs\nLocal Directory\nNeighbor Posts\nLifestyle\nHome & Garden\nRestaurants & Bars\nPets\nKids & Family\nHealth\nArts & Entertainment\nTravel\nCalendar\nReal Estate\nTown Info\nNew York\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nGet Tickets\nSee All Places\nNearby Places\nCentral Park, NY\nUpper West Side, NY\nUpper East Side, NY\nMidtown Manhattan, NY\nHarlem, NY\nAstoria-Long Island City, NY\nChelsea, NY\nGramercy-Murray Hill, NY\nWest Village, NY\nEast Village, NY\nState Edition\nNew York\nNational Edition\nTop National News\nSee All Places\nThis Mother\'s Day Gift Will Last A Lifetime\nseasonal & holidays\nPost Your Valentine On LinkNYC Kiosks Once Famous For Public Porn\nYou can declare your love on the devices where shady characters once watched porn in public.\nBy Noah Manskar, Patch Staff |\nJan 25, 2018 4:18 pm ET | Updated Jan 26, 2018 8:36 am ET\n{{ replyButtonLabel }}\nReply\n{{ replyCount }}\nNEW YORK, NY \xe2\x80\x94 The city wants New Yorkers to declare their love \xe2\x80\x94 or even pop the question \xe2\x80\x94 on the kiosks that were once infamous for public porn-watching.\nTo celebrate Valentine\'s Day, anyone who posts a cute photo to Instagram and tags it with #LinkLoveNYC could have the picture projected on the sides of more than 1,200 LinkNYC kiosks across city on Feb. 14. Link, the company behind the kiosks, is even offering to help New Yorkers "set up a special proposal" using the screens. But anyone popping the question might have to shuffle around other people charging their phones or making phone calls. "LinkNYC\'s digital displays feature fun facts about New York City, historic photos, important PSAs, and advertising that keeps our services free for all," Link President Jen Hensley said in a statement. "This Valentine\'s Day, you can use it to tell someone you love them \xe2\x80\x94 and even propose." The attempt at romance is Link\'s latest holiday-themed display on the kiosks, which had internet browsers until people reportedly spent hours camped out next to them playing music or watching smutty videos. The kiosks still allow free phone calls, maps and wireless internet connections. The company thinks it\'s solved that problem \xe2\x80\x94 loitering complaints dropped by 96 percent "immediately" after the web browsers were pulled in September 2016, a Link spokesman said.\nLink staff will review every tagged Instagram photo to make sure it\'s not too risque before putting it goes on the screens, the spokesman said. But every appropriate picture will likely be featured. Link will ask users for permission before broadcasting their photos, the company says.\nAnyone who wants to take the next step and propose with the LinkNYC screens should email hello@link.nyc. (Lead image: A LinkNYC kiosk is pictured in Manhattan in August 2016. Mascali\nPublished : February 07, 2018\nUpdated\n:\nFebruary 07, 2018\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nMore\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsapp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\n1/2\nNBC Olympics partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content across the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city. (NBC Sports Group)\nBack to top\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nReddit\nWhatsapp\nEmail\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re worried about missing even a single minute of the upcoming PyeongChang Olympics, you\xe2\x80\x99ll only have to find the nearest LinkNYC kiosk to see the latest highlights.\nNBC Olympics, a division of NBC Sports Group, partnered with smart cities tech and media company Intersection to broadcast exclusive Olympic content on the more than 1,300 LinkNYC kiosks across the city.\nNBC\xe2\x80\x99s digital-based content for the Olympic Winter Games, which take place in PyeongChang, South Korea, Feb. 9 through Feb. 25, will include morning highlights, medal counts, primetime previews, schedules, real-time alerts and more.\nRecommended Slideshows\n22 PicturesPHOTOS: Celebrities attend 'Avengers: Endgame' premiere in Los Angeles22 Pictures\n14 PicturesPHOTOS: Memorial spotlights the man behind Nipsey Hussle rap persona14 Pictures\n36 PicturesAll of these celebrities have had their nudes leaked\n36 PicturesMore picture galleries\n16 PicturesThese photos of Trump and Ivanka will make you deeply uncomfortable\n16 Pictures\n2 Pictures5 fun things to do in Grand Central Terminal this May2 Pictures\n4 PicturesGet away to Florida\xe2\x80\x99s Captiva Island4 Pictures\nThe Olympics coverage isn\xe2\x80\x99t just relegated to New York City, though. Chicago residents will be able to see the content on digital urban panels and platform displays in the Chicago Transit Authority, and Philadelphians can see it on digital bus shelters, urban panels and platform displays throughout SEPTA, PATCO and city streets.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether walking the streets of New York, riding the Chicago L or waiting in Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s 30th Street Station, Olympics fans in these three cities will be surrounded by the excitement of the Winter Games,\xe2\x80\x9d Gary Zenkel, president of NBC Olympics, said in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cEmerging media platforms like the LinkNYC network in New York City represent another way for NBCUniversal to reassemble the television audience by extending the reach of our Olympic coverage, content and promotion to spaces where the American audience now consumes media.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWe're thrilled to partner with @NBCOlympics to bring the Winter Olympics to Chicago, Philadelphia, and New York City! https://t.co/ldq8ZqGpOW via @Adweek #WinterOlympics #BestOfUS pic.twitter.com/D8NmJyYcsDRelated ArticlesWhat is the time zone difference in South Korea Winter Olympics?\nCar Free Day coming to New York Saturday for the fourth year in a rowMayor de Blasio rolls out New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Green New Deal\n\xe2\x80\x94 Intersection (@intersection_co) February 7, 2018\nTags:OlympicsPyeongchang OlympicsSportsNew York City\nLoading...\nLatest From ...\nNews\nShare Now\nShare this article\nFacebook\nTwitter\nMail\nWhatsApp\nReddit\nLinkedIn\nBusiness schools, companies getting creative to stem decline in MBA enrollment\nThieves pinch rifles as Kenyan police watch Champions League football\nWorkers save dog spotted more than 100 miles off Thailand coast\nDon't like surprises? aS'Inside LinkNYC\'s free public gigabit WiFi plan - Business Insider\nTech\nFinance\nPolitics\nStrategy\nLife\nAll\nTech\nTech Insider\nMedia\nScience\nTransportation\nFinance\nFinance\nMarkets Insider\nRetail\nYour Money\nPolitics\nPolitics\nMilitary & Defense\nStrategy\nStrategy\nAdvertising\nCareers\nLife\nLife\nCoupons\nEntertainment\nInsider Picks\nSports\nFeatured\nBetter Capitalism\nEmbracing Disruption\nInsider TV\nSubscribe\nBI Intelligence\nBI Prime\nAbout BI\nAbout\nCareers\nContact Us\nAdvertise\nContributors FAQ\nCorporate\nCorrections Policy\nFollow BI\nNewsletters\nEvents\nRSS\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nLinkedIn\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nEdition\nBI Prime\nIntelligence\nMenu Icon\nA vertical stack of three evenly spaced horizontal lines.\nEdition\nInternational Editions:\nUnited States\nUS\nInternational\nINTL\nDeutschland\nDE\nAustralia\nAUS\nFrance\nFR\nIndia\nIN\nItaly\nIT\nJapan\nJP\nMalaysia\nMY\nNetherlands\nNL\nNordic\nSE\nPoland\nPL\nSingapore\nSG\nSouth Africa\nZA\nSpain\nES\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nTech\nEnterprise\nScience\nadvertising\nMedia\nTransportation\nFinance\nMarkets\nRetail\nYour Money\nMarkets Insider\nPolitics\nMilitary & Defense\nNews\nStrategy\nCareers\nLife\nEntertainment\nTravel\nSports\nAll\nCoupons\nTarget\nWalmart\nEBay\nNike\nContainer Store\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nEdition\nUS\nINTL\nDE\nAUS\nFR\nIN\nIT\nJP\nMY\nNL\nSE\nPL\nSG\nZA\nES\nFollow us on:\n* Copyright \xc2\xa9 2019 Insider Inc. All rights reserved. Registration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our\nTerms of Service\n,\nPrivacy Policy\nand\nCookies Policy\n.\nSitemap\nDisclaimer\nCommerce Policy\nCoupons\nMade in NYC\nStock quotes by\nfinanzen.net\nInside the plan to cover New York City\'s streets with free, blazing fast Wi-Fi\nAlex Heath\nMar. 1, 2016, 9:28 AM\nAppleton/Mayoral Photography Office\nOn February 18, a throng reporters and cameramen gathered at the northwest corner of 16th Street and 3rd Avenue in Manhattan to watch New York City mayor Bill de Blasio make a phone call.\nLeaning toward a sleek, metallic tower that looked more at home in "The Jetsons" than the streets of New York, de Blasio dialed "311" to showcase the free phone calling capability of LinkNYC, a network of free WiFi hubs that will eventually blanket the entire city.\n"LinkNYC will be the WiFi network New York City deserves," de Blasio said during a short press conference after the demonstration. "It will be the biggest and fastest network in the world and completely free of charge."\nOver a dozen of these hubs, or "Links," are already operational on street corners in Manhattan. There will be 510 Links installed in all five of New York City\'s main boroughs by July. And eventually there will be over 7,500 Links accessible to the 8.5 million citizens of the city that never sleeps.\n"In 2016 internet access is not a luxury," de Blasio said. "It\'s not something optional. It\'s something everybody needs."\nLinkNYC isn\'t the first project to bring free public WiFi to an entire city \xe2\x80\x94 cities around the world like Taipei and Helsinki already offer free public WiFi that\'s faster than the internet service many Americans pay for at home. But LinkNYC is the only public WiFi network of its scale that\'s promising gigabit internet speeds, the fastest kind of connection that\'s commercially available.\nGigabit is so fast \xe2\x80\x94 you can download an HD movie in 7 seconds \xe2\x80\x94 that the latest iPhone isn\'t even capable of accessing half of its available speed. "For the first time in the history of the internet, your device is the bottleneck," Jen Hensley, the general manager of LinkNYC, told Tech Insider.\nHuge advertising opportunities balanced with privacy concerns\nCityBridge\nLinkNYC is set up to be completely funded by advertising and will cost nothing to the user or taxpayers. Hensley, who is employed by Intersection, the parent company of LinkNYC, stressed that the goal of the network is to offer a "pure internet experience," which means ads won\'t actually be shown on your device.\nInstead, ads will be displayed on the two 55-inch screens on the sides of each Link. Hensley described the advertising model as "definitely a first of its kind." Over the life of its 12-year contract \xe2\x80\x94 which promises 4,500 Link installations in four years and eventually more than 7,000 Links total \xe2\x80\x94 LinkNYC expects to eventually generate over $500 million in revenue through ad partnerships and sponsorships. That\'s quite a bit more than the $40 million a year existing phone booth ads generate. LinkNYC\'s own network deployment costs are expected to cost $200 million.\nThe appeal for businesses, especially local merchants that wish to advertise a sale or happy hour down the block, is obvious. "We think it will work," Hensley said. "We think the scale of digital advertising in New York, one of the world\'s biggest media markets, is extremely compelling."\nLinkNYC\'s network will help advertisers tap into foot traffic around specific neighborhoods. Hensley stressed that even though certain data is collected on an aggregate level, LinkNYC isn\'t snooping on all of the web traffic that goes through its network \xe2\x80\x94 for now.\n"We have access to some, not all of that data," she said. "We\'re not monitoring what websites people go to right now. That\'s not currently part of the strategy. But we will gain insights into how people use the network and how people move through the city. And we think that\'s where there\'s a lot of value."\nCityBridge\nWhen pressed about exactly the kind of user data LinkNYC accesses, Miles Green, the director of infrastructure engineering at Intersection, said anonymous information will be gathered from devices that connect to the network to help inform advertisers.\n"We will use anonymous, aggregated information from device IDs about area demographics to build profiles of specific locations that\'s valuable to advertisers," Green said. "We could understand if an area skews male or female, and we\'ll know, for example, if the Nets are playing or there\'s a Justin Bieber concert happening at the Barclay\'s Center. We will never sell personal information or share with third- parties for their own use."\nBeyond advertisers, the data that will funnel through LinkNYC\'s network will be a gold mine for any company or hacker looking to get their hands on someone\'s personal information.\nThat\'s why LinkNYC has a separate WiFi network it\'s offering that\'s encrypted. Anyone can join the main public network, but that runs the risk of having any non-encrypted web traffic (anything without the little padlock icon next to the URL in your web browser) exposed to others. "This is the risk of an open network anywhere," Green said. Each Link tower will have a dedicated button for dialing 911, a headphone jack, keypad for making free phone calls, and USB ports for charging.\nCityBridge\nOnly iPhones and iPads can get on LinkNYC\'s private, encrypted network for now due to Android\'s lack of support for technology called Hotspot 2.0, which the network uses to authenticate with devices. Besides the added safety, another benefit of the encrypted network is that once you\'ve joined at one Link, your Apple device will automatically connect whenever it gets near any Link in the city.\nLinkNYC is able to facilitate this digital handshake by installing its own certificate on iPhones, which the user has to manually approve with his or her passcode. The certificate installation process used by LinkNYC may be convenient, but such certificates are capable of infecting Apple devices with malware, according to Will Strafach, an experienced iPhone hacker and CEO of mobile security firm Sudo Security. "It\'s not good for run of the mill users," he said. "You don\'t want them getting used to installing certificates. They should view any certificate that\'s trying to be installed as potentially sketchy."\nGreen, Intersection\'s director of infrastructure engineering, said that the certificate used by LinkNYC is safe and only intended to encrypt web traffic. "You do want to think twice when you\'re installing something on your machine, but we\'ve done everything we can to ensure that we\'re doing it in the way that the internet secures itself," he said. "It\'s the same kind of process that you use when you visit a website to validate the authenticity of something." He also acknowledged that the need for a certificate to access the encrypted network will not be required as soon as it\'s technically possible to remove.\nThe smart city of the future LinkNYC\'s WiFi hubs will eventually be working in all 5 of New York City\'s boroughs.\nSidewalk Labs\n34 million Americans, or 10% of the U.S. population, still don\'t have basic broadband access,\naccording to the FCC.\nA 2014 study by the city of New York found that nearly 30% of citizens lacked internet connectivity faster than dial-up.\nAnd LinkNYC won\'t replace broadband at home for most people. Each Link tower only has a signal radius of 150 feet, which means that the network is strictly intended for public use. But given how ridiculously fast and easy to use the network is, Links could become sought after pockets of WiFi that save people from cellular data plan caps and signal drop-outs.\nWhen you begin to look at all of the players involved, making it easier for people to get online is only a piece of what LinkNYC is about. Mapping web traffic patterns and the ebb and flow of devices as they move through the city could inform everything from smart cars to law enforcement. "I really think it\'s about order of magnitude change in what citizens can expect from the streets of their city," Intersection\'s Hensley said.\nAll roads lead back to Google\nCityBridge\nThe roots of LinkNYC can be traced all the way back to Alphabet, the multi-billion-dollar tech conglomerate that owns Google.\nIn May 2014, the de Blasio Administration announced a competition for proposals on how to replace New York\'s thousands of old payphones with state-of-the-art WiFi hubs. Six months later, it announced that the winner of the multi-year-long contract was LinkNYC.\nAt the time, the two main companies behind LinkNYC were Control Group, a tech and advertising consulting firm, and Titan, the outdoor advertising giant responsible for all of the ads on the city\'s existing payphones.\nSkye Gould / Tech Insider\nIt wasn\'t until September 2015 that Sidewalk Labs, an urban development startup created by Google (before it was called in Alphabet), came into the picture. Under the leadership of Dan Doctoroff, who previously served as president of Bloomberg LP and was New York City\'s deputy mayor of economic development, Sidewalk Labs led the merger of Control Group and Titan to become a single entity called Intersection.\nTo add another layer of corporate complexity to the mix, Intersection partnered with CIVIQ Smartspaces, Qualcomm, and Antenna to create a consortium called CityBridge, a group directly responsible for everything from designing the Link towers to maintaining its robust network.\nWithin CityBridge, Intersection is responsible for the day-to-day management and deployment of LinkNYC\'s aggressive rollout.\nSidewalk Labs provides financial support \xe2\x80\x94 it remains a minority investor \xe2\x80\x94 as well as guidance from Doctoroff, who also serves as chairman of Intersection. And most importantly, the startup\'s staff can provide expertise in navigating the government bureaucracy and stringent regulations LinkNYC has managed to fly through in less than a year.\nSidewalk Labs is developing what Doctoroff calls the "completely connected streets" platform, "which would collect ground data from streets and sidewalks to inform decisions about things like parking, lane-changing, and traffic-enforcement,"\naccording to Business Insider.\nOutside of LinkNYC, Sidewalk is currently working with 10 cities on the U.S. Department of Transportation\'s "Smart City Challenge," which plans to fund "bold, data-driven ideas to improve lives by making transportation safer, easier, and more reliable." Links are equipped with Bluetooth beacon technology that can track phones and other devices as they move through the city (it\'s an opt-in process), which could eventually make Sidewalk\'s other initiatives smarter.\nAlphabet\'s connection to LinkNYC may be distant on paper, but its involvement is obvious in the end product millions of residents and tourists will come into contact with on the streets of New York. Besides a USB charging port and phone number dialing pad powered by Vonage, each Link has its own Android tablet with free access to Google Maps and Google search.\nNOW WATCH: Here are all of Google\'s awesome science projects \xe2\x80\x94 that we know about\nMore:\nLinkNYC\nSidewalk Labs\nDan Doctoroff\nInteresection\nTI Graphics\nPopular\nThe best smartphone maker you\'ve never heard of is announcing a new smartphone in May that\'s expected to have a more advanced display than the iPhone or Galaxy S10\nPopular\nChina shows off its new destroyer during massive display of naval power\nPopular\nI drove a $45,000 Ford Ranger pickup truck to see if it\'s ready to take on the Chevy Colorado and Toyota Tacoma \xe2\x80\x94 here\'s the verdict\nPopular\nTim Cook said Apple\'s fight with the FBI in 2016 was a \'very rigged case,\' and he wishes it went to court\nPopular\nI have 26 credit cards and excellent credit. Here\'s the best advice I can give you on keeping up your score, no matter how many cards you have.\nFollow us on:\nAlso check out:\n* Copyright \xc2\xa9 2019 Insider Inc. All rights reserved.
