aS'De Blasio confirms Fulton Houses plan \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Fort Cuomo expands \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Cuomo pens 35-question op-ed - POLITICO\nSkip to Main Content\nPOLITICO\nMagazine\nThe Agenda\nPro\nSearch\nSearch\nSECTIONS\nThe Agenda\nMagazine\nCongress\nWhite House\nElection 2020\nElection Results 2018\nVideo\nPodcasts\nNEWSLETTERS\nPlaybook\nPlaybook PM\nHuddle\nAll Newsletters\nSERIES\nThe Deciders\nThe Agenda: The Future of Prosperity\nWhat Works Next\nWomen Rule\nPOLITICO LIVE\nLive Home\nUpcoming Events\nPrevious Events\nAbout POLITICO Live\nCOLUMNS & CARTOONS\nJosh Gerstein\nRich Lowry\nJack Shafer\nMatt Wuerker\nCartoon Carousel\nPOLICY\nAgriculture\nCybersecurity\nDefense\nEducation\neHealth\nEmployment & Immigration\nEnergy & Environment\nFinance & Tax\nHealth Care\nSpace\nTechnology\nTrade\nTransportation\nEDITIONS\nCalifornia\nCanada\nChina\nEurope\nFlorida\nNew Jersey\nNew York\nPro\nFollow us\nTwitter\nInstagram\nFacebook\nMy Account\nLog InLog Out\nPolitico\nNew York Playbook\nLaura Nahmias\' and Nick Niedzwiadek\'s must-read briefing informing the daily conversation among knowledgeable New Yorkers\nGet the New York Playbook Newsletter\nEmail\nSign Up\nBy signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nPrint\nDe Blasio confirms Fulton Houses plan \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Fort Cuomo expands \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0Cuomo pens 35-question op-ed\nBy\nLAURA NAHMIAS,\nNICK NIEDZWIADEK and\nDANIEL LIPPMAN\n04/23/2019 07:20 AM EDT\nMayor Bill de Blasio started off his day Monday with an appearance on MSNBC\xe2\x80\x99s Morning Joe to rally Democrats around the idea of picking a progressive who could unseat Republican President Donald Trump in 2020. But he spent the rest of the day emulating Trump\xe2\x80\x99s playbook, attacking a scoop from our Sally Goldenberg about his plans to tear down two of NYCHA\xe2\x80\x99s 11 Fulton Houses in Chelsea and build new mixed-income housing as "rumors and misinformation," before he was ultimately forced to admit by day\'s end that every detail was accurate. Under the city\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, residents would be moved to two new buildings on an adjacent parking lot before the demolition of the towers took place, and would relocate to the new mixed-income building after its construction.\nIn the long and tortured history of public housing, one constant is a fear of poor people somehow being evicted from their homes. As The Root\xe2\x80\x99s Dara Sharif wrote yesterday, \xe2\x80\x9cAsk any native New Yorkers, especially black and brown New Yorkers, and \xe2\x80\x98word on the street\xe2\x80\x99 has long been the notion that with gentrification would come the demolition of public housing, long the place many poorer black and brown New Yorkers have called home.\xe2\x80\x9d Story Continued Below\nSome Fulton Houses residents don\xe2\x80\x99t believe the mayor when he tries to reassure them they\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to stay.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe they\xe2\x80\x99re going to make those high risers and just forget about us,\xe2\x80\x9d one resident told NY1. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of the tenants in my building are not leaving. At least not without a fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWhen he first took office back in 2014, de Blasio promised that any development on NYCHA land would take place with the input of public housing residents.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only way we\xe2\x80\x99re going to consider development is with the tenants,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said then. \xe2\x80\x9cIf there is a way we can find a responsible platform with tenants that is transparent, when there\xe2\x80\x99s real guarantees what the benefits will be to the tenants in the immediate area, that\xe2\x80\x99s a very worthy proposal to discuss.\xe2\x80\x9d\nHe\xe2\x80\x99s since embraced the idea he once criticized, put forward by Mayor Michael Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s administration, to allow market rate development on NYCHA land, and argued the problem with Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s idea wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the developments themselves, but the way the former mayor failed to adequately discuss his administration\xe2\x80\x99s plans with public housing tenants.\nA major problem with Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s plan, de Blasio said last year, was \xe2\x80\x9cthere were a number of things missing when it came to talking about development on a NYCHA land site and things that really caused people real concern, legitimate frustration.\xe2\x80\x9d\nNow the mayor is facing the daunting task of getting buy-in from residents terrified of having their homes taken away. Can he convince Fulton Houses residents and city elected officials that his idea is a great one? Or will he retreat at the first signs of opposition?\nIT\xe2\x80\x99S TUESDAY. Got tips, suggestions or thoughts? Let us know ... By email: LNahmias@politico.com, NNiedzwiadek@politico.com and Daniel@politico.com, or on Twitter: @nahmias, @NickNiedz, and @dlippman.\nWHERE\xe2\x80\x99S ANDREW? In Albany, where he\xe2\x80\x99s scheduled to appear on CNN\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNew Day" at 7:30 a.m. and WAMC at 10 a.m.\nWHERE\xe2\x80\x99S BILL? In New York City with no public schedule.\nFRONT PAGES\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s Tabloids: \xe2\x80\x94 New York Post: "STONE AGE" \xe2\x80\x94 Daily News: "NOT ON MY WATCH" \xe2\x80\x94 Newsday: "FIGHT OVER NASSAU ASSESSOR\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 El Diario New York: "They have the right to health \xe2\x80\x94 See them\nToday\'s Broadsheets: \xe2\x80\x94 New York Times: \xe2\x80\x94 3 col., above the fold: "Justices to Weigh Wider View of Sex Bias Law" \xe2\x80\x94 1 col., below the fold: "Pelosi Cautions Restive Caucus On Impeaching" \xe2\x80\x94 Wall Street Journal: \xe2\x80\x94 1 col., above the fold: "Cain Drops His Bid For Fed" \xe2\x80\x94 3 col., below the fold: "Oil Prices Surge as Trump Ends Waivers for Iran\xe2\x80\x99s Crude" \xe2\x80\x94 See them\nWHAT CITY HALL IS READING\n\xe2\x80\x9cCOSMETICS TYCOON RON LAUDER IS BANKROLLING A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR EFFORT to stop Mayor Bill de Blasio from eliminating the admissions test to the city\xe2\x80\x99s top high schools, sources told The Post on Monday. The billionaire Clinique chairman \xe2\x80\x94 a 1961 graduate of the Bronx High School of Science \xe2\x80\x94 is prepared to spend at least \'seven figures\' of his personal fortune on TV commercials and other efforts to block de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s controversial proposal, sources said.\nThe campaign will target Albany lawmakers, whom the mayor needs to amend a 1971 state law that created the Specialized High School Admission Test \xe2\x80\x94 and may even include attack ads against de Blasio, one source said. ... The group\xe2\x80\x99s efforts are being spearheaded by political strategist Bradley Tusk, who in 2015 helped Uber defeat de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s plan to limit the company\xe2\x80\x99s expansion. Tusk fired the first shot Monday morning with a press release announcing that Kirsten John Foy, a former regional director for Al Sharpton\xe2\x80\x99s National Action Network, was among the founding members of the Education Equity Campaign.\xe2\x80\x9d New York Post\xe2\x80\x99s Carl Campanile and Bruce Golding\n\xe2\x80\x94via @MadinaToure: Tusk Strategies is managing the overall effort and is getting $7,500 a month. Education Equity has $125,000 in contracts w/three lobbying firms \xe2\x80\x94 Bolton-St. Johns, Patrick B. Jenkins & Associates and Blue Suit Strategies \xe2\x80\x94 to support its plan.\n\xe2\x80\x9cA PROMINENT TOXICOLOGIST who lost her job after calling for more transparency about a controversial form of DNA testing won a $1 million settlement from the city on Monday. Marina Stajic said she was fired on April 9, 2015, because she voted in favor of publicly releasing an internal Office of Chief Medical Examiner study on \xe2\x80\x98low copy number\xe2\x80\x99 DNA testing, which analyzes small amounts of genetic material. Critics have said the form of DNA testing \xe2\x80\x94 which the city has since abandoned \xe2\x80\x94 may have led to wrongful convictions.\xe2\x80\x9d Daily News\xe2\x80\x99s Stephen Rex Brown\n\xe2\x80\x9cPROSECUTORS ACROSS THE CITY ARE USING SECRET SPREADSHEETS to identify cops who could have trouble on the witness stand because they\xe2\x80\x99ve been sued, arrested, accused of misconduct or testified suspiciously in the past \xe2\x80\xa6 District attorneys offices in Manhattan, Brooklyn and The Bronx have maintained internal databases for several years, while the Queens DA\xe2\x80\x99s Office created one last year and the Staten Island DA\xe2\x80\x99s Office is developing one, sources said. The issue is currently the subject of a court battle being waged by a former Manhattan prosector-turned-defense lawyer who\xe2\x80\x99s suing to get a copy of the list maintained by Manhattan DA Cyrus Vance Jr.\xe2\x80\x9d New York Post\xe2\x80\x99s Craig McCarthy and Bruce Golding\n\xe2\x80\x94 City Council Member Donovan Richards wants DAs to crack down on law enforcement officials who lie in public documents or on the stand.\nWHAT ALBANY\'S READING\nTHE FOUR 23-STORY AGENCY BUILDING TOWERS THAT DOMINATE ALBANY\xe2\x80\x99S SKYLINE WILL SOON BE CLOSED TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. Entry gates have appeared on the Concourse and Empire State Plaza entrances to each of the buildings in recent weeks, as well as signs encouraging employees to make sure their ID cards are correctly programmed to open the gates. Office of General Services spokesperson Heather Groll said the work on these upgrades \xe2\x80\x9cwill be completed in the next week or so.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cEmployees will scan their ID cards to get in and visitors will need to show identification and sign in at the front desk before going to appointments in the building,\xe2\x80\x9d Groll said. \xe2\x80\x9cThis system does not require going through a magnetometer or pockets being emptied.\xe2\x80\x9d The changes are being made as \xe2\x80\x9cpart of ongoing building access upgrades at State office buildings,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. POLITICO\xe2\x80\x99s Bill Mahoney\nTOP-ED: \xe2\x80\x9cAndrew Cuomo: 35 questions about our current political climate\xe2\x80\x9d ... \xe2\x80\x9c35. Is it time that all Americans look ourselves in the mirror and ask if each of us is doing all we can to make a positive difference in our future? Only when we say \xe2\x80\x98yes\xe2\x80\x99 to the last question will we be able to answer the first: Which came first, President Trump or the degradation of our political system: Which is the cause and which is the effect?\xe2\x80\x9d Cuomo in The Washington Post\n\xe2\x80\x9cTHE STATE TRANSPORTATION DEPARTMENT HAS NAMED \xe2\x80\x98THE COMMUNITY GRID\xe2\x80\x99 ITS PREFERRED CHOICE FOR INTERSTATE 81, according to a document the state posted online. \xe2\x80\x98Based on a balanced consideration of the need for safe and efficient transportation; the social, economic, and environmental effects of the project alternatives; and national, state, and local environmental protection goals, the Community Grid Alternative would be selected as the preferred alternative,\xe2\x80\x99 according to the document. The document is part of a draft environmental impact statement, which is thousands of pages long, and evaluates alternatives for the 1.4-mile section of highway.\xe2\x80\x9d Syracuse Post-Standard\xe2\x80\x99s Patrick Lohmann\n\xe2\x80\x9cNASSAU COUNTY LAWMAKERS ON MONDAY UNANIMOUSLY VOTED TO OPT OUT IF ALBANY PASSES A LAW LEGALIZING THE SALE OF RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA IN NEW YORK. The full Legislature voted against the sale of adult-use marijuana within county lines.\xe2\x80\x9d News 12 Long Island\n#UpstateAmerica: Amherst police reunited a pig with its owners after it escaped.\n... 2020 VISION ...\nTHE DELEGATION: \xe2\x80\x9cTHE 2018 GENERAL ELECTION WAS ONLY SIX MONTHS AGO. But now multiple former candidates are launching or considering second bids for office. \xe2\x80\x98I think in the last election, we did everything in our power to fight him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Nate McMurray, the Democrat who unsuccessfully challenged Republican Chris Collins last year. \xe2\x80\x98He fought dirty against us. He did everything he could to undermine who I am. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be perfectly frank, I want another chance to fight against him...\xe2\x80\x99 Collins is still under indictment for insider trading, but continues to represent a deeply Republican House district (NY-27) in western New York\xe2\x80\xa6\nMcMurray could soon join an increasingly long list of former candidates already launching second campaigns this year. Democrat Tedra Cobb announced she plans to once again challenge Republican Elise Stefanik in the North Country (NY-21). Democrat Tracy Mitrano wants to again face off against Republican Tom Reed in the Southern Tier (NY-23). Republican former U.S. Senate candidate Chele Farley has started to raise money to challenge Democrat Sean Patrick Maloney in the Hudson Valley (NY-18). Democrat Perry Gershon is considering another challenge to Rep. Lee Zeldin (NY-1).\nRepublican former Rep. Michael Grimm, who failed in a primary bid last year to retake his Staten Island House seat, is eyeing another run against incumbent Democrat Max Rose (NY-11). But he may face Republican Assemblywoman Nicole Malliotakis, who ran for New York City mayor against Bill de Blasio in 2015. Just last week, in central New York, Dana Balter launched her second bid to oust Republican John Katko for a Syracuse-area House seat (NY-24).\xe2\x80\x9d Spectrum News\xe2\x80\x99s Nick Reisman\nSOCIAL DATA\nHAPPY BIRTHDAY: John Oliver is 42 ... State Senator Michael Gianaris is 49 ... Alexis Hurley is 43 (h/t David A. Andelman) ... Alexis Kleinman, editor at NYT\xe2\x80\x99s T Brand Studio ... Kindred Motes is 29 ... Aerin Lauder is 49 ... MSNBC\xe2\x80\x99s Alex Lupica ... Alex Swieca ... WNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Beth Fertig ... Paula Dwyer, senior editor at Bloomberg News ... Andrew Brent \xe2\x80\xa6 Lisa Wager, director of government and community relations at Fashion Institute of Technology\nWELCOME TO THE WORLD \xe2\x80\x93 Tom Crosson, director of comms at SunTrust, and Hope Crosson, assistant director of MBA admissions at Emory, on Friday welcomed Talbott Rogers Crosson, who came in at 7lbs. 10oz, and 20 inches. Pic\nAROUND NEW YORK\n\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWegmans plans to eliminate single-use plastic grocery bags in New York by year\'s end \xe2\x80\x94 just before a state ban takes effect. The Rochester-based grocery chain announced the move on Monday along with steps to reduce the usage of bags, straws and other plastic items at its stores in other states. New York will join California and Hawaii when its ban on plastic grocery bags takes effect in March.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cHealth officials have issued a warning about potential measles exposure at a restaurant in New Jersey.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x94 A vandal smashed at least 30 LinkNYC kiosk screens throughout Chelsea and the West Village.\n\xe2\x80\x94 De Blasio promised to end the city\xe2\x80\x99s wireless contract with Northrop Grumman following recent problems.\n\xe2\x80\x94 GlobalFoundries is selling the former IBM semiconductor plant in Dutchess County that it acquired four years ago as it focuses on leveraging its three major manufacturing plants, including its sprawling operation in Malta.\nREAL ESTATE\nNO MORE SKYSCRAPERS? \xe2\x80\x9cTHE MAYOR CELEBRATED EARTH DAY BY ANNOUNCING A PROPOSAL THAT HE CLAIMS WOULD BAR CONSTRUCTION of many of the glass-and-steel towers that have joined the city skyline in recent years. The plan, which requires legislation in the City Council, is part of what he termed his own Green New Deal. \xe2\x80\x98Buildings got built that should never have been built to begin with, if we were thinking about the needs of our Earth,\xe2\x80\x99 the mayor said. \xe2\x80\x98So we are going to introduce legislation to ban the glass-and-steel skyscrapers that have contributed so much to global warming. They have no place in our city or on our Earth anymore.\xe2\x80\x99\nThe mayor described it as a ban, though he and his aides acknowledged that developers still would have ways to use lots of glass. They could, for instance, employ heat-retaining panes or compensate by reducing their carbon footprint in other ways. The aides cited as examples of proper \xe2\x80\x98modern\xe2\x80\x99 use of glass walls the East Side\xe2\x80\x99s American Copper Building apartments and the Cornell Tech campus on Roosevelt Island.\xe2\x80\x9d Crain\xe2\x80\x99s Will Bredderman\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98AFFORDABLE HOUSING\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x93 for upwards of $3,000 a month \xe2\x80\x93 could be coming to Staten Island\xe2\x80\x99s Bay Street under a rezoning proposal up for a City Planning Commission vote Monday. If the plan ultimately makes it through the City Council, the high-end apartments would count toward Mayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s goal of creating 300,000 new affordable flats amid a citywide housing crunch. That would mark a first for a neighborhood rezoning spearheaded by City Hall. Staten Island Borough President Jimmy Oddo pushed for allowing developers to opt to build apartments for households earning as much as $127,000 a year for a family of three.\xe2\x80\x9d The City\xe2\x80\x99s Clifford Michel\nTHE HOME TEAMS, BY HOWARD MEGDAL\nMets 5, Phillies 1: A stellar six innings from Steven Matz, and Jeff McNeil provided his first home run of the season.\nThe day ahead: The Nets face a do-or-die in Philly, down 3-1 in a best-of-7. The Mets host the Phillies. The Yankees are in Los Angeles of Anaheim.\nFollow us on Twitter\nLaura Nahmias @Nahmias\nNick Niedzwiadek @NickNiedz\nDaniel Lippman @dlippman\nSubscribe to the POLITICO Playbook family\nPlaybook\nPlaybook PM\nCalifornia Playbook\nFlorida Playbook\nIllinois Playbook\nMassachusetts Playbook\nNew Jersey Playbook\nNew York Playbook\nBrussels Playbook\nLondon Playbook\nView all our political and policy newsletters\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xab View Archives\nAbout The Author : Laura Nahmias\nLaura Nahmias is a reporter for POLITICO New York, covering City Hall and Mayor Bill de Blasio. Before she began covering City Hall, she wrote about Albany politics for POLITICO New York. She has also written for City and State, The Wall Street Journal and the New York Post.A native of Memphis, Tennessee, Laura earned her undergraduate degree from Wesleyan University in Connecticut, before earning a Masters Degree in Journalism at Columbia University.\nAbout The Author : Nick Niedzwiadek\nNick Niedzwiadek is a reporter for POLITICO New York. He is a graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and has previously written for the Times Union and the Wall Street Journal.\nAbout The Author : Daniel Lippman\nDaniel Lippman is a reporter for POLITICO and a co-author of POLITICO\'s Playbook, the most indispensable morning newsletter for the biggest influencers in politics.Before joining POLITICO, he was a fellow covering environmental news for E&E Publishing and a reporter for The Wall Street Journal in New York. He has also interned for McClatchy Newspapers and Reuters. During a stint freelancing in 2013, he traveled to the Turkish-Syrian border to cover the impact of the Syrian civil war for The Huffington Post and CNN.com.He graduated from The Hotchkiss School in 2008 and from The George Washington University in 2012. Daniel hails from the Berkshires in western Massachusetts and enjoys playing tennis, seeing movies and trying out new restaurants in his free time.SUBSCRIBE to Politico Playbook: http://politi.co/2lQswbh\nTrump unleashes on the media in morning tweetstorm\nFurious Trump orders officials to boycott correspondents\' dinner\nWhat you missed in the Mueller report\nTrump Isn\xe2\x80\x99t Just Reversing Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Foreign Policies. He\xe2\x80\x99s Making it Impossible for His Successor to Go Back to Them.\nThe rude awakening creeping up on Kamala Harris\nNew York Playbook - POLITICO Archive\nTue Apr 23 07:20:49 EDT 2019,\nTue Apr 23 07:20:49 EDT 2019\nMon Apr 22 09:19:39 EDT 2019,\nMon Apr 22 09:19:39 EDT 2019\nMon Apr 22 07:20:57 EDT 2019,\nMon Apr 22 07:20:57 EDT 2019\nFri Apr 19 07:20:42 EDT 2019,\nFri Apr 19 07:20:42 EDT 2019\nThu Apr 18 07:20:43 EDT 2019,\nThu Apr 18 07:20:43 EDT 2019\nView the Full New York Playbook Archives \xc2\xbb\nPolitico Magazine\nJoe Biden\xe2\x80\x99s Toughest 2020 Opponent Is Joe Biden\nBy Jeff Greenfield\nTrump Isn\xe2\x80\x99t Just Reversing Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Foreign Policies. He\xe2\x80\x99s Making it Impossible for His Successor to Go Back to Them.\nBy Aaron David Miller and Richard Sokolsky\nIf You\xe2\x80\x99re Reading This, You\xe2\x80\x99re Probably Running for President\nBy Jack Shafer\nReagan\xe2\x80\x99s Supply-Side Warriors Blaze a Comeback Under Trump\nBy Ben Schreckinger\nAbout Us\nAdvertising\nBreaking News Alerts\nCareers\nCredit Card Payments\nDigital Edition\nFAQ\nFeedback\nHeadlines\nPhotos\nPOWERJobs\nPress\nPrint Subscriptions\nRSS\nSite Map\nTerms of Service\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 POLITICO LLC'
p43
aS'LinkNYC\'s free gigabit WiFi is here, and it is glorious\nEngadget\nLogin\nHome\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer\'s Guide\nVideo\nReviews\nLog in\nSign up\nShow More Results\nEngadget\n3 related articles\nLogin\nTwitter CEO Jack Dorsey met with Donald Trump today\nDC\'s full comics catalog is available through DC Universe\nReturn your Amazon orders to any Kohl\'s store starting in July\nLatest in Gear\nThese gaming laptops pack the latest Intel and NVIDIA hardware\n1h ago\nView\nApple offers next-day repairs for faulty MacBook keyboards\n2h ago\nView\nAcer updates select laptops with the latest from Intel and NVIDIA\n3h ago\nView\nReturn your Amazon orders to any Kohl\'s store starting in July\n4h ago\nView\nImage credit:\nsave\nSave\nshare\nLinkNYC\'s free gigabit WiFi is here, and it is glorious\nIt\'s so fast it\'ll make you hate your ISP.\nDevindra Hardawar, @devindra\n01.19.16\nin Internet\nComments\n17\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nI\'m standing on the corner of 15th Street and Third Avenue in New York City, and I\'m freezing. But my iPhone is on fire. After connecting to one of LinkNYC\'s gigabit wireless hotspots, the futuristic payphone replacements that went live for beta testing this morning, I\'m seeing download speeds of 280 Mbps and upload speeds of 317 Mbps (based on Speedtest\'s benchmark). To put it in perspective, that\'s around ten times the speed of the average American home internet connection (which now sits at 31 Mbps). And to top it all off, LinkNYC doesn\'t cost you a thing.\nGallery: Hands-on with LinkNYC | 9 Photos\n9\n+5\nOf course, my experience was a charmed one. The LinkNYC hotspot (or Link, for short) I tested went live just a few hours before I arrived, and there were only a handful of other people on it. I was also standing right in front of it -- speeds will vary depending on your distance, as well as the type of device you\'re using. Still, seeing Speedtest\'s bandwidth meter rocket to 300 Mbps was astonishing. It felt like I was staring at the future of urban internet access in my cold, gloved hand.LinkNYC is the culmination of New York City\'s big push to modernize payphones. Its tall and thin kiosks feature gigabit fiber connections (yes, most are plugged right into fiber lines) delivered via 802.11ac WiFi, USB charging, free voice calls, and a tablet for internet access, maps and directions. They also sport two large screens which display ads (the only way LinkNYC is making money, at the moment), as well as public service announcements. Wireless range clocks in at 150 feet, though as always, that may be affected by obstacles, windows and walls. Each kiosk also offers a private, fully encrypted network accessible by devices that support Hotspot 2.0 (at this point, LinkNYC only supports Apple gear).Signing onto a Link for the first time was surprisingly easy, as far as WiFi onboarding goes. After joining the "LinkNYC Free Wi-Fi" network, you just need to plug in your email address into a landing page to get connected. If you\'ve got a Hotspot 2.0 device, you\'ll automatically get a prompt to install a security key for the the private LinkNYC network. I had no trouble connecting to the kiosk with my MacBook Air while sitting in the Starbucks right in front of it.The process was a bit more complex for my iPhone, since I wanted to test out LinkNYC\'s encrypted offering. After receiving the prompt to install the additional security key, I had to manually approve it and restart my WiFi before my phone phone would hop onto the private network. Unfortunately, while I wanted to test out LinkNYC\'s estimated range this morning, my iPhone ended up dying before I could (likely because I had it exposed to the extreme cold for a while).On my MacBook Air, I saw speeds of around 70 Mbps up and down while sitting just a few feet from the Link. That speed was likely being limited by my laptop\'s connection to AOL\'s VPN, which can\'t be disabled easily. Being indoors definitely slowed things down a bit as well, but that\'s still insane speed for free WiFi. It\'s likely a great deal faster than your home internet connection, unless you\'re paying for an expensive 100 Mbps plan.Even with slower speeds at greater distances, I wouldn\'t be surprised if some New Yorkers end up dumping their home ISP and using Links full-time instead. LinkNYC representatives say they won\'t stop anyone from doing that, though they might have to throttle data hogs who end up ruining the experience for others. Links could also end up being a major gateway to the internet for millions of New Yorkers who can\'t afford service at home.When it comes to security, LinkNYC won\'t be able to detect anything you\'re doing on its private network. On its public network, though, it\'ll be able to track your MAC address. (Update: Representatives tell me LinkNYC won\'t track any web traffic on its public or private network.) The full privacy policy, published by NYC\'s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DOITT), notes that Citybridge (the consortium behind LinkNYC) might share anonymized data with third-parties, but not anything personally identifiable.While there are only a handful of kiosks installed at the moment, LinkNYC plans to have 500 up and running by July. They\'ll remain in beta testing until around 200 units are deployed, according to representatives, and by 2020 the group plans to have at least 4,450 kiosks in the wild. It\'s tough to tell if LinkNYC will reach its long-term goals, but the fact that it was able to develop and deploy its kiosks in about a year is impressive.\nIn this article:\nculture,\ngear,\ngigabitWiFi,\ninternet,\nLinkNYC,\nNYC,\nWiFi\nBy Devindra Hardawar\n@devindra\nDevindra has been obsessed with technology for as long as he can remember -- starting with the first time he ever glimpsed an NES. He spent several years fixing other people\'s computers before he started down the treacherous path of writing about technology. Mission accomplished?\n17\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nComments\nSign In\n16m\n16m ago in\nAV\nWatch the trailer for Ang Lee\'s 120 fps film \'Gemini Man\'\nWill Smith battles... young Will Smith.\nBy\nC. Fisher,\n16m ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n58m\n58m ago in\nInternet\nTwitter CEO Jack Dorsey met with Donald Trump today\nPer a leaked internal email, it\'s about "the health of the public conversation."\nBy\nR. Lawler,\n58m ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nBusiness\nSnapchat\xe2\x80\x99s user base is growing again\nThe company had 190 million active users in Q1, four million more than the quarter before.\nBy\nN. Ingraham,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nPersonal Computing\nThese gaming laptops pack the latest Intel and NVIDIA hardware\nIt\'s a good time to be a gamer on the go.\nBy\nJ. Fingas,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n2h\n2h ago in\nServices\nApple offers next-day repairs for faulty MacBook keyboards\nNo sign yet that the company will actually fix the underlying design flaws.\nBy\nA. Dellinger,\n2h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\nMore Stories\nFrom around the web\nAbout\nAbout Engadget\nAbout Our Ads\nAdvertise\nBrand Kit\nBuyers Guide\nContact Us\nRSS Feed\nSections\nReviews\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer\'s Guide\nVideo\nPodcasts\nDeals\nContribute\nComment Guidelines\nSend us a tip!\nSupport\nInternational\n\xe7\xb9\x81\xe9\xab\x94\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe7\xae\x80\xe4\xbd\x93\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe7\x89\x88\nUK\nApps\nAndroid\niPhone\niPad\nJoin Our Newsletter\nSubscribe\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Verizon Media. All rights reserved.\nLearn More\nReprints and Permissions\nSuggestions\nPrivacy Policy (Updated)\nTerms of Service (Updated)\nTrademarks\nAdvertise\nPage 1Page 1ear iconeye iconFill 23text filevr'

aS'Opinion | We Built an \xe2\x80\x98Unbelievable\xe2\x80\x99 (but Legal) Facial Recognition Machine - The New York Times\nNYTimes.com no longer supports Internet Explorer 9 or earlier. Please upgrade your browser.\nLEARN MORE \xc2\xbb\nSections\nHome\nSearch\nThe New York Times\nOpinion\nSunday Review\n|We Built an \xe2\x80\x98Unbelievable\xe2\x80\x99 (but Legal) Facial Recognition Machine\nClose search\nSite Search Navigation\nSearch NYTimes.com\nClear this text input\nGo\nhttps://nyti.ms/2DgkaQV\nSite Navigation\nSite Mobile Navigation\nWe Built an \xe2\x80\x98Unbelievable\xe2\x80\x99 (but Legal) Facial Recognition Machine\nBy SAHIL CHINOY\nAPRIL 16, 2019\nOn the east side of Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan, three cameras on the roof of a restaurant film the lunch crowds, tourists and commuters \xe2\x80\x94 everything that goes on each day. The feeds are streamed publicly online.\nFootage from one day in March.\n12:30:01 PM\nNext\nWe were able to turn those cameras into a facial recognition-powered tracking system for less than $100 \xe2\x80\x94 using a service available to anyone with an internet connection and a credit card. The process was completely legal.\nWe pixelated the faces shown here, which were captured over one day.\nBack\nNext\nHow easy would it be to figure out who was in the park? We built a database using public photos of people who work in the area and matched this college professor on his way to lunch. All it took was a few days\xe2\x80\x99 work.\n12:51:37 PM\nBack\nNext\nThe cameras are just three among thousands across New York City. And if you\xe2\x80\x99re an adult in America, there\xe2\x80\x99s more than a 50 percent chance that you\xe2\x80\x99re already in a law enforcement facial recognition database, according to researchers at Georgetown.\nSecurity cameras in Lower Manhattan in 2005\n1 camera recorded by the N.Y.C.L.U.\nBack\nNext\nOpinionThe Privacy Project\nWe Built an \xe2\x80\x98Unbelievable\xe2\x80\x99 (but Legal) Facial Recognition Machine\nBy Sahil Chinoy\nMost people pass through some type of public space in their daily routine \xe2\x80\x94 sidewalks, roads, train stations. Thousands walk through Bryant Park every day. But we generally think that a detailed log of our location, and a list of the people we\xe2\x80\x99re with, is private. Facial recognition, applied to the web of cameras that already exists in most cities, is a threat to that privacy.\nTo demonstrate how easy it is to track people without their knowledge, we collected public images of people who worked near Bryant Park (available on their employers\xe2\x80\x99 websites, for the most part) and ran one day of footage through Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s commercial facial recognition service. Our system detected 2,750 faces from a nine-hour period (not necessarily unique people, since a person could be captured in multiple frames). It returned several possible identifications, including one frame matched to a head shot of Richard Madonna, a professor at the SUNY College of Optometry, with an 89 percent similarity score. The total cost: about $60.\nImage fromcaptured video\nImage from SUNY College of Optometry\n89% match\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy first reaction was, \xe2\x80\x98Oh my god, that is unbelievable,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Madonna said, after we reached him and explained the experiment. \xe2\x80\x9cI was shocked at how readily it seems that it picked me up, because, really \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s the side of my head.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn our exercise, we built a database using only photos from public websites, and we obtained Dr. Madonna\xe2\x80\x99s consent before publishing this story. We\xe2\x80\x99ve deleted the images and data that we collected and are no longer monitoring the Bryant Park cameras.\nOur facial recognition system detected Dr. Richard Madonna walking through Bryant Park.\nDamon Winter/The New York Times\nOver decades, businesses and individuals have installed millions of cameras like the ones we used, inadvertently setting up the infrastructure for mass surveillance. In the past, a human would have to watch the video feed to identify people, making it impossible to comprehensively record everyone\xe2\x80\x99s movements. But the accuracy and speed of modern facial recognition technology means that building a dragnet surveillance system is now feasible.\nThe law has not caught up. In the United States, the use of facial recognition is almost wholly unregulated.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe technology has advanced faster than even I thought that it would,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jennifer Lynch, surveillance litigation director at the Electronic Frontier Foundation. She said that because of how quickly the technology has advanced, she would now support a wholesale ban on government use of facial recognition.\nThe cameras in Bryant Park were installed more than a decade ago so that people could see whether the lawn was open for sunbathing, for example, or check how busy the ice skating rink was in the winter. They are not intended to be a security device, according to the corporation that runs the park.\nThe camera, nestled among plants on the roof of a restaurant, films the park grounds and the eastern walkway.\nDamon Winter/The New York Times\nBut our experiment shows that a person equipped with just a few cameras and facial recognition technology can learn people\xe2\x80\x99s daily habits: when they arrive at the office each day, who they get coffee with, whether they left work early. When we identified Dr. Madonna, he was on his way to lunch with a job candidate \xe2\x80\x94 an example of how the midday outings of even law-abiding citizens can sometimes be sensitive information.\nThe police and governments may also have access to a vast network of cameras. Combine that with a comprehensive database of faces \xe2\x80\x94 like a driver\xe2\x80\x99s license database \xe2\x80\x94 and it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to track citizens throughout an entire region in real time. There is no evidence that this is happening on a wide scale in the United States. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not because the technology doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exist. Last year, companies claimed they could compare live feeds to a database of billions of faces.\nAuthorities have used facial recognition to track down criminal suspects and find missing children. But civil liberties advocates warn about the chilling effect on free speech if the government could monitor everyone\xe2\x80\x99s whereabouts \xe2\x80\x94 or, say, identify individuals at a protest. This is not a purely hypothetical concern: During 2016 protests after Freddie Gray died in the custody of Baltimore police, law enforcement used facial recognition on social media images to identify protesters with outstanding warrants.\n"Once the government has the ability to track us and identify us wherever we go, it is impossible to speak and participate in society anonymously," Ms. Lynch said.\nFacial recognition in New York City\nNew York City is nowhere near China, where the government has installed approximately one surveillance camera for every seven citizens. But according to the A.C.L.U., police here have access to more than 9,000 camera feeds in Lower Manhattan alone.\nThe M.T.A. has tried using facial recognition on feeds from license-plate cameras at the city\xe2\x80\x99s entry points to identify drivers through their windshields, although those efforts have been unsuccessful so far, according to The Wall Street Journal. And the Department of Transportation already has hundreds of cameras across New York City used to monitor traffic, feeds that are also streamed publicly online.\nFootage from traffic cameras across New York City.\nN.Y.C. Department of Transportation\nThe traffic cameras are most likely too low-resolution for effective facial recognition. But the city\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC kiosks, which are scattered through the streets and intended to provide free wireless internet, each have two security cameras. Law enforcement agencies need a subpoena or court order to gain access to the footage, and using facial recognition is against the policy of the company that owns the kiosks. However, the existence of more than 3,000 additional cameras has raised concerns about their potential to bolster the city\xe2\x80\x99s surveillance capabilities.\nCameras on\nNew York City Streets\nLinkNYC kiosk\nTraffic camera\nManhattan\nqueens\nBrooklyn\nCameras on\nNew York City Streets\nLinkNYC kiosk\nManhattan\nTraffic camera\nBrooklyn\nSources: OpenStreetMap, N.Y.C. Department of Transportation, N.Y.C. Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications\nDetails are sparse, but there is evidence that those capabilities are formidable. The Police Department claims its Domain Awareness System, developed jointly with Microsoft (which also offers facial recognition software), \xe2\x80\x9cutilizes the largest network of cameras, license plate readers, and radiological sensors in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s unclear whether the Domain Awareness System currently uses facial recognition, though the Police Department experimented with it in 2012, according to Clare Garvie, an associate at the Center on Privacy and Technology at Georgetown Law School. The police have been reluctant to divulge details, and the center has sued the department for more information.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe compare facial images picked up by cameras at crime scenes to mugshots in law enforcement records,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sgt. Jessica McRorie, a spokeswoman for the department, in an emailed statement. \xe2\x80\x9cWe do not engage in mass or random collection of facial records from N.Y.P.D. camera systems, the internet, or social media.\xe2\x80\x9d\nLaw enforcement use of the technology\nAmazon is one of several companies that sell facial recognition services to the public. The company has highlighted positive applications of the service we used, Rekognition, such as its ability to help find lost children. It insists that it requires customers comply with the law and respect others\xe2\x80\x99 rights, but has been criticized for pushing its technology to law enforcement agencies.\nRekognition is already actively used by the sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s office in Washington County, Ore., including to investigate minor crimes like shoplifting. The Orlando, Fla., Police Department is also using the technology in a pilot program.\nAmazon notes that its service makes predictions, not decisions, and that the confidence level the service provides should be incorporated in a human review process. The company recommends using a threshold of at least 99 percent for applications of its facial recognition service that involve identification or public safety, though critics of the technology say that the scoring is opaque and that the company has no way of enforcing that threshold. None of the matches we obtained from the Bryant Park footage, correct or incorrect, met the threshold.\nMatt Wood, the general manager of artificial intelligence for Amazon Web Services, noted that it is possible that Rekognition, like other types of information available to law enforcement officials, could be used inappropriately. \xe2\x80\x9cThe law enforcement agency will have to be accountable to these individuals and to the law if they violate people\xe2\x80\x99s civil liberties,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. He added that the company has not received any reports of misuse by law enforcement.\nIn January, however, the A.C.L.U. sent a letter to Amazon asking it to stop selling facial recognition technology to police and government agencies, saying that the company\xe2\x80\x99s attention to civil liberties has lagged behind that of Google and Microsoft.\n\xe2\x80\x9cRekognition marketing materials read like a user manual for authoritarian surveillance,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicole Ozer, the technology and civil liberties director for the A.C.L.U. of California, in a statement last year.\nRegulate or ban?\nIn the United States, there are no federal laws that restrict the use of facial recognition. Most states don\xe2\x80\x99t have regulations (exceptions include Illinois and Texas), nor does New York City, though a city councilman proposed legislation last year that would require businesses to disclose their use of the technology. That would apply to our exercise, but would not extend to law enforcement\xe2\x80\x99s use of facial recognition.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s kind of like a wild, wild west out there,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Lynch, the E.F.F. lawyer, said.\nThe lack of regulation has opened the door to a wide range of applications. In 2007, an Arizona sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s office enrolled all of Honduras\xe2\x80\x99s driver\xe2\x80\x99s licenses and mugshots into its database, and a Florida sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s office runs 8,000 searches each month without requiring its officers to have reasonable suspicion of a crime, according to the Georgetown report.\nThe Georgetown center along with the E.F.F. and others have proposed regulations, including requiring that authorities have reasonable suspicion before conducting a search; prohibiting, except in life-or-death situations, live facial recognition searches using driver\xe2\x80\x99s license databases; and forbidding tracking individuals based on political beliefs, race or religion.\nAmazon itself has called for a legal framework that incorporates human review and transparency. But some say that the technology is so dangerous that no regulation is sufficient.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe future of human flourishing depends upon facial recognition technology being banned,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Woodrow Hartzog, a professor of law and computer science at Northeastern, and Evan Selinger, a professor of philosophy at the Rochester Institute of Technology, last year. \xe2\x80\x9cOtherwise, people won\xe2\x80\x99t know what it\xe2\x80\x99s like to be in public without being automatically identified, profiled, and potentially exploited.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFacial recognition is categorically different from other forms of surveillance, Mr. Hartzog said, and uniquely dangerous. Faces are hard to hide and can be observed from far away, unlike a fingerprint. Name and face databases of law-abiding citizens, like driver\xe2\x80\x99s license records, already exist. And for the most part, facial recognition surveillance can be set up using cameras already on the streets.\nIt might be too late for a moratorium or ban, however. Facial recognition is already being used by police departments around the country, Ms. Garvie said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t lock law enforcement agencies into 20th-century technology just because 21st-century technology raises very serious risks,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\nDr. Madonna, the person we identified, said he understood that tension. He was initially astonished when we reached out to him, but he said that as a doctor, he often talks to students about the ratio of risk to benefit. He saw the tremendous benefits that facial recognition could offer, he said.\nBut the technology is open to abuse, he added, when individuals or governments can use facial recognition to track any group, or just about any ordinary citizen \xe2\x80\x94 even someone walking through Bryant Park.\nDesigned by Jessia Ma. Video animations by Drew Jordan.\nSahil Chinoy is a graphics editor for The New York Times Opinion Section.\nThe Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We\xe2\x80\x99d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here\xe2\x80\x99s our email: letters@nytimes.com.\nFollow @privacyproject on Twitter and The New York Times Opinion Section on Facebook and Instagram.\nCorrection: April 16, 2019 An earlier version of this article misstated Woodrow Hartzog\xe2\x80\x99s affiliation. He is a professor at Northeastern University, not Northwestern.\nCorrection: April 16, 2019 An earlier version of this article erroneously included a business among companies that sell facial recognition services. Google does not do so.\nThe Privacy Project\nThe New York Times is launching an ongoing examination of privacy. We\xe2\x80\x99ll dig into the ideas, history and future of how our information navigates the digital ecosystem and what\xe2\x80\x99s at stake.See all Privacy articles\nFrom the NewsroomTracking Phones, Google Is a Dragnet for the PoliceApril 13, 2019\nSee all Privacy articles\nMore on NYTimes.com\nAdvertisement\nSite Information Navigation\n\xc2\xa9 2019 The New York Times Company\nHome\nSearch\nAccessibility concerns? Email us at accessibility@nytimes.com. aS'New York City\'s LinkNYC WiFi Plan - Business Insider\nTech\nFinance\nPolitics\nStrategy\nLife\nAll\nTech\nTech Insider\nMedia\nScience\nTransportation\nFinance\nFinance\nMarkets Insider\nRetail\nYour Money\nPolitics\nPolitics\nMilitary & Defense\nStrategy\nStrategy\nAdvertising\nCareers\nLife\nLife\nCoupons\nEntertainment\nInsider Picks\nSports\nFeatured\nBetter Capitalism\nEmbracing Disruption\nInsider TV\nSubscribe\nBI Intelligence\nBI Prime\nAbout BI\nAbout\nCareers\nContact Us\nAdvertise\nContributors FAQ\nCorporate\nCorrections Policy\nFollow BI\nNewsletters\nEvents\nRSS\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nYouTube\nLinkedIn\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nEdition\nBI Prime\nIntelligence\nMenu Icon\nA vertical stack of three evenly spaced horizontal lines.\nEdition\nInternational Editions:\nUnited States\nUS\nInternational\nINTL\nDeutschland\nDE\nAustralia\nAUS\nFrance\nFR\nIndia\nIN\nItaly\nIT\nJapan\nJP\nMalaysia\nMY\nNetherlands\nNL\nNordic\nSE\nPoland\nPL\nSingapore\nSG\nSouth Africa\nZA\nSpain\nES\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nTech\nEnterprise\nScience\nadvertising\nMedia\nTransportation\nFinance\nMarkets\nRetail\nYour Money\nMarkets Insider\nPolitics\nMilitary & Defense\nNews\nStrategy\nCareers\nLife\nEntertainment\nTravel\nSports\nAll\nCoupons\nTarget\nWalmart\nEBay\nNike\nContainer Store\nBI ACCOUNTS\nBUSINESS INSIDER\nBI PRIME\nSIGN OUT\nBI INTELLIGENCE\nEdition\nUS\nINTL\nDE\nAUS\nFR\nIN\nIT\nJP\nMY\nNL\nSE\nPL\nSG\nZA\nES\nFollow us on:\n* Copyright \xc2\xa9 2019 Insider Inc. All rights reserved. Registration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our\nTerms of Service\n,\nPrivacy Policy\nand\nCookies Policy\n.\nSitemap\nDisclaimer\nCommerce Policy\nCoupons\nMade in NYC\nStock quotes by\nfinanzen.net\nNew York City Has A New Plan To Give Everyone High-Speed WiFi Internet Access For Free\nMaya Kosoff\nNov. 17, 2014, 1:00 PM\nFree WiFi is coming to the city in the form of Links.\nLinkNYC\nBy the end of next year, New Yorkers will be able to access free, fast public Wi-Fi across all five boroughs.\nThe plan, called LinkNYC, will replace the city\'s aging pay phone system with "Links."\nLinks are hubs for free Wi-Fi that run at up to gigabit speeds, and they offer a bunch of other services, including free phone calls within the U.S., access to 311 and 911, a free charging station for your phone, and a touchscreen tablet interface so users can access directions and city services.\nLinks will also serve as digital displays for advertising, and they\'re expected to generate more than $500 million in revenue for New York City over the next 12 years.\nBuilding the service won\'t cost taxpayers anything. The five-borough LinkNYC plan will be funded through advertising revenue.\nLinkNYC will install up to 10,000 Links. Thousands of those Links will have free gigabit WiFi, which is more than 100 times faster than average municipal Wi-Fi speeds.\n"LinkNYC is a first-of-its-kind communications network that will bring the fastest available municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers and visitors," according to a press release from CityBridge and LinkNYC.\nLinkNYC will also offer an encrypted network connection, though the press release adds: "We encourage you to continue to use end-to-end encryption, such as HTTPS, for any sensitive matters or data. The network will also prevent peer-to-peer security threats by eliminating the ability to communicate device to device."\nThe project is the result of a partnership between the NYC Mayor\'s Office of Technology and Innovation, the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, and a New York-based group called CityBridge. Mobile tech giant Qualcomm will serve as CityBridge\'s technology advisor. Titan, the outdoor media company that in October\nquietly installed and later removed 500 beacons in pay phone booths throughout the city, will oversee LinkNYC\'s advertising program. Work on the LinkNYC network will begin in 2015. The first Link structures will be operational by the end of 2015.\nSEE ALSO:\nNew York City Tells The Company Secretly Hiding Beacons In Phone Booths To Take Them Out\nMore:\nWiFi\nNew York City\nLinkNYC\nWi-Fi\nPopular\nThe best smartphone maker you\'ve never heard of is announcing a new smartphone in May that\'s expected to have a more advanced display than the iPhone or Galaxy S10\nPopular\nChina shows off its new destroyer during massive display of naval power\nPopular\nI drove a $45,000 Ford Ranger pickup truck to see if it\'s ready to take on the Chevy Colorado and Toyota Tacoma \xe2\x80\x94 here\'s the verdict\nPopular\nTim Cook said Apple\'s fight with the FBI in 2016 was a \'very rigged case,\' and he wishes it went to court\nPopular\nI have 26 credit cards and excellent credit. Here\'s the best advice I can give you on keeping up your score, no matter how many cards you have.\nFollow us on:\nAlso check out:\n* Copyright \xc2\xa9 2019 Insider Inc. All rights reserved. Registration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our\nTerms of Service\n,\nPrivacy Policy\nand\nCookies Policy\n.\nSitemap\nDisclaimer\nCommerce Policy\nCoupons\nMade in NYC\nStock quotes by\nfinanzen.net\nEdition\nInternational Editions:\nUnited States\nUS\nInternational\nINTL\nDeutschland\nDE\nAustralia\nAUS\nFrance\nFR\nIndia\nIN\nItaly\nIT\nJapan\nJP\nMalaysia\nMY\nNetherlands\nNL\nNordic\nSE\nPoland\nPL\nSingapore\nSG\nSouth Africa\nZA\nSpain\nES'

aS"Will New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Free Wi-Fi Help Police Watch You? - The Atlantic\nSkip to content The Atlantic\nPopular Latest\nSectionsSections\nPolitics Culture Technology Ideas Science Books Family Business Global Health Education Letters The Masthead\nPhoto Podcasts The Atlantic Crossword Video Events Writers Projects\nMagazineMagazine\nCurrent issue\nAll issues\nManage subscription\nGive a Gift\nSubscribe\nMore CategoriesMore Create account Your accountSign in Sign out Newsletters The Atlantic Crossword iOS App Life Timeline Events Books Shop Help Center\nView all\nSubscribe Search Search\nQuick Links\nJames Fallows\nMegan Garber\nDavid Frum\nAdam Serwer\nManage subscription\nSearch The Atlantic\nQuick Links\nJames Fallows\nMegan Garber\nDavid Frum\nAdam Serwer\nManage subscription\nTechnology\nWill New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Free Wi-Fi Help Police Watch You?\nThe city is building the biggest and fastest free network in the country\xe2\x80\x94but it could put low-income users' privacy at risk. Kaveh Waddell\nApr 11, 2016\nJohannes Schmitt-Tegge / dpa / Corbis\nInternet access is getting faster and cheaper by the year. Four out of five households in developed countries now have home Internet connections. But a home connection is still out of reach of many in the United States. People in major American cities pay more for basic broadband speeds than city-dwellers abroad. Fewer than half of Americans who make less than $20,000 a year have broadband access at home, and the number-one reason that Americans give for not having broadband at home is that it\xe2\x80\x99s too expensive.That\xe2\x80\x99s the problem New York City is taking on with LinkNYC, a program launched in February that aims to bring free, fast wireless service to the city\xe2\x80\x99s millions of residents. New York isn\xe2\x80\x99t the first place to offer a free municipal wi-fi network, but LinkNYC is designed to be the fastest and most wide-reaching such project in the country when it expands to cover the whole city in the next 10 years.The system takes advantage of the infrastructure behind New York\xe2\x80\x99s now-outdated pay phones. Touchscreen kiosks are sprouting up where the iconic phones used to be, and will eventually number in the thousands. The kiosks function as public Internet terminals, free Internet phones, and access points for the citywide wi-fi network.\nThe kiosks are being built by a consortium that includes Qualcomm, and an Alphabet-funded company called Intersection. The system\xe2\x80\x99s kiosks actually broadcast two wi-fi networks: an open network that\xe2\x80\x99s just a fast, citywide version of the Internet connection at your local Starbucks, and a \xe2\x80\x9cprivate\xe2\x80\x9d network that encrypts all the traffic between devices and the Link kiosk. Both networks require users to input an email address to connect, but for now, only new Apple devices can access the private network.Rolling out an ambitious municipal-wireless project in one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s biggest cities is a chance for New York to establish an important standard for others to follow. But simply getting more New Yorkers online isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough.People who who can\xe2\x80\x99t afford broadband access would be most likely to take advantage of a fast, free option for Internet access like LinkNYC. And since low-income communities are already among the most surveilled communities in the country, it\xe2\x80\x99s particularly important that such a service offer robust privacy protections.The LinkNYC privacy policy has already sparked some concerns at the New York office of the American Civil Liberties Union, which the human-rights organization outlined in a letter to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office last month. Mariko Hirose, a senior staff attorney at the New York Civil Liberties Union, said the city requested input from NYCLU on the project, but that group hasn\xe2\x80\x99t yet received a response to its March 16 letter.The letter\xe2\x80\x99s main concerns had to do with how LinkNYC gathers and preserves data on the users that connect to its network. The service\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy says that when users access LinkNYC networks, they agree to share information about their devices, browsing and search history, and the ways they interact with the web pages they visit. It also says that the system preserves user data for 12 months after the last time the user logs in.But according to a spokesperson for LinkNYC, detailed browsing information is gathered only on people who are surfing the web on public Link kiosks stationed on city sidewalks. The spokesperson said that the service only gathers two pieces of information on its users: An email address (which is never verified) and a MAC address, a unique string of letters and numbers that identifies Internet-connected devices. That\xe2\x80\x99s far less personal information than traditional Internet service providers and telecom services collect, the spokesperson said.That\xe2\x80\x99s true: Most home broadband providers and mobile-data providers gather and store detailed information about the sites that their users access, and will turn over that information to the government in response to a subpoena or a court order.But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean an email and a MAC address alone wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be of use to law enforcement. If, for example, LinkNYC keeps logs of where and when a particular mobile device connects to different kiosks, that trail could reveal a pretty complete picture of where the device\xe2\x80\x99s owner lives, works, commutes, and visits. The police could request a list of devices connected to a kiosk near a crime scene during a certain time window, and could learn a lot about the nearby devices\xe2\x80\x99 owners from their connection patterns.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s too early to know if that could happen, because LinkNYC service is still in its first months of operation. The spokesperson said that the program hasn\xe2\x80\x99t yet received any government requests for information, and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say what specific information would be available for production in response to a legal request from law enforcement.LinkNYC \xe2\x80\x9cwould require a subpoena or similar lawful request before sharing any data with the NYPD or law enforcement, and we will make every effort to communicate government requests to impacted users,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jen Hensley, the program\xe2\x80\x99s general manager, in a statement.Hirose, the NYCLU staff attorney, said it\xe2\x80\x99s encouraging that LinkNYC doesn\xe2\x80\x99t intend to collect browsing data on its wi-fi users, but stressed the importance of reflecting that fact in the official privacy policy. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are people for whom this will be their way to connect to the Internet,\xe2\x80\x9d Hirose said. The essential nature of Internet access creates an power imbalance that could leave those people vulnerable, so she said she hopes people will push for more protective privacy rules.In rolling out a huge public network, LinkNYC had to attend to a huge range of security and privacy issues. Those challenges are clearly on their minds: The program\xe2\x80\x99s CTO, Colin O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell, told The Verge about the network\xe2\x80\x99s security protections, which aim to keep malware out of the system.The encrypted private network, too, is a very important feature that will make browsing safer for the system\xe2\x80\x99s regular users. The fact that it\xe2\x80\x99s currently only available on newer, higher-end Apple devices leaves the security feature out of reach of those who need it most, but LinkNYC says they\xe2\x80\x99re working to bring it to more devices soon.When its rollout is complete, New York\xe2\x80\x99s municipal wireless system will be a boon to all sorts of users. But since the low-income communities don\xe2\x80\x99t have as much bargaining power as the rest of the city, it\xe2\x80\x99s important that the network be designed to keep those vulnerable users as safe as possible. If New York can navigate that successfully, and keep the municipal wi-fi network from becoming another tool for surveillance, then it could provide a model for smaller cities that might not have the resources to start a citywide network project from scratch. We want to hear what you think about this article. Submit a letter to the editor or write to letters@theatlantic.com.\nKaveh Waddell is a former staff writer at The Atlantic.\nFacebook\nTwitter\nEmail\nAboutOur HistoryStaffCareersShopContactHelp CenterContact UsSend a News TipAdvertisePressPodcastsRadio AtlanticCrazy/GeniusThe Atlantic InterviewAudio ArticlesSubscriptionPurchaseGive a GiftManage SubscriptionDownload iOS AppNewslettersFollowPrivacy\xc2\xa0PolicyAdvertising\xc2\xa0GuidelinesTerms\xc2\xa0ConditionsResponsible\xc2\xa0DisclosureU.S.\xc2\xa0EditionWorld\xc2\xa0EditionSite\xc2\xa0MapTheAtlantic.com Copyright (c) 2019 by The Atlantic Monthly Group. All Rights Reserved.The Atlantic"

aS'What a ban on online porn can teach us about Internet law - The Washington Post\nSections\nHome\nThe Washington Post logo\nDemocracy Dies in Darkness\nTry 1 month for $1\nUsername\nSign In\nMy Post My Reading List Account Settings Newsletters & alerts Gift subscriptions Contact us Help desk\nMy Post My Reading List Account Settings Newsletters & alerts Gift subscriptions Contact us Help desk\nAccessibility for screenreader\nThe Switch\nAnalysis\nAnalysis\nInterpretation of the news based on evidence, including data, as well as anticipating how events might unfold based on past events\nWhat a ban on online porn can teach us about Internet law\nAdd to list\nIn my list\n( dominox_o / Flickr )\nBy\nBrian Fung\nBrian Fung Reporter focusing on telecommunications, media, and competition\nEmail\nBio\nFollow\nJune 21, 2016\nWhen New York City first started\xc2\xa0replacing its public pay phones with free\xc2\xa0Internet\xc2\xa0kiosks, it probably didn\'t expect homeless people\xc2\xa0to start watching porn\xc2\xa0on\xc2\xa0them. So the company behind the Internet\xc2\xa0service, LinkNYC,\xc2\xa0has now installed a software filter to prevent people\xc2\xa0from accessing adult material\xc2\xa0from\xc2\xa0each of the 180 Web-enabled kiosks scattered around Manhattan and the Bronx. "It sucks, man. It was great," one homeless man said of the ban (and the porn), according to the New York Post. [The tremendous ambitions behind New York City\'s free WiFi] LinkNYC\'s\xc2\xa0decision effectively creates a curated version of\xc2\xa0the Internet for the kiosk\'s millions of potential users.\xc2\xa0Why is that interesting? Well, as part of\xc2\xa0a closely watched federal court case last week, a panel of judges ruled\xc2\xa0that curated Internet services are exempt from the government\'s rules on net neutrality \xe2\x80\x94 a set of regulations aimed at ensuring that no ISP can block or slow down the websites you want to reach. Those very rules were upheld in a 2-to-1 vote last week at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.\xc2\xa0The decision marked a major victory for\xc2\xa0regulators and a defeat for the ISPs that had sued to have\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0rules overturned.\xc2\xa0The broadband companies claimed the regulations were illegal and unconstitutional; the court ultimately disagreed, siding with the government. [Cable and telecom companies just lost a huge court battle on net neutrality] Although the Federal Communications Commission prevailed over the ISPs, it now falls to the agency to implement its regulations. And, partly because of\xc2\xa0the judges\' comments on curated Internet services, this may be a messy process. It raises tough,\xc2\xa0murky\xc2\xa0questions about how the federal\xc2\xa0government should\xc2\xa0think about\xc2\xa0such filtered\xc2\xa0broadband\xc2\xa0services as the FCC\xc2\xa0tries to enforce its rules for an open Internet. You see,\xc2\xa0the government\'s\xc2\xa0ban on carriers blocking or throttling websites\xc2\xa0applies to "broadband Internet access service," but only as defined by the FCC. An ISP whose service\xc2\xa0does not\xc2\xa0fit this definition is exempt from the regulations, meaning it can block content\xc2\xa0without legal repercussions. The problem is, while the FCC took pains to define what was a "broadband Internet access service," or BIAS, it left things a little unclear as to what wasn\'t. Are you still a BIAS provider \xe2\x80\x94 and therefore required\xc2\xa0to obey net neutrality \xe2\x80\x94 if you only offer up a curated Internet experience? Until the court addressed this in its ruling last week, it wasn\'t clear\xc2\xa0where\xc2\xa0services like these\xc2\xa0stood with respect to net neutrality.\xc2\xa0But now, it\xc2\xa0seems\xc2\xa0the answer is\xc2\xa0no. If an Internet provider were to deliberately "exercise editorial discretion \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0for instance, by picking a limited set of websites to carry and offering that service as a curated internet experience," then it would not meet the FCC\'s definition of a\xc2\xa0BIAS, the court said, because the service wouldn\'t be offering\xc2\xa0"substantially all" websites to consumers, just a limited subset of them. So it looks as if\xc2\xa0curated Internet services, at least in the eyes of the law, aren\'t really "Internet providers." And what\'s more, trying\xc2\xa0to regulate these selective curators risks\xc2\xa0violating the Constitution, the court hinted, because the act of curation,\xc2\xa0as with\xc2\xa0newspapers, is protected by the First Amendment. The challenge is establishing who falls into which camp, a task that may\xc2\xa0make life more difficult for regulators as they try to implement their net neutrality regulations. Instead of being able to apply its rules across the board, the FCC now must pause to consider which bucket an ISP falls into before trying to enforce\xc2\xa0the rules\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 or be accused of infringing on free speech. The D.C. Circuit didn\'t create this ambiguous situation; the FCC did when it chose to distinguish between BIAS and non-BIAS providers.\xc2\xa0But the court\'s ruling forces us to think about what\'s essentially a whole other class of ISPs and its\xc2\xa0relationship to what we\'d probably call "regular" Internet providers by comparison. Could this exemption for filtered Internet service be used as a loophole for major Internet providers, such as Verizon and AT&T, to try to evade the rules? FCC officials\xc2\xa0said no, because the rules are written to prevent that kind of chicanery. For one, they still allow the FCC to\xc2\xa0go after misbehaving\xc2\xa0companies that provide the "functional equivalent" of broadband Internet access service, even if it isn\'t strictly BIAS. For another,\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0regulations\xc2\xa0contain\xc2\xa0specific language allowing the FCC to investigate perceived\xc2\xa0cases\xc2\xa0of deliberate rule evasion. Besides, large Internet providers such as Comcast would just be shooting themselves in the foot if they didn\'t allow customers to go everywhere on the Internet, said Matt Wood, policy director for the consumer group Free Press, in an interview with The Washington Post on C-SPAN\'s "The Communicators" series. [New data: Americans are abandoning home Internet] But that doesn\'t minimize the task for regulators. And it still doesn\'t tell us very much about what rules, if any, filtered Internet services must abide by if not net neutrality. Analysts say\xc2\xa0that curated Internet services\xc2\xa0aren\'t\xc2\xa0common, but\xc2\xa0such ISPs\xc2\xa0do serve important groups of customers who feel that the mainstream\xc2\xa0carriers\xc2\xa0aren\'t the right choice for them. Many block violent or sexual Internet content on moral or religious grounds. Fred Campbell, director of the think tank Tech Knowledge, said his research has led him to several providers that fit this description, such as a New York-based ISP that\'s geared toward Jewish customers. The service essentially blocks all content that\'s inconsistent with the Jewish faith, Campbell said on "The Communicators." "If the\xc2\xa0FCC\xc2\xa0were to take action against this\xc2\xa0ISP for their editorial decisions," he said, "they then could say, \'As this is being applied to me, it\'s violating my First Amendment rights.\'" And as the\xc2\xa0example\xc2\xa0of LinkNYC suggests, this thorny conundrum doesn\'t just affect small, minority-focused ISPs. Nobody has yet complained that LinkNYC\'s porn ban is a violation of net neutrality \xe2\x80\x94 and it\'s likely nobody will \xe2\x80\x94 but what if it started filtering other types of content it decided were inappropriate?\xc2\xa0Unlike\xc2\xa0Twitter or Facebook deciding to filter objectionable material, LinkNYC is a company that offers access to the Internet, not a website\xc2\xa0on the\xc2\xa0Internet. And\xc2\xa0that means the\xc2\xa0FCC would need to take seriously consumer complaints stemming from such practices, even if it\'s less than clear that the agency is empowered to do anything about them. If you think this is just an academic exercise, think again: Industry officials who have a stake in the First Amendment claims are arguing this point precisely.\nAs an ISP exercising editorial discretion, at least NYC does not have to worry about #NetNeutrality https://t.co/PHFoWnP42F\xe2\x80\x94 Hank Hultquist (@HankHultquist) June 20, 2016\nComments\nBrian Fung Brian Fung covers business and technology for The Washington Post. Before joining The Post, he was the technology correspondent for National Journal and an associate editor at the Atlantic.\nFollow\nMarket Watch\nDow 26,656.39\nToday\n0.55%\nS&P 2,933.68\nToday\n0.88%\nNASDAQ 8,120.82\nToday\n1.32%\nLast Updated:4:59 PM 04/23/2019'

aS"NYCLU Raises Privacy Concerns on LinkNYC's Wi-Fi Hotspots | Digital Trends\nDigital Trends\nMore\nProduct Reviews\nNews\nVideos\nFeatures\nBest Products\nHow To\nDeals\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nMenu\nSearch\nBack to Menu\nMore\nTech for Change\nAwards We Offer\nSend Us Your News Tip\nGiveaways\nDT Espa\xc3\xb1ol\nThe Manual\nWho We Are\nAbout Us\nCareers\nAdvertise\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Use\nContact Us\nSocial\nLinkedIn\nPinterest\nYouTube\nGoogle+\nRSS Home\nNewsletter\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nCategories\nPhones\nTVs\nLaptops\nCars\nGames\nHeadphones\nCameras\nDesktops\nSmart Home\nAppliances\nSmartwatches\nPrinters\nSoundbars\nStreaming Devices\nMonitors\nMore Product Reviews\nTopics\nMobile\nHome Theater\nComputing\nGaming\nCars\nPhotography\nSmart Home\nMovies & TV\nMusic\nEmerging Tech\n5G\nBusiness\nSocial Media\nVirtual Reality\nWearables\nApple\nMore News\nOriginal Series\nDigital Trends Live\nTrends with Benefits\nBetween the Streams\nBehind the Wheel\nAwesome Tech You Can\xe2\x80\x99t Buy Yet\nInnovators: And now for something amazing\nHands-On\nConnect my Crib\nTech for Less\nThe Deets\nTheUnlockr\nVs.\nMore Videos\nOriginal Series\nWomen With Byte\nTech for Change\nInnovators\nBacklog\n(in)Secure\nSmart Cities\nRoad Rave\nBlockchain\nMore Features\nBest of Everything\nTVs\nSmartphones\nLaptops\nDesktops\nHeadphones\nSoundbars\nCameras\nDrones\nStreaming Devices\n3D Printers\nMonitors\nHome Security Systems\nPrinters\nGame Consoles\nPlaystation 4 Games\nXbox One Games\nMore Best Products\nShare on Facebook\nTweet this\nShare\nMobile\nNYCLU raises privacy qualms about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Wi-Fi hotspots\nBy\nJulian Chokkattu\n@julianchokkattu\n\xe2\x80\x94\nPosted on\nMarch 16, 2016\n2:03PM PST\n03.16.16 -\n2:03PM PST\nShare on Facebook\nTweet this\nShare\nTurning old phone booths into public Wi-Fi hotspots may seem like a great way to increase connectivity so people don\xe2\x80\x99t have to rely as much on using their data, but the New York Civil Liberties Union\xe2\x80\x99s latest report may have you reconsidering connecting to the\xc2\xa0free service.\nLinkNYC is a project backed by Mayor Bill de Blasio, and it\xe2\x80\x99s primarily being funded and operated by a consortium of companies including Qualcomm, Intersection, and Civiq Smartscapes. The project involves converting phone booths into Wi-Fi hot spots that offer free 24/7 gigabit Wi-Fi with a 150-foot radius, free calls to anywhere in the U.S., a touchscreen tablet interface, a digital display that shows ads and announcements, as well as ports so you can charge your devices (cable not included).\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC will eventually become a network of as many as 7,500 to 10,000 public kiosks offering fast and free Wi-Fi.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NYCLU says CityBridge, the company behind LinkNYC, \xe2\x80\x9cretains vast amount\xc2\xa0of information about users \xe2\x80\x94 often indefinitely \xe2\x80\x94 building a massive database that carries a risk of security breaches and unwarranted NYPD surveillance,\xe2\x80\x9d in a letter sent to the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC, which was publicly launched in January, will eventually become a network of as many as 7,500 to 10,000 public kiosks offering fast and free Wi-Fi throughout all five boroughs,\xe2\x80\x9d the NYCLU says in the letter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sheer volume of information gathered by this powerful network will create a massive database of information that will present attractive opportunities for hackers and for law enforcement surveillance, and will carry an undue risk of abuse, misuse and unauthorized access.\xe2\x80\x9d\nCityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy for the Link hubs says that by accepting the\xc2\xa0terms\xc2\xa0connected\xc2\xa0to the use of its service, CityBridge will be permitted to monitor information about your visits to websites, information used to facilitate use of its services, and pages viewed or searched for, including page response times, download errors, length of visits to certain pages, and more.\nBut LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s General Manager, Jen Hensley, told Digital Trends that\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC does not collect or store any data on users\xe2\x80\x99 personal web browsing on their own devices.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo use its services, you need to sign in with your email address, and after asking for consent, CityBridge will also permit \xe2\x80\x9cselected third parties to provide you with information about goods or services that may interest you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes we supplement technical information we collect from you with information collected by third parties,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the privacy policy. \xe2\x80\x9cThird parties may include advertising partners or other providers that help us understand our users. We do not collect information about your precise location. However, we know where we provide WiFi services, so when you use the Services we can determine your general location.\xe2\x80\x9d\nMayor Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s office responded to NYCLU\xe2\x80\x99s allegations that CityBridge is retaining vast user data.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City and CityBridge have created customer-first privacy protections to ensure our users\xe2\x80\x99 personal information stays that way \xe2\x80\x94 personal,\xe2\x80\x9d Natalie Grybauskas, spokesperson for the Mayor, told Digital Trends. \xe2\x80\x9cWe believe our privacy policy is the best way to protect New Yorkers and LinkNYC users while they safely and securely enjoy free superfast Wi-Fi across the five boroughs. We will continue to work to ensure legitimate concerns are addressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC does not collect or store any data on users\xe2\x80\x99 personal web browsing on their own devices.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NYCLU\xe2\x80\x99s letter also raised the issue of whether\xc2\xa0the NYPD could be requesting access to user data via the LinkNYC hubs, and whether\xc2\xa0sensors and cameras on the hubs would feed into the NYPD\xe2\x80\x99s systems and the Domain Awareness System. The DAS is a surveillance system designed by Microsoft that tracks targets and gets detailed information from them, and connects to 6,000 cameras in New York City.\nBut Grybauskas specifically mentioned that\xc2\xa0cameras and environmental sensors aren\xe2\x80\x99t fed into the Domain Awareness System, and that the NYPD would have to secure a subpoena to acquire this information. The same goes for personal information, as it won\xe2\x80\x99t be shared or sold for third-party use unless it\xe2\x80\x99s ordered by a court or through a subpoena.\nHensley, echoed Grybauskas\xe2\x80\x99 sentiments and said\xc2\xa0CityBridge would need a subpoena \xe2\x80\x9cor similar lawful request\xe2\x80\x9d before sharing any data with the NYPD or law enforcement, and once they have, they would \xe2\x80\x9cmake every effort\xe2\x80\x9d to let users know about those requests.\nHensley also referred to the\xc2\xa0Domain Awareness System, and said that the cameras in the Link hub are \xe2\x80\x9ccurrently inactive and are not designed to feed into any NYPD systems.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NYCLU\xe2\x80\x99s letter reminds us of the\xc2\xa0important point that there\xe2\x80\x99s no such thing as a free lunch.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 private online activities shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be used to create a massive database that\xe2\x80\x99s within the ready grasp of the NYPD,\xe2\x80\x9d Donna Lieberman, executive director of the NYCLU, said in the letter. \xe2\x80\x9cFree public Wi-Fi can be an invaluable resource for this city, but New Yorkers need to know there are too many strings attached.\xe2\x80\x9d\nEditors' Recommendations\nFederal investigation digs into Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s data-sharing deals\nYes, data is the new oil and the fight to reclaim it from tech giants starts now\nIn latest blow to Facebook, 540 million user records exposed by third-party apps\nWhat is Wi-Fi 6?
