aS'LinkNYC kiosks likely to remain \'homeless hubs\' even without web browsing - New York Daily News LinkNYC kiosks likely to remain \'homeless hubs\' even without web browsing\nSkip to content\nTopics\nxml:space="preserve">\nSubscriber Services\nManage Subscription\nEZ Pay\nDelivery Issue\nSubscriber Terms\nNew York\nNYC Crime\nBronx\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nEducation\nObituaries\nWeather\nSports\nYankees\nMets\nGiants\nJets\nKnicks\nNets\nRangers\nIslanders\nFootball\nBasketball\nBaseball\nHockey\nSoccer\nMore Sports\nI\'d Click That\nOdds\nGolf\nNews\nCrime\nU.S.\nPolitics\nWorld\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nHealth\nEats\nViva\nGames\nBest Reviews\nOpinion\nPhotos\nHoroscopes\nDaily\nE-Newspaper\nAutos\nCovers\nSpecial Sections\nClassifieds\nPublic Notices\nBranded Content\nPaid Partner Content\nPaid Content By Brandpoint\nSearch\nxml:space="preserve">\nNew York\nSports\nNews\nEntertainment\nOpinion\nAdvertisement\nAdvertisement\nNew York\nLinkNYC kiosks likely to remain \'homeless hubs\' even without web browsing\nBy Chelsia Marcius , Kerry Burke \xc2\xa0and Jennifer Fermino\n| NEW YORK DAILY NEWS |\nSep 15, 2016\n|\n7:52 PM\nAlthough LinkNYC web kiosks will no longer offer web browsing capabilities, critics argue the kiosks will still attract homeless loiterers. (Michael Appleton/Michael Appleton)\nPorn or no porn, the city\'s free web kiosks will still likely remain hotspots for Big Apple homeless, according to businesses and locals who live near them.\nA day after the city announced it was disabling web browsing from the kiosks after they\'d become magnets for people watching porn and complaints about homeless encampments around the spots, many weren\'t expecting any relief.\nAdvertisement\n"They\'ve become these little homeless hubs," said Carmine Soprano, manager of Iron Bar on W. 45th St. and 8th Ave. in Manhattan.\nThe kiosks will still allow free phone calls, feature charging stations and act as hotspots for devices within a 150-foot radius.\nAll of which will continue to draw loiterers, critics fear.\n"They camp out, start smoking weed and are just having a little party outside," said Soprano, who has a kiosk right in front of his bar.\nThe web kiosks still operate as free phones, charging stations and Wi-Fi hotspots. (TIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP/Getty Images)\nHe said one time a woman came screaming into his business saying a "creeper" was on the street.\n"I looked and saw he was watching some kind of crazy animal porn. He has his hand down his pants. The whole experience was just out of control," Soprano said, adding that he called the cops.\nSoprano also said people who use the phone on the kiosks rarely have headphones, which means his whole bar can hear the conversation.\n"Usually they\'re not appropriate (conversations), and we have families sitting here," he said.\nHe\'s also heard drug deals go down on the phone calls.\nManhattan Borough President Gale Brewer likened the issues surrounding the kiosks to those surrounding pay phones in the \'80s and \'90s. (Theodore Parisienne/for New York Daily News)\nAmadou Mangassa, 46, the manager of Mr. Joe sneaker store in the Garment District agreed.\n"Every single day, you have homeless people sitting there all day long, doing their thing," he said.\nAs he spoke, outside his store a homeless woman hung out at the kiosk, leaning on the box for over an hour with her high heels in her hands.\nManhattan Borough President Gale Brewer, who had urged the city to impose limits on web time back in August because of the issues, said the kiosks might be new but the problem isn\'t.\n"I was around in the \'80s and \'90s in the crack epidemic, and there we had payphones and people used them as their place of business," she said.\nAdvertisement\nThe kiosks often attract homeless people, who hang out by the boxes all day.\nShe predicted that curbing web browsing would eliminate many of the problems.\nLinkNYC, the consortium that runs the kiosks, said they are working out the kinks.\n"As New Yorkers ourselves, we want LinkNYC to provide the best possible experience for Link users and the communities around them," said Jen Hensley, General Manager of LinkNYC.\n"We designed the network to be flexible so that we can make changes, evaluate their impact and continue to make adjustments over time."\nnyc homeless\ngale brewer\nAdvertisement\nRecommended'
p50
aS'The real issue with New York\xe2\x80\x99s free Internet kiosks isn\xe2\x80\x99t porn - The Washington Post\nSections\nHome\nThe Washington Post logo\nDemocracy Dies in Darkness\nTry 1 month for $1\nUsername\nSign In\nMy Post My Reading List Account Settings Newsletters & alerts Gift subscriptions Contact us Help desk\nMy Post My Reading List Account Settings Newsletters & alerts Gift subscriptions Contact us Help desk\nAccessibility for screenreader\nThe Switch\nAnalysis\nAnalysis\nInterpretation of the news based on evidence, including data, as well as anticipating how events might unfold based on past events\nThe real issue with New York\xe2\x80\x99s free Internet kiosks isn\xe2\x80\x99t porn\nAdd to list\nIn my list\nOne of LinkNYC\'s free Internet kiosks. (LinkNYC / Instagram)\nBy\nBrian Fung\nBrian Fung Reporter focusing on telecommunications, media, and competition\nEmail\nBio\nFollow\nSeptember 15, 2016\nNew York City\'s free Internet kiosks are getting a big downgrade after the company that operates them said users were hogging the on-street machines to watch movies and pornography. The 400 kiosks, which\xc2\xa0have been\xc2\xa0pitched to consumers as a kind of telephone booth of the future, have a built-in tablet that lets passers-by look up directions and make free phone calls. They also offered\xc2\xa0a Web browser\xc2\xa0--\xc2\xa0but not anymore. \xc2\xa0LinkNYC, the company\xc2\xa0behind the access points, said Wednesday that "some users have been monopolizing the Link tablets and using them inappropriately." Because of that problem, LinkNYC\xc2\xa0is\xc2\xa0cutting off access to the Web browser indefinitely, or at least until it can figure out how to keep users from abusing the kiosks for their "extended, personal use." [The tremendous ambitions behind New York City\'s free WiFi] New Yorkers have complained about homeless people using the tablets to watch porn. Although some\xc2\xa0news outlets are reporting this as a new revelation, we\'ve known about this issue for months. LinkNYC had already tried to do something about it \xe2\x80\x94 and apparently\xc2\xa0failed. Back in June, LinkNYC said it was responding to complaints of user abuse by installing a software filter aimed at blocking all pornography from its\xc2\xa0tablets. The software was sourced\xc2\xa0from a "highly regarded, professional-grade content monitoring system used by thousands of businesses, schools and libraries," LinkNYC said. [New York\'s futuristic pay phones don\'t require any payment at all] Since then, LinkNYC has had months to install the filters. So why, as recently as Sunday,\xc2\xa0was LinkNYC still getting\xc2\xa0reports about the same abuses?\n"There was a crackdown because people were watching porn" isn\'t the story. The story is that LinkNYC\'s efforts to stem the excessive usage didn\'t really work, which may say more about the\xc2\xa0implementation\xc2\xa0of the filter than people\'s interest in online smut.\nA spokesperson for LinkNYC said that no filter is perfect and that it\'s difficult to strike a balance between blocking content that some people might deem innocuous and maximizing the kiosks\' usefulness to members of the public. The spokesperson said\xc2\xa0that LinkNYC faced a bigger problem: People are overturning newspaper boxes and pulling up chairs in front of the kiosks to settle in, keeping\xc2\xa0others from using the devices. The company said\xc2\xa0it is\xc2\xa0weighing policies that might prevent the nuisance, such as time limits and cooldown periods where the kiosk\'s Web browsing feature becomes inactive. While that could deter some from abusing the tablets, it may also make life more difficult for the next people who want to use them. If you build it, they will come. And stay too long.\nComments\nBrian Fung Brian Fung covers business and technology for The Washington Post. Before joining The Post, he was the technology correspondent for National Journal and an associate editor at the Atlantic.\nFollow\nMarket Watch\nDow 26,656.39\nToday\n0.55%\nS&P 2,933.68\nToday\n0.88%\nNASDAQ 8,120.82\nToday\n1.32%\nLast Updated:4:59 PM 04/23/2019'

aS'Retail Privacy | Facial Recognition | Online Privacy\nSections\nLogin / Register\nNew York\nMiami\nLos Angeles\nChicago\nSubscribe\n|\nLog In\nMy Account\nNews\nResidential\nCommercial\nDevelopment\nTech\nArchitecture and Design\nMagazine\nCurrent Issue\nIssue archives\nSpecial issue archive\nThe Closings\nEvents\nIndustry Calendar\nTRD Events\nTools\nTRData\n3-D New Development Map\nBig data could save physical retail. But privacy concerns are bubbling.\nLegislators will target not just e-commerce in upcoming privacy bills\nApril 15, 2019 09:10AM\nStores say the new practices are meant to improve the overall shopping experience.(Credit: iStock)\nConcerns about consumer privacy are not just flourishing online but in brick and mortar stores as well.\nRetailers are already using Bluetooth technology to detect customers\xe2\x80\x99 smartphones when they walk into stores and hit them with promotions while they shop, and companies are also marketing facial-recognition technology to them, describing it as a way to flag shoplifters, according to the Wall Street Journal.\nStores say the new practices are meant to improve the overall shopping experience and help them stay competitive in the world of online shopping, but privacy advocates say they are bringing concerns about online surveillance into the physical world.\nThe debate over data privacy in Congress has mostly focused on e-commerce and social media companies, but legislators say they will include physical stores in their bills as well. Retailers worry that this could lead to a ban on some of the new technologies they are using and limit their ability to collect data for things such as customer loyalty programs.\nAmazon and other e-commerce companies maintain that rules about privacy and data should be the same for online and physical stores, while some retailers worry that Amazon could just end up buying the data they have at a low price.\nAt the $25 billion Hudson Yards, developer Related Companies says it will hold user data indefinitely. Surveillance and privacy watchdogs are particularly concerned about the real estate company\xe2\x80\x99s partnership with the firm behind the controversial LinkNYC kiosks.\nFacial recognition technology has proven to be particularly sensitive for retailers, with 18 of 20 companies declining to answer an ACLU survey from last year about whether they use it. They are concerned about a backlash from customers and that the software could mistakenly identify people.\nOne bill from Senators Roy Blunt and Brian Schatz would ban companies that use facial recognition from tracking consumers without their consent.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe need guardrails to ensure that, as this technology continues to develop, it is implemented responsibly,\xe2\x80\x9d Blunt told the Journal. [WSJ] \xe2\x80\x93 Eddie Small\nTags: Real Estate and Technology, Real Estate Technology, retail\nAirbnb to buy HotelTonight, marking company\'s biggest acquisitionWhy the Dubai developer behind the Burj Khalifa is launching a digital toke...Intelligent design: "Business is booming" for smart buildings\nShort URL\nPopular\nFelix Sater: \xe2\x80\x9cMy main motivation was in building a Trump tower in Moscow and making $100M in the process\xe2\x80\x9d\nAmid financial woes, Brookland Capital is selling another Brooklyn property\nThese are some of the most notable resi sales of the week\nWATCH: Gary Barnett on the residential market, Brooklyn and discounts at One Manhattan Square\nZillow sues Compass for poaching tech talent, allegedly stealing trade secrets\nQueens property purchased for $125M by Chinese firm headed to foreclosure\nJLL I-sales broker out amid merger with HFF\nMore Stories\nVideos\nWATCH: TRD talks shop with the developers behind Hudson Yards\nMore Videos\nSites\nSouth Florida\nLos Angeles\nChicago\nOther Links\nDirectory\nShop\nSubscription\nAdvertising\nDigital Ad Products\nAbout Us\nStaff Directory\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nSTAY CONNECTED\nJoin over 200,000 real estate professionals who receive our daily newsletter\nAll rights reserved \xc2\xa9 2019\t\t\t\tThe Real Deal is a registered Trademark of Korangy Publishing Inc.\n450 West 31st Street,\nNew York, NY 10001\nPhone:\n212-260-1332'

aS'LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s free WiFi and phone kiosks hit London as LinkUK, in partnership with BT \xe2\x80\x93 TechCrunch\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s free WiFi and phone kiosks hit London as LinkUK, in partnership with BT\nIngrid Lunden\n@ingridlunden\n/\n2 years\nLondon\xe2\x80\x99s iconic red phone boxes may be mostly gone from the streets of the city \xe2\x80\x94 and many\xc2\xa0of those that remain are no longer home to phones (one in my hood\xc2\xa0is now a book exchange, another is a dingy mess) \xe2\x80\x94 but the promise of offering communication services\xc2\xa0to people on the go remains.\nToday, UK\xc2\xa0carrier BT announced that it has partnered with Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 Intersection, the Google/Alphabet-backed startup\xc2\xa0behind\xc2\xa0New York\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC free WiFi kiosks, to roll out\xc2\xa0LinkUK, free internet and phone hubs for\xc2\xa0London and the rest of the country.\nAs with its Big Apple counterpart, the plan is to provide people near the kiosks\xc2\xa0with free WiFi (speeds of up to 1 Gigabit per second), along with free voice calls\xc2\xa0and a few\xc2\xa0other services \xe2\x80\x94 which users can get through their own\xc2\xa0WiFi-enabled devices or a tablet on the kiosk.\nPerhaps taking a tip from the NYC service, which found that unsavory types were congregating around the LinkNYC kiosks to browse porn, LinkUK will not provide unrestricted internet access as part of the deal.\nThe partnership will be\xc2\xa0a three-way affair in the UK between Intersection, BT and ad partner Primesight.\nIntersection is providing the kiosk architecture and technology for the service,\xc2\xa0as part of its bigger ambition to take its business model to more markets and evolve it beyond being a pure moon shot.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs a global hub for media and technology, London is the ideal city for Intersection to invest in the expansion of connectivity, digital innovation and our business,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Dan Doctoroff, Chairman & CEO at Intersection and Sidewalk Labs, said. \xe2\x80\x9cLinkUK from BT will bring tremendous benefits to Londoners, visitors, local businesses, and international brands and we look forward to working with our partners, BT and Primesight, to transform this great city\xe2\x80\x99s streetscape.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBut while\xc2\xa0Google itself has been making inroads into providing high-speed broadband services in the UK (note: some of that, it announced today, will now be paused) , a spokesperson confirmed that it will be BT providing all of the connectivity for LinkUK.\nLastly, the whole service will be underwritten by way of an advertising partnership with Primesight, an independent outdoor advertising network, which will run digital ads on the kiosks. As the kiosk rollout will start slow \xe2\x80\x94 100 in the first phase, 750 in London longer-term \xe2\x80\x94 Primesight has also cut a deal with BT to provide ads on an additional 17,500 older kiosks across the country. These will be in the form of non-digital vinyl display ads, a spokesperson said.\nBT declined to specify the financial terms of the deal except to say that BT, Intersection, and Primesight will all share in the ad revenues from LinkUK.\nLink UK, which is projected to start its rollout in 2017, has yet to get full approval from local authorities, the spokesperson said. But the Mayor of London\xe2\x80\x99s office, as well as\xc2\xa0Camden, the\xc2\xa0first borough in London that will get the kiosks, have\xc2\xa0already enthusiastically endorsed the project. In part, that\xe2\x80\x99s because, with the rise of mobile phones, many existing phone boxes are hardly used for their original purposes anymore. Vandalised and worn out, they\xc2\xa0are more\xc2\xa0reminders of the seedier side of city life than communications hubs.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI welcome this exciting new addition to London\xe2\x80\x99s streets. Expanding London\xe2\x80\x99s digital infrastructure is a priority for the Mayor, and LinkUK can play a big part in improving connectivity for Londoners and visitors to our city, while reducing street clutter by upgrading and reducing the number of phone boxes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rajesh Agrawal, London\xe2\x80\x99s Deputy Mayor for Business, in a statement. \xe2\x80\x9cI look forward to working with BT, Intersection and Primesight to see how we can roll LinkUK across the capital, and to explore its future potential.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor BT, it\xe2\x80\x99s also a useful way of trying to figure out how to shift some of these boxes \xe2\x80\x94 which isn\xe2\x80\x99t as straightforward as you might think to do, since they are considered a public service.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re evolving the phone box to make it relevant in the 21st century by offering people ultrafast Wi-Fi and a range of digital and information services entirely for free. London is one of the greatest cities in the world and it\xe2\x80\x99s entirely fitting that it becomes the first UK city to benefit from the\xc2\xa0Links,\xe2\x80\x9d said\xc2\xa0Gerry McQuade, CEO, BT Wholesale and Ventures.\xc2\xa0But we will be rolling out many more\xc2\xa0Links\xc2\xa0to the other great cities across the UK over the coming months as we look to transform the look and functionality of our public payphones.\xe2\x80\x9d\nToday, there are a lot of existing free WiFi and hotspot services around the London and other urban areas, but bandwidth can be patchy and connections unreliable, and having the added bonus of free calling is\xc2\xa0a useful addition.\nLinkNYC is an encouraging template for the impact that LinkUK might have. The company says that since it launched in January of this year, some\xc2\xa0671,000 people have used WiFi from the kiosks, with some 34 million WiFI sessions and \xe2\x80\x9ctens of thousands of free phone calls\xe2\x80\x9d made every week.\nSince LinkNYC launched in January, New Yorkers and visitors have embraced Link with more than 671,000 Wi-Fi users, 34 million Wi-Fi sessions, and tens of thousands of free phone calls made every week.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCities around the world look to New York for what\xe2\x80\x99s next. We\xe2\x80\x99re proud that LinkNYC has already helped nearly three quarters of a million people get online at super-fast speeds, and that excitement and adoption continues to spread,\xe2\x80\x9d said LinkNYC General Manager Jen Hensley. \xe2\x80\x9cLink\xe2\x80\x99s expansion into London and the UK underscores how cities around the world are looking for ways to modernize their infrastructure to bring connectivity and digital services to their residents without burdening taxpayers. We\xe2\x80\x99re excited to bring our valuable learnings from New York to London and help more people get connected.\xe2\x80\x9d'
p54
aS"The heavy price we pay for 'free' Wi-Fi\nEditions\nAfrica\nAustralia\nCanada\nCanada (fran\xc3\xa7ais)\nEspa\xc3\xb1a\nFrance\nGlobal Perspectives\nIndonesia\nNew Zealand\nUnited Kingdom\nUnited States\nSections\nHome\nArts + Culture\nEconomy + Business\nEducation\nEnvironment + Energy\nEthics + Religion\nHealth + Medicine\nPolitics + Society\nScience + Technology\nEn Espa\xc3\xb1ol\nSearch\nServices\nNewsletter\nRead on Play Newsstand\nRead on Apple News\nRead on Flipboard\nInformation\nWho we are\nOur charter\nOur team\nPartners and funders\nRepublishing guidelines\nContact us\nDonate\nFriends of The Conversation\nPrivacy policy\nTerms and conditions\nCorrections\nEdition:\nAvailable editions\nUnited States\nAfrica\nAustralia\nCanada\nCanada (fran\xc3\xa7ais)\nEspa\xc3\xb1a\nFrance\nGlobal Perspectives\nIndonesia\nNew Zealand\nUnited Kingdom\nDonate\nBecome an author\nSign up as a reader\nSign in\nGet newsletter\nSearch\nAcademic rigor, journalistic flair\nArts + Culture\nEconomy + Business\nEducation\nEnvironment + Energy\nEthics + Religion\nHealth + Medicine\nPolitics + Society\nScience + Technology\nFollow Topics\nFree trade\nUnemployment\nPrescription drugs\nSubscribe\nDreams of Cybersyn\nRestoring humanism to the digital\xc2\xa0age\nThe heavy price we pay for \xe2\x80\x98free\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi\nJanuary 25, 2016 5.48am EST\nBenjamin Dean, Columbia University\nAuthor\nBenjamin Dean\nFellow for Internet Governance and Cyber-security, School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University\nPartners\nView all partners\nRepublish this article\nRepublish our articles for free, online or in print, under Creative Commons license.\nFree, but at what cost?\nReuters\nEmail\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nWhatsApp\nMessenger\nFor many years, New York City has been developing a \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d public Wi-Fi project. Called LinkNYC, it is an ambitious effort to bring wireless Internet access to all of the city\xe2\x80\x99s residents.\nThis is the latest in a longstanding trend in which companies offer ostensibly free Internet-related products and services, such as social network access on Facebook, search and email from Google or the free Wi-Fi now commonly provided in cafes, shopping malls and airports.\nThese free services, however, come at a cost. Use is free on the condition that the companies providing the service can collect, store and analyze users\xe2\x80\x99 valuable personal, locational and behavioral data.\nThis practice carries with it poorly appreciated privacy risks and an opaque exchange of valuable data for very little.\nIs free public Wi-Fi, or any of these other services, really worth it?\nOrigins of LinkNYC\nNew York City began exploring a free public Wi-Fi network back in 2012 to replace its aging public phone system and called for proposals two years later.\nThe winning bid came from CityBridge, a partnership of four companies including advertising firm Titan and designer Control Group.\nTheir proposal involved building a network of 10,000 kiosks (dubbed \xe2\x80\x9clinks\xe2\x80\x9d) throughout the city that would be outfitted with high-speed Wi-Fi routers to provide Internet, free phone calls within the U.S., a cellphone charging station and a touchscreen map.\nRecently, Google created a company called Sidewalk Labs, which snapped up Titan and Control Group and merged them.\nGoogle, a company whose business model is all about collecting our data, thus became a key player in the entity that will provide NYC with free Wi-Fi.\nHow free is \xe2\x80\x98free\xe2\x80\x99?\nLike many free Internet products and services, the LinkNYC will be supported by advertising revenue.\nLinkNYC is expected to generate about US$500 million in advertising revenue for New York City over the next 12 years from the display of digital ads on the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 sides and via people\xe2\x80\x99s cellphones. The model works by providing free access in exchange for users\xe2\x80\x99 personal and behavioral data, which are then used to target ads to them.\nYet LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t actually use the word \xe2\x80\x9cadvertising,\xe2\x80\x9d preferring instead to vaguely state it \xe2\x80\x9cmay use your information, including Personally Identifiable Information,\xe2\x80\x9d to provide information about goods or services of interest.\nIt also isn\xe2\x80\x99t clear the extent to which the network could be used to track people\xe2\x80\x99s location.\nTitan previously made headlines in 2014 after installing Bluetooth beacons in over 100 pay phone booths, for the purpose of testing the technology, without the city\xe2\x80\x99s permission. Titan was subsequently ordered to remove them.\nBut the beacons are back as part of the LinkNYC contract, though users have to choose to opt in to the location services. The beacons allow targeted ads to be delivered to cellphones as people pass the hotspots, but their use isn\xe2\x80\x99t spelled out in the privacy policy.\nAfter close examination, it becomes evident that far from being free, use of LinkNYC comes with the price of mandatory collection of potentially sensitive personal, locational and behavioral data.\nThis is all standard practice in the terms of use and privacy policies for free Internet-based products and services. Can we really consider this to be a fully informed agreement and transparent exchange when the actual uses of the data, and the privacy and security implications of these uses, are not clear?\nA privacy paradox\nPeople\xe2\x80\x99s widespread use of products and services with these data collection and privacy infringing practices is curiously at odds with what they say they are willing to tolerate in studies.\nSurveys consistently show that people value their privacy. In a recent Pew survey, 93 percent of adults said that being in control of who can get information about them is important, and 90 percent said the same about what information is collected.\nIn experiments, people quote high prices for which they would be willing to sell their data. For instance, in a 2005 study in the U.K., respondents said they would sell one month\xe2\x80\x99s access to their location (via a cellphone) for an average of \xc2\xa327.40 (about US$50 based on the exchange rate at the time or $60 in inflation-adjusted terms). The figure went up even higher when subjects were told third party companies would be interested in using the data.\nIn practice, though, people trade away their personal and behavioral data for very little. This privacy paradox is on full display in the free Wi-Fi example.\nBreaking down the economics of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s business model, recall that an estimated $500 million in total ad revenue will be collected over 12 years. With 10,000 Links, and approximately eight million people in New York City, the monthly revenue per person per link is $0.000043.\nFractions of a cent. This is the indirect valuation that users accept from advertisers in exchange for their personal, locational and behavioral data when using the LinkNYC service. Compare that with the value U.K respondents put on their locational data alone.\nHow to explain this paradoxical situation? In valuing their data in experiments, people are usually given the full context of what information will be collected and how it will be used.\nIn real life, though, a lot of people don\xe2\x80\x99t read the terms of use or privacy policy. Those that do are not always able to understand what these documents are saying owing partly to the legalese used and partly to the intentionally vague wording of some passages.\nPeople thus end up exchanging their data and their privacy far less than they might in a transparent and open market transaction.\nThe business model of some of the most successful tech companies is built on this opaque exchange between data owner and service provider. The same opaque exchange occurs on social networks like Facebook, online search and online journalism.\nPart of a broader trend\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s ironic that, in this supposed age of abundant information, people are so poorly informed about how their valuable digital assets are being used before they unwittingly sign their rights away.\nTo grasp the consequences of this, think about how much personal data you hand over every time you use one of these \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d services. Consider how upset people have been in recent years due to large-scale data breaches: for instance, the more than 22 million who lost their background check records in the Office of Personnel Management hack.\nNow imagine the size a file of all your personal data in 2020 (including financial data, like purchasing history, or health data) after years of data tracking. How would you feel if it were sold to an unknown foreign corporation? How about if your insurance company got ahold of it and raised your rates? Or if an organized crime outfit stole all of it? This is the path that we are on.\nSome have already made this realization, and a countervailing trend is already under way, one that gives technology users more control over their data and privacy. Mozilla recently updated its Firefox browser to allow users to block ads and trackers. Apple too has avoided an advertising business model, and the personal data harvesting that it necessitates, instead opting to make its money from hardware, app and digital music or video sales.\nDeveloping a way for people to correctly value their data, privacy and information security would be a major additional step forward in developing financially viable, private and secure alternatives.\nWith it might come the possibility of an information age where people can maintain their privacy and retain ownership and control over their digital assets, should they choose to.\nFacebook\nOnline privacy\nPrivacy\nGoogle\nNew York\nData\nData privacy\nWi-Fi\nLocation data\nPrevious post\nAugust 4, 2015\n\xe2\x80\x98Zero-day\xe2\x80\x99 stockpiling puts us all at\xc2\xa0risk\nTweet\nShare\nGet newsletter\nNewsletter\nMost popular on The Conversation\nWhy Easter is called Easter, and other little-known facts about the\xc2\xa0holiday\nIf my measles shot was years ago, am I still protected? 5 questions\xc2\xa0answered\nOur calculator will guess how many healthy years of life you have\xc2\xa0left\nThe new digital divide is between people who opt out of algorithms and people who\xc2\xa0don\xe2\x80\x99t\nCan changing the microbiome reverse lactose intolerance?\nNew cholesterol study may lead you to ask: Pass the eggs, or pass on the\xc2\xa0eggs?\nMapping the US counties where traffic air pollution hurts children the\xc2\xa0most\nWho are Sri Lanka\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Christians?\nDoes a year in space make you older or\xc2\xa0younger?\nHow Columbine became a blueprint for school\xc2\xa0shooters\nExpert Database\nFind experts with knowledge in:*\nWant to write?\nWrite an article and join a growing community of more than 82,900 academics and researchers from 2,816 institutions.\nRegister now\nThe Conversation\nCommunity\nCommunity standards\nRepublishing guidelines\nFriends of The Conversation\nResearch and Expert Database\nAnalytics\nOur feeds\nDonate\nCompany\nWho we are\nOur charter\nOur team\nPartners and funders\nResource for media\nContact us\nWork with us\nEn Espa\xc3\xb1ol\nStay informed and subscribe to our free daily newsletter and get the latest analysis and commentary directly in your inbox.\nEmail address\n\xe2\x9c\x94\nFollow us on social media\nPrivacy policy\nTerms and conditions\nCorrections\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2010\xe2\x80\x932019, The Conversation US, Inc."

Here are the latest Insider stories.\nHow to fix six Windows 10 headaches\nGoogle hopes AI, collaboration will win G Suite customers\nMicrosoft surrenders control over Windows 10 upgrades: What you need to know\nWindows 10 update (and retirement) calendar: Mark these dates\nMore Insider\nSign Out\nSearch for\nSuggestions for you\nInsider email\nBrowsers\nCloud Computing\nAll Cloud Downloads\nNewsletters\nComputerworld Events\nResources/White Papers\n\xc3\x97\nClose\nHome\nEmerging Technology\nFeature\nNew York gets smarter, one tech trial at a time (with video)\nWi-Fi kiosks, smart park benches and sensors that detect gunshots are just a few of the technologies the Big Apple has on tap.\nEmail a friend\nTo\nUse commas to separate multiple email addresses\nFrom\nPrivacy Policy\nThank you\nYour message has been sent.\nSorry\nThere was an error emailing this page.\nBy Matt Hamblen\nSenior Editor,\nComputerworld |\nPT\nSmart Cities\nSmart Cities: New York\n(8:55)\nSmart Cities: New York\n(8:55)\nMore for you to like:\nSmart Cities: Singapore\nSmart Cities: Singapore\n(13:05)\nSmart Cities: Barcelona\nSmart Cities: Barcelona\nSmart Cities: Montreal\nSmart Cities: Montreal\n(14:56)\nNew York\'s smart city strategy centers around multiple small pilot projects. Computerworld pounded the Manhattan pavement to see how citizens are taking to the tech changes around them.\nCurrent Job Listings\nSmart city technology beta projects and pilot programs are gaining ground in New York City. Walk around the Big Apple, as Computerworld did recently, and you encounter everything from free public Wi-Fi to smart park benches and even sophisticated listening devices that can detect gunshots to allow a quick police response.\nMuch of this wide-ranging tech focus goes back to 2014 when Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed the city\'s first Chief Technology Officer. He picked private sector tech veteran Minerva Tantoco for the role.\xc2\xa0During her tenure, she made a practice of pushing for small tech trials that could be modified and adjusted before being expanded.\n"Taking a page from the CTO playbook is the concept of using pilots and prototypes," Tantoco\nsaid in a video interview with Computerworld recorded at City Hall in June of 2016. "The way you do that is create small tests of tech before you take them citywide. That actually has the effect of \'de-risking\' the project on a wide scale," she said. "It\'s a fairly common tech approach, but not so common in government. So this is where some my private sector experience is being brought to the public sector role."\ncourtesy photo\nNew York CTO Miquel Gami\xc3\xb1o Jr.\nTantoco served nearly two years in her city CTO post before departing Aug. 31, 2016 to return to the private sector as senior advisor of Future\\Perfect Ventures, a woman-run tech venture capital firm. On Oct. 25, De Blasio named her replacement, Miguel Gami\xc3\xb1o Jr., a former CIO for both San Francisco and El Paso, Texas, and co-founder of the Council of Global City CIOs.\nAs CTO, Gami\xc3\xb1o works with all city agencies to further New York\'s smart city and internet of things initiatives and has taken the lead on city\'s broadband program, which was previously led by the counsel to the mayor.\nTo find out more about New York\'s smart city prowess, Computerworld strolled the sidewalks of Manhattan over two days. Here\'s what we found.\nFree Wi-Fi on city streets\nOne of the most ambitious tech projects underway in New York, LinkNYC is intended to replace the city\'s 7,500 eyesore pay phones on city sidewalks with permanent Link kiosks. The kiosks, slated to be installed in all five city boroughs over eight years, provide fast, free Wi-Fi, device charging and a tablet computer for accessing city services, maps and directions.\xc2\xa0Free public internet calls are also possible from the units, and there\'s also a red 911 button that can be pushed to call emergency services.\n[ Take this mobile device management course from PluralSight and learn how to secure devices in your company without degrading the user experience. ]\nNYC Mayor\'s Office\nNew York City Mayor Bill de Blasio tried out a LinkNYC Wi-Fi kiosk soon after test units were rolled out.\nA team of city leaders helped shape the project in 2015, which is now under franchise by a consortium called CityBridge that includes telecommunications heavyweight Qualcomm, among others. CityBridge won a 12-year franchise from the city to build the kiosks on the footprint of thousands of former phone booths. The organization is investing more than $200 million to install fiber optic cable for the kiosks, which are funded by revenue from advertising -- large, full-color displays on the sides of the kiosks.\nAmong a number of challenges identified by the New York Times and others,\nsome critics have questioned the privacy of personal data of users of the machines. There is a guarantee to users that any personal identifiable data they enter into the tablet will be encrypted and that user data won\'t be sold to third parties. (LinkNYC does collect some user data to monitor how well the system is working and determine how many people are using it, primarily to be able to sell ads.)\nCity Wi-Fi: Too much of a good thing?\nWhen they launched in January 2016, New York City\'s LinkNYC kiosks offered free web browsing via built-in Android tablets, but browsing was shut down in September "to curb long-term use of the kiosks," according to LinkNYC\'s website. There were reports early on that users were lingering at the kiosks for hours, browsing porn sites or playing loud music, according to the New York Times and other sources.\nAt one point early in 2016, LinkNYC installed porn filtering software and dimmed the volume and brightness of the tablet displays at night to respond to community objections. But by September, amid continued complaints, LinkNYC\nremoved the browsing capability.\nMore than 450 kiosks were installed by Dec. 1, 2016 in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. The project rollout fell behind a midsummer goal of 500 kiosk installations, partly because access was hindered to manholes and other under-street locations for fiber optic cable, according to a LinkNYC spokeswoman.\nHowever, the total goal of more than 7,000 kiosks is still envisioned, and the beta project is moving ahead. LinkNYC says its core mission is to provide free phone calls and free, fast Wi-Fi, adding that a team is investigating adding new features such as a direct portal to a voter registration form.\n[ Video profile:\nSmart Cities - Singapore ]\nCity leaders from around the world are watching how LinkNYC unfolds. That\'s because free public Wi-Fi has a spotty record -- at least in some large cities.\xc2\xa0Barcelona promotes its\xc2\xa0free Wi-Fi at beaches and other gathering spots, but maintaining outdoor equipment and keeping speeds fast enough for users has clearly been a challenge.\xc2\xa0Seattle and Mountain View, Calif., offered free Wi-Fi as early as 2005, then backed off due to high costs or limited wireless capacity.\nSmart park benches\nOne of the more charming uses of smart tech in New York is being tested with several park benches installed in High Bridge Park at 175th and Amsterdam in Manhattan.\xc2\xa0The solar-powered benches, designed by Soofa, a startup with connections to the MIT Media Lab, allow park visitors to charge a smartphone or other device while resting, socializing or sunbathing.\nChanging Environments Inc.\nThe Soofa smart park bench.\nThe smart benches also allow park officials to count Wi-Fi-enabled devices as they pass by, which allows them to estimate foot traffic and in turn determine if more security or trash removal might be needed in an\xc2\xa0area of a park.\nAssuaging citizen concerns, the Soofa pilot incorporates a set of internet of things guidelines created by the city which govern privacy and security concerns for new devices.\nFaster bus rides\nMeanwhile, for frantic commuters, New York is testing smart bus technology to speed up their rides. The Traffic Signal Priority project, along a bus line in busy lower Manhattan, allows buses equipped with GPS to connect into the existing traffic signal control network. When a bus is stopped for a red light, for example, the system can shorten the amount of time the light is red to allow the bus to move ahead, or the system can extend the green time for an approaching bus.\nThe technology, first piloted in 2012, appears to be taking hold. Results from 2016 showed a savings in bus commute time of up to 20%, and as of January 2017, the city has four bus corridors equipped with the prioritization technology, according to a New York City Department of Transportation spokeswoman. An additional three corridors are under study, and six more are being considered for future operations, she adds.\n[ Video profile:\nSmart Cities - Barcelona ]\nThe system also could help reduce the number of single-occupant vehicles on the city\'s congested streets, according to Doug Newcomb, an analyst and president of C3 Group.\xc2\xa0Since New York has more than 5,700 buses operating 2,800 miles of routes used for 2.5 million bus rides every day, a 20% savings over an expanded base of riders could\xc2\xa0make a significant dent in congestion.\nWhat\'s more, in perhaps a decade, many cities like New York could be deploying high-occupancy driverless buses along those same routes, further reducing congestion, Newcomb says.\nIdentifying individual gunshots\nOne of New York\'s more unusual and recent tech projects is designed to help fight crime.\xc2\xa0ShotSpotter relies on sophisticated rooftop listening sensors and software to identify the\xc2\xa0acoustic fingerprint of gunfire. (A 2015 city document, Building a Smart + Equitable City, describes the project on page 18.)\nThree sensors are used to triangulate a gunshot sound and report the location of the gunshot, within 27 yards, to the nearest police precinct in about one minute.\xc2\xa0(For more on how the technology works, see Cool cop tech: 5 new technologies helping police fight crime.)\nAfter a year-long test over 15 square miles in the Bronx and Brooklyn, police found that 73% of the shots detected by ShotSpotter had not been reported by citizens, sometimes, perhaps, because they didn\'t recognize the noise as a gunshot. Police found the initial test effective in helping them respond to crimes faster; the technology has been expanded to 24 square miles, including in upper Manhattan.\nWhat the future holds . . .\nNew York City has many other smart initiatives in the test phase -- including technologies to more efficiently use water, dispose of trash, protect the air and make it easier to find and use city services.\n[ Further reading:\n5 disruptive technologies to track in 2017\n]\nFor now, city officials only laugh when asked whether New York will allow flying, driverless cars over Manhattan skyscrapers. But stay tuned: At the rate at which New York is adopting smart city technology, flying cars might yet be on the docket and in the air.\nRelated:\nEmerging Technology\nMobile\nInternet of Things\nICYMI\nMatt Hamblen is a multi-media journalist covering mobile, networking and smart city tech. He previously was a senior editor at Computerworld.\nFollow\nHow collaboration apps foster digital transformation\nShop Tech Products at Amazon\nSponsored Links\ndtSearch\xc2\xae instantly searches terabytes of files, emails, databases, web data.\nSee site for hundreds of reviews; enterprise & developer evaluations\nOnline Master of Science in Information Systems at Northwestern University\nThe future of ITSM is Cognitive Services.\nHumanizing the Digital Experience\nThe Modern IT Infrastructure Insight Report\nRising to the Security in the Cloud Challenge\n5 Great Reasons to Make Electronic Signatures Part of Your Business\nComputerworld\nThe Voice of Business Technology\nFollow us\nBrowsers\nCloud Computing\nData Centers\nEmerging Technology\nHardware\nIT Leadership\nInternet\nMobile\nOperating Systems\nSecurity\nSoftware\nVertical Industries\nNews\nFeatures\nReviews\nBlogs\nOpinions\nInsider\nShark Tank\nSlideshows\nVideo\nNewsletters\nComputerworld Events\nResources/White Papers\nAbout Us\nContact\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nMember Preferences\nAdvertising\nIDG Careers\nAd Choices\nE-commerce Links\nEditorial Beats\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 IDG Communications, Inc.\nExplore the IDG Network descend\nCIO\nComputerworld\nCSO\nIDC\nIDG\nIDG Connect\nInfoWorld\nITwhitepapers\nJavaWorld\nNetwork World'
p56
aS"LinkNYC Disables Internet From Hubs After Porn Use | Digital Trends\nDigital Trends\nMore\nProduct Reviews\nNews\nVideos\nFeatures\nBest Products\nHow To\nDeals\nEspa\xc3\xb1ol\nMenu\nSearch\nBack to Menu\nMore\nTech for Change\nAwards We Offer\nSend Us Your News Tip\nGiveaways\nDT Espa\xc3\xb1ol\nThe Manual\nWho We Are\nAbout Us\nCareers\nAdvertise\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Use\nContact Us\nSocial\nLinkedIn\nPinterest\nYouTube\nGoogle+\nRSS Home\nNewsletter\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nCategories\nPhones\nTVs\nLaptops\nCars\nGames\nHeadphones\nCameras\nDesktops\nSmart Home\nAppliances\nSmartwatches\nPrinters\nSoundbars\nStreaming Devices\nMonitors\nMore Product Reviews\nTopics\nMobile\nHome Theater\nComputing\nGaming\nCars\nPhotography\nSmart Home\nMovies & TV\nMusic\nEmerging Tech\n5G\nBusiness\nSocial Media\nVirtual Reality\nWearables\nApple\nMore News\nOriginal Series\nDigital Trends Live\nTrends with Benefits\nBetween the Streams\nBehind the Wheel\nAwesome Tech You Can\xe2\x80\x99t Buy Yet\nInnovators: And now for something amazing\nHands-On\nConnect my Crib\nTech for Less\nThe Deets\nTheUnlockr\nVs.\nMore Videos\nOriginal Series\nWomen With Byte\nTech for Change\nInnovators\nBacklog\n(in)Secure\nSmart Cities\nRoad Rave\nBlockchain\nMore Features\nBest of Everything\nTVs\nSmartphones\nLaptops\nDesktops\nHeadphones\nSoundbars\nCameras\nDrones\nStreaming Devices\n3D Printers\nMonitors\nHome Security Systems\nPrinters\nGame Consoles\nPlaystation 4 Games\nXbox One Games\nMore Best Products\nShare on Facebook\nTweet this\nShare\nWeb\nPublic internet removed from New York kiosks after wide-spread porn usage\nBy\nLulu Chang\n@luchanglu\n\xe2\x80\x94\nPosted on\nSeptember 14, 2016\n2:23PM PST\n09.14.16 -\n2:23PM PST\nShare on Facebook\nTweet this\nShare\nWant to know why we can\xe2\x80\x99t have nice things?\xc2\xa0Because apparently, the public \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 or at least parts of New York \xe2\x80\x94 is not to be trusted.\nEight months after the appearance of the first LinkNYC hubs, which are \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 or were \xe2\x80\x94 internet kiosks meant to help bring the Big Apple into the 21st century, the city has taken a step back. Some of these kiosks were not used to \xe2\x80\x9csave data on their mobile plans, call relatives across the country, and get a much-needed quick charge\xe2\x80\x9d as they were originally intended. Instead, they were used to watch pornography.\nPer an announcement from the LinkNYC team, \xe2\x80\x9cWe \xe2\x80\xa6 know that some users have been monopolizing the Link tablets and using them inappropriately, preventing others from being able to use them while frustrating the residents and businesses around them. The kiosks were never intended for anyone\xe2\x80\x99s extended, personal use and we want to ensure that Links are accessible and a welcome addition to New York City neighborhoods.\xe2\x80\x9d Which, as it turns out, they were not, particularly along Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s 8th Avenue, where abuse of the kiosks was particularly rampant.\nThe decision was released shortly after Motherboard published its own\xc2\xa0report\xc2\xa0examining the prevalence of homeless men stationing themselves in front of the LinkNYC hubs to use the internet. Evidently, the hubs have also become hotspots for public drinking and drug use \xe2\x80\x94 \xc2\xa0the opposite of the hubs\xe2\x80\x99 original intention to \xe2\x80\x9cimprove the quality of life.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs New Yorkers ourselves, we want LinkNYC to provide the best possible experience for Link users and the communities around them,\xe2\x80\x9d LinkNYC said. As of Wednesday, that includes, \xe2\x80\x9cremoving web browsing on all Link tablets while we work with the City and community to explore potential solutions, like time limits\xe2\x80\x9d that mitigate some of the problems the hubs\xc2\xa0are experiencing.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOther tablet features \xe2\x80\x94 free phone calls, maps, device charging, and access to 311 and 911 \xe2\x80\x94 will continue to work as they did before, and nothing is changing about LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s superfast Wi-Fi,\xe2\x80\x9d the team notes.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cAs planned, we will continue to improve the Link experience and add new features for people to enjoy while they\xe2\x80\x99re on the go.\xe2\x80\x9d\nEditors' Recommendations\nThe best moneymaking apps for Android and iOS\nFacebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp went down worldwide for 2 hours this morning\nHow big screens and small explosions shaped the VFX of Solo: A Star Wars Story\nSonos Beam review\nAdobe gives peek at 7 advertising projects that may make their way to all of us\nDon't Miss\nThe best Chromebooks for 2019\nUp Next\nSony unveils its first 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray player, $15K HDR projector\nRelated on DT\nHome Theater\nSonos Beam review\nCars\n21 charged in Chicago carsharing heist; 100+ cars stolen, many still\xe2\x80\xa6\nProduct Review\nIt sounds like a Sonos, but the Beam pulls one trick none of its siblings can\nSonos makes really good surround sound speakers for home theaters, but they\xe2\x80\x99re expensive. aS"New York City\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99 To Replace Payphones With 10K Internet Pylons For Free Public Wi-Fi\nGoogle Tag Manager\nApr 23, 5:58 PM EDT\nNewsletter Signup\nSearch\nBusinessTechnologyWorldNationalMedia & CultureOpinionSportsLuxury\nTechnology\nNew York City\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99 To Replace Payphones With 10K Internet Pylons For Free Public Wi-Fi By\nKukil Bora\n@KukilBora\n11/18/14 AT 4:19 AM\nThe construction of the network will begin in 2015, and the first structures will become operational by the year\xe2\x80\x99s end.\nPhoto: LinkNYC, Flickr\nNew York City is planning to replace public payphones with a new communications network expected to \xe2\x80\x9cbring the fastest available municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers,\xe2\x80\x9d for free. The construction of the network will begin in 2015, and the first structures will become operational by the year\xe2\x80\x99s end.As part of a new plan dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC,\xe2\x80\x9d the city\xe2\x80\x99s aging payphone system will make way for the deployment of 10,000 Wi-Fi hubs, called \xe2\x80\x9cLinks,\xe2\x80\x9d which will be installed across all five boroughs of New York. In addition to being free Wi-Fi hubs that can run up to gigabit speeds seven days a week, \xe2\x80\x9cLinks\xe2\x80\x9d also offer other services, including free phone calls anywhere within the U.S., easy access to 911 and 311 calls, and a free charging station for mobile devices.\nLinkNYC is a first-of-its-kind communications network that will bring the fastest available municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers, small businesses, and visitors. Photo: LinkNYC, Flickr\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cLinks\xe2\x80\x9d Wi-Fi hubs \xe2\x80\x9cwill be funded through advertising revenues, will be built at no cost to taxpayers, and will generate more than $500 million in revenue for the City over the first 12 years,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the LinkNYC website.\nThe Link structures will include a touchscreen tablet interface to help people access city services, directions and other features. The physical pillars will also have digital displays for advertising and public service announcements.While LinkNYC has said that the upcoming service will offer gigabit speeds, the claim has raised some eyebrows as commonly used Wi-Fi networks do not yet support sustained gigabit connections from individual devices, The Verge reported.\nThe Link structures will include a touchscreen tablet interface to help people access city services, directions and other services.\nPhoto: LinkNYC, Flickr\nLinkNYC does not say which Wi-Fi standard will be used in the Links pylons, but it claims that \xe2\x80\x9cgigabit Wi-Fi is more than a 100 times faster than the average public Wi-Fi and more than 20 times faster than the average home Internet service in NYC. Downloading a two-hour HD movie can take as little as 30 seconds.\xe2\x80\x9dAccording to LinkNYC, the service will offer an encrypted network connection between the user and a hotspot.\xe2\x80\x9cWe encourage you to continue to use end-to-end encryption, such as HTTPS, for any sensitive matters or data\xe2\x80\xa6 The network will also prevent peer-to-peer security threats by eliminating the ability to communicate device to device,\xe2\x80\x9d LinkNYC said in a statement.The LinkNYC project is the result of a partnership between the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Technology and Innovation, the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, and CityBridge, a New York City-based consortium.\nLoading...\nMost Read\nStay up to date with our daily newsletterRelated StoriesNew York's Skyline In 2018 Revealed In PhotosGoogle Prepares To Deliver Ultra-Fast Internet Service: Report\nLatest News Android App Leaked 2 Million Private WiFi Passwords Online\nKim-Putin Summit Scheduled For This Weekend\nAfrica Receives Malaria Vaccine From WHO\nAmazon Gives Up On Challenging Alibaba And JD.com In China\nWoman Hacked Facebook Accounts To Recruit For ISIS\nTesla 'Robotaxi' Could Be The Next Uber\nYour Smart Speaker Now Comes With Free Music\nAmazon Returns Just Got Easier With The Help Of Kohl\xe2\x80\x99s\nIBTAbout UsAdvertise with UsMedia KitTerms & ConditionsPrivacy PolicyCookie PolicyEditionsAustraliaChinaIndiaSingaporeUnited KingdomUnited States\xc2\xa9 Copyright 2019 IBT Media Inc. All Rights Reserved."

aS"Could Public Wifi Like LinkNYC Replace Your Data Plan? | InverseExploreFollowInnovationInternet of ThingsShareSubscribeThe Internet Will Be New York's Biggest Public ParkThe free wifi insurgency will not be stopped.By Jack Crosbie on July 26, 2016Filed Under GoogleNew York City\xe2\x80\x99s remaining pay phones are, much to the chagrin of public urinators, are on their way out. LinkNYC, a New York-based communications company, is steadily replacing those obsolete boxes with public wifi installations. It\xe2\x80\x99s a sidewalk land grab to be sure, but its also the future of the city\xe2\x80\x99s public data infrastructure. Over the next several years, LinkNYC plans to install 7,500 of its kiosks across New York City\xe2\x80\x99s five boroughs. The kiosks offer free public wifi, and promise speeds 100 times faster than other public wifi networks and mobile LTE connections. They have two USB ports for charging devices, a tablet interface for browsing the web and making free phone calls, and an emergency 911 button. They\xe2\x80\x99ve been called a magnets for the homeless, drug deal hubs, and, by city officials, a massive success. According to company stats, the LinkNYC network has been used more than five million times since its debut, and 15,000 people use it for the first time every week.Here\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable: During those millions of visits, users aren\xe2\x80\x99t taking up that much bandwidth. As of June 20, LinkNYC users have used 53.77 terabytes of data in 6,691,186 sessions. On average, that means that each session uses about eight megabytes of data. To put that in context, browsing Facebook on a mobile device usually takes up about two megabytes of data per minute, so each LinkNYC session only equates to about 4-5 minutes on Facebook. The average wireless customer uses 1.8 gigabytes, (roughly 1,800 megabytes) of data per month, so it would take a lot of trips to a LinkNYC kiosk to equal that amount of browsing. This is what the birth of a utility \xe2\x80\x94 or a new type of public space \xe2\x80\x94 looks like. Nothing happens all at once.LinkNYC is operating nowhere near capacity, but there\xe2\x80\x99s reason to believe that New Yorkers will come around and begin using it as a resource to speed their browsing while avoiding hitting their carriers\xe2\x80\x99 data limits. Still, as the LinkNYC terminals expand to cover more of the city, it\xe2\x80\x99s possible that they could expand wifi coverage to a lot of New Yorkers. Office buildings and work sites have wifi networks, so for most people, the only time they rely on data networks is while they\xe2\x80\x99re in public above ground. This is where LinkNYC comes in and why it represents such a critical last link in a chain.But it isn\xe2\x80\x99t that easy.Free, fast public wifi might not be as simple as it sounds. The Link terminals are funded by advertising that\xe2\x80\x99s displayed on large LCD screens on their sides, but the company has some powerful backers: LinkNYC is the result of a group of companies called CityBridge, which include Qualcomm, CIVIQ Smartscapes, and Intersection. Intersection is itself a merger between Control Group, a technology and design consultant, and the advertising company Titan (the logo of which you\xe2\x80\x99d see on pay phones), which is in turn owned by a company called Sidewalk Labs. Sidewalk Labs is owned by Alphabet, the umbrella corporation that, for all intents and purposes, ties together everything that we refer to as \xe2\x80\x9cGoogle.\xe2\x80\x9dA man listens to music while charging his phone from a LinkNYC terminal on 8th Avenue and West 14th Street in Manhattan.\xc2\xa0Of course, the web of tech startups leading back to one of Silicon Valley\xe2\x80\x99s kingpins is nothing new: That recent Voice story conveys concerns about the concept of happily linking devices and sharing data with LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s omnipresent installation are ultimately owned by one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful and ubiquitous companies.The inherent privacy concerns are so strong that some digital rights advocates refer to Link terminals as \xe2\x80\x9cspy stations,\xe2\x80\x9d paranoid about their bank of cameras on top and monitoring capabilities. At a panel on Sunday at New York\xe2\x80\x99s HOPE Convention, hackers and privacy advocates discussed the intricacies of LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policies.\xe2\x80\x9cFree wifi comes with a cost, and that cost is in terms of security most of the time,\xe2\x80\x9d Benjamin Dean, a fellow at Columbia University and the founder of Iconoclast Tech said during the panel. \xe2\x80\x9cAs we all know that when you\xe2\x80\x99re not paying, you\xe2\x80\x99re not the customer, you\xe2\x80\x99re the product.\xe2\x80\x9dSponsoredWHAT'S THE GREENEST ROUTE FROM LA TO NYC??Join Shell for The Great Travel Hack, an energy conscious roadtrip across the country.Watch More \xc2\xbbLinkNYC flatly denies that they will sell anybody\xe2\x80\x99s personal information. A spokesperson for the company tells Inverse that it would keep its hands off data from personal devices hooked up to the wifi service:\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC does not collect or store any data on users\xe2\x80\x99 personal web browsing on their own devices,\xe2\x80\x9d the spokesperson tells Inverse. \xe2\x80\x9cCityBridge will never sell any user\xe2\x80\x99s personal information or share with third parties for their own use. This includes the city, law enforcement, investors, vendors, partners, and advertisers. Alphabet, Sidewalk Labs, and Google are all third parties to CityBridge.\xe2\x80\x9dIn other words, LinkNYC and CityBridge, despite their financial and ownership ties to Alphabet and its subsidiaries, are considered separate companies, and assert that they won\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9csell user\xe2\x80\x99s personal information.\xe2\x80\x9dThe company\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy, however, is far more vague. The most accessible privacy policy is linked to on the company\xe2\x80\x99s website, but only relates to the website www.link.nyc. The terminal-specific privacy policy is linked to on the same page and is a far more dense document governing the specific rights and permissions users grant the company when they sign on to a terminal or connect their device to wifi. There are two wifi networks, one of which is public, and one of which is private and has better security and privacy protections. Both are available for anyone to use, but accessing the private network requires a device running iOS 7 or better \xe2\x80\x94 something critics of LinkNYC say will only heighten the technological divide between New York\xe2\x80\x99s social classes. For one, the people most likely to use free wifi services are those who don\xe2\x80\x99t have networks in their home. Lower-income socioeconomic groups, which are predominantly black or latino in New York City, are also subject to far more police surveillance even without camera-equipped terminals.Skepticism of a \xe2\x80\x9ctoo good to be true\xe2\x80\x9d promise of free, blazing-fast public wifi is healthy, but for the average user, hopping on to a LinkNYC terminal probably won\xe2\x80\x99t tie your data to Google\xe2\x80\x99s vast network any more than it already is. Still, being able to accept a reasonable amount of compromised privacy is a privilege enjoyed most by communities who have little to fear from government or law enforcement. Like the subway, cheap hole-in-the-wall restraints, hot dog carts, and \xe2\x80\x9cauthentic\xe2\x80\x9d Oakley sunglasses vendors in Central Park, LinkNYC users do so at their own risk.\nMedia via Jack Crosbie, Young Suk YunRelated StoriesMove Into the Future With the Best Smart Switches, S...Top 6 Amazon Smart Home ProductsIBM Is Fitting Europe\xe2\x80\x99s Biggest Port to Support Auto...Forget the Apple Watch, an Incredible Teen DIY'ed Hi...Bitcoin's Bottom Hasn't Arrived: 5 Reasons the Crypt...Follow inverse on FacebookFollow humans+ on FacebookFollow star wars on FacebookFollow science & chill on FacebookFollow inverse on FlipboardFollow inverse on Apple NewsWatch your brain on blank on FacebookSign up for our newslettersign upAboutTopicsArchiveBrowsePrivacyCommerceTermsDMCACorrectionsNewsletter Contest2019FiltersSort by relevanceSort by recentSort by oldestScienceInnovationEntertainmentCultureMind & BodyBrave New WorldsBrave New WorldsHumans+Humans+Life in SpaceLife in SpacePoint BPoint BReplicantReplicantScience & ChillScience & ChillAboutTopicsArchiveBrowsePrivacyCommerceTermsDMCACorrectionsNewsletter Contest2019"
p59

Watch\nShop\nCoupons\nPCMag Shop\nDeals\nSearch\nSubscribe:\nSubscribe\nEmail\nSearch\nSearch for\nClose\nArrow_Path\nSurfaceHub2S\nSamsungGalaxyFold\nPlayStation5\nSpringCleaning\n5G\nNews & Analysis/\nHands On With the Free Android Tablets at LinkNYC\'s Sidewalk Kiosks\nNew York City residents and visitors can access the Internet and make phone calls for free at the sidewalk kiosks.\nBy\nTom Brant\nFebruary 18, 2016 12:00PM EST\nFebruary 18, 2016\nPCMag reviews products independently, but we may earn affiliate commissions from buying links on this page. Terms of use.\nWith LinkNYC\'s blazing-fast Wi-Fi already operational, the public-private consortium today activated the other innovative feature that its sleek boxes provide: a built-in Android tablet.\nThat\'s right, New York City residents and visitors now have free access to Internet-connected tablets at each one of the dozens of LinkNYC stations installed so far. Mayor Bill DeBlasio\xc2\xa0today\xc2\xa0joined other city officials and representatives from the LinkNYC consortium to declare the kiosks fully operational. But earlier this week PCMag got a hands-on preview of the tablets, which are custom-designed for the kiosks\xc2\xa0and powered by Qualcomm processors.\nFor now, the options are fairly simple. You can browse the Internet, access city services, get maps and directions, and make free phone calls to any U.S. number.\nEach of the functions will feel familiar to anyone who\'s used an Android tablet. After tapping on the Internet icon at the bottom of the screen, we browsed to YouTube and started streaming a video, which loaded instantly thanks to the gigabit Wi-Fi\xc2\xa0the kiosks also provide.\nFor city services and maps, LinkNYC provides a link to the 311 web app (New York City\'s information service) and the Google Maps app. They both work the same as they would on your own tablet.\nPhone calls use VOIP and are powered by Vonage in an interface that looks very similar to the Vonage Android app,\xc2\xa0minus your personal address book and Vonage credit for international calling. In addition to using the screen,\xc2\xa0you can type numbers on\xc2\xa0the keypad built into the kiosk.\nA built-in speaker will broadcast the voice of whoever\'s on the other end of the line. It\'s loud enough to be heard over honking taxis and idling delivery truck engines, but that also means anyone walking by will be able to hear both sides of your conversation. A standard 35mm audio jack is provided should you want a little more privacy. There\'s also a one-touch 911 button placed prominently next to the keypad for emergency use.\nFinally, two USB charging ports are also available next to the tablet. We can\'t imagine using them in the winter, but when the weather\'s nice, the combination of power and a tablet to use while you\'re waiting for a charge to revive your dead phone could be handy.\nOne thing we noticed about the screen was that it feels like tapping on a window pane rather than a tablet display. That\'s understandable, since it\'s tested to withstand temperatures as low as -20C, vandalism, and even a vehicle crashing into it, according to a LinkNYC spokesperson.\nThe toughness means that it\'s not quite as responsive as you\'d expect from a tablet. In some instances, it took more than one tap before the tablet recognized our input.\nRelated\nLinkNYC Wi-Fi Hotspots Tested: They Crush Starbucks\nLinkNYC Wi-Fi Hotspots Tested: They Crush Starbucks\nThe tablets take security seriously. After a minute or two of no inputs, the session will automatically end and all data will be erased. Users can also tap an "end session" button when they\'re finished to manually log out.\nThough the current functionality is pretty basic, LinkNYC has big plans for the future. The consortium will roll out more apps and services, including a planned community events calendar, as more stations are installed.\nTo find the one nearest you (hint: all of the currently operational stations are along 3rd Avenue in Manhattan), check the map on LinkNYC\'s website. By July, 510 kiosks will be installed in all five boroughs, with the full 7,500-strong network planned to be finished in four years.\nTop\nRead More\nIndonesia Bans Tumblr, Because Porn\nNews & Analysis\nIndonesia Bans Tumblr, Because Porn\nSkype Brings Group Video Calling to Mobile Phones, Tablets\nNews & Analysis Skype Brings Group Video Calling to Mobile Phones, Tablets\nAbout the Author\nTom Brant\nAs a hardware analyst, Tom tests and reviews laptops, peripherals, and much more at PC Labs in New York City. He previously covered the consumer tech beat as a news reporter for PCMag in San Francisco and Silicon Valley, where he rode in several self-driving cars and witnessed the rise and fall of many startups. Before that, he worked for PCMag\'s s... aS'Wi-Fi kiosks will replace Bronx pay phones under city initiative LinkNYC - New York Daily News Wi-Fi kiosks will replace Bronx pay phones under city initiative LinkNYC\nSkip to content\nTopics\nxml:space="preserve">\nSubscriber Services\nManage Subscription\nEZ Pay\nDelivery Issue\nSubscriber Terms\nNew York\nNYC Crime\nBronx\nBrooklyn\nManhattan\nQueens\nEducation\nObituaries\nWeather\nSports\nYankees\nMets\nGiants\nJets\nKnicks\nNets\nRangers\nIslanders\nFootball\nBasketball\nBaseball\nHockey\nSoccer\nMore Sports\nI\'d Click That\nOdds\nGolf\nNews\nCrime\nU.S.\nPolitics\nWorld\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nHealth\nEats\nViva\nGames\nBest Reviews\nOpinion\nPhotos\nHoroscopes\nDaily\nE-Newspaper\nAutos\nCovers\nSpecial Sections\nClassifieds\nPublic Notices\nBranded Content\nPaid Partner Content\nPaid Content By Brandpoint\nSearch\nxml:space="preserve">\nNew York\nSports\nNews\nEntertainment\nOpinion\nAdvertisement\nAdvertisement\nBronx\nNew York\nWi-Fi kiosks will replace Bronx pay phones under city initiative LinkNYC\nBy Ginger Adams Otis\n| NEW YORK DAILY NEWS |\nAug 30, 2016\n|\n10:54 PM\nNew Wi-Fi kiosk that will be implemented in the Bronx will offer free web surfing, phone calls and charging stations. (Spencer Platt/Getty Images)\nTwenty pay phones bit the dust in the Bronx \xe2\x80\x94 to be replaced with high-tech Wi-Fi kiosks, officials said Tuesday.\nThe pay phones were relegated to history to make room for LinkNYC, the largest municipal Wi-Fi network in the world.\nAdvertisement\nThe launch of LinkNYC in the Bronx will bring kiosks connected to high-speed fiber optic cables to the borough.\nThe kiosks also let passersby connect to the Web, as well as charge their phones at special ports.\nRuben Diaz Jr., Bronx Borough President, says LinkNYC is helping the borough to take "yet another giant step forward towards providing better communication access for city residents." (Jeremy Bales/for New York Daily News)\nThe city plans to install 4,550 kiosks across the city by July 2019. There are 25 now in the Bronx \xe2\x80\x94 with about 700 more on the way.\n"LinkNYC is taking yet another giant step forward towards providing better communication access for city residents," Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr. said. "(It\'s) an important part of our continued push for social and technological equality."\ntechnology\nruben diaz jr.\nAdvertisement\nRecommended'
p61
aS'LinkNYC\'s free gigabit WiFi officially launches, we go hands-on\nEngadget\nLogin\nHome\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer\'s Guide\nVideo\nReviews\nLog in\nSign up\nShow More Results\nEngadget\n3 related articles\nLogin\nTwitter CEO Jack Dorsey met with Donald Trump today\nThese gaming laptops pack the latest Intel and NVIDIA hardware\nApple offers next-day repairs for faulty MacBook keyboards\nLatest in Gear\nThese gaming laptops pack the latest Intel and NVIDIA hardware\n1h ago\nView\nApple offers next-day repairs for faulty MacBook keyboards\n2h ago\nView\nAcer updates select laptops with the latest from Intel and NVIDIA\n3h ago\nView\nReturn your Amazon orders to any Kohl\'s store starting in July\n4h ago\nView\nImage credit: Devindra Hardawar/Engadget\nsave\nSave\nshare\nLinkNYC\'s free gigabit WiFi officially launches, we go hands-on\nAfter a month of beta testing, LinkNYC finally enables its built-in tablets with free VoIP calls.\nDevindra Hardawar, @devindra\n02.18.16\nComments\n171\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nQualcomm VP Kiva Allgood tests out a LinkNYC hotspot\nDevindra Hardawar/Engadget\nA month ago, we were hot on LinkNYC\'s free gigabit WiFi hotspots when they kicked off beta testing. Today, the organization is officially launching its payphone replacement hotspots (or Links, for short) --- and with that, it\'s turning on their integrated tablets for the first time. That means you\'ll be able to do a lot more than just tap into blazing fast WiFi from the Links. You can also browse the web, get directions with Google Maps, and make free VoIP calls to anywhere in America. After testing out one of the tablets briefly, I can say one thing for sure: New Yorkers won\'t miss their dirty old payphones at all.\nGallery: LinkNYC tablet hands-on | 10 Photos\n10\n+6\nOn the surface, the Link\'s tablet doesn\'t appear much different than your average Android slate. It features a customized home screen with clearly labeled options: "Internet" opens up a web browser; "Free Calls" launches the dialer; "311" sends you right to NYC\'s services website (it\'s also the number New Yorkers dial for city help); and "Maps" does exactly what you\'d expect (it even uses the standard Google Maps icon).All of the apps worked without issue, and the performance felt like a typical mid-range tablet. That is to say, they\'re functional, but not exactly zippy. Interacting with the touch screen also takes more effort than usual, since the Links use two thick layers of glass to protect its hardware. Still, I can\'t imagine anyone would complain when it\'s free (LinkNYC makes money from ads displayed on screens on both sides of the hotspots).The front of the Links are designed specifically to avoid the accumulation of city grime. It\'s pretty much a flat surface -- there\'s no space for people to rest their food or drinks (thereby avoiding spills). Below the tablet there\'s a big read 911 button, a nostalgically designed dial pad, and two USB ports for charging your phone. (You\'ll have to bring your own charging cables, though.) LinkNYC\'s reps say their designers have experience creating military products, and that\'s evident in the Link\'s tough and utilitarian look. As part of their testing, they even crashed cars into the Links to make sure they wouldn\'t harm pedestrians.Eventually, LinkNYC plans to add even more tablet apps and signage capabilities. Links could make people aware of local events, or give updates on when nearby trains are arriving, for example. Since the tablets are based on Android, it wouldn\'t be too difficult for the organization to add more features (and perhaps even open the door for local developers to feature their apps). More than a dozen Links will be going live today along Third Avenue in Manhattan, and LinkNYC says it plans to have 500 up by July.As for LinkNYC\'s most compelling feature -- gigabit WiFi! -- I noticed that speeds were much slower than my previous test. Instead of around 300 megabits per second upload and download speeds, I saw around 70 Mbps down and 150 Mbps up. That\'s still damn impressive for free WiFi, especially compared to what most Americans have at home, but it\'ll be interesting to see if speeds fall any further as more people are connected to a single Link.\nIn this article:\nculture,\ngadgetry,\ngadgets,\ngear,\ninternet,\nLinkNYC\nBy Devindra Hardawar\n@devindra\nDevindra has been obsessed with technology for as long as he can remember -- starting with the first time he ever glimpsed an NES. He spent several years fixing other people\'s computers before he started down the treacherous path of writing about technology. Mission accomplished?\n171\nShares\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nSave\nComments\nSign In\n17m\n17m ago in\nAV\nWatch the trailer for Ang Lee\'s 120 fps film \'Gemini Man\'\nWill Smith battles... young Will Smith.\nBy\nC. Fisher,\n17m ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n59m\n59m ago in\nInternet\nTwitter CEO Jack Dorsey met with Donald Trump today\nPer a leaked internal email, it\'s about "the health of the public conversation."\nBy\nR. Lawler,\n59m ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nBusiness\nSnapchat\xe2\x80\x99s user base is growing again\nThe company had 190 million active users in Q1, four million more than the quarter before.\nBy\nN. Ingraham,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n1h\n1h ago in\nPersonal Computing\nThese gaming laptops pack the latest Intel and NVIDIA hardware\nIt\'s a good time to be a gamer on the go.\nBy\nJ. Fingas,\n1h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\n2h\n2h ago in\nServices\nApple offers next-day repairs for faulty MacBook keyboards\nNo sign yet that the company will actually fix the underlying design flaws.\nBy\nA. Dellinger,\n2h ago\nsave\nSave\nshare\nView\nMore Stories\nFrom around the web\nAbout\nAbout Engadget\nAbout Our Ads\nAdvertise\nBrand Kit\nBuyers Guide\nContact Us\nRSS Feed\nSections\nReviews\nGear\nGaming\nEntertainment\nTomorrow\nThe Buyer\'s Guide\nVideo\nPodcasts\nDeals\nContribute\nComment Guidelines\nSend us a tip!\nSupport\nInternational\n\xe7\xb9\x81\xe9\xab\x94\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe7\xae\x80\xe4\xbd\x93\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x96\x87\n\xe6\x97\xa5\xe6\x9c\xac\xe7\x89\x88\nUK\nApps\nAndroid\niPhone\niPad\nJoin Our Newsletter\nSubscribe\nFollow Us\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Verizon Media.
