aS'Is New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Public Wi-Fi Actually Connecting the Poor? - Motherboard\nGoogle|by Linda Huber|Sep 14 2016, 11:00amIs New York City\xe2\x80\x99s Public Wi-Fi Actually Connecting the Poor?I spent hours visiting LinkNYC internet kiosks to find out if they were helping bridge the digital divide.SHARETWEETby Linda Huber|Sep 14 2016, 11:00amLink NYC users. Image: Michael HirschSHARETWEETTwo young men sit on the corner of 3rd Avenue and 54th Street, huddled against a tall silver obelisk on a hot summer day. One man is sprawled on the ground in dirty sweatpants, and the other is 20-something, shirtless and examining an iPhone plugged into the kiosk\'s USB port. Around them on the ground is a backpack, a duffel, loose cigarettes, and a roughed-up phone.LinkNYC, New York City\'s newest communications network, includes more than 350 kiosks installed on sidewalks throughout the city and was created to repurpose payphone infrastructure through public kiosks offering free internet, phone calls, and USB charging ports. The project is a collaboration between the city and a consortium of private technology and media companies including Sidewalk Labs, an Alphabet (read: Google) company, and represents an important innovation in the "smart city" movement integrating information and communication technologies into all aspects of urban life.I spent nearly four hours of an August afternoon walking down 3rd Avenue\xe2\x80\x94where Links now appear on almost every block\xe2\x80\x94to see what it actually looks like we put our newest and most innovative technology out onto city streets, instead of into our pockets.Read More: What the LinkNYC Project Means for the Average New YorkerMy small sample of Link users that Saturday afternoon suggests these kiosks are indeed mostly used by the city\'s least privileged. Of the 15 people I saw using a Link, only two or three of them would be likely to appear on LinkNYC promotional materials (i.e., one well-dressed woman making a phone call, or one middle aged, casually-dressed tourist waiting for his phone to finish charging). A tourist charges his phone at a LinkNYC hub. Image: Michael HirschMost users were more like the two young men on the street corner\xe2\x80\x94camped out for the long haul, for hours or even days at a time, surrounded by their possessions and browsing music videos on YouTube, making phone calls, and checking Facebook. These campers often make themselves comfortable on makeshift chairs and couches devised from newspaper stands, milk crates, and furniture pulled from alleys and street corners. Miraculously, it seems that these users face relatively little police harassment. The two young men on 54th Street said that they are there nearly every day, but that they usually don\'t have a problem. One of them told me: "They look at me like, \'okay, you on the floor\', but they don\'t usually bother you...It depends on the police."Given that these kiosks have already gained some notoriety for attracting the homeless, this apparent laissez-faire approach surprises me. I can imagine that the city would police these kiosks as part of brand management for this flagship piece of public infrastructure, a "first-of-its-kind communications network".Admittedly, the city has repeatedly emphasized that a central part of the mission of LinkNYC is to help break down the digital divide. According to a 2015 report from the NYC Bureau of Policy and Research, about a quarter of NYC households lack broadband internet at home, and 32 percent of people outside the workforce lack broadband at home.It is worth noting, however, that only 700 of the planned 7,500 Links are to be installed in the Bronx, the borough with the highest percentage of households without broadband. This raises the question of just how central the digital divide is to the mission of LinkNYC, or whether it is just the piece that seems sexiest to emphasize. A LinkNYC user in Manhattan. Image: Michael HirschAnd while the city may generally support the use of Links by those with restricted internet access, it is hard to say whether these home-offices-for-the-homeless are really what LinkNYC\'s designers or financial backers had in mind. In response to questions about this phenomena, LinkNYC recently stated that "We are in conversations with the city about how to ensure that links remain open and accessible for all, and are not monopolized by any individual users."LinkNYC also represents the burgeoning "smart city" trend, meant to create a more efficient and intelligent city. However, a quick review of the companies behind LinkNYC suggests that the focus is less on the futuristic goal of improving citizen\'s daily lives, and more on the well-worn moneymaking practices of collecting user data and providing targeted digital advertising. As Sidewalk Labs CEO Dan Doctoroff stated, "We\'re in this business to make money." Read More: LinkNYC\'s New Free Network Is Blazingly Fast. But At What Cost to Privacy?While it is admirable that ad revenue from the kiosks pays for this public good, increasing digital surveillance and digital advertising doesn\'t seem like the fresh face of the future that one would hope for.Meanwhile, the improvised chairs and office spaces created by NYC\'s street people suggests the emergent, innovative potential of this technology, regardless of the goals of its designers. The users I came across applied their own ingenuity to make the kiosks meet a set of needs not considered or not supported by LinkNYC\'s designers: the need for entertainment, and a space of comfort and connection.To offer poor or homeless people prolonged access to LinkNYC might actually give them access to a resource that the "on the go urban professional" already has in their homes, their offices, and their pockets. For now, that seems promising.Get six of our favorite Motherboard stories every day by signing up for our newsletter.SHARETWEETTagged:digital divideBroadbandmotherboard showSmart CitiesLinkNYCWhere we\'re going, we don\'t need email.Sign up for Motherboard Premium.subscribeReadWatchTopicsMoveableHackingEnvironmentSpaceGamingHealthTechScienceInfluenceVICE ElsewhereVICE AppsVICE on TVVICE MagazineEditionenUnited StatesptBrasilfrFrancedeGermanyitItalynlNetherlandsesSpainenUnited StatesAboutTerms of UseContent Funding on VICEPrivacy Policy\xc2\xa9 2019 VICE Media LLC'
p63

Your weather is set to . You can change the location at any time.\nAccuWeather.com Quick Look\nChange your current location \xc2\xbb\nCurrent\nTonight\nTomorrow\nView Full Weather Report\nSubscribe\nStaten Island Advance\nE-Edition\nNewsletters\nApps\nSign In\nClose\nYou are signed in as\nPublic Profile Edit Profile Sign Out\nSearch\nNews\nLinkNYC: Fast, free WiFi comes to Staten Island\nUpdated Dec 13, 2016;\nPosted Dec 13, 2016\nBy Erik Bascome | tbascome@siadvance.com\nNWS WiFi hubsWith the activation of two Link Wi-Fi kiosks in New Dorp, LinkNYC is now live in all five boroughs. (Courtesy/Advance file shot)(Third-Party-Submitted)STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. -- Two WiFi hubs have been installed in New Dorp as part of LinkNYC, the new network replacing the city\'s payphones, bringing the service\xc2\xa0to all five boroughs.Since Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the launch of LinkNYC is February, nearly 600 Link Wi-Fi kiosks have been installed throughout the city.\nEach Link provides New Yorkers with free, fast WiFi, free domestic calling, two USB charging ports, and direct access to 911 and 311. More than 850,000 people have signed up to use the free WiFi.LinkNYC was made possible by\xc2\xa0CityBridge and the New York City\'s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications (DoITT)."We\'re incredibly thrilled to bring LinkNYC to Staten Island," said Anne Roest, commissioner of DoITT.\xc2\xa0"The free services that LinkNYC provides - superfast WiFi, USB charging, City and emergency services, and phone calls - will now be available to Staten Island residents and visitors alike."The Staten Island kiosks can be found at the corner of New Dorp Lane and Hylan Boulevard and at the corner of New Dorp Lane and 10th Street.New Yorkers can see where Links are being installed and get more information at\xc2\xa0www.link.nyc.\nView Comments\nFooter Navigation\nDisclaimer\nRegistration on or use of this site constitutes acceptance of our User Agreement and Privacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 SILive.com. aS'In New York, Starbucks and now Internet on almost every corner - CNET\nCNET tambi\xc3\xa9n est\xc3\xa1 disponible en espa\xc3\xb1ol.\nIr a espa\xc3\xb1ol\nDon\'t show this again\nCNET\nBest Products\nVersus\nBest Headphones\nBest Laptops\nBest Phones\nBest TVs\nBest Speakers\nBest Routers\nBest Smart Home\nBest Tablets\nBest Refrigerators\nBest Washing Machines\nBest Digital Cameras\nBest Hard Drives\nBest Printers\nBest Wearable Tech\nBest AV Receivers\nBest iPhone Apps\nBest Media Streamers\nBest Dishwashers\nBest Coffee Machines\nReviews\nAppliances\nAudio\nCameras\nCars\nDesktops\nDrones\nHeadphones\nLaptops\nMedia Streamers\nMonitors\nNetworking\nPhones\nPrinters\nSmart Home\nSpeakers\nTablets\nTVs\nVPNs\nWearables & VR\nWeb Hosting\nNews\n5G\nApple\nComputers\nCulture\nGoogle\nHealth & Wellness\nInternet\nMicrosoft\nMobile\nSci-Tech\nSecurity\nTech Industry\nSpecial Features\nCNET @ Work\nPhoto Galleries\nSubscribe\nNewsletters\nMagazine\nVideo\nNews\nHow To\nSpecial Features\nMost Popular\nProduct Videos\nAppliances\nAudio\nCameras\nDrones\nGaming\nHome Entertainment\nLaptops\nSmart Home\nTablets\nTVs\nWearable Tech\nShows\nTop 5\nTech Today\nThe Apple Core\nWhat the Future\nAlphabet City\n3:59\nCNET Podcasts\nHow To\nTipster\nAppliances\nComputers\nGaming\nHome Entertainment\nInternet\nMobile Apps\nPhones\nPhotography\nSecurity\nSmart Home\nStreaming TV\nTablets\nWearable Tech\nForums\nSmart Home\nBest smart home devices\nGuide to smart living\nNews\nTour our smart apartment\nTour our smart house\nProduct Compatibility\nAmazon Alexa\nApple HomeKit\nBelkin WeMo\nGoogle Assistant\nLutron\nNest\nPhilips Hue\nSamsung SmartThings\nWink\nCars\nBest Cars\nNews\nReviews\nRecalls\nPictures\nAutoComplete\nCarfection\nCooley On Cars\nCar Audio\nElectric Cars\nThe Best\nAffordable Cars\nCrossovers\nElectric Cars\nFamily Cars\nFuel-Efficient Cars\nHybrids\nSedans\nSUVs\nDeals\nThe Cheapskate\nBest VPN Services\nBest Web Hosting\nBest Password Managers\nBy Category\nAll Deals\nAudio\nCameras\nDesktops\nHard Drives\nLaptops\nMonitors\nPhones\nPrinters\nSoftware\nTablets\nTVs\nDownload\nJoin / Sign In\nMy Profile\nKorea\nChina\nFrance\nGermany\nJapan\nEnglish\nCNET en Espa\xc3\xb1ol\nMy Profile\nForums\nSign Out\nInternet\nIn New York, Starbucks and now Internet on almost every corner\nOn Road Trip 2015, CNET gets up close with a new structure that will supply the city with free, public Wi-Fi via a project that swaps phone booths for hotspots.\nBy\nPaula Vasan\nAugust 13, 2015 5:00 AM PDT\nCheck out all the places we\'ve been on CNET\'s Road Trip 2015. \t \t \tOn the 21st floor of New York\'s Woolworth Building, the tallest building in the world when it was completed in 1913, there\'s a new structure that\'s on track to break records. \t \t \t \tDavid Etherington, the chief strategy officer at municipal advertising giant Titan, is helping to create a structure that will supply free, ultra-high-speed Wi-Fi Internet to anyone within about 150 feet. Once completed, there will be up to 10,000 of these structures, known as Links, that will replace all of the city\'s unused phone booths scattered across the five boroughs. \t \t \t \tThe new Wi-Fi hubs represent a push among city officials to elevate New York as a technology and innovation destination, a description that is most often resigned to Silicon Valley in the US and to many other cities abroad, namely London, Singapore and Seoul, where broadband is one-tenth the price it is in New York and twice as fast, according to the Open Technology Institute. And it underscores an effort to narrow the digital divide in New York with free, public high-speed Internet -- a resource that President Barack Obama has called a 21st century necessity.Enlarge ImageTitan\'s Chief Strategy Officer Dave Etherington is helping to drive the LinkNYC project, which will provide high-speed broadband throughout New York.\nPaula Vasan/CNET\nThe project is the result of a $200 million plan approved by city leaders in December 2014, called LinkNYC. A consortium called CityBridge won the bid to remove old payphones and install new Internet infrastructure in their place. The group includes mobile chipmaker Qualcomm, which has helped with connection technology, and outdoor advertiser Titan, which already has the largest contract in the city for maintaining and advertising on city payphones. Comark, which will fabricate the actual kiosks, and strategy firm Control Group are also part of the consortium. The plan with LinkNYC is for the initiative to be not only self-sustaining, but hugely profitable with an anticipated half a billion dollars in ad revenue to New York over the next 12 years -- money that will be used by the city for Internet connectivity-related projects. \t \t \t \tThe first 500 Link structures will be available by summer 2016, with the construction of the first 7,500 Links expected to go on for four years. The contract -- exclusively for providing the Internet service and maintaining the Link structures -- will last for up to 15 years. As planned, it would be the largest and fastest free public Wi-Fi network in the world, providing a cloud of gigabit-speed Wi-Fi access, and it would be the largest deployment of digital displays globally. \t \t \t \t"These really are going to look amazing and they\'re going to change the streetscape of New York," Etherington said while pointing to an early prototype of the new phone installation, which\nlooks like a mini modern skyscraper itself: a thin, sleek, 9.5-foot-tall hub providing unlimited Internet access at up to one gigabit per second, or roughly 100 times the average speed of public Wi-Fi. To put that into perspective for a busy New Yorker, those speeds allow you to download a two-hour high-definition movie in about 30 seconds. Each Link also comes with two USB outlets, letting you charge your phone by 10 percent in less than two minutes (but you have to bring your own cable).What free Internet means for the Big Apple \t \t \t \tEach Link structure will be able to serve just under 500 people with Wi-Fi at any one time, according to Etherington \t \t \t \t"It will start to change people\'s expectations around Wi-Fi if you can pop out for a pint of milk and download the Hobbit trilogy in a minute...it\'s probably going to change your perceptions about what Wi-Fi is all about," he said, before rattling off an alarming stat about Internet usage in the city: a total of 3.5 million people don\'t have access to broadband Internet.\nLinkNYC to bring free, public Wi-Fi to New York (pictures)\n15 Photos\nWhat if you luckily happen to live or work next to these structures? It could theoretically mean free Internet for thousands of New Yorkers who happen to live on the first and second floors of a building near a Link. Small businesses, too, may particularly benefit from free Internet, according to city officials. \t \t \t \tThe potential to lower that 3.5 million figure to zero, in terms of the number of people who lack Internet access, speaks volumes about opportunities in closing the digital divide. \t \t \t \tAccording to the city\'s Center for Economic Opportunity, 45.1 percent of New Yorkers live in households earning less than 150 percent of the poverty line, which, for a family of two adults and two children, is just over $31,000 in New York. "This divide is a big issue in our modern age," said Minerva Tantoco, chief technology officer of New York City -- a native New Yorker who witnessed that divide in various forms throughout her public school upbringing, surrounded by classmates on opposite ends of the city\'s wide socioeconomic spectrum. \t \t \t \tYou need Internet access to participate in the modern economy, because "people who don\'t have it are shut out," she said on a call from outside Bronx High School of Science (her alma mater), where she had just finished serving as a judge for a student hardware competition. \t \t \t \tTantoco, who was appointed by New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio to the newly created chief technology officer position in September 2014 with the mission of making "the most technology-friendly and innovation-driven city in the world," has been a key player in getting LinkNYC off the ground. Her mission in achieving free Internet can be summed up in a single sentence: Create a more equitable playing field through technology for everyone living in and visiting New York.The goal: innovation and social equality \t \t \t \tWith ad revenue funding the entire LinkNYC initiative over the next 12 years, the city hopes that the digital advertising on the structures themselves will help spur innovation and social equity. At the start of the project, there will be six advertisers over four weeks, but after a few months when data on usage is collected, Etherington said companies will eventually be able to conduct smaller, more targeted ad buys for a lower price tag. It\'s a setup that\'s a result of a public-private partnership between the city and private businesses, which Etherington calls a strategy unlike any other municipality\'s trying to offer free public Internet.Advertisers will eventually be able to buy ads on Links, which each have a\n55-inch digital screen, in specific neighborhoods, on specific streets, at specific times, rather than having to advertise on the entire network throughout the five boroughs.\nMore Road Trip 2015\nNew York\'s tech scene: More melting pot, less Silicon Valley\nTake a look at New York\'s quietly vibrant tech scene (pictures)\nFor a moment, Times Square plays art gallery\nThe Midnight Moment in Times Square (pictures)\nCity officials say that the link structures will pay for themselves, not only because they will be self-sustaining from a business sense, but because it will spur a more informed community. "If you don\'t have water or electricity you\'re going to be at a huge disadvantage and it\'s the same with the Internet," Tantoco said. \t \t \t \tOf course these structures aren\'t intended to be a panacea for Wi-Fi in New York. But it\'s certainly a first step...a leap actually...to turn New York into a smarter city. \t \t \t \tWhile millions of people still lack Internet access, particularly in poorer neighborhoods, the people behind LinkNYC say the payphone upgrade represents the city\'s commitment to eradicating the digital divide. The long-term goal, one championed by de Blasio, is for every resident and business to have access to affordable, reliable, high-speed broadband service by 2025. "Stories of kids sitting on library stoops late at night struggling to get homework done with spotty Wi-Fi is an example of what the digital divide can do, and a problem LinkNYC aims to solve," said Etherington.But what about privacy?\nTantoco and her team helped craft the privacy policy associated with the Wi-Fi hotspots, enforcing end-to-end encryption -- which scrambles information so only the sender and intended receiver, and no one in between, can read it -- using technology called "Hotspot 2.0." That also let\'s LinkNYC authenticate users once and allow them to roam from one Link to the next without re-authenticating each time. \t \t \t \tWhat does that mean for you? To join the LinkNYC network you\'ll need to give up your email address and username and create a password. So the network will know a fraction of what your home Internet provider or wireless carrier knows. \t \t \t \t"In\naddition to privacy protections, LinkNYC will also be among the\nmost secure Wi-Fi networks available," said Nicholas Sbordone, a\nspokesman for New York City\'s Department\nof Information Technology and Telecommunications. "It will be one of\nthe first public encrypted networks -- so the act of listening to\nunencrypted wireless traffic will be eliminated." \t \t \t \tTo prevent one device from being able to see any other device, the network will block peer-to-peer communication once a device is on the network. Therefore, a wireless device will only be able to access the Internet as opposed to other users\' devices, which will prevent the spread of viruses from one computer to another and stop a hacker from being able to attack another computer or device on the network, said Sbordone. \t \t \t \t"If you go on a regular free Wi-Fi hotspot today like at the Hong Kong airport, it\'s not encrypted and the data that you send can be reused for other purposes," Tantoco said. "We wanted New York City\'s policy for Wi-Fi to be much stronger than that." \t \t \t \t"I used to work in the financial sector, where security has always been the No. 1 consideration, and I\'m applying that to government," she adds, noting her experience in technology and product management positions at companies like UBS and Merrill Lynch. \t \t \t \tThat level of end-to-end encryption for LinkNYC is a new frontier of free public Wi-Fi. In fact, according to Etherington, LinkNYC will be the only free public Wi-Fi in the world to have and mandate that level of end-to-end encryption throughout the network. \t \t \t \tStill, the familiar objection to public Wi-Fi largely centers on the ability among hackers to defeat security and encryption settings, security experts say. "Expanded Wi-Fi connectivity will have a tremendous benefit, but as we have seen in recent months, such as with the hacking of devices, increased connectivity comes with an increased opportunity for cyberattacks and malicious activity, even if there is end- to-end encryption," said privacy and cybersecurity lawyer Stuart Levi.\nIt\'s an opportunity for New York to leapfrog places like Tokyo and Seoul and become the connectivity heart of the world.\nDavid Etherington, chief strategy officer at Titan\nEtherington acknowledges the validity of these critics. "When it does go wrong it can really go wrong. But we don\'t have that level of information in the first place," Etherington said of LinkNYC\'s encryption policy, which Tantoco said will discourage hackers from hanging around LinkNYC sites in the first place. If you want to use the Wi-Fi from LinkNYC, all you\'ll need is your name and your email address. And once you log in once, you won\'t have to ever again, whether you\'re using LinkNYC Wi-Fi in Manhattan or Staten Island. \t \t \t \tSteve Koonin, founding director of New York University\'s Center for Urban Science and Progress, said the benefits of free public Internet in New York City outweigh the privacy concerns associated with it. "I think those concerns are just becoming a fact of modern life," he said, equating the trade-off of information in exchange for a service to giving up his financial information to his credit card company in exchange for fraud protection alerts.With free Internet, NYC is far from the first \t \t \t \tThe arrival of LinkNYC comes despite a turbulent history of municipal Wi-Fi projects, with cities including New York, Philadelphia and dozens others throughout the US trying -- and failing -- to develop such technology and keep it running. In 2004, for example, San Francisco\'s Mayor Gavin Newsom declared: "We will not stop until every San Franciscan has access to free wireless-internet service." But stopping proved inevitable, as the project turned out to be harder than expected. And now, more than 10 years later, a sliver of Newsom\'s vision is becoming a reality, with Google covering 33 of the city\'s 220 parks with Wi-Fi. Officials say the Wi-Fi speed is lower than gigabit speed, with endpoint-to-endpoint encryption an option only at one location as opposed to being enforced throughout the network. \t \t \t \tIn April 2014, Boston started providing free public Wi-Fi in public spaces, targeting an area that consists largely of low-income families who may not be able to afford the high cost of speedy broadband service. There are now 180 hotspots, often lower than gigabit speed. Similar to San Francisco\'s policy, end-to-end encryption is an option as opposed to being enforced. \t \t \t \tCities from San Francisco and Seattle to Boston and New York have claimed these kinds of projects can help ignite economic activity and innovation, narrowing the digital divide between those who can afford to access the Internet and those who can\'t. But despite the progress in US cities, many of these projects have been curtailed after cities and developers encountered financial, competitive and technical obstacles. \t \t \t \t"It\'s an opportunity for New York to leapfrog places like Tokyo and Seoul and become the connectivity heart of the world," Etherington said of LinkNYC.\nGoogle Play: We\'ve cracked down on bad apps: Google says it rejected at least 55 percent more app submissions in 2018.\nThe best meal kit delivery services: Are you an enthusiastic cook with not enough time? These services can help.\nRoad Trip 2015\nreading\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nIn New York, Starbucks and now Internet on almost every corner\nSep 27\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nChasing the Silicon Valley dream is harder than you\'d think\nSep 25\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nTarget turns to tech to bust out of its big-box image\nSep 24\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nIsraeli military uses tech as its protective edge\nSep 24\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nUp close with the Israel Defense Forces\' F-16I and Iron Dome (pictures)\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nSee All\nShare your voice\nComments\nTags\nRoad Trip 2015\nInternet\nCulture\nClose\nDiscuss: In New York, Starbucks and now Internet on almost every corner\nSign in to comment\nBe respectful, keep it civil and stay on topic. aS'\'LinkNYC\' to Replace Pay Phones With 10,000 Free Wi-Fi Hubs - AOL Finance\nStay in the loop! Get breaking news and big stories on your desktop.\nNotify Me\nWhen prompted, click "Allow" you can always change your mind later.\nfinance\nSearch The Web\nSearch Aol.com\nSearch\nLogin / Join\nMail\nDownloads\nAOL App\nDiscover AOL\nMyBenefits\nID Theft Protection\nTravel Tips\nGames\nFavorites\nMaps\nTech Help\nSecure PC\nLive Help\n0\xc2\xb0\nEnter City/ZIP\nCity or Zip\nChange weather location\nMail\nLogin / Join\nNews\nU.S. News\nWorld News\nPolitics\nSports\nScience & Tech\nEntertainment\nCelebrity\nMovies\nMusic\nTV\nFinance\nBusiness\nCareers\nPersonal Finance\nRetirement\nReal Estate\nMy Portfolios\nResources\nTaxes\nLifestyle\nStyle\nBeauty\nWellness\nFood\nTravel\nLiving\nShop\nVideo\nGames\n\'LinkNYC\' to Replace Pay Phones With 10,000 Free Wi-Fi Hubs\nShare\nNov 18th 2014 11:31AM\nGrady Coppell/Getty ImagesBy Kukil Bora\nNew York City is planning to replace public payphones with a new communications network expected to "bring the fastest available municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers," for free. The construction of the network will begin in 2015, and the first structures will become operational by the year\'s end.\nAs part of a new plan dubbed "LinkNYC," the city\'s aging payphone system will make way for the deployment of 10,000 Wi-Fi hubs, called "Links," which will be installed across all five boroughs of New York. In addition to being free Wi-Fi hubs that can run up to gigabit speeds seven days a week, "Links" also offer other services, including free phone calls anywhere within the U.S., easy access to 911 and 311 calls, and a free charging station for mobile devices.LinkNYC, FlickrLinkNYC is a first-of-its-kind communications network that will bring the fastest available municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers, small businesses, and visitors.\nThe "Links" Wi-Fi hubs "will be funded through advertising revenues, will be built at no cost to taxpayers, and will generate more than $500 million in revenue for the City over the first 12 years," according to the LinkNYC website.\nThe Link structures will include a touchscreen tablet interface to help people access city services, directions and other features. The physical pillars will also have digital displays for advertising and public service announcements.\nWhile LinkNYC has said that the upcoming service will offer gigabit speeds, the claim has raised some eyebrows as commonly used Wi-Fi networks don\'t yet support sustained gigabit connections from individual devices, The Verge reported.LinkNYC, FlickrThe Link structures will include a touchscreen tablet interface to help people access city services, directions and other services.\nLinkNYC doesn\'t say which Wi-Fi standard will be used in the Links pylons, but it claims that "gigabit Wi-Fi is more than a 100 times faster than the average public Wi-Fi and more than 20 times faster than the average home Internet service in NYC. Downloading a two-hour HD movie can take as little as 30 seconds."\nAccording to LinkNYC, the service will offer an encrypted network connection between the user and a hotspot.\n"We encourage you to continue to use end-to-end encryption, such as HTTPS, for any sensitive matters or data ... The network will also prevent peer-to-peer security threats by eliminating the ability to communicate device to device," LinkNYC said in a statement.\nThe LinkNYC project is the result of a partnership between the Mayor\'s Office of Technology and Innovation, the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, and CityBridge, a New York City-based consortium.\nTags\ncellphone\ninfrastructure\ninternet\nlinknyc\nmobile technology\nnew york city\nnycwireless\nsmartphone\ntablet\nThis Built America\nwifi\nRead Full Story\nFrom Our Partners\n20 Years After Doctor Vanishes, Mushroom Pickers Make A Strange Discovery\nWhen This Guy Got An Old Tank On Ebay, He Little Knew A $2 Million Fortune Lay Inside\nTeenage Football Star Makes A Wild Move That Leaves The Entire School Floored\nThe Latest from our PartnersSavings Interest Rates SkyRocket After Fed MeetingWith the Recent Rate Hike, CDs Become Best InvestmentMortgage Rates Remain Low by Historical Standards \xe2\x80\x93 Experts Urge Locki\xe2\x80\xa6Read more fromMortgage rates are on the rise, but rates are still low. (Do This)Spend $500, Pocket $150 with one of these cash back cardsRead more fromForget the 30yr mortgage if you owe less than $679k (Do this instea\xe2\x80\xa6How to pay off your house ASAP (So simple it\'s unbelievable)New refi program gives homeowners one more chanceRead more fromSavings Account Rates Still Skyrocketing - Earn Over 2.45%This Company is Disrupting the $27T Retirement IndustrySPRING 2019: How to Maximize Your SavingsRead more from\nScroll to continue with content\nAD\nRecommended For YouApple\'s flagship New York City store is dealing with a serious bed bug infestation: r\xe2\x80\xa6Amazon customers can now return their items at Kohl\'sFish market owner has worked in the same place since the day he was bornUSGlobalsCurrenciesDJI26656.39145.340.55%NASDAQ8120.82105.561.32%S&P 5002933.6825.710.88%NIKKEI 22522259.7441.840.19%Hang Seng29963.24-0.02-0.00%DAX12235.5113.120.11%USD (PER EUR)1.12-0.0035-0.31%USD (PER CHF)0.98-0.0050-0.50%JPY (PER USD)111.86-0.0770-0.07%GBP (PER USD)1.29-0.0049-0.38%My Portfolio >All index data provided on a 15 minute delayPowered byMore to ExploreFrom Our PartnersMake something different out of yourself every 3 yearsLadders4 keys to successful teamworkLaddersThis floating city concept is one way to cope with climate chan\xe2\x80\xa6NBC News MACHThe 5 differences between amateurs and true professionalsLaddersIf you fake this a lot at work, you may develop a drinking prob\xe2\x80\xa6LaddersBy PubExchange\nAOL Logo\nFinance\nSearch The Web\nSearch The Web\nJOIN AOL\nDOWNLOADS\nHELP\nFEEDBACK\nABOUT US\nADVERTISING\nPRIVACY(Updated)\nTERMS(Updated)\nABOUT OUR ADS\nSITEMAP\nShare on Facebook\nFacebook\nShare on Twitter\nTwitter\nShare on Instagram\nInstagram\nFollow us via newsletter\nNewsletter\nFollow us via RSS\nRSS\nFollow us on mobile\nAOL Mobile\n\xc2\xa9 2019\xc2\xa0 Verizon Media. aS'City\'s LinkNYC Kiosks Discriminate Against the Blind, Lawsuit Says\n- Upper East Side - New York - DNAinfo\nThe DNAinfo archives brought to you by WNYC.Read the press release here.New YorkChicago\nNeighborhoods\nManhattan\nChelsea & Hell\'s Kitchen\nDowntown\nEast Village & Lower East Side\nGreenwich Village & Soho\nHarlem\nMidtown & Theater District\nMurray Hill, Gramercy & Midtown East\nUpper East Side & Roosevelt Island\nUpper West Side & Morningside Heights\nWashington Heights & Inwood\nBrooklyn\nBedford-Stuyvesant\nCobble Hill, Carroll Gardens & Red Hook\nCrown Heights, Prospect Heights & Prospect-Lefferts Gardens\nFort Greene & DUMBO\nPark Slope, Windsor Terrace & Gowanus\nWilliamsburg, Greenpoint & Bushwick\nQueens\nAstoria & Long Island City\nFlushing & Whitestone\nForest Hills, Rego Park & Jamaica\nJackson Heights & Elmhurst\nMaspeth, Middle Village & Ridgewood\nThe Rockaways\nThe Bronx\nFordham & Tremont\nNorwood & Bedford Park\nRiverdale & Kingsbridge\nSouth Bronx\nWoodlawn & Wakefield\nStaten Island\nNews\nArts & Entertainment\nCrime & Mayhem\nEducation\nFood & Drink\nHealth & Wellness\nParenting & Schools\nPolitics\nReal Estate\nTransportation\nUrban Animals\nWeather\nFeatures\nBack to School Checklist\nThe Outside Chance\nNew York Visualized\nApartmentality\nGet Out & Do This\nOpenings & Closings\nPrincipal Of The Week\nThis Is New York\nHolidays in the Neighborhood\nNeighborhood PartnersAdvertise With UsOur TeamTerms of UsePrivacy Policy\xc2\xa9 2018 DNAinfoSearchSearch\nUpper East Side & Roosevelt IslandTechnology\nCity\'s LinkNYC Kiosks Discriminate Against the Blind, Lawsuit Says\nBy Shaye Weaver\n|&nbspAugust 1, 2016 2:47pm@shayeweaver\nTwitter\nFacebook\nEmail\nMore\nThe LinkNYC machines currently don\'t have accessibility for the blind, according to a lawsuit.\nView Full Caption\nDNAInfo/Noah Hurowitz\nNEW YORK CITY\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0If you\'re blind, it is impossible to call 911, get directions\xc2\xa0or access free Wi-Fi\xc2\xa0using\xc2\xa0the city\'s newly installed LinkNYC kiosks, according to a lawsuit filed by\xc2\xa0residents.The kiosks\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0which are meant to be\xc2\xa0an alternative to pay\xc2\xa0phones and\xc2\xa0have been touted by Mayor Bill de Blasio for improving\xc2\xa0life for people with disabilities\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 lack basic requirements for use by vision-impaired New Yorkers, including not adding braille onto the keypad and failing to include tech-driven audio functions, the lawsuit states.The city and Citybridge, which operates the kiosks, "failed to take the minimal and routine steps to make these tablets and other of the various services of LinkNYC accessible to blind New Yorkers," the National Federation of the Blind and three city residents wrote in a civil rights lawsuit filed in\xc2\xa0U.S. District Court on July 28.\n"Defendants ignored their responsibilities and excluded blind people from the technological revolution of LinkNYC."\xe2\x96\xba Read more: LinkNYC Kioks Clogging Sidewalks With Encampments and Drug Deals, Locals SayBay Ridge resident Mindy Jacobsen, one of the New Yorkers included in the lawsuit, said she was on her way to a friend\'s house on July 20\xc2\xa0and needed directions so she tried to access a LinkNYC\xc2\xa0map. But because the machine didn\'t have a function that reads what\'s on the screen, she couldn\'t get any help."I touched the screen and nothing happened," she told DNAinfo\xc2\xa0New York on Monday. "I plugged in my headphones and there was no speech...nothing that would give me any idea of what to touch or press.""I know that my sighted friends could have figured out where to go and I had no reason to believe the blind community would have been left out," Jacobsen said. "All too often, things are done without keeping the blind in mind. To add speech these days is not a problem."Manhattan resident\xc2\xa0Joyce Carrico and\xc2\xa0Long Island City resident Nihal\xc2\xa0Erkan\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 who are both blind and are also party to the lawsuit \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0tried to use\xc2\xa0kiosks on Eighth Avenue on July 22\xc2\xa0and 25, respectively, and were also\xc2\xa0unable to decipher how the machines worked because of the lack of accommodation, they said.Already, the city is taking heat from residents who say they should have been approached about the machines\' placement, considering\xc2\xa0many of them have become spots for homeless encampments.The lawsuit calls on the city and tech company\xc2\xa0Citybridge to immediately stop the installation of the kiosks and add accessibility\xc2\xa0to those already installed, according to attorney Michelle Caiola of Disability Rights Advocates.A spokeswoman for LinkNYC\xc2\xa0said that even though current kiosks don\'t have some accessibility features, it has been a part of the company\'s plan to incorporate them. But she would not provide a timeline for when those features would be added."We have been working with the Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office for People with Disabilities\xc2\xa0since the beginning of the project, incorporating braille, wheelchair accessibility, a tactile keypad, and a rim around the 911 button into the design," said Ruth Fasoldt, LinkNYC\'s community affairs manager. "We are actively collaborating with MOPD on software updates that will incorporate new accessibility features and that will improve ease of use for the blind, including better 911 audio cues, talkback features, and mobile applications, among others, and we will continue to work with the City to make updates to LinkNYC to ensure accessibility for all.\xe2\x80\x9d\nShe pointed to an award the city gave to LinkNYC and Citybridge last year for their "inclusive" product.The company was given\xc2\xa0an\xc2\xa0ADA Sapolin Award in August 2015 because they "have fought for the rights of people with disabilities, and in particular those individuals and organizations who have shown exemplary commitment to inclusion, accessibility and equality," Mayor de Blasio\xc2\xa0said then.A spokeswoman for the city\'s Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications, Maya\xc2\xa0Worman,\xc2\xa0said the agency\xc2\xa0takes accessibility seriously and that its franchise agreement with LinkNYC requires compliance with ADA. She did not explain why the kiosks were permitted to be installed without such accommodations.Jacobsen, who is a 55-year-old technology teacher at the Vision Services for the Blind\xc2\xa0at 23rd Street,\xc2\xa0said it would be helpful to have braille on the keypads and\xc2\xa0braille that clearly marks what things are in addition to a speech option.But Caiola says there is no exception under ADA law for a roll-out period or test period."It\'s just astounding since we just celebrated the 26th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act," Caiola\xc2\xa0said. "The city is often treating the disabled as an afterthought and correct issues once a lawsuit is filed against them.""Once they provide services or a program, it needs to be accessible at that time," she continued. "We believe it would be most cost-effective to have these accessible from the get-go. I can\'t imagine a scenario where they\'d have to go back and fix them and it be a good thing."\nTwitter\nFacebook\nEmail\nMore\nNext in Upper East Side & Roosevelt Island48,000 Students With Disabilities Not Getting Help They Need, DOE AdmitsNext in Upper East Side & Roosevelt IslandTerrorist Planned to Continue Killing Spree at Brooklyn Bridge, Feds SayNext in Upper East Side & Roosevelt aS'NYC Continues Its Great Phonebooth Transformation As First Tablets Hit Its Gigabit Wi-Fi Spots \xe2\x80\x93 TechCrunch\nNYC Continues Its Great Phonebooth Transformation As First Tablets Hit Its Gigabit Wi-Fi Spots\nJonathan Shieber\nAnthony Ha\n3 years\nThe plan to turn unused NYC phonebooths into free\xc2\xa0digital\xc2\xa0hubs for local neighborhoods continues as Mayor Bill DeBlasio announced the second phase of the city\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC program \xe2\x80\x94 with the unveiling of new, slightly generic tablets at the city\xe2\x80\x99s newly installed hotspots.\nLinkNYC demonstrated the android-powered tablet for the press yesterday, taking advantage of a \xe2\x80\x9cLink\xe2\x80\x9d structure at a nondescript intersection near New York\xe2\x80\x99s Gramercy neighborhood. The demo was pretty short (and our man on the scene was stuck behind a bunch of taller writers), but it was enough to show that yep, you can make phone calls (through a service provided by Vonage).\nThe tablets look like generic tablets, with a basic, straightforward interface. They\xe2\x80\x99re positioned on the side of the Link structures, so you have to be comfortable making your call from what is essentially the middle of the sidewalk \xe2\x80\x94 you can plug in your own headphones for a little more privacy.\nThe tablets do more than just allow folks to make free calls \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0the city will also be rolling out selected apps, features and services.\nRight now the tablets are installed in the 15 hotspots that are actually live \xe2\x80\x93 all placed along a pretty uninspired stretch of Third Avenue in Manhattan.\nEventually the goal will be to have the 7,500 kiosks bringing gigabit speed, encrypted Wi-Fi \xe2\x80\x94 and free phone calls to anyone in the U.S. (who uses the phone to talk to people anymore?), digital mapping services, apps, and Internet browsing via tablets \xe2\x80\x94 to the five boroughs over the next several years.\nBy July the LinkNYC program will have connected the first 510 installations\xc2\xa0to select areas in Manhattan, the South Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island. After four years that number will jump to 4,550 \xe2\x80\x94 with all locations outside of Manhattan getting gigabit speed Internet.\nIn addition to all of the telecommunications features, there\xe2\x80\x99re some features to the LinkNYC kiosks that are \xe2\x80\x94 if not distinctly New York \xe2\x80\x94 inspired by the city surrounding them.\nThe consortium of companies behind the project touts that each kiosk can withstand extreme heat and cold, rain, snow and flooding, earthquakes, vandalism and theft (so, basically the conditions of the city throughout this winter). Niftily, sensors in the devices will also be used to understand how the environment is effecting the structures.\nWe first wrote about the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s plan when it was announced in 2014\xc2\xa0and though much of the story remains the same, some of the players have changed.\nInterestingly, since the program was announced of the major players that comprises the CityBridge consortium rolling out the project was acquired by the world\xe2\x80\x99s second most valuable company \xe2\x80\x94 Alphabet.\nIntersection, the group that handles design and implementation of the project is the cornerstone of Alphabet\xe2\x80\x99s Sidewalk Labs division.\n\xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC is just the beginning of what\xe2\x80\x99s possible when media and technology work together to bring digital experiences into physical space,\xe2\x80\x9d said Intersection\xe2\x80\x99s new chief executive Al Kelley in a statement announcing his assumption of the executive role at the company.\nAdditional partners in the\xc2\xa0Citybridge consortium include Qualcomm,\xc2\xa0CIVIQ Smartscapes, and Antenna Design, which created the physical Link kiosk.\nThe move is a big step forward in the development of a citywide free internet service for New York. The only question remaining is how long the tablets remain functional before they\xe2\x80\x99re bricked by people downloading and watching porn.'

Maybe Just a Little\nLinkNYC Wi-Fi may be an almost accidental residential ISP. We talk to project partner Qualcomm.\nBy\nSascha Segan\nFebruary 9, 2016 3:11PM EST\nFebruary 9, 2016\nPCMag reviews products independently, but we may earn affiliate commissions from buying links on this page. Terms of use.\nCan a smart city free us from the tyranny of the cable companies? When we tested the new LinkNYC hotspots here in New York, their blinding speed and 200-foot range made them start to look not just like hotspots for passing tourists, but like an actual municipal Internet service provider\xe2\x80\x94something that would probably cause Time Warner Cable and Verizon to worry.\n"We actually had a joke of people setting up their living rooms right next to it," said Kiva Allgood, Qualcomm\'s VP of smart cities. The LinkNYCs are part of a broader "smart city" strategy from Qualcomm, which has been working in other cities on gunshot spotters, smart water metering, and even smart trash cans that tell sanitation departments when to pick up the trash.\nThe LinkNYC poles run Qualcomm Snapdragon 600 processors, like midrange smartphones, and hook into their own municipal fiber network under the streets. They then pump out Wi-Fi using Qualcomm Vive-powered 802.11ac access points with multi-user MIMO, which helps them get the epic range we saw in our tests.\n"It\'s purpose-built fiber," Allgood said. "The city owns the network. Municipal gigabit fiber under the streets."\nThe hotspots are designed to mesh together, Allgood said, so as you walk between access points you\'ll keep one session ID and won\'t have to log in again. And use will be unlimited: "we do not have any intentions of metering or fettering people on our network," she said. (We\'ll see if they stick to that tune once LinkNYC users discover BitTorrent.)\nSo here\'s where things get...a little mysterious. The city and Qualcomm don\'t want to be seen necessarily as interfering in the businesses of commercial ISPs. But they can\'t deny that they\'re beaming free Wi-Fi into people\'s apartment buildings, all over the city.\n"Our goal is that this is a city service, on the corner, that people could leverage instead of having to go to the library," Allgood said. "That will work for the first two floors of a building but not seven others. Our goal is to give them access. If they can do that from their living room, it\'s just because they happen to be in the right place."\nRelated\nLinkNYC Wi-Fi Hotspots Tested: They Crush Starbucks\nLinkNYC Wi-Fi Hotspots Tested: They Crush Starbucks\nLinkNYC will only get more pervasive, as Qualcomm plans to equip up to 10,000\xc2\xa0of the poles across the city. It\'s also looking into putting public Wi-Fi into New York\'s "big belly" smart trash cans.\nIf LinkNYC succeeds, it could show the way for more cities to combine a citywide municipal Wi-Fi plan with their less visible smart city efficiency initiatives. That means it\'s worth keeping an eye on this project, even if you never set foot in New York.\n"If you think about the growth in cities and where we\'re going, cities and their infrastructure are going to have to adapt and do things differently," Allgood said.\nTop\nRead More\nGoogle Patent Teases Self-Driving Delivery Trucks\nNews & Analysis\nGoogle Patent Teases Self-Driving Delivery Trucks\n1Password for Android Adds Fingerprint-Unlocking Support\nNews & Analysis 1Password for Android Adds Fingerprint-Unlocking Support\nAbout the Author\nSascha Segan\nLead Analyst, Mobile\nTwitter\nEmail\nPCMag.com\'s lead mobile analyst, Sascha Segan, has reviewed hundreds of smartphones, tablets and other gadgets in more than 13 years with PCMag. He\'s the head of our Fastest Mobile Networks project, hosts our One Cool Thing daily Web show, and writes opinions on tech and society.\nSegan is also a multiple award-winning travel writer. aS"New York City Officially Launches Free Public Wi-Fi\nFast CompanyCo.DesignTechWork LifeCreativityImpactAudioVideoNewsRecommenderSubscribeHomepageCo.DesignTechWork LifeCreativityImpactAudioVideoNewsRecommenderSubscribeHelp CentercollectionsRecommenderThe apps, books, movies, music, TV shows, and art are inspiring our some of the most creative people in business this monthStrong Female LeadThe struggles and triumphs of prominent women in leadership positionsProductivityProductivity tips and hacksPlatform WarsThe major tech ecosystems that battle for our attention and dollarsTech ForecastWhat\xe2\x80\x99s next for hardware, software, and servicesMost Innovative CompaniesOur annual guide to the businesses that matter the mostMost Creative PeopleLeaders who are shaping the future of business in creative waysWorld Changing IdeasNew workplaces, new food sources, new medicine--even an entirely new economic systemInnovation By DesignCelebrating the best ideas in businessFastCo.Works StudioAn award-winning team of journalists, designers, and videographers who tell brand stories through Fast Company's distinctive lensNewsletterEventsInnovation FestivalThe GrillCurrent IssueCurrent IssueSUBSCRIBEFollow us:advertisementadvertisementadvertisement02.18.16fast feedNew York City Officially Launches Free Public Wi-FiAfter a soft launch of four hubs in January, the LinkNYC system officially goes live today.\n[Images: via LinkNYC] By Michael Grothaus1 minute ReadNew York City will see the official launch of its new citywide LinkNYC free Wi-Fi system today. At noon on Thursday, NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio is announcing the public launch of the Wi-Fi hotspots that have replaced old payphones at the northwest corner of 16th Street and 3rd Avenue. Mayor de Blasio will be joined by members from CityBridge, the consortium of companies behind the LinkNYC system.advertisementadvertisementThough the LinkNYC system had a soft launch in January, with the Wi-Fi at four LinkNYC hubs turned on on Manhattan\xe2\x80\x99s Third Avenue, today\xe2\x80\x99s official rollout includes more hub locations and support for LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s tablet capabilities.Each LinkNYC hub is a 10-foot-tall structure made of aluminum, which connects to a newly laid fiber Internet network in the city. The hubs act as wireless routers that New Yorkers and visitors can connect to for free with their devices to get ultrafast Internet. But each LinkNYC hub also includes a built-in Android tablet, which allows passersby without their own device to browse the web, access city services, contact 311, view maps and directions, and even make free Vonage phone calls to anywhere in the U.S. With the official public launch of the LinkNYC system today, existing LinkNYC hub tablet capabilities will go live for the first time.\nEach LinkNYC hub also features two USB charging ports, so visitors can top up the power on their own devices. The USB ports are designed to be one-way, charging only ports, to prevent them being hacked to pull data from a user\xe2\x80\x99s device. The LinkNYC hubs will also feature a dedicated 911 button that can be pressed in the event of an emergency.The hubs also include two 55-inch HD displays on either side that show advertising to passersby, which is how the free Wi-Fi is funded.When the Wi-Fi capabilities of the first four LinkNYC hubs were switched on in January, their connection speeds lived up to the hype, with many users reporting between 150 Mbps and 300 Mbps download speeds and well over 100 Mbps upload speeds.\nBy July of this year, the city will have rolled out 510 LinkNYC hubs across the five boroughs, and within the next eight years, over 7,500 hubs will be set up across the city. To find the nearest active LinkNYC hub near you you can check out the Find a Link web app.advertisementadvertisementadvertisementadvertisementAbout the authorMichael Grothaus is a novelist, journalist, and former screenwriter represented worldwide by Marjacq Scripts Ltd\n. aS'Why free Wi-Fi kiosks in NYC can\'t stop people from watching porn in public\nMarkets\nTech\nMedia\nSuccess\nPerspectives\nVideo\nMarkets\nPremarkets\nDow 30\nAfter-Hours\nMarket Movers\nFear & Greed\nWorld Markets\nSector Performance\nInvesting\nMarkets Now\nBefore the Bell\nLeading Indicator\nImpact Investing\nEconomy\nEnergy\nTech\nInnovate\nGadget\nMission: Ahead\nUpstarts\nBusiness Evolved\nWork Transformed\nInnovative Cities\nMedia\nReliable Sources\nSuccess\nBoss Files\nFresh Money\nCars\nHomes\nWealth Coach\nBiz + Leisure\nCenter Piece\nPerspectives\nVideo\nInternational\nSwitzerland\nIndia\nDavos\nPassion to Portfolio\nOn: Germany\nMore\nNewsletters\nAbout Us\nAccessibility and CC\nU.S.\nWorld\nPolitics\nBusiness\nOpinion\nHealth\nEntertainment\nTech\nStyle\nTravel\nSports\nVideo\nShop\nVR\nMore...\nFollow CNN Business\nWhy free Wi-Fi kiosks in NYC can\'t stop people from watching porn in public\nby Hope King \xc2\xa0 @lisahopeking\nJuly 30, 2016: 1:28 PM ET\nPrivate habits are becoming more public as cities like New York build free Wi-Fi kiosks on busy street corners.\nLinkNYC has launched more than 300 stations in New York this year by transforming old payphone booths into digital towers. Each is equipped with USB charging ports, high-speed Wi-Fi access and an Android-powered tablet that anyone can use for free.\nBut over the past few weeks, there\'s been an uptick in reports of people using the kiosks to access porn in public -- and even pleasuring themselves while doing so.\nMany of these people are homeless, according to the New York Post, with Penn Station and Port Authority Bus Terminal becoming especially problematic areas.\nWhile watching porn in public is not a crime, pleasuring yourself in public is an act of public lewdness. Those caught in the act are arrested, according to the New York Police Department.\nRelated: Google wants to beam super-fast Wi-Fi into your home\nLinkNYC says it has put many measures in place to try to prevent this type of activity, but it says it\'s hard to solve the problem completely.\nRuth Fasoldt, Community Affairs Manager for LinkNYC, told CNNMoney the kiosk\'s tablets use a professional-grade content monitoring system similar to what\'s already in place at thousands of businesses, schools and libraries across the country. And even though the system "is constantly being updated and adjusted to block inappropriate content," it can\'t catch everything.\nThe challenges are due to new websites constantly popping up on the internet that can\'t get blocked in real-time. Even general audience platforms such as Tumblr or YouTube can contain materials that some might find stimulating.\nCompanies that provide filtering technology are also reluctant to block certain keywords or limit services to a set number of websites because people have different needs for looking things up.\nFor instance, one user might put in certain keywords to search for a local gay bar, while another might be looking for porn. It\'s difficult for a simple word filtering system to predict intent.\nIn April, LinkNYC activated Google SafeSearch to try to curb abuse, but the move isn\'t fully sufficient. Someone who really wants to see a naked woman could get around the system by searching for terms that raise less flags.\n"The problem is that the internet is very big," said Richard Ford, CTO of Forcepoint, a cybersecurity company which provides web filtering services.\nBut he notes there are ways to learn more about what a user is finding. For example, by looking at the URL of a website, which can include words such as "porn," a system can determine more about its content. And the "gold standard" is looking at the contents itself, such as other links within the page or file names. There\'s also the issue of getting around encrypted websites that can skirt filtering systems.\n"It\'s more invasive and more intensive," Ford said of the possible methods.\nRelated: Inventor of the cell phone says this is the next big thing\nLinkNYC wants to build at least 7,500 free Wi-Fi kiosks in New York City over the next eight years, so this is a problem that will likely grow if left unresolved.\nMaya Worman, a spokeswoman from the New York City Department of IT, told CNNMoney that the city will work with the kiosk operators to "enhance and adjust as needed."\n"While no content filtering system can ever be perfect, [LinkNYC partners are] constantly monitoring and updating LinkNYC to block inappropriate content on the tablets," Worman said. "We are focused on the greater good Link is already providing and will continue to provide as the project matures and expands."\nThe kiosks intend to help people stay connected to high-speed web access and communication tools wherever they are in the city. A group of companies in charge of LinkNYC, including Google (GOOGL)\'s parent company Alphabet, says its tablets are used more than 50,000 times a week, and that making free calls is one of the most popular tasks.\nAdvertising displayed on the sides of the towers help cover the costs of the services.\nCNNMoney (New York)\nFirst published July 30, 2016: 10:34 AM ET\nCNNMoney Sponsors\nSmartAssetPaid Partner\nSavings APY Keeps Climbing - Top Banks Offering 1.86%\nCertificate of Deposit Rates\nCompare the Top 3 Financial Advisors in Your Neighborhood\nIs a Money Market Account or CD Right for You?\nNextAdvisor Paid Partner\nAn Insane Card Offering 0% Interest Until Nearly 2020\nTransferring Your Balance to a 14-Month 0% APR is Ingenious\nThe Top 7 Balance Transfer Credit Cards On The Market Today\nGet $300 Back With This Outrageous New Credit Card\nU.S\nCrime + Justice\nEnergy + Environment\nExtreme Weather\nSpace + Science\nWorld\nAfrica\nAmericas\nAsia\nAustralia\nEurope\nMiddle East\nUK\nPolitics\n45\nCongress\nSupreme Court\n2018\nKey Races\nPrimary Results\nBusiness\nMarkets\nTech\nMedia\nSuccess\nVideo\nOpinion\nPolitical Op-Eds\nSocial Commentary\nHealth\nFood\nFitness\nWellness\nParenting\nVital Signs\nEntertainment\nStars\nScreen\nBinge\nCulture\nMedia\nTech\nInnovate\nGadget\nMission: Ahead\nUpstarts\nInnovative Cities\nStyle\nArts\nDesign\nFashion\nArchitecture\nLuxury\nAutos\nVideo\nTravel\nDestinations\nFood & Drink\nPlay\nStay\nVideos\nSports\nPro Football\nCollege Football\nBasketball\nBaseball\nSoccer\nOlympics\nVideo\nLive TV\nDigital Studios\nCNN Films\nHLNTV\nSchedule\nTV Shows A-Z\nCNNVR\nShop\nCNN Underscored\n-Explore\n-Wellness\n-Gadgets\n-Lifestyle\nCNN Store\nMore...\nPhotos\nLongform\nInvestigations\nCNN Profiles\nCNN Leadership\nCNN Newsletters\nWork for CNN\nMost stock quote data provided by BATS. aS"New York&rsquo;s New Public Wi-Fi Kiosks Are Spying on You, Says Civil-Liberties Group\nIntelligencer\nThe Cut\nVulture\nGrub Street\nThe Strategist\nThe Magazine\nSubscribe to the Magazine\nGive a Gift Subscription\nBuy Back Issues\nCurrent Issue Contents\nSubscribe\nSign In\nAccount\nProfile\nSign Out\nMenu\nMenu\nClose\nClose\nPolitics\nBusiness\nTechnology\nIdeas\nNewsletters\nNYMag.com\nNew York Magazine\nIntelligencer\nVulture\nThe Cut\nThe Strategist\nGrub Street\nSearch\nSearch\nClose\nMenu\nMenu\nClose\nClose\nPolitics\nBusiness\nTechnology\nIdeas\nNewsletters\nNYMag.com\nNew York Magazine\nIntelligencer\nVulture\nThe Cut\nThe Strategist\nGrub Street\nShare\nTweet\nPin It\n+Comments\nLeave a Comment\nSearch\nSearch\nClose\nprivacy\nMar. 18, 2016\nNew York\xe2\x80\x99s New Public Wi-Fi Kiosks Are Spying on You, Says Civil-Liberties Group\nBy Joe DeLessio\nOne of the new LinkNYC kiosks.\nPhoto: Richard Levine/Corbis\nLast month, the city began the rollout of its LinkNYC program, which replaces phone booths with interactive kiosks that also serve as high-speed Wi-Fi hotspots. Inevitably, we\xe2\x80\x99re now finding out that we are giving away more data than we think we are: In a letter sent to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office this week, the New York Civil Liberties Union raised concerns about \xe2\x80\x9cthe vast amount of private information retained by the LinkNYC system and the lack of robust language in the privacy policy protecting users against unwarranted government\xc2\xa0surveillance.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe NYCLU is mostly concerned with the amount of data that CityBridge, the consortium of companies behind the kiosks, can collect. CityBridge requires users to submit their email addresses and agree to allow the company to collect information on what websites they visit, as well as details about how long they view pages and what links they click. In a statement to Daily Intelligencer, LinkNYC general manageer Jen Hensley said that \xe2\x80\x9cLinkNYC does not collect or store any data on users\xe2\x80\x99 personal web browsing on their own devices.\xe2\x80\x9d According to DNAinfo, such information is collected only from the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 built-in tablet\xc2\xa0screens.\nThe NYCLU also highlighted the LinkNYC privacy policy, which states that CityBridge will make \xe2\x80\x9creasonable efforts to retain Personally Identifiable Information that you provide to us during registration no longer than 12 months after your last login.\xe2\x80\x9d In their letter, the civil-liberties group said that the promise to make \xe2\x80\x9creasonable efforts\xe2\x80\x9d to delete information is inadequate, and also noted that for regular users who don\xe2\x80\x99t have a yearlong gap between log-ins, it amounts to an indefinite retention of\xc2\xa0data.\nThe group also raised concerns about surveillance and sought a clarification about CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s policies regarding the sensors and cameras on the kiosks. From the\xc2\xa0letter:\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe policy states that \xe2\x80\x9c[CityBridge] will not give any data collected by environmental sensors or cameras to anyone other than the City or governmental law enforcement ,\xe2\x80\x9d with a few exceptions. One of those exceptions is with \xe2\x80\x9cadvanced, written permission from the City.\xe2\x80\x9d We would like to know whether the environmental sensors and cameras will be routinely feeding into any City or NYPD systems, including the Domain Awareness System; if so, that should be made explicit in the privacy policy.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAfter receiving the letter, LinkNYC responded with a\xc2\xa0statement:\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York City and CityBridge have created customer-first privacy protections to ensure our users\xe2\x80\x99 personal information stays that way \xe2\x80\x93 personal. We believe our privacy policy is the best way to protect New Yorkers and LinkNYC users while they safely and securely enjoy free superfast Wi-Fi across the five boroughs. We will continue to work to ensure legitimate concerns are addressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIn her statement to Daily Intelligencer, Hensley told us the city and CityBridge will never sell users\xe2\x80\x99 personal information. \xe2\x80\x9cCityBridge would require a subpoena or similar lawful request before sharing any data with the NYPD or law enforcement, and we will make every effort to communicate government requests to impacted users,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Hensley adds that the kiosks\xe2\x80\x99 cameras are currently inactive and not designed to feed into any NYPD systems. The mayor\xe2\x80\x99s office also emphasized that the kiosks use encryption to protect against hackers, and that any data shared with advertisers and the city will be\xc2\xa0anonymized.\nTags:\nlinknyc\nnyclu\nprivacy\n+Comments\nLeave a Comment\nNew Wi-Fi Kiosks Are Spying on You, Says NYCLU\nMost Viewed Stories\nMueller Exposed Trump\xe2\x80\x99s Biggest Betrayal\nJoe Biden Reportedly Delays Wednesday Campaign Announcement\nHighlights From CNN\xe2\x80\x99s Town Halls With Five 2020 Candidates\nSarah Sanders Lies About Reporter Who Called for Her to Be Fired for Lying\nWatch Amy Klobuchar\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Please Clap\xe2\x80\x99 Moment\nMost Viewed Stories\nMueller Exposed Trump\xe2\x80\x99s Biggest Betrayal\nJoe Biden Reportedly Delays Wednesday Campaign Announcement\nHighlights From CNN\xe2\x80\x99s Town Halls With Five 2020 Candidates\nSarah Sanders Lies About Reporter Who Called for Her to Be Fired for Lying\nWatch Amy Klobuchar\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Please Clap\xe2\x80\x99 Moment\nPromoted links by Taboola\nTHE FEED\n6 mins ago\nOperation Bury Your Boss\xe2\x80\x99s War Crimes\nStabbing a defenseless teenage captive to death. Picking off a school-age girl and an old man from a sniper\xe2\x80\x99s roost. Indiscriminately spraying neighborhoods with rockets and machine-gun fire.Navy SEAL commandos from Team 7\xe2\x80\x99s Alpha Platoon said they had seen their highly decorated platoon chief commit shocking acts in Iraq. And they had spoken up, repeatedly. But their frustration grew as months passed and they saw no sign of official action.ired of being brushed off, seven members of the platoon called a private meeting with their troop commander in March 2018 at Naval Base Coronado near San Diego. According to a confidential Navy criminal investigation report obtained by The New York Times, they gave him the bloody details and asked for a formal investigation.But instead of launching an investigation that day, the troop commander and his senior enlisted aide \xe2\x80\x94 both longtime comrades of the accused platoon leader,\xc2\xa0Special Operations Chief Edward Gallagher\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x94 warned the seven platoon members that speaking out could cost them and others their careers, according to the report.\nNavy SEALs Were Warned Against Reporting Their Chief for War Crimes\n\xe2\x80\x94New York Times\n4:45 p.m.\nimpeachment\nimpeachment\nWarren\xe2\x80\x99s Impeachment Gambit Could Work Out Well for Her\nBy Ed Kilgore\nBy endorsing impeachment even as House Democratic leaders and most of her rivals held back, she could strengthen her claim to progressive support.\n4:29 p.m.\nThe stuff of sci-fi prologues\nA \xc2\xa0dome-shaped\xc2\xa0probe\xc2\xa0known as SEIS landed on the surface of Mars in December after hitching a ride on NASA\xe2\x80\x99s InSight spacecraft.Its instruments measure surface vibrations caused by weather but are also capable of detecting movement from deep within the planet\xe2\x80\x94so called \xe2\x80\x9cmarsquakes\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94or those caused by meteorite impacts.The French space agency Cnes, which operates SEIS, said it had detected \xe2\x80\x9ca weak but distinct seismic signal\xe2\x80\x9d from the probe.According to NASA\xe2\x80\x99s Bruce Banerdt, the quake detection \xe2\x80\x9cmarks the birth of a new discipline: Martian seismology.\xe2\x80\x9d\n'Marsquake': first tremor detected on Red Planet\n\xe2\x80\x94Phys.org\nMost Popular\nMueller Exposed Department\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Inspector General has opened an investigation into whether six of President Trump\xe2\x80\x99s appointees have violated federal ethics rules by engaging with their former employers or clients on department-related business.The new inquiry, which the office confirmed in an April 18 letter to the nonprofit Campaign Legal Center, is looking into senior Interior officials, including Assistant Secretary for Insular and International Affairs Doug Domenech, White House liaison Lori Mashburn and three top staffers at the Office of Intergovernmental and External Affairs. The Campaign Legal Center detailed the officials\xe2\x80\x99 actions in\xc2\xa0a Feb. 20 letter\xc2\xa0to the inspector general\xe2\x80\x99s office, suggesting a probe was warranted.To avoid conflicts of interest, Trump signed an executive order days after taking office that requires appointees to recuse themselves from specific matters involving their former employers and clients for two years. The complaint, which cites reports in HuffPost and the Guardian as well as extensive public records, outlines how a half-dozen political appointees at Interior continued to discuss policy matters with organizations that had employed them in the past.\nSix Trump Interior appointees are being investigated for possible ethical misconduct\n\xe2\x80\x94Washington Post\n2:19 p.m.\nvision 2020\nvision 2020\nTexas Senator John Cornyn\xe2\x80\x99s Path to Reelection Just Got Tougher\nBy Sarah Jones\nTexas Democrat MJ Hegar narrowly lost a congressional race in 2018. before 8 AM today:- Joe Scarborough \xe2\x80\x9cPsycho\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAngry, Dumb and Sick\xe2\x80\x9d- Democrats \xe2\x80\x9ctotally insane\xe2\x80\x9d- New York Times \xe2\x80\x9cFake News\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEnemy of the People\xe2\x80\x9d- Paul Krugman \xe2\x80\x9cstupid\xe2\x80\x9d- Twitter \xe2\x80\x9cvery discriminatory\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x94@ddale8\n8:01 a.m.\nThe Times responds to Trump\xe2\x80\x99s latest dangerous insult\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe phrase \xe2\x80\x9cenemy of the people\xe2\x80\x9d is not just false, it\xe2\x80\x99s dangerous. It has an ugly history of being wielded by dictators and tyrants who sought to control public information.\xe2\x80\x9c - NYT publisher\xe2\x80\x99s response from Feb. to the president\xe2\x80\x99s attacks on media. https://t.co/l7ZM3cGkpu\n\xe2\x80\x94@NYTimesPR\n8:00 a.m.\nvision 2020\nvision 2020\nMedicare for All Should Hurt (Some) Hospitals and Doctors\nBy Eric Levitz\nAchieving health-care justice in the U.S. will require taking on price-gouging hospitals and overpaid specialists.\n7:58 a.m.\nWhy do congressional Democrats think they have any right to investigate King Trump?\nThe White House has instructed\xc2\xa0a former official who was in charge of the security clearance process\xc2\xa0to not comply with\xc2\xa0a House subpoena demanding his appearance\xc2\xa0for an interview, the latest move by the Trump administration to thwart Democratic-led investigations into all aspects of the presidency.After a day of tense negotiations, the White House late Monday told\xc2\xa0the former official, Carl Kline, who now works at the Defense Department, to not appear at Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s deposition, contending that Democrats were seeking access to confidential information that should be off limits.The move raises the prospect that the House Oversight Committee could seek to hold Kline in contempt, a step that Chairman Elijah Cummings warned Monday he would take. And it\xe2\x80\x99s the latest White House effort to stonewall Democratic investigations, coming the same day the Trump Organization filed a lawsuit to prevent an accounting firm from complying with Cummings\xe2\x80\x99 subpoena for President Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s past financial records.\nWhite House tells official not to comply with Democratic subpoena over security clearances\n\xe2\x80\x94CNN\n7:55 a.m.\nTrump is throwing a tantrum because New York Times columnist Paul Krugman said he \xe2\x80\x9cbetrayed his country\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe modern G.O.P. is perfectly willing to sell out America if that\xe2\x80\x99s what it takes to get tax cuts for the wealthy\xe2\x80\x9d\nI wonder if the New York Times will apologize to me a second time, as they did after the 2016 Election. But this one will have to be a far bigger &\nbetter apology. On this one they will have to get down on their knees & beg for forgiveness-they are truly the Enemy of the People!\n\xe2\x80\x94@realDonaldTrump\nSign In to Comment\nEmail\nYou\\'ll receive the next newsletter in your inbox.\n*Sorry, there was a problem signing you up.\nAlready a subscriber?\nLog in or link your magazine subscription\nLike Us\nFollow Us\nNewsletters\nAbout Us\nContact\nMedia Kit\nWe\xe2\x80\x99re Hiring\nPress\nTrademark\nPrivacy\nTerms\nAd Choices\n\xc2\xa9 2019, New York Media LLC.\nView all trademarks"

aS"LinkNYC, free Wi-Fi system, uses city\xe2\x80\x99s old phone booths | Newsday\nMenu\nToday's paper\nGet breaking news alerts from Newsday\nTurn on notifications?\nYes\nNot now\nDesktop notifications are on\nNot Enabled\nYou might be using private browsing or have notifications blocked. Please enable notifications or using normal browsing mode.\nLog in\nACCOUNT\nSubscribe\nSEARCH\nLong Island\nSports\nEntertainment\nNews\nFeed Me\nOpinion\nBusiness\nObituaries\nAll\nTODAY'S PAPER\n64\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nSEARCH\nSubscribe\nHome\nLong Island\nNassau\nSuffolk\nEducation\nCrime\nPolitics\nTowns\nInvestigations\nData and maps\nCommuting\nLI Life\nHistory\nObituaries\nSports\nYankees\nMets\nIslanders\nRangers\nJets\nGiants\nKnicks\nNets\nHigh school\nCollege\nColumns\nVideos\nScores\nBaseball\nBasketball\nBoxing\nFootball\nGolf\nHockey\nHorse Racing\nMedia\nMMA\nMotor Racing\nOlympics\nSoccer\nEntertainment\nMovies\nTV\nCelebrities\nMusic\nBooks\nTheater\nReality TV\nNassau Coliseum\nCrosswords\nPuzzles\nComics\nFeed Me\nThings to Do\nRestaurants\nFamily\nPets\nTravel\nFood and Drink\nTop 100 Restaurants\nFashion and Shopping\nHome and Garden\nLI Getaways\nRecreation\nRetirement\nAdvice\nEvents\nSpring\nNews\nNation and World\nNYC\nState and Region\nHealth\nTechnology\nLottery\nOpinion\nMatt Davies\nColumnists\nLetters to the editor\nSubmit your letter\nBusiness\nReal Estate\nTechnology\nCars\nColumns\nMutual funds\nMarkets\nStocks\nCars\nReal Estate\nJobs\nObituaries\nSpecial Sections\nClassifieds\nCrosswords\nWeather\nTraffic\nData\nHoroscopes\n64\xc2\xb0\n4/23/2019\nGood Evening\nLOG IN\nSUBSCRIBE\nNEWSLETTERS\nLOG OUT\nCHANGE PASSWORD\nMANAGE MY ACCOUNT\nMANAGE NEWSLETTERS\nNewsNew York\nLinkNYC, free Wi-Fi system, uses city\xe2\x80\x99s old phone booths\nA LinkNYC\nkiosk\nat Third Avenue\nand 15th Street in Manhattan\non Wednesday, Feb. 17, 2016. The free Wi-Fi\nstations will soon be placed throughout the five boroughs.\nPhoto Credit: Linda Rosier\nBy Emily Ngo emily.ngo@newsday.com\n@epngo\nUpdated February 18, 2016 7:34 PM\nPrint\nShare\nfbShare\nTweet\nEmail\nThousands of pay phone booths around the city that have outlived their usefulness are being transformed into \xe2\x80\x9cultrafast communication hubs\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 with a Wi-Fi network, USB charging ports, a tablet for Web browsing and a 911 button for emergency services, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Thursday.\nThe LinkNYC program will be free for the public to use through a franchise agreement with a consortium of tech and media companies, he said at the official launch.\nCityBridge, the for-profit group footing the bill for the installation and maintenance of what will be 7,500 kiosks within 7 1\xe2\x81\x842 years, will own the program\xe2\x80\x99s data.\nAbout a dozen of the kiosks were up and running in beta mode in Manhattan as of Thursday. By July, 500 stations will be in areas around the five boroughs.\nLinkNYC is a step toward an \xe2\x80\x9cinclusive city through technology,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said after testing out a kiosk near Union Square by using a tablet app to contactll the city government\xe2\x80\x99s 311 information service.\nFree Internet can help a child doing homework or an adult on a job search, the mayor said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we\xe2\x80\x99re going to have fairness, we have to make sure that there is equality of access to the Internet,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said.\nLinkNYC uses an encrypted connection, and CityBridge and city representatives promise security and privacy. CityBridge will collect data from users, who must enter an email address upon connecting, company and city officials said.\nSign up to get the latest updates\nGet Newsday's Breaking News alerts in your inbox.\nSign up\nBy clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will not share any personally identifiable information. That means your name, email address,\xe2\x80\x9d said Colin O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell, chief innovation officer at Intersection, a managing member of CityBridge. \xe2\x80\x9cWe do recognize there\xe2\x80\x99s an opportunity to create aggregate, anonymous data that we can use to create better policies, better understand broadband utilization across the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe tablets have a camera that is user-operated, and also vibration detectors to deter vandalism and detect damage, as well as security cameras for use in emergencies, O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell said.\nIntersection\xe2\x80\x99s president for media, Scott Goldsmith, said his company would cooperate with authorities when LinkNYC is used in connection with alleged crimes.\nThe city expects to receive a $500 million in advertising revenue over 10 years. The ads will appear on the kiosks; the network itself will be free of ads.\nThe Wi-Fi hubs have a 150-foot radius for their signals and are 100 times faster than most public hot spots, the mayor said. The city will eventually have the \xe2\x80\x9cbiggest and fastest network in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d de Blasio said\nThe equipment will be visited twice a week for maintenance, Intersection officials said. The kiosks are \xe2\x80\x9crugged\xe2\x80\x9d enough to withstand vandalism, and such actions would also set off vibration detectors, they said.\nBut Goldsmith said that\xe2\x80\x99s not a big worry.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe find that when things are useful ... and they\xe2\x80\x99re designed beautifully, people leave them alone,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\nTo use LinkNYC:If you\xe2\x80\x99re in range of a kiosk, log onto the LinkNYC network, register an e-mail address, accept the terms and conditions and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be online.The system provides super-fast gigabit Wi-Fi.The kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s Android tablet provides apps for web browsing, maps, 311 and domestic phone calls. For the calls, you need your own headset or you\xe2\x80\x99ll be on a speakerphone.\n\xe2\x80\x94 Ivan Pereira\nBy Emily Ngo emily.ngo@newsday.com\n@epngo\nEmily Ngo covers the White House and national politics for Newsday, having followed President Donald Trump to Washington, D.C., after following him on the campaign trail.\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nComments\nWe're revamping our Comments section. Learn more and share your input.\nMost Popular\nLast LI location of popular Italian chain closes Video may show how SCPD treated Hispanic family Killer of NYC jogger gets life without parole Village plans deer cull, says population up to\xc2\xa0500 Urshela's clutch hit in 14th lifts Yankees\nTop stories\nSuffolk police test attracts fewer applicants\nVideo may show how SCPD treated Hispanic family\nTravel agency hit with lawsuit over spring break trip\nBilly Joel not looking at retirement\nProm couple is 'different' and they embrace it\nDown Syndrome children's group co-founder dies\nMore news\nTown considers easing strict short-term rental law\nDems challenge Kabot petitions for legislature\nPolice agencies make arrests in pot checkpoints\nA fallen Marine from Long Island remembered\nDown Syndrome children's group co-founder dies\nSuffolk police test attracts fewer applicants\nQuick Links\nSubscribe\nToday\xe2\x80\x99s paper\nEmail newsletters\nNewsday Charities\nCareers\nFunbook\nObituaries\nCrosswords\nManage my account\nMedia Kit\nSitemap\nPartners\nNews 12\nam New York\nNewsday Cars\nNewsday Homes\nNewsday Jobs\nNewsday Connect\nHometown Shopper\nNews12 Varsity\nNews\nLong Island\nSports\nOpinion\nPolitics\nNews\nBusiness\nTowns\nHigh school sports\nMore\nThings to Do\nEntertainment\nRestaurants\nFamily\nTravel\nPrivacy Policy |\nTerms of service |\nSubscription terms |\nYour ad choices |\nRSS |\nContact Newsday |\nReprints & permissions |\nAdvertise with Newsday |\nHelp\nCopyright \xc2\xa9\nNewsday.
