aS'After \xe2\x80\x9clewd acts,\xe2\x80\x9d NYC\xe2\x80\x99s free Internet kiosks disable Web browsing | Ars Technica\nSkip to main content\nBiz & IT\nTech\nScience\nPolicy\nCars\nGaming & Culture\nStore\nForums\nSubscribe\nClose\nNavigate\nStore\nSubscribe\nVideos\nFeatures\nReviews\nRSS Feeds\nMobile Site\nAbout Ars\nStaff Directory\nContact Us\nAdvertise with Ars\nReprints\nFilter by topic\nBiz & IT\nTech\nScience\nPolicy\nCars\nGaming & Culture\nStore\nForums\nSettings\nFront page layout\nGrid\nList\nSite theme\nBlack on white\nWhite on black\nSign in\nComment activity\nSign up or login to join the discussions!\nStay logged in | Having trouble?\nSign up to comment and more\nSign up\nWhy NYC can\'t have nice things\n\xe2\x80\x94\nAfter \xe2\x80\x9clewd acts,\xe2\x80\x9d NYC\xe2\x80\x99s free Internet kiosks disable Web browsing\nLinkNYC disables Web browsing on tablets until better solution is found.\nJon Brodkin\n-\nSep 14, 2016 7:14 pm UTC\nEnlarge / A LinkNYC user making a phone call on the kiosk\'s tablet.LinkNYC\nreader comments\n168\nwith 71 posters participating\nShare this story\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Reddit\nThe operators of free Internet kiosks in New York City plan to\xc2\xa0disable Web browsing on publicly available tablets after reports of "lewd acts," such as people watching porn and masturbating.\nLinkNYC kiosks have been replacing New York pay phones, offering free Wi-Fi access and a tablet that can be used by anyone who doesn\'t have their own mobile device.\xc2\xa0But LinkNYC announced today\xc2\xa0that it "will be removing Web browsing on all Link tablets while we work with the City and community to explore potential solutions, like time limits."Further ReadingLink NYC kiosks provide public Wi-Fi you\xe2\x80\x99ll actually want to use\nThe tablets will still offer free phone calls, maps, and access to emergency services. New Yorkers can also\xc2\xa0continue to connect their own devices to LinkNYC Wi-Fi hotspots. But browsing on the publicly accessible tablets is being\xc2\xa0restricted after some disturbing reports.\n"A Murray Hill resident was horrified when she witnessed a vagrant masturbating" at one of the kiosks "while walking her dog Sunday morning," the\xc2\xa0New York Post reported Sunday. The\xc2\xa0Post\xc2\xa0report said that "horny homeless men have been plaguing the [LinkNYC stations] since they debuted in January."\nIn July, "LinkNYC responded to the spate of public masturbation by adding a filtering system" to limit\xc2\xa0access to porn, Gothamist reported at the time. Users apparently found ways to evade the filters, and the PIX11 news station said\xc2\xa0this week that reports\xc2\xa0of porn watching and other "lewd acts" have not stopped.\xc2\xa0Bronx borough president Ruben Diaz Jr. expressed concern.\xc2\xa0"After learning about the inappropriate and over-extended usage of LinkNYC kiosks throughout the city, in particular in Manhattan, it is time to make adjustments that will allow all of our city residents to use this service safely and comfortably," Diaz said, according to PIX11.\nLinkNYC is provided by a consortium called CityBridge through a franchise agreement granted by the city. LinkNYC\'s announcement today said that "some users have been monopolizing the Link tablets and using them inappropriately, preventing others from being able to use them while frustrating the residents and businesses around them. The kiosks were never intended for anyone\xe2\x80\x99s extended, personal use and we want to ensure that Links are accessible and a welcome addition to New York City neighborhoods."\nDespite the setback,\xc2\xa0LinkNYC is excited about the program\'s successes. "With 400 Links installed in three boroughs, nearly 475,000 New Yorkers and visitors have signed up to use the fastest broadband publicly available in New York City, and they have used it more than 21 million times," the group said. "We\xe2\x80\x99ve heard from New Yorkers who use the Links to save data on their mobile plans, call relatives across the country, and get a much-needed quick charge."\nArs reporter\xc2\xa0Valentina Palladino used one of the kiosks last month and demonstrated the LinkNYC tablet\'s features in\xc2\xa0a hands-on video (link is safe for work).\nreader comments\n168\nwith 71 posters participating\nShare this story\nShare on Facebook\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Reddit\nJon Brodkin\nJon is Ars Technica\'s senior IT reporter, covering the FCC and broadband, telecommunications, wireless technology, and more.\nEmail jon.brodkin@arstechnica.com\n//\nTwitter @JBrodkin\nYou must login or create an account to comment.\nChannel Ars Technica\n\xe2\x86\x90 Previous story Next story \xe2\x86\x92\nRelated Stories\nSponsored Stories\nPowered by\nToday on Ars\nStore\nSubscribe\nAbout Us\nRSS Feeds\nView Mobile Site\nContact Us\nStaff\nAdvertise with us\nReprints\nNewsletter Signup\nJoin the Ars Orbital Transmission mailing list to get weekly updates delivered to your inbox.\nCNMN Collection\nWIRED Media Group\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Cond\xc3\xa9 Nast. aS"Meet the Brave Souls Who Read LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Two Different Privacy Policies |\n| Observer\nTechnology|\nEconomy|\nStartups|\nPersonal Finance|\nEvents\nNewsletters\nSearch for:\nSubmit\nObserver\nPolitics\nNational\nInternational\nNew York\nNew Jersey\nEditorials\nNational Security\nLifestyle\nFashion\nCelebrity\nFood & Drink\nHome Design\nReal Estate\nTravel\nBusiness\nTechnology\nPersonal Finance\nStartups\nInternet Culture\nMedia\nEntertainment\nTV\nMovies\nMusic\nBooks\nArts\nTheater\nVisual Art\nDance\nOpera\nHealth\nPsychology\nRelationships\nFitness\nNutrition\nVideos\nEvents\nNewsletters\nFreedom from Privacy\nMeet the Brave Souls Who Read LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s Two Different Privacy Policies\nBy Brady Dale \xe2\x80\xa2 07/28/16 9:17am\nForeign press checking out a LinkNYC kiosk on 3rd Avenue in Manhattan). TIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP/Getty Images\nLinkNYC has been replacing all of New York\xe2\x80\x99s public payphones with advertising emblazoned wifi kiosks. Residents and visitors curious about what those kiosks will do with data their routers, cameras and Bluetooth beacons collect about them might look on\xc2\xa0its website for some kind of privacy policy. There is one there, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not that one. Columbia professor Benjamin Dean got a big laugh at this weekend\xe2\x80\x99s HOPE XI conference in Manhattan when he pointed out that the privacy policy on LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s website only applies to the website itself, not to the actual network of kiosks. It\xe2\x80\x99s not quite as bad as it sounds. In LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s defense, the page in question points out the difference between the two policies up top, but given the cursory way most people read online, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprising if many users initially missed it (I did). Meanwhile, it\xe2\x80\x99s encouraging that Dean and his co-panelist,\xc2\xa0New York Civil Liberties Union attorney Mariko Hirose, actually did read those two privacy policies and that a room full of people showed up to hear\xc2\xa0what they found. Tech privacy policies in general have been constructed primarily to guard companies against liability and discourage users from reading closely. This is unfortunate. They could be standardized and easy to understand. That said, Dean and Hirose\xe2\x80\x99s workshop this weekend\xc2\xa0showed the internet\xe2\x80\x99s power of crowdsourced self-defense. In a way, it countered\xc2\xa0a working paper\xc2\xa0by communications professors Jonathan Obar and Anne Oeldorf-Hirsch which received attention last week for showing that out of a group of 543 college students asked to check out a new website, only 11 noticed that when they signed up they agreed\xc2\xa0to terms that gave its operators rights to the users\xe2\x80\x99 first born children.\nCoverage of the paper focused on the fact that so few users even looked at the papers, but what surprised me was that anyone looked at all. In other words, there\xe2\x80\x99s a Dean or a Hirose in any group.\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think the answer is to find a way to have everyone read every privacy policy. This, as I note in the paper above, is an \xe2\x80\x98unattainable ideal.'\xe2\x80\x9d Obar wrote the Observer in an email. \xe2\x80\x9cSo efforts to standardize language, even simplify language, even in accordance with American law aimed at making policies easier to understand, continue to fail.\xe2\x80\x9dTo a degree, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter if everyone checks everything. Terms of service apply to lots of people at once. If one person looks at them and sees something disturbing, he or she can put out the word. If it\xe2\x80\x99s bad enough the internet will respond.\nA LinkNYC wifi kiosk going in. Edward Blake / Flickr\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s powerful about this weekend\xe2\x80\x99s workshop: Dean and Hirose told a roomful of people what they found. Those people chattered about it on Twitter and then a reporter at Inverse wrote a detailed story breaking what they had to say\xc2\xa0down.LinkNYC, by the way, is a product of Intersection, which is owned by Sidewalk Labs, which is owned by Alphabet (the company formerly known as Google). Google likes to link data about your behavior to\xc2\xa0your location. Your phone\xe2\x80\x99s wi-fi antenna constantly broadcasts a map of your favorite places, as artists dramatized with a multimedia installation next year. It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprising if LinkNYC kiosks started recording which wifi access points the phones passing it are looking for.As Hirose pointed out in the talk, just because LinkNYC kiosks don\xe2\x80\x99t use a sensor now doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean they won\xe2\x80\x99t. \xe2\x80\x9cThey essentially have a privacy policy that says, \xe2\x80\x98we can collect anything and do anything\xe2\x80\x99 and that sets the outer bound,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\xc2\xa0The policy does forbid the company from some activities. For example, it promises not to use facial recognition, which has become dramatically more powerful; however, nothing stops the company from retracting that guarantee. In fact, Hirose said that she\xe2\x80\x99s been told by the company that the kiosk\xe2\x80\x99s cameras haven\xe2\x80\x99t even been turned on yet, but it is also under no obligation to tell the public when the cameras go live.And when users notice an objectionable change in policy: what can they\xc2\xa0do from there? If a website really did try to reserve rights to all members\xe2\x80\x99 first born child, the outcry\xc2\xa0of the internet would likely be enough to get the policy retracted (though the provision could also attract a niche audience for a company, but only if it\xc2\xa0promised). The trouble is, here in America, that\xe2\x80\x99s really all we have to defend ourselves with: outrage. If it\xe2\x80\x99s deafening, it can be enough, but if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t amount to more than a slow rumble, tech companies will shrug it off with a bit of spin.\nMayor Bill de Blaisio, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got mail. Michael Appleton for the Mayoral Photography Office\nFor example, the NYCLU sent a letter to the city in March pushing for stronger language around data volume, retention, government use and sharing, but the city\xe2\x80\x94which has secured a substantial promised payday from Sidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x94has ignored it. There\xe2\x80\x99s little more attorneys can do under current law. We have this outmoded idea called the \xe2\x80\x9cthird party doctrine,\xe2\x80\x9d that once someone uses a company\xe2\x80\x99s service, they give up all rights to privacy over whatever data that use generates.For example, I don\xe2\x80\x99t really like Facebook, but I keep it active because I want to get the invite if someone wants me to come to a party. Yet the fact that I want to get invitations leaves everything else I might have done on the site over the last 10 years up for grabs by the government and Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s commercial partners. Of course, I could quit the site, but walking away from those invitations would impose a very high cost. Most people are\xc2\xa0unwilling to pay the price of giving up such networks, which allows their owners to gradually ratchet up the rights they grant themselves under terms of service that we can\xe2\x80\x99t negotiate unless we do it en masse.It\xe2\x80\x99s not that way everywhere. Last week, French authorities\xc2\xa0called out Microsoft for releasing the Windows 10 operating system, which turns personal computers into the sort of tattletales that smartphones have been all along. It\xe2\x80\x99s one more way in which all Americans envy the French.\xe2\x80\x9cData privacy self-management is a fallacy under the current model,\xe2\x80\x9d Obar wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cMore needs to be done to involve users (automated systems, infomediaries\xe2\x80\xa6) and ensure that the mosaic of Big Data approaches and threats can be properly monitored.\xe2\x80\x9dBig tech companies find new ways to watch us every day. It\xe2\x80\x99s reassuring, at least, to know that there are a few people out there watching back.UPDATE: A previous version of this story incorrectly identified Benjamin Dean as Benjamin Read. July 29, 2016 10:52 AM.\nFiled Under:\nBusiness, Facebook, Video, Google, Microsoft Corporation, France, Privacy, surveillance\nSEE ALSO: Will Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s New \xe2\x80\x98Clear History\xe2\x80\x99 Feature Actually Help Protect Privacy?\nMust Reads\nObserver\nPolitics\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\nArts\nHealth\nContact\nAbout\nAdvertise\nNewsletters\nSitemap\nPrivacy\nTerms\nPowered by WordPress.com VIP\nWe noticed you're using an ad blocker.\nWe get it: you like to have control of your own internet experience. But advertising revenue helps support our journalism. To read our full stories, please turn off your ad blocker.\nWe'd really appreciate it.\nHow Do I Whitelist Observer?\nHow Do I Whitelist Observer?\nBelow are steps you can take in order to whitelist Observer.com on your browser:\nFor Adblock:\nClick the AdBlock button on your browser and select Don't run on pages on this domain.\nFor Adblock Plus on Google Chrome:\nClick the AdBlock Plus button on your browser and select Enabled on this site.\nFor Adblock Plus on Firefox:\nClick the AdBlock Plus button on your browser and select Disable on Observer.com.\nThen Reload the Page"

just four days before the event - after a torrent of furious tweets accusing media of partisan bias\nAll Kohl\'s 1,150 stores to accept Amazon returns: Fashion retailer will send back opened packages for free and will NOT require a box, label or reason\nPervert Columbia gynecologist is hit with new lawsuit by 25 women - including two underage girls - who claim he licked their genitals, groped their naked bodies, and squeezed one new mother\'s nipples so hard her breast milk came out\nREVEALED: Obama\'s former national security advisor Susan Rice made $286,000 on the board of Netflix last year after conservative viewers claimed they cancelled their subscription over her appointment\nFilthy home of of woman, 54, who was arrested for \'dumping seven newborn puppies in the trash\' is revealed after 38 other dogs were removed\n\'This is your Nuremberg moment\': Amal Clooney urges UN Security Council to take action on \'genocide\' of sexual violence perpetrated by ISIS fighters\nMIT-educated engineer and a Chinese businessman are charged with conspiring to steal trade secrets from General Electric to benefit China - and\xc2\xa0 hiding data in picture of a SUNSET\n\'If it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for the homeless guy digging through the trash they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been found.\' Meet the hero who rescued seven newborn puppies that were left for dead in scorching Coachella heat\nPolice report reveals Robert Kraft\'s sex worker, 58, went from room to room performing manual and oral jobs on men who groped, grabbed and kissed her - and even stimulated her genitals\nListen to the first marsquake ever recorded: NASA\'s InSight lander detects likely tremor on the red planet in what could finally be \'proof that Mars is still seismically active\'\n\'It\'s a p***ing contest\': Rival Connecticut politicians take urine tests to prove they are clean after they accused each other of abusing drugs in a nasty feud\nFrom capturing unstaged moments to choosing colours that \'pop\' on camera, experts reveal the clever tricks Kate uses when taking snaps of her children (and say she\'s definitely improved over time)\nTrump meets Twitter boss Jack Dorsey face-to-face just hours after blasting company\'s \'political games\' as CEO says he welcomes discussion about \'the health of the public conversation\' online\nTrump attacks Twitter as \'playing political games\' in making it \'hard for people to sign on\' as he complains social media site doesn\'t \'treat me well as a Republican\' on day it reported soaring earnings\n\'They will have to get down on their knees & beg for forgiveness\': Trump demands an apology from The New York Times as he also slams CNN and MSNBC\'s morning shows in rant against media\n\'I screamed for 5 or 10 minutes!\' Winner of $768 million Powerball jackpot - third largest in US history- is revealed to be a 24-year-old man who has already quit his job and plans to use the money to \'help out the world\'\nUSC soccer coach pleads guilty in college admissions scam after signing plea agreement that could result in her testifying against Lori Loughlin at trial\n\'Sinatra made a brand-new start in New York, just like Miss Sorokin did\': Fake German heiress\' lawyer compares her to the legendary crooner because he faked his own success by paying women to come to his concerts\nPIERS MORGAN: Why should the taxpayer fork out millions to make Harry and Meghan the King and Queen of Africa just to keep them away from Wills and Kate?\n\xe2\x80\x98She will always be a Southern California woman at heart.\' Meghan\'s brother takes DailyMailTV down memory lane to the places where she grew up with \'a lot of love\' and says he hopes her impending baby will heal broken family\n\'I can keep these boys under control!\' Dean McDermott will referee Celebrity Boxing match between Thomas \'The Duke\' Markle Jr and Mark Wahlberg\'s BFF Henry \'Nacho\' Luan\nHarry and Meghan share a sweet message wishing nephew Louis a happy birthday with \'lots of love\' on Instagram as the prince turns one\nMeghan is a \'showstopping firecracker\' who is \'all about her brand\' while Kate is \'dignified\' but \'needs to \'relax more\', Princess Diana\'s former astrologer claims\nPrevious\nNext\n\'It will be the biggest and fastest network in the world\': Free Wi-Fi kiosks go live as part of New York\'s LinkNYC program The kiosks, referred to as Links, were launched on ThursdayUsers are able to make free domestic calls, charge their cell phones, access the Internet, and dial 911Mayor Bill de Blasio said: \'In 2016, Internet access is not a luxury. It\'s not something optional\'His office has said \'Overall, at least at 7,500 Links \xe2\x80\x93 and as many as 10,000 \xe2\x80\x93 will be installed across the five boroughs\'By Zoe Szathmary For Dailymail.com\nPublished: 16:39 EDT, 20 February 2016\n|\nUpdated: 19:32 EDT, 20 February 2016\ne-mail\n68 shares\n51 View\ncomments\nFree Wi-Fi kiosks with New York City\'s LinkNYC program were launched Thursday.Mayor Bill de Blasio was filmed telling reporters at a news conference: \'LinkNYC will be the Wi-Fi network New York City deserves.\'It will be the biggest and fastest network in the world - and completely free of charge.\'And one thing I know about my fellow New Yorkers: they like things that are completely free of charge, so this is going to be very popular.\'Scroll down for video\nFree Wi-Fi kiosks with New York City\'s LinkNYC program were launched Thursday. Mayor Bill de Blasio is seen Thursday at the launch event\nNecessity: de Blasio said Thursday \'In 2016, Internet access is not a luxury. It\'s not something optional. It\'s something everybody needs and we\'re gonna have fairness\'\nThe mayor\'s office said in a news release: \'These kiosks, called \'Links,\' will provide New Yorkers with an incredibly fast, secure and private Wi-Fi network with a 150-foot radius, free domestic calling, two USB charging ports, a tablet for accessing the internet, and a red 911 button to contact emergency services.\'Overall, at least at 7,500 Links \xe2\x80\x93 and as many as 10,000 \xe2\x80\x93 will be installed across the five boroughs.\'Several Links were part of a January 2016 beta test, New York reported.De Blasio said at the Thursday news conference: \'In 2016, Internet access is not a luxury. It\'s not something optional.\'It\'s something everybody needs and we\'re gonna have fairness.\'We have to make sure that there is a quality of access to the Internet.\'\nThe mayor\'s office said that \'Overall, at least at 7,500 Links \xe2\x80\x93 and as many as 10,000 \xe2\x80\x93 will be installed across the five boroughs\'According to the mayor\'s office, \'Links will be installed and activated on a rolling basis, with over 500 kiosks in all five boroughs by the end of July, and over 4,500 by mid-2019.\'It also said Thursday that \'The five-borough network is funded entirely through advertising revenues, will be built at no-cost to taxpayers, create new local jobs and generate more than $500 million in revenue for the City.\'de Blasio told reporters: \'So with LinkNYC, New Yorkers will be able to access free Wi-Fi at speeds of up to one gigabit per second.\'That\'s 100 times faster than most public hot spots around the country.\'\nThe kiosks can be used to charge phones and also make domestic calls. LinkNYC is a free program for usersCompanies Intersection, Qualcomm, and CIVIQ Smartscapes together form a consortium called CityBridge which has worked on the program.Intersection\'s chief innovation officer Colin O\'Donnell was filmed saying at the press conference: \'We ask for your email address so that we can communicate with you if there is changes in policy.\'If there is \xe2\x80\x93 if we need to contact you in any way so, privacy is very important to us.\'\nAccording to the mayor\'s office, \'Links will be installed and activated on a rolling basis, with over 500 kiosks in all five boroughs by the end of July, and over 4,500 by mid-2019\'\nLinkNYC posted this photograph on Facebook January 26, writing: \'Great photo from @civiqsmartscapes of the #linknyc street team on 3rd Avenue today! If you see them, say hello\'The mayor\'s counsel Maya Wiley was filmed telling reporters: \'The city does not own the data.\'CityBridge actually owns the data. The city will only have anonymized data.\'We will not have any personally identifiable information on anyone using the system.\'Wiley said the information cannot be accessed via the Freedom of Information Act, or FOIA.\nRELATED ARTICLES\nPrevious 1 Next\nApple doesn\'t have to share the software used to hack into...\nRiding into the future: FEMAIL tests the chain-free electric...\nTech, gadgets and toys: Hottest new trends at this year\'s...\nEccentric tech millionaire John McAfee says his team of...\nShare this article\nShare\n68 shares\nO\'Donnell told reporters: \'We advise you to use common Internet hygiene practices to always ensure that you are connecting to an SSL connection when you are doing anything that requires a level of privacy.\'Most websites and services, like banks, will always use SSL.\'We do offer an encrypted connection, which is incredibly secure.\'So the latest generations of phones, example iOS7 and up, will be able to use this encrypted network.\'And that\'s encrypted from your device out to the Internet, offering an incredibly strong level of encryption for your connection.\'For more information on the program, visit the website for LinkNYC.\nMap: A map from LinkNYC\'s website shows live kiosks (in blue) located along Third Avenue in Manhattan\nAdvertisement\nRead more:\nMayor de Blasio Announces Public Launch of LinkNYC Program aS"Web Browsing Removed From LinkNYC Kiosks Amid Concerns \xe2\x80\x93 CBS New York\nMenu\nSports\nCBS2 VideosCBS Sports LiveGiantsNew York GiantsJetsNew York JetsYanksNew York YankeesMetsNew York MetsKnicksNew York KnicksNetsNew Jersey NetsRangersNew York RangersDevilsIslesOdds\nVideo\nCBSN New YorkCBS2 Digital FeaturesSpecial ReportsCBSN From CBS NewsCBS Sports LiveNewsWeatherSnap Shot NYCHealth & FitnessThe Dig With Elle McLoganAll Latest Videos\nBest Of\nBest OfTravelTantillo\nMore\nContests & PromotionsPhoto GalleriesTravelEntertainment\nNews\nAll News\nNew YorkHealthWatchNew JerseyConsumerConnecticutBusinessUS & WorldEntertainmentPoliticsTechOffbeat & OddOnly CBS\nLatest Headlines\nBrooklyn Botanic Garden Hosts Annual Cherry Blossom Festival This WeekendThe annual Sakura Matsuri Festival kicks off this weekend, celebrating all things Japanese.Lifelike Sculptures Garnering Lots Of Attention In N.J. MinneapolisWith thousands of Final Four fans heading to downtown Minneapolis in the coming days, you better believe the Instagram filters will be flying.\nCBS Entertainment\nCBS Entertainment\nLatest Photos\nVisiting The Armour-Stiner (Octagon) HouseHidden along the Hudson River is an eight-sided house that fascinates people who admire odd architecture.\nIcons & Disruptors Podcast\nCBSN New YorkWatch Now\nWeb Browsing Removed From LinkNYC Kiosks Amid\xc2\xa0Concerns\nSeptember 14, 2016 at 8:33 pmFiled Under:Alex Silverman, Free Wi-Fi Kiosks, Jessica Layton, LinkNYC\nNEW YORK (CBSNewYork)\xe2\x80\x93 LinkNYC kiosks throughout the city will no longer have access to internet browsing.\nIn a press release Wednesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio said that due to concerns regarding loitering and extended use of free internet, that browsing capabilities will be removed from LinkNYC tablets.\nHis administration said that the move will not affect LinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s other services including Wi-Fi, free phone calls and access to key city services.\nThe web browsing feature\xc2\xa0will be\xc2\xa0disabled as of September 14.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeb browsing will be disabled in a two-phase process beginning immediately this afternoon. The first step will be a testing phase on a few of the kiosks previously used for testing. The second step will be network-wide implementation, which will be complete within 36-48 hours,\xe2\x80\x9d the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s press release said.\nSince the project launched, there have been nearly 400 Links installed in three boroughs.\nPeople making themselves comfortable at the kiosks \xe2\x80\x93 many of them homeless \xe2\x80\x93 was already an issue for some New Yorkers back in June. Many took to documenting the problem on social media.\nMurray Hill resident Evan Rofheart told CBS2\xe2\x80\x99s Jessica Layton that he has been fed up since February as he watched people camp out at the free Wi-Fi kiosks.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne individual put a chair here and sat for hours,\xe2\x80\x9d Rofheart said.\nThis past weekend at the corner of 31st Street and Third Avenue, one of Rofheart\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors snapped a photo of someone who had been masturbating while watching pornography.\nNear the Port Authority Bus Terminal, one man sat at a kiosk for 30 minutes as commuters squeezed past.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s obviously trying to get something done, so it\xe2\x80\x99s no a problem for me,\xe2\x80\x9d Chris Palatucci said.\nBut Rob Bijoyan said one homeless man recently spent six hours plugged into a kiosk.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very unpleasant, it actually seems like it pulls these people to the units themselves,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\nDorri Olds has a LinkNYC kiosk on the block where she has lived for more than 20 years.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I see is people that look very stoned, and they\xe2\x80\x99re singing, and I guess they think they\xe2\x80\x99re Beyonce or whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d she told WCBS 880\xe2\x80\x99s Alex Silverman.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s general manager Jennifer Hensley said they have heard the concerns loud and clear.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe changes we\xe2\x80\x99ve made today are the removal of the web browser on the tablet on every kiosk in New York City,\xe2\x80\x9d Hensley said, adding they \xe2\x80\x9clearned quickly\xe2\x80\x9d and are \xe2\x80\x9cbeing responsive.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBack in September, LinkNYC said they were aware of the concerns and addressing them.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are in conversations with the city about how to ensure that links remain open and accessible for all, and are not monopolized by any individual users,\xe2\x80\x9d it said.\nCity Councilman Cory Johnson (D-3rd) was happy to see the free internet access go.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s going to make a big difference, but we\xe2\x80\x99re going to see it if it ends up putting an end to some of the behavior we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson said.\nThe web-browsing options will be gone by Thursday night.\nFollow Us\nfacebook_urltwitter_urlyoutube_urlinstagram_urlreddit_urllinkedin_url\nOur\nNewsletter\nMost\nViewed\n'What We Heard, We Didn't Like': NYPD Counterterror Chief Analyzes Sri Lanka Attacks\nBrooklyn Man Accused Of Brutal Ax Murder Of Pregnant Woman\nExclusive: Mother Alleges Horrific Stabbing Attack By Babysitter Angry Over Pay\nJudge Denies Motion On Juror Misconduct In Vetrano Case\nChanel Lewis Sentenced To Life In Prison In 2016 Murder Of Queens Jogger Karina Vetrano\nSpecial Needs Drum Corps To Make History By Competing At World Championships\nFamily Of Singer Kate Smith Speak Out On Racism Controversy\nVideo: Suspect Uses Police Taser On 3 Officers During Brooklyn Robbery\nConnecticut Man Facing Charges In Anguilla Over Death Of Resort Worker\n2 NYPD Patrol Officers Under aS'How smart cities like New York City will drive enterprise change | Computerworld\nClose Ad\nDon\'t Miss:\nWindows 10 update (and retirement) calendar\nOutlook vs. Gmail\nIDG TECH(talk)\nTech event calendar\nResources/White Papers\nSearch\ncomputerworld\nSign In | Register\nHi! Here are the latest Insider stories.\nHow to fix six Windows 10 headaches\nGoogle hopes AI, collaboration will win G Suite customers\nMicrosoft surrenders control over Windows 10 upgrades: What you need to know\nWindows 10 update (and retirement) calendar: Mark these dates\nMore Insider\nSign Out\nSearch for\nSuggestions for you\nInsider email\nBrowsers\nCloud Computing\nAll Cloud Computing\nCloud Security\nCloud Storage\nHybrid Cloud\nPrivate Cloud\nPublic Cloud\nData Centers\nAll Data Centers\nData Management\nDisaster Recovery\nHigh-Performance Computing (HPC)\nInfrastructure\nVirtualization\nEmerging Technology\nAll Emerging Technology\n3D Printing\nArtificial Intelligence\nInternet of Things\nRobotics\nWearables\nHardware\nAll Hardware\nChromebooks\nMacs\nPCs\nIT Leadership\nAll IT Leadership\nCareers\nDigital Transformation\nOutsourcing\nSkills and Training\nInternet\nAll Internet\nCommerce\nSearch\nSocial Networking\nWeb Applications\nMobile\nAll Mobile\nAndroid\nCellular Networks\nMobile Apps\nMobile Security\nPayments\nSmartphones\nTablets\niOS\nOperating Systems\nAll Operating Systems\nChrome Management\nEnterprise Architecture\nOffice Software\nOpen Source\nSaaS\nSocial Business\nUnified Communications\nVertical Industries\nAll Vertical Industries\nFinancial Services Industry\nGovernment IT\nHealth Care Industry\nRetail Industry\nThe Future of TeamworkSponsored by Cisco Webex\nNews\nFeatures\nReviews\nBlogs\nOpinions\nInsider\nShark Tank\nSlideshows\nVideo\nDigital Magazine\nDigital Downloads\nNewsletters\nComputerworld Events\nResources/White Papers\n\xc3\x97\nClose\nHome\nMobile\nOpinion by Mike Elgan\nHow smart cities like New York City will drive enterprise change\nLaying high-speed fiber across an entire city and connecting sensor-based public Wi-Fi kiosks is good for the public -- and very good for business.\nEmail a friend\nTo\nUse commas to separate multiple email addresses\nFrom\nPrivacy Policy\nThank you\nYour message has been sent.\nSorry\nThere was an error emailing this page.\nBy Mike Elgan\nContributing Columnist,\nComputerworld |\nPT\nSmart Cities\nSmart Cities: New York\n(8:55)\nSmart Cities: New York\n(8:55)\nMore for you to like:\nSmart Cities: Singapore\nSmart Cities: Singapore\n(13:05)\nSmart Cities: Barcelona\nSmart Cities: Barcelona\nSmart Cities: Montreal\nSmart Cities: Montreal\n(14:56)\nNew York\'s smart city strategy centers around multiple small pilot projects. Computerworld pounded the Manhattan pavement to see how citizens are taking to the tech changes around them.\nCurrent Job Listings\nOpinion by Mike Elgan\nThere\'s no such thing as a \'remote\'...\nThe \'retail apocalypse\' is a myth\nSmartphones make people distracted and...\nThe latest iPhones show why A.I. is the...\nHow smart cities like New York City...\nHow voice technology will re-shape...\nSorry, gamers. Magic Leap means...\nHow to survive in the fake-information...\nWhy smartwatches failed\nApple\'s iPhone X proves it: Silicon...\nShow More\nEditor\'s Note: This story has been updated\xc2\xa0to clarify the respective roles of Intersection and ZenFi in the formation of New York\xe2\x80\x99s smart city infrastructure.Everybody talks about smart cities, but few are doing anything about it.New York City is an exception. It\'s in the early stages of an ambitious project to blanket the city with ultrafast Wi-Fi via smart kiosks, which will replace obsolete public telephones.These kiosks are the work of a Google-backed startup called Intersection. The company has already installed around 1,000 kiosks, and aims to install more than 6,000 more, Intersection Chief Innovation Officer Colin O\'Donnell said in an interview this week. Mike Elgan\nIntersection Chief Innovation Officer Colin O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell on stage at Cannes Lions on June 18, 2017.\nEach kiosk is around nine feet high and relatively flat. Each flat side houses a big-screen display that pays for the whole operation with advertising. The screens also show emergency and other public information.A smaller user terminal on the skinny edge facing away from the street allows one user at a time to access information and make calls. The screen is a locked-down Android tablet with a custom interface offering a few apps to access various services, including one for paying parking tickets and another for voter registration. [ To comment on this story, visit Computerworld\'s Facebook page. ]Below the screen on the left is a big, red button for a one-press 911 emergency call. Under that is an audio jack, where non-iPhone users can insert their headphones or earbuds for privacy. (The hardware supports standard audio jacks, but not Apple\'s newer lightning cable configuration.) Next to those options is a numeric keypad for dialing calls. And below all that are two USB ports for charging devices.[ Take this mobile device management course from PluralSight and learn how to secure devices in your company without degrading the user experience. ] Each kiosk provides free, high-speed Wi-Fi for anyone in range. By selecting the Wi-Fi network at one kiosk, and authenticating with an email address, each user will be automatically connected to every other LinkNYC kiosk they get within range of. Eventually, anyone will be able to walk around most of the city without losing the connection to these hotspots. Wide-angle cameras on each side of the kiosks point up and down the street and sidewalk, approximating a 360-degree view. The company claims it deletes stored videos after 7 days, unless there\'s a compelling reason to keep them, according to O\'Donnell.While the built-in kiosk tablet doesn\'t appear to offer a high-performance user experience, the public Wi-Fi is blistering fast -- far faster than the average connection speeds offered by mobile carriers over cell networks. Some New York content creators producing massive amounts of content, such as HD videos, are now hauling their laptops down to the street for faster uploading. CityBridge\nIntersection has already installed 1,000 LinkNYC smart kiosks on New York sidewalks. It\'s planning more than 6,000 more.\nThis is possible because LinkNYC kiosks are connected by fiber.It\'s paid for by the advertising and costs nothing to taxpayers. In fact, the city is expected to earn $500 million over the 10-year Intersection contract. London is the second Intersection city, where the project is called InLinkUK and the kiosks are called "InLinks." The London project is more modest, with a goal of around 1,000 kiosks. O\'Donnell told me Intersection plans to deploy in 20 more cities after that.Intersection is tightly conjoined with Alphabet\'s Sidewalk Labs company, which works to accelerate and guide the creation of smart cities. They even share an office in Manhattan. Other partners in the LinkNYC project include Qualcomm and\xc2\xa0Civiq Smartscapes (BT is a partner for the London project).Smart cities: the immediate impactLinkNYC is already changing New York; two million people are now using the system -- twice as many as in January.The existence of smart-city implementations like Intersection\'s LinkNYC means that New Yorkers won\'t actually need mobile contracts anymore. Most who would otherwise pay for them will no doubt continue to do so for the convenience. But those who could not afford a phone contract in the past will have ubiquitous fast connectivity in the future.This strongly erodes the digital divide within smart cities. A 2015 study conducted by New York City found that more than a quarter of city households had no internet connectivity at home, and more than half a million people didn\'t own their own computer.At the same time, smart city kiosks widen the gap between urban and rural people, where the urban take a big leap forward and the rural stay behind with no solution in sight.Smart cities are built on citywide fiber networks, which can eventually (as with the case of ZenFi\'s network) connect 5G wireless antennas on every street corner and every floor of every office building back to the core network. This densification of the wireless networks is the true hero of the smart cities revolution, enabling not only smart-city kiosks, but capacity for high-speed wireless applications on smartphones and tablets, widespread IoT deployments, mobile augmented reality applications, self-driving cars and more.It\'s also amazing that New York is leading the smart city charge. Because if the concept can make it there, it can make it anywhere. Dark-fiber deployments in New York typically cost far more than in just about any other city because of heavy unionization and the scale of any disruption when streets have to be closed for fiber installation.New York\'s example in aggressively enabling thousands of high-speed kiosks also puts pressure on other U.S. cities to follow suit. The first step is not only to wire up entire cities with fast fiber, but to architect it in a way that enables flexible deployment, as ZenFi is doing. And this is the best part of the smart cities revolution.Smart cities: the long-term impactO\'Donnell claims that smart city rollouts happen in three phases, which he says is about "building the city from the internet up."1. Instrumentation 2. Intelligence 3. Responsiveness.New York is currently at the beginning of the instrumentation phase, where the immediate benefits are to underserved and under-connected members of the public. Over the next 15 years, the city will go through the other two phases, where sensor data will be processed by artificial intelligence (A.I.) to gain unprecedented insights about traffic, environment and human behavior and eventually use it to intelligently re-direct traffic and shape other city functions.The two most transformational technologies will be augmented reality (AR) and autonomous cars. AR won\'t be one specific set of technologies, but many variations that will range from low-bandwidth and even offline applications to ultra HD streaming AR.New York\'s LinkNYC kiosks mean everyone in the city will have network support for high-end streaming AR as they move around the city. Enterprises operating in the city can deploy top-of-the-line equipment and applications and rely on 5G connectivity on every block.And as autonomous cars gradually roll out, New York will be well positioned to be one of the first cities to legalize them, because they\'ll be safer thanks to 5G, sensors and data from all those kiosks. This will enable a revolution in delivery systems, among other things.(Note: The use of LinkNYC kiosks in the future for AR and self-driving cars is my own\xc2\xa0expectation; it\'s not based on current plans by Intersection.)\xc2\xa0Risks and rewardsSmart kiosks do carry risks, however. One involves privacy. O\'Donnell said privacy policies aren\'t set by Intersection, but are negotiated agreements between the company and the city. So if a city wants to use those cameras and sensors for surveillance, it can.But the biggest risk revolves around hacking and the theft of data, monitoring of cameras and -- a worst-case scenario -- eventual control of the "Responsiveness" phase technology, where mayhem is deliberately caused.Futurists and tech pundits often assume that if a beneficial set of technologies exists, it will be implemented and widely distributed. But this is obviously not true. Technology revolutions require drivers to realize them.In this case, New York City and Intersection are the drivers, showing the enormous benefits of ubiquitous high-speed wireless, as well as connected sensor stations all over a city. This will drive huge demand in other cities to replicate the technology, which will create demand for city-wide flexible dark-fiber installation, which will transform how enterprises operate.For enterprises, the advances change assumptions about what\'s possible for how offices, warehouses, field service, delivery and, eventually, next-generation technologies will work.The most important calculation is the question of where: Where should offices, warehouses, factories and other major locations be built? Answer: They\'ll gravitate to smart cities. Because the benefits to enterprises of ubiquitous and dense high-speed wireless, sensor-based city services and fiber everywhere will prove incalculable.\nRelated:\nMobile\nWi-Fi\nMobile Apps\nGoogle\nMike Elgan is a technology-obsessed journalist, author, blogger, podcaster and digital nomad. Learn more at his website: elgan.com.\nFollow\nHow collaboration apps foster digital transformation\nOpinion by Mike Elgan\nThere\'s no such thing as a \'remote\' employee\nThe \'retail apocalypse\' is a myth\nSmartphones make people distracted and unproductive\nThe latest iPhones show why A.I. is the new electricity\nCurrently reading\nHow smart cities like New York City will drive enterprise...\nHow voice technology will re-shape business\nSorry, gamers. Magic Leap means business!\nHow to survive in the fake-information age\nWhy smartwatches failed\nApple\'s iPhone X proves it: Silicon Valley is getting...\nDisinformation as a service? DaaS not good!\nWhy you\'ll wear a body camera\nShop Tech Products at Amazon\nSponsored Links\ndtSearch\xc2\xae instantly searches terabytes of files, emails, databases, web data.\nSee site for hundreds of reviews; enterprise & developer evaluations\nOnline Master of Science in Information Systems at Northwestern University\nThe future of ITSM is Cognitive Services.\nHumanizing the Digital Experience\nThe Modern IT Infrastructure Insight Report\nRising to the Security in the Cloud Challenge\n5 Great Reasons to Make Electronic Signatures Part of Your Business\nComputerworld\nThe Voice of Business Technology\nFollow us\nBrowsers\nCloud Computing\nData Centers\nEmerging Technology\nHardware\nIT Leadership\nInternet\nMobile\nOperating Systems\nSecurity\nSoftware\nVertical Industries\nNews\nFeatures\nReviews\nBlogs\nOpinions\nInsider\nShark Tank\nSlideshows\nVideo\nNewsletters\nComputerworld Events\nResources/White Papers\nAbout Us\nContact\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nMember Preferences\nAdvertising\nIDG Careers\nAd Choices\nE-commerce Links\nEditorial Beats\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 IDG Communications, Inc.\nExplore the IDG Network descend\nCIO\nComputerworld\nCSO\nIDC\nIDG\nIDG Connect\nInfoWorld\nITwhitepapers\nJavaWorld\nNetwork World'

aS'Aberdeen to benefit from free ultrafast wi-fi and phone calls - BT Regions\nSkip to main content\nMenu\nClose\nFree trial\nLog in\nSearch stories\nPricing\nHow it works\nAbout us\nContact us\nHelp & support\nLog in\nCreate news alert\nTo learn more about how your data is used by us when you use the website, please read our Privacy Policy. We use cookies to deliver our services and to ensure that we give you the best experience on our website. For details on our use of cookies, please go to the Cookie Policy\nGot it!\nBT Regions\nOverview\nNews\nImages & Videos\nContacts\nDocuments\nUnited Kingdom\nSelect Pressroom United Kingdom\nFollow BT Regions\nAberdeen to benefit from free ultrafast wi-fi and phone calls\nPress Release\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nApr 19, 2019\xc2\xa007:00\xc2\xa0BST\nAberdeen has become the second city in Scotland to benefit from the free InLink from BT service, offering residents, visitors and shoppers the fastest free public wi-fi in the UK, free calls to landlines and mobiles, free mobile charging points plus a range of digital services, including local council and community information.The InLink service from BT, which will provide an expected investment of \xc2\xa31.7 million in the city over the next ten years, will join the likes of Glasgow, London and Cardiff in offering access to these innovative free services. More than 400 InLink units are now live across the UK.With two ultra-modern InLink units initially introduced into Aberdeen city centre, at Upperkirkgate and Palmerston Road, a further eight activations are expected in the coming weeks, including Union Street and George Street. The new state of the art InLinks are replacing 23 existing payphones, offering more space on pavements, as on average, one unit replaces two BT payphones. BT\xe2\x80\x99s iconic red phone boxes will remain.Jenny Laing, co-leader of Aberdeen City Council, said: \xe2\x80\x9cAberdeen continues to build its reputation as a destination for business and tourism. It\xe2\x80\x99s great to see another development for local people, visitors and businesses which supports our digital ambitions.\xe2\x80\x9cSupporting our city centre with fast wi-fi and other services will help increase footfall, and aid retail and economic growth as a result.\xe2\x80\x9dAlso welcoming the investment, Innes Walker, city centre manager for Aberdeen Inspired, said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe addition of InLink devices to the city centre will help visitors recognise Aberdeen as a modern, forward-looking, technologically advanced city, supporting the tourist and retail economy and helping to attract investment. It is a great enhancement and one that Aberdeen inspired, along with Aberdeen City Council, have worked closely with BT on. By providing facilities for people to make free calls, access free wi-fi and charge their phones, the InLink service will add much to our city.\xe2\x80\x9dThe InLink service from BT, which is funded by advertising revenue to deliver free services at no cost to the taxpayer and local councils, already has more than 319,000 subscribers across the UK. Additional unique InLink features include encrypted WiFi, which protects your personal information when connected on compatible devices, interactive maps which allow users to easily get from one location to another, an emergency 999 call button and the option to add air quality monitors to allow local governments to build sustainable clean-air strategies.David Wallace, BT Director for public sector in Scotland and chair of the BT Scotland board, said: \xe2\x80\x9cAt BT, inclusive services are really important to us and we want everyone to be able to make the most of digital opportunities. The new InLink service from BT will benefit all of those who live, work and visit Aberdeen.\xe2\x80\x9cWe welcome the support from Aberdeen City Council and Aberdeen Inspired in helping us deliver this new service. Across the UK, InLink is already transforming high streets, removing unwanted payphones and giving streets a modern facelift with our compact and free of charge wi-fi and digital services.\xe2\x80\x9dProviding ultrafast wi-fi speeds of up to one gigabit per second (1Gbps), the fastest free public wi-fi service available in the UK, each InLink also provides more than 1,000 hours of local messaging a year, acting as a community notice board for the local area. These services are provided to the community at no public cost, as the project is funded by advertising revenue.Matt Bird, General Manager of InLinkUK, said: \xe2\x80\x9cWe are keen to continue our very successful roll out of the InLink from BT service to benefit consumers in Aberdeen. We want to support consumers\xe2\x80\x99 digital innovation ambitions by offering city workers, shoppers and tourists free digital services and help to create a Smart city in Aberdeen.\xe2\x80\x9dThe InLinkUK from BT service is dedicated to providing all-inclusive digital services, one of which is their charity icon on the tablet. A free one-touch lifeline to four national charities, which provides free calls to Childline, End Youth Homelessness, Runaway Helpline and Samaritans. The InLinks are also designed for wheelchair access and offer additional digital services, including for those who have sight and visual impairments.InLinkUK from BT is a partnership between BT and tech start up InLinkUK.NotesAbout InLinkUKInLinkUK is a tech start up providing a new communications network that will replace over 1,000 pay phones in major cities across the UK, with new units called InLinks. Each InLink provides ultrafast, free public wi-fi, phone calls, device charging and a tablet for access to city services, maps and directions, connecting those who visit, live and work in urban hubs across the UK. Hundreds of users within range of an InLink will be able to access free ultrafast wi-fi on the move, with speeds of up to 1Gbps - the fastest free public wi-fi service available. InLinkUK from BT is being brought to the UK through a joint venture between Intersection, the urban innovation company behind LinkNYC, and Primesight, a leading UK out-of-home media company, in partnership with BT.Learn more at http://www.inlinkuk.com\nBT\xe2\x80\x99s wi-fi network in the UK:\nBT already operates the biggest network in the UK, giving customers unlimited access to the most extensive wi-fi coverage with more than five million hotspots.\nAbout BTBT\xe2\x80\x99s purpose is to use the power of communications to make a better world. It is one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s leading providers of communications services and solutions, serving customers in 180 countries. Its principal activities include the provision of networked IT services globally; local, national and international telecommunications services to its customers for use at home, at work and on the move; broadband, TV and internet products and services; and converged fixed-mobile products and services.\nBT consists of four customer-facing units: Consumer, Enterprise, Global Services and Openreach.For the year ended 31 March 2018, BT Group\xe2\x80\x99s reported revenue was \xc2\xa323,723m with reported profit before taxation of \xc2\xa32,616m.British Telecommunications plc (BT) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of BT Group plc and encompasses virtually all businesses and assets of the BT Group. BT Group plc is listed on stock exchanges in London and New York.For more information, visit www.btplc.com\nShare\nFacebook\nTwitter\nLinkedIn\nE-mail\nRegions:\nAberdeen (City)\nTags:\nscotland\nRelated / Contacts\nBT Press office\nPress Contact\nnelbwsaxroavomoa@bwmt.wdcodomyu\nIf you are a journalist, please contact the press office via the BT headquarters switchboard number on 020 7356 5000\nAbout Mynewsdesk\nLoading page'
p82
aS"Users will get faster free Wi-Fi from hubs in New York\n| PCWorld\nClose Ad\nSubscribe\n\xe2\x96\xb2\nLearn more about PCWorld's Digital Editions\n\xef\x98\x90\n\xef\x98\x91\n\xef\x98\xb0\n\xf0\x9f\x94\x8e\nHome\nNews\nReviews\nHow-To\nVideo\nDeals\nDeals\nCoupon Codes\nShop\nBusiness\nLaptops\nSmartphones\nHardware\nPCs\nGraphics Cards\nInput Devices\nDisplays\nPrinters\nStorage\nNetworking\nCameras\nSecurity\nSoftware\nGadgets\nSubscribe\nResources\nPCs\nSmartphones\nPrinters\nUltrabooks\nBlogs\nViruses\nCameras\nComponents\nComputer Accessories\nConsumer Advice\nDigital Assistants\nDisplays\nE-readers\nGraphics Cards\nHard Drives\nHome Theater\nInput Devices\nKeyboards\nLaptop Accessories\nMobile\nNetworking\nOperating Systems\nOptical Drives\nCPUs\nServers\nSmartwatches\nStreaming Services\nStorage\nTablets\nWindows\nPCs\nGraphics Cards\nInput Devices\nDisplays\nPrinters\nStorage\nNetworking\nCameras\nHome\nHardware\nNews\nUsers will get faster free Wi-Fi from hubs in New York\nNew York's 7,500 LinkNYC hotspots will get processor, Wi-Fi and screen upgrades every few years\nEmail a friend\nTo\nUse commas to separate multiple email addresses\nFrom\nPrivacy Policy\nThank you\nYour message has been sent.\nSorry\nThere was an error emailing this page.\nBy Agam Shah\nU.S. Correspondent,\nIDG News Service |\nPT\nLinkNYC\nMore like this\nAndroid A to Z: A glossary of Android jargon and technical terms\nWhat you need to know about home IoT standards at CES\nCool Yule Tools for the Home\nVideo\nIntel Optane Memory H10 SSD review\nNew York City is replacing pay phones with new high-tech wireless hubs that will dish out free, high-speed Wi-Fi service, charge mobile devices and provide access to city services.In coming months, the city will install\xc2\xa0about 7,500 LinkNYC hubs, which include an Android tablet for surfing the Internet, connecting to city services and making VoIP calls. The hub will also include a wireless hotspot for connecting smartphones, tablets and PCs to the Internet.But the new technology has one potential challenge that pay phones didn't have: How do you keep the hubs -- also called Links -- up to date in a fast-changing technology world?[ Further reading: The best CPUs for gaming ]The project will handle that problem by bringing major technology upgrades to Links, at least during the first six years, a spokesman for the LinkNYC project said Monday. The city is still testing the Links and figuring out an upgrade schedule.The upgrades will focus in part on increasing processing power and wireless speeds.\xc2\xa0Sitting at the center of Links is an Android tablet on which a user can surf the Internet, use pre-installed apps, or make phone calls. On each side of the Link are 55 high-definition displays for advertisements and city notices.Qualcomm has provided some of the technologies for the Links, which are designed so the networking equipment, processor, tablet and other components can be regularly swapped out and upgraded.Qualcomm is committed to maintaining and upgrading systems over\xc2\xa0the lifetime of Links, said Kiva Allgood, vice president at Qualcomm's Smart Cities and Industrial IoT initiative. The goal is to keep the Links up to date with the latest technologies much like latest smartphones, Allgood said.The Links and the Android tablets are powered by a Qualcomm Snapdragon 600 processor with an Adreno 320 GPU. It'll be easy to snap out old technologies and plug in the latest processor and tablet, or change the screen to a higher resolution display, project organizers said.The Links' Wi-Fi and modem technologies will also be upgradable. A Link has 802.11ac multi-mode MIMO chip for gigabit Wi-Fi. It also has a 3G modem for 911 emergency calling and location services.\xc2\xa0Qualcomm designs modems and Wi-Fi chipsets, which are used in other companies' products like smartphones and routers. The company didn't say whether upgrades would be made by the company or by partners. LinkNYC is in beta, and product plans will be released to partners over time,\xc2\xa0Allgood said.Systems like LinkNYC need hardware flexibility to keep up with new Internet of Things implementations, said Jim McGregor, principal analyst at Tirias Research.The way New York City uses the LinkNYC systems could change over time, and they may be the backbone to connect lighting systems, smart meters, traffic networks, connected cameras and other IoT systems, McGregor said.Hardware changes like memory and modem upgrades will be needed over time, McGregor said. An example could be an upgrade to 5G connectivity, a technology designed to facilitate IoT and machine-to-machine communication.But upgrades will need to be relevant, not random. For example, a processor upgrade would make sense if it's used to handle faster modems and high-resolution screens, McGregor said.\nTo comment on this article and other PCWorld content, visit our Facebook page or our Twitter feed.\nRelated:\nHardware\nCPUs\nShop Tech Products at Amazon\nPCWorld\nPCWorld helps you navigate the PC ecosystem to find the products you want and the advice you need to get the job done.\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nDigital Magazine\nGift Subscription\nAd Choices\nMember Preferences\nCookie Policy\nNewsletters\nTerms of Service Agreement\nRSS\nPrivacy Policy\nShop\nCoupon Codes\nAliexpress\nEbay\nHome Depot\nHP\njcpenney\nOnePlus\nWalmart\nTarget\n6PM\nE-commerce Affiliate Relationships\nPCWorld Categories\nBusiness\nLaptops\nMobile\nPC Hardware\nDeals\nPrinters\nSecurity\nSoftware\nVideos\nWindows\nIDG Network Sites\nAdvertise\nPermissions\nMacworld\nTech Advisor\nTechHive\nIDG TechNetwork\nIDG\nIDG Blog\nCareers at IDG\nGet PCWorld's Digital Editions\nSubscribe Now\nFollow us\n\xef\x98\x90\n\xef\x98\x91\n\xef\x98\xb0\nVisit other IDG sites:\nSelect One\nGameStar\nGreenbot\nMacworld\nPCWorld\nTechHive\nCopyright \xc2\xa9 2019 IDG Communications, Inc."
p83
aS'How a Smart Wi-Fi Hub Could Change Tech Access and City Advertising - Curbed\nclock\nmenu\nmore-arrow\nno\nyes\nSubscribe\nLog In or Sign Up\nLog In\nSign Up\nCities\nTopics\nHandbook\nShopping\nMore\nCities\nAtlanta\nAustin\nBoston\nChicago\nDetroit\nHamptons\nLos Angeles\nMiami\nNew Orleans\nNew York\nPhiladelphia\nSan Francisco\nSeattle\nWashington DC\nTopics\nNews\nArchitecture\nHome Tech\nCampers and RVs\nInterior Design\nHouse Calls\nFor Sale\nLongform\nMaps\nHandbook\nShopping\n\xe2\x9c\x95\nUrban Planning\nHow a Smart Wi-Fi Hub Could Change Tech Access and City Advertising\nNew York\'s new LinkNYC program is beginning to replace defunct pay phones with ad-supported high-tech kiosks\nBy\nPatrick Sisson\nJul 25, 2016,\n3:44pm EDT\nShare\nTweet\nShare\nShare\nHow a Smart Wi-Fi Hub Could Change Tech Access and City Advertising\ntweet\nshare\nReddit\nPocket\nFlipboard\nEmail\nNew Yorkers have started to see them pop up around Manhattan and the Bronx, but if the creators of the LinkNYC high-tech kiosks have their way, city dwellers around the country and world will soon see these wi-fi hotspots and data hubs everywhere. Created by City of New York and CityBridge, a NYC\xe2\x80\x93based consortium of leading experts in technology, media, connectivity and user experience, these high-tech replacements for pay phones have already appeared on hundreds of street corners in Manhattan and the Bronx. Eventually 7,500 of the kiosks, nine-and-a-half feet tall curbed monoliths which offer free access to maps and city services, voice calls, device charging, and internet browsing, will cover the five boroughs, providing $500 million in ad revenue to the city over the next 12 years (the ad-supported network is being installed at no cost the the city)\nWill these new hubs live up to their promise of delivering tech equity by providing free high-speed internet access and helping bridge the digital divide, or are they just another invasive smart screen cluttering our landscape, a "personalized propaganda engine?" Curbed spoke with Dave Etherington, Chief of Strategy for Intersection, about the introduction of these high-tech kiosks and how to balance usefulness and ubiquity when designing a new advertising medium.\nWhat have you learned about how these kiosks are operating on the streets?\n"It\xe2\x80\x99s exceeded our expectation around usage. We\xe2\x80\x99re pretty early on, only about 5 percent of the Link kiosks have been installed. That\xe2\x80\x99s 330 in Manhattan and the Bronx, then Queens this week, and construction has been started in both Brooklyn and Staten Island. With those 330, adoption has been great. We already have 250,000 registered users. Every week the number changes. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been saying 15,000 new registers a week, and this week, I\xe2\x80\x99m happy to say it was over 20,000 new users. So we\'re well on the way to 1 million unique users. Last week, we had 1,000,000 wi-fi sessions and 40,000 tablet sessions, around half being phone calls. It\xe2\x80\x99s been stunning the amount of use we\xe2\x80\x99re getting. And there are plenty of surprising things; people have been playing YouTube videos and having impromptu dance parties in the street."\nYou mentioned the plans to expand to all five boroughs. How do you see this network helping underserved communities and turning wi-fi into a public utility?\n"Cities across the world are dealing with the issue of internet access. In New York, there\xe2\x80\x99s something like 2.5 million people in the city that don\xe2\x80\x99t have access to high-speed internet. We\'re part of changing the infrastructure of the city to democratize communications for everyone. We hope, and we\xe2\x80\x99re already seeing it, that Link is becoming something that\xe2\x80\x99s being used by people from every background."\nPeople have been playing YouTube videos and having impromptu dance parties in the street.\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the next step, and how does this network create a backbone for more smart city technology?\n"The next step is deploying more of the Link units, that\xe2\x80\x99s our first concern. We\xe2\x80\x99re still in beta, and learning. There are a lot of new test cases for the tablet itself that\'s built into the kiosk, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve been toying around with lots of different ideas. One day people could perhaps vote on these things. We\xe2\x80\x99re interested in pursuing these sorts of idea with the city, our big partner in this. I\xe2\x80\x99m really excited about future technology and AI; we think about Link as an open platform. Perhaps one day we could hold a hackathon to determine future use cases."\nWhat criteria are you using to make sure this is helping all New Yorkers?\n"We\xe2\x80\x99ll see it replace the entire payphone system. They\xe2\x80\x99ll be some greenfield sites, and in places where there are banks of phones, we\xe2\x80\x99ll replace them with just one or two Links. The idea is to have them where people are, so you know, there is heavily trafficked area where people live, work, and travel. In and of themselves, they\xe2\x80\x99re reflective of New Yorkers. There will be greenfield sites that we will create to fill in the gap. But for the most part, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be replacing the pay phone network."\nWhat are the other use cases you\xe2\x80\x99ve been considering with the tablets?\n"I suppose one of the immediate potential use cases is allowing people to make free video calls, not just voice calls, which would be a cool and interesting one. I think as these use cases develop, we want to make sure Link is open to including new ways of approaching different problems and challenges."\nThere have been a lot of discussion about the security and privacy implications of using this system. Can you explain from the perspective of someone walking down the street and linking to the network, how their privacy will be respected?\n"We have always taken privacy and security incredibly seriously. We set out to create the most robust, citizen-first privacy policy we could. To begin with, if you\xe2\x80\x99re a new user, when you begin the enrollment process, you only need to provide a very small amount of data, just an email address. Consider what you need for home email service, a credit card and sometimes even a social security number. So it requires a much smaller amount of personal data. We also anonymize and aggregate data. Our privacy policy dictates we\xe2\x80\x99ll never share any personally identifiable information, an email address or a name, with a third party. From a security perspective, we use end-to-end encryption, bank-like encryption. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s the first time public wi-fi has had end-to-end encryption like this. We\xe2\x80\x99re pretty focused on making sure people fall in love with Link and use it every day, and to do that, we need to put them first, we can\xe2\x80\x99t compromise them in any way. That\xe2\x80\x99s our raison d\xe2\x80\x99etre."\nThis is free for the city, but not a free system. it\xe2\x80\x99s supported by advertising. What kind of data will be utilized by this advertising? What will be collected and utilized, and how will it offer new advertising opportunities?\n"We know the exact location of every Link, and can utilize the time of day to deliver more relevant information. We don\xe2\x80\x99t just tell you about stadiums or teams, we tell you who\xe2\x80\x99s playing where and when. We have the ability to understand demographics with a variety of different measurement tools. That allows you to understand different locations and think about audiences with much more granularity. Both of those tools are becoming more and more dynamic, they\xe2\x80\x99re becoming more analogous to the type of dynamic digital measurement that exists online. You can think about the composition of an audience at a specific time, and trigger a change in advertising. You can use third-party data sets, and that gets really interesting. You can adjust to events like weather. The kiosk could say, there will be sideways rain at this location in several minutes; buy an umbrella or get an Uber. In the case of an advertising campaign with StreetEasy, we displayed nearby apartments and property. We have super fast wi-fi, so you can download the app to look at the apartment very quickly. In effect, we create this closed ecosystem; giving consumers a message and the bandwidth to take the next action."\nWhat do you define as success with the LinkNYC program?\n"When we came up with the idea for LinkNYC, we were inspired by Google Maps and YouTube. Really, none of us think about them as advertising platforms. They\xe2\x80\x99re products that people use everyday and have become an integral part of everyday life. And they\xe2\x80\x99re given away for free, they\xe2\x80\x99re just supported by advertising. I think at the very first stages, when we were thinking about Link, we wanted to create the best possible product. For instance, once you\xe2\x80\x99re on the network, you don\xe2\x80\x99t have to re-authenticate, because if you had to, it would be a bad experience. Once we\xe2\x80\x99re further down the road with roll-out, and it becomes a contiguous online experience for those walking and traveling throughout the city, and people just switch over to it without thinking, then they\'ll see how it changes their online behavior. They won\xe2\x80\x99t need to wait to go to work to do heavy lifting such as uploading photos. We can show them how to save money on their data plan. For us, keeping a close eye on usage is a measure of success. And as I said earlier, it\xe2\x80\x99s been a great start with the rollout thus far, and exactly where we want to be."\n"As far as advertising is concerned, it\xe2\x80\x99s about encouraging brands who haven\xe2\x80\x99t advertised in physical spaces before to try out Link. That would be a real measure of success, being able to show them we can deliver the creative and strategic potential of the internet in public. Think of newsprint, when you see, say, a Labor Day sale in the paper. With the proliferation of displays on the Link network, we can offer huge impact on those types of campaigns that traditionally wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t use this kind of advertisement."\n"It\xe2\x80\x99s really interesting since we have so many LinkNYC kiosks, and they have a place and role in people\xe2\x80\x99s daily lives. When the sad news of Muhammad Ali and Prince broke earlier this year, we pretty much instantly posted creative that really mirrored back the emotion of the city and connected the infrastructure of the city to its heartbeat. The Olympics is coming up, and we\xe2\x80\x99re interested in seeing how that works with Link. We\xe2\x80\x99re also interested in expanding to global cities, and other cities in the United States."\nWe have a million screens in our lives, and now this is another screen offering a new means of communication.\n"What\xe2\x80\x99s new is the additional context. There used to be very one-dimensional context to signs; put it up for four weeks, no editorial, no value proposition, no updates, that\xe2\x80\x99s it. No dynamism. With Link, we hope to not just solve the issue of technical inequity, but help bring about a smarter and more reactive city. And the network is going to be so fast, the phone will be the roadblock, not the network."\nHow do you create something in a public space that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t add more visual pollution or white noise, something people like as opposed to a screens everywhere, Blade Runner type situation?\n"Well, all that stuff I said about context is key. Design is also hugely important. We worked with Antenna design, urban architects who have won many awards, and we\xe2\x80\x99re proud of the way Link looks. When you see a unit on the street, it looks like an enduring part of the city. And of course, over the course of the 12-year contract, we\xe2\x80\x99ll update both the software and the hardware. Messaging and content are really important, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve just started figuring that out. Being part of the zeitgeist can help. We did this interesting campaign with Shazam where we surfaced live Shazam data; here are the top 10 songs people are listening to right now. And so, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got Sade on the West Side, and I was doing an interview on Turtle Bay, and Sonny Rollins was number two, in the neighborhood. That was pretty great."\nThese kiosks will also have sensors to measure data such as pollution levels. Will those be open source, and will the data be available to others seeking to build their own apps?\n"Definitely. We\xe2\x80\x99ve been working with the city and Argonne National Labs on how to put sensors in the kiosks that will measure information such as congestion, noise pollution, etc. We will have an incredible amount of new data, and we\xe2\x80\x99re interested in seeing what people do with it."\nNext Up In\nUrban Planning\nHow Mayor Pete used good urbanism to revitalize South Bend\nSidewalk Labs\xe2\x80\x99 new app helps designers and planners study how public spaces are used\nWhy U.S. cities need to learn from Copenhagen\xe2\x80\x94fast\n8 ways cities are transforming urban rooftops\nHow Seiichi Miyake\xe2\x80\x99s tactile blocks changed cities\nCan self-driving cars really make cities safer?\nMost Read\nWant to understand U.S. real estate trends? Look to Florida\nIn central Florida, sprawl, supercommuters, and seniors fuel growth.\n10 things to ask before buying your first camper van\nWhether you want to go the DIY route or buy from a manufacturer, here are 10 things to consider before you go all-in on a purchase.\nThe best furniture stores in the U.S.\nFrom antique stores in Detroit to a steel and wood manufacturer in Philadelphia, we\xe2\x80\x99ve rounded up 13 standout furniture and decor stores across the U.S.\n101 ways to fight climate change\nCurbed searched communities, consulted experts, and pulled from our voluminous coverage on sustainable cities to create a go-to guide for climate action.\nMultigenerational home designed like a \xe2\x80\x98mini apartment building\xe2\x80\x99\nThe bottom floors house an office, patio, and bedrooms for the young family, while the upper floor is an apartment for the grandparents.\nCurbed Daily Newsletter\nA daily dose of design and real estate news, intel, and eye candy\nEnter your email address\nSubscribe\nBy signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and European users agree to the data transfer policy.\nThis Article has a component height of 26. The sidebar size is long.\nThe Latest\nThe best Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Day gifts to shop right now\nFrom a terrazzo cheese board to a fresh-smelling eucalyptus shower spray, these affordable gifts say more than just "Thanks, mom."\nBy\nMegan Barber\nThese marble-like tables are made from recycled jeans\nSophie Rowley\xe2\x80\x99s designs are a practice in upending expectations.\nBy\nLiz Stinson\nShells, feathers, volcanic ash: How exciting materials are powering sustainable design\nMilan Design Week 2019 offered materials galore, including inventive uses for natural materials and various new takes on recycled plastic.\nBy\nSarah Hucal\nHow five cities are expanding bike share to underserved communities\nMaking car-free options available, and more welcoming, to all riders.\nBy\nPatrick Sisson\nThe best furniture stores in the U.S.\nFrom antique stores in Detroit to a steel and wood manufacturer in Philadelphia, we\xe2\x80\x99ve rounded up 13 standout furniture and decor stores across the U.S.\nBy\nMegan Barber\n2\ncomments\n/\nnew\nMediterranean-style mansion with picture-perfect pool wants $3.7M\nLocated in Rancho Santa Fe, California, this sprawling house features a dreamy resort-style pool.\nBy\nMegan Barber\nChorus\nTerms of Use\nPrivacy Policy\nCookie Policy\nGDPR Commitment\nCommunications Preferences\nContact\nSend Us a Tip\nCommunity Guidelines\nMasthead\nAbout Curbed\nNewsletters\nEditorial Ethics and Guidelines\nAll Systems Operational\nCheck out our status page for more details.\nVox Media\nAdvertise with us\nJobs @ Vox Media\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Vox Media, Inc. Following Intense Privacy Scrutiny\nResearchers Find YouTube Is Heavily Influencing Evidence-Challenged Flat Earthers\nVIDEOS\nAll videos\n2.5 Geeks\nReviews/How Lilly\n\xe2\x80\x94\nTuesday, December 29, 2015\nLinkNYC Free Gigabit Public Wi-Fi Takes Shape In New York\nTime change at a rapid pace, and whereas it was once common to communicate with each other when out and about using a payphone, these days everyone owns a smartphone. Every wonder what happened to all those phone booths? In New York, they\'re being converted into free municipal Wi-Fi hotspots.It\'s part of an effort called LinkNYC. It\'s described as a first-of-its-kind communications network designed to bring fast municipal Wi-Fi to millions of New Yorkers and tourists at no cost. The network is being fleshed out through five boroughs at no cost to taxpayers. Instead, it will general hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue for New York over the next 12 years primarily through advertising.New York is converting old phone booths into free Wi-Fi hotspots and digital hubsWorkers can already be seen installing LinkNYC hubs in certain parts of New York, The goal is to install around 7,500 hubs throughout the city, each of which will replace a telephone booth. Converted hubs will not only serve as Wi-Fi hotspots, but will also be equipped with USB ports for charging mobile devices, touchscreens for browsing the web, and big size displays to serve up advertisements. In addition, users will be able to make free phone calls to anywhere in the U.S. using the integrated tablet and microphone (you can plug in your headphones for more privacy).As for wireless speeds, officials claim LinkNYC\'s gigabit Wi-Fi is up to 100 times faster than the average public Wi-Fi that\'s available in parks and cafes. It also promises to be much faster than 4G LTE connections, provided you\'re within 150 feet of a Link.Though construction has already begun, there will be an initial beta phase to try out some of the features and provide feedback. After that, LinkNYC will roll out additional apps an services over the next few months and "on an ongoing basis over the next several years."\nTags:\nNew York, wireless, LinkNYC, wi-fi\nVia:\nThe Verge\nShow comments\nPlease enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus.\nblog comments powered by Disqus\nFollow Us:\nTwitter\nFacebook\nRSS\nEmail\nYouTube\nAppStore\nGoogle+\n85K\n12K\n32K\nNext Show TBD\nCONVERSATIONS\nAMD Zen 3 Ryzen, Threadripper And...35\nMicrosoft Next Gen Anaconda Xbox...27\nMan Receives 84-inch LG TV From...25\nCyberpunk 2077 Vastly Different Now...10\nFlexible Facepalm, Samsung Galaxy...5\nApple\xe2\x80\x99s Sinister Plan To Squeeze...5\nUS DOJ Has Serious Concerns About...5\nFEATURED\nNVIDIA GeForce GTX 16 Series...\nIntel Launches New 9th Gen Mobile...\nIntel Optane Memory H10 Review:...\nCrucial P1 SSD Review: Nimble NVMe...\nMaingear Vybe 2019 Review: Fast,...\nGigabyte Z390 Designare Review: A...\nAlienware Area-51m Review:...\nFAVORITES\nBest Ethereum Mining GPUs - A...3473K\nSamsung SSD 970 Pro And 970 EVO...1189K\n6 TB Hard Drive Round-Up: WD Red, WD...810K\nIntel Core i7-6700K And Z170 Chipset...652K\nQuadro P6000 And P5000 Review:...649K\nAMD Ryzen Review: Ryzen 7 1800X,...594K\nIntel SSD 750 Series PCIe SSD Review:...588K\nYour Next GPU\nRadeon VII\nGeForce RTX\nNext AMD\nNext NVIDIA\nIntel In 2020\nMore Results\nMORE HOT HEADLINES\nApple Pushes MacBook Keyboard...\nSony\'s 4K Flagship OLED TV Family...\nRazer Blade Pro 17 And Blade 15 4K...\nOnePlus 7 Series Snapdragon 855 5G...\nA Wonderful Super Mario Bros...\nTeen Slaps Apple With A $1 Billion...\nTesla Claims Its New Self-Driving...\nSITE\nHome\nReviews\nNews\nBlogs\nFull Site\nSitemap\nCATEGORIES\nPC Components\nSystems\nMobile\nIT/Enterprise\nLeisure\nVideos\nCOMPANY\nAbout\nAdvertise\nNews Tips\nContact\nHotTech Vision And Analysis\nMORE\nForums\nShop\nSTAY CONNECTED\nTwitter\nFacebook\nYouTube\nFeedburner\nThis site is intended for informational and entertainment purposes only.
