aS'LinkNYC Kiosks Provide Free Internet, But for a Price\nimage/svg+xml\nCONTINUE TO SITE\nThis website uses cookies in order to offer you the most relevant information.\n\xc3\x97\nLearn More\nI Accept\nMAGAZINE\nNEWSLETTERS\nEVENTS\nPAPERS\nMARKET NAVIGATOR\nSECTIONS\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL EDUCATION\nCENTER FOR DIGITAL GOVERNMENT\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nDIGITAL STATES PERFORMANCE INSTITUTE\nTOP 25\nGOVTECH 100\nSEARCH\nCybersecurity\nGovTech Biz\nEmerging Tech\nCloud\nGov Experience\nMore\nDC_Logo\nArticles\nLinkNYC Kiosks Provide Free Internet, But for a Price\nAs New York City replaces payphones with high-tech hotspots that deliver targeted ads, some concerns are being raised.\nby Craig Campbell\n/\nFebruary 9, 2016\nLink.nyc\nThe streets of New York City are one step closer to super-fast public Wi-Fi. LinkNYC, a public-private partnership between the city and a consortium of technology companies, has debuted its first two payphone-turned-tech kiosks in Manhattan. These gleaming aluminum "Links," as they are called, contain Wi-Fi beacons, mobile device chargers and informational tablets that include an app allowing free phone calls to anywhere in the country. The city plans to roll out 500 more of them by July and to have at least 4,550 spread across the five boroughs by 2020.\nThe Links are an early example of efforts by cities across the country to retool their public rights of way to provide better services and even generate revenue. In the case of LinkNYC, that revenue comes from advertisements that light up 55-inch HD screens on each side of the kiosks, changing every 15 seconds. The ad revenue will be split between the city and CityBridge, the designer and operator of the Links. The city is guaranteed at least $500 million over the next 12 years.\nThat arrangement is leading some to raise questions about privacy. Ad space on the Links is so valuable because of the user information (including IP addresses, GPS location and browsing data) that allows advertisers to deliver highly targeted content to passersby. The back end works similarly to ad-targeting algorithms users encounter while surfing the Web.\nRELATEDKC Kiosks Avoid LinkNYC\'s Porn Troubles, Rollout Going SmoothlyAfter Users Watch Porn, New York City Removes Web Browsing from LinkNYC KiosksNew York City Chief Digital Officer Bids Farewell \xe2\x80\xa6 for NowIn a recent article in The Conversation, Benjamin Dean, who researches Internet governance and cybersecurity at Columbia University, wrote that "far from being free, use of LinkNYC comes with the price of mandatory collection of potentially sensitive personal, locational and behavioral data." To underscore this point, he cited a Pew Research Center survey in which nine in 10 adults said that "being in control of what information is collected about them is important."\nA more recent Pew report, however, found that "there are a variety of circumstances under which many Americans would share personal information or permit surveillance in return for getting something of perceived value." That "something" might be a social media platform, a search engine -- or ubiquitous wireless Internet where payphones used to be. To echo the Pew report, "Free is a good price."\nLinkNYC has a transparent privacy policy promising that no personally identifiable information will be shared outside of CityBridge. But as with all public services, users must assume some risk. Even with the cybersecurity protections CityBridge has built into the Links, it still falls on users to make informed choices when connecting their devices to new sources of Internet service. As the Wall Street Journal\'s Joanna Stern put it in a recent video feature on LinkNYC, "You wouldn\'t use a public toilet without the proper precautions. Don\'t use a public hotspot without them either."\nCertainly privacy is a real concern in any public-private partnership involving citizens\' data. High-profile data breaches at the federal-government level and concerns over exploitive corporate data-mining practices have rightly elicited unease. But municipal governments have sustained a good track record so far. As partnerships of this sort become commonplace, cities have an opportunity to raise the bar and chart a path as public stewards of citizens\' information.\nIt remains to be seen whether LinkNYC\'s privacy protections will be as customer-focused as promised. But if it holds up, it will be a big step in advancing the city\'s tech ecosystem in a common direction, whether in city agencies, emerging start-ups in "Silicon Alley," schools in underserved communities or -- yes, the curbs of city sidewalks.\nThis column is part of a Better, Faster, Cheaper series\xc2\xa0featured on Governing, following the ways in which states and municipalities are reimagining public infrastructure as an underdeveloped resource. If you have tips on examples, please email them to bfc@hks.harvard.edu or tweet them to @GoldsmithOnGov.\nRELATED\nKC Kiosks Avoid LinkNYC\'s Porn Troubles, Rollout Going Smoothly\nAfter Users Watch Porn, New York City Removes Web Browsing from LinkNYC Kiosks\nNew York City Chief Digital Officer Bids Farewell \xe2\x80\xa6 for Now\nDISCUSS\nWe invite you to discuss and comment on this article using social media.\nNEW ON THE PODCAST\nThe Long Road to Autonomous Mobility\nDigital Communities Program Sponsors\nSponsored Content\nFeatured Papers\nFuture of Work: Recruiting and Retaining Employees in the Government IT Workforce\nGetting Your Arms Around the Cloud\nListening To Your Radio Network\nDigital First Engagement Management Solution eBook\nInnovating on a Budget\nSurveys & Awards\nAwards Calendar\nand Notifications\nNEWSLETTERS\nGOVTECH TODAY\nGOVTECH BIZ\nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT\nFUTURESTRUCTURE\nPUBLIC CIO\nDIGITAL COMMUNITIES\nSPECIAL DISTRICTS\nK-12\nHIGHER EDUCATION\nSubscribe\nABOUT\nPRIVACY\nCONTACT\nADVERTISE\nGT Logo\n\xc2\xa9 2019 All rights reserved. e.Republic'
p86
aS"LinkNYC: Wi-Fi kiosks delayed in city\xe2\x80\x99s poorer boroughs | StateScoop\nSubscribe\nAbout\nRSS\nBrought to you by\nSpecial Reports\nState\nCity\nCounty & Local\nWatch\nListen\nAttend\nContent Studio\nLinkNYC: Wi-Fi kiosks delayed in city's poorer boroughs\nShare\nWritten by Alex Koma\nNov 18, 2016 | STATESCOOP\nNew York City now boasts hundreds of LinkNYC kiosks that provide free Wi-Fi service \xe2\x80\x94 with more on the way \xe2\x80\x94 but one city lawmaker shared concerns that low-income neighborhoods are getting left behind.\nCouncilmember Jimmy Vacca held a hearing on the issue\xc2\xa0Tuesday as part of his Committee on Technology, pressing city IT leaders and their private sector partners for more details on their timetable for installing at least 7,500 kiosks by 2024.\nWhile Vacca praised the project for how it \xe2\x80\x9ccontinues to level the playing field\xe2\x80\x9d and get New Yorkers better internet access, he also expressed worry that Manhattan enjoys an outsized advantage.\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight now, we have more kiosks in Manhattan than in the other four boroughs combined, and that is inequitable and unfair,\xe2\x80\x9d Vacca said. \xe2\x80\x9cMany of these kiosks are in high-end neighborhoods that have access to Wi-Fi, but in neighborhoods that are poorer or middle income, they may never see these kiosks, or may see them 12 years from now.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Information Technology & Telecommunications oversees LinkNYC, while CityBridge \xe2\x80\x94\xc2\xa0 a group of tech companies including Qualcomm and Civiq Smartscapes \xe2\x80\x94 assumes responsibility for installation of the kiosks in exchange for the advertising revenue generated by the project. That bargain may be letting the city offer the service at no cost to taxpayers, but Vacca said those profit incentives \xe2\x80\x94 not concerns of equity \xe2\x80\x94 are guiding CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s involvement in the project.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rationale is that people in higher income neighborhoods with more money will see those advertisements and spend money on those products, while people in poorer neighborhoods in the outer boroughs don\xe2\x80\x99t have that disposable income,\xe2\x80\x9d Vacca said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey don\xe2\x80\x99t provide the bang for the buck that advertisers want, and that\xe2\x80\x99s called inequity.\xe2\x80\x9d\nStanley Shor, assistant commissioner for franchise administration with the city\xe2\x80\x99s IT department, acknowledged that the city is indeed a bit \xe2\x80\x9cbehind schedule\xe2\x80\x9d when it comes to installing kiosks in the city\xe2\x80\x99s outer boroughs.\nA report by committee staff confirms this. A city contract with CityBridge set a goal of 510 kiosks operational by fiscal year 2016, and while the city has 558 kiosks installed, only 434 are active, owing to technical difficulties. Analysts also found that the city has just two of a promised 20 kiosks installed in Staten Island \xe2\x80\x94 neither of which are active \xe2\x80\x94 while Brooklyn has only two functional kiosks of a scheduled 62.\nBut Jen Hensley, general manager of the LinkNYC program for CityBridge, stressed that there are mitigating circumstances that explain those delays. In Manhattan and the Bronx, Hensley said her workers could easily get access to conduit systems to install the equipment, but Verizon\xe2\x80\x99s ownership of infrastructure in the other boroughs complicates the process.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve found that 21st century infrastructure doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fit neatly in a 20th century footprint,\xe2\x80\x9d Hensely said.\nHensley noted that Verizon has \xe2\x80\x9cstrict policies and guidelines for third parties who want to do work in Verizon-managed manholes,\xe2\x80\x9d necessitating months of coordination with the telecom giant just to secure inspectors to accompany CityBridge workers for even basic tasks. In Staten Island, she added that much of the infrastructure is mostly on utility poles, forcing the company to negotiate a \xe2\x80\x9cwhole new agreement\xe2\x80\x9d with Verizon, further slowing work.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll of this means that before construction can even begin, we\xe2\x80\x99ve been working with partners for a minimum of five months and as much as a year,\xe2\x80\x9d Hensley said.\nCityBridge does share the city\xe2\x80\x99s equity goals, Hensley insisted, as evidenced by its work to install roughly a quarter of its kiosks in Upper Manhattan near Harlem.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe expect we\xe2\x80\x99ll see the pace pick up significantly in the outer boroughs in the coming weeks,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\nShor added that the city is keeping a close eye on CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s progress, and plans to fully review the consortium\xe2\x80\x99s work by the time they reach the contract\xe2\x80\x99s second anniversary in July 2017.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody wants to have them not meet their numbers,\xe2\x80\x9d Shor said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they don\xe2\x80\x99t look good, we don\xe2\x80\x99t look good.\xe2\x80\x9d\nBut he also warned Vacca that even if the contract is fulfilled on schedule, the outer boroughs will still not\xc2\xa0have as many\xc2\xa0kiosks as Manhattan. Once the project is finished, he predicted that half of all the kiosks built will be in Manhattan.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s still a bias towards Manhattan because of its enormous central business district, and the whole premise is that this is being paid for by advertising, which is extremely valuable in Manhattan,\xe2\x80\x9d Shor said.\nThat explanation did little to placate Vacca.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore this all started, I expressed concern that advertisers would want only Manhattan and told this wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the case,\xe2\x80\x9d Vacca said. \xe2\x80\x9cI was told, \xe2\x80\x98No, there will be equity.\xe2\x80\x99 This, to me, is not equity and only goes to reinforce my original belief. It was unacceptable then and it\xe2\x80\x99s unacceptable now.\xe2\x80\x9d\nShor insisted that the his hands are tied in that department, but noted that the contract allows for the city to opt for the construction of an additional 2,500 kiosks once the 2024 deadline arrives, which could mean other boroughs eventually get more attention. But, he admitted that other neighborhoods may need to rely on other projects to achieve the internet access promised by LinkNYC.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not the only way broadband is coming to other parts of the city,\xe2\x80\x9d Shor said.\n-In this Story-\nBroadband, Digital Services, equity, IT Infrastructure, Mobility, New York, Smart Cities, State & Local News, States, Tech News, Wi-Fi\nRelated news\nCity\nNew York City hires Obama administration tech adviser as CTO\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 2 mins ago\nCity\nWhy local governments should lead multi-jurisdiction disaster response\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 3 hours ago\nCity\nSt. Louis IT agency revised security policies after audit, CIO says\nby Benjamin Freed \xe2\x80\xa2 1 day ago\nAd Specs\nSponsor\nRSS\nPrivacy Policy\n\xc2\xa9 2019 Scoop News Group\n|\nAll Rights Reserved\nSearch for:\nThe latest state and local government tech news, delivered straight to your inbox.\nSign up for our daily newsletter.\nPrivacy Policy\nWe use cookies to provide you with the best experience across all Scoop News Group websites. By using Scoop News Group websites, you consent to the use of cookies. Learn more\nGOT IT!"

aS"Free, high-speed Wi-Fi hotspots launch in NYC -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nFree, high-speed Wi-Fi hotspots launch in NYC\nBy Derek MajorJan 29, 2016\nThe first of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s LinkNYC kiosks went live for beta testing Jan. 19, marking the city\xe2\x80\x99s first step in its plans to provide free, high-speed Wi-Fi.\nLinkNYC aims to create a communications network with its 7,500 Link stations that will be erected across the five boroughs by 2020, with 500 being installed by this summer.\nBACKGROUNDER\nNYC replacing payphones with Wi-Fi hotspots\nWi-Fi network connection points will be installed in NYC public payphone kiosks, replacing the aging devices. The hotspots will also still include an option for voice services and offer free calling to 911 and 311 (June 2014). Read more.\nNYC transforms pay phones into Wi-Fi network\nNew York City will install multi-function, Wi-Fi-based phone kiosks across the city offering free gigabit Wi-Fi and free domestic calls across the United States (November 2014). Read more.\nThe beta phase begins a handful of operational kiosks, each of which will allow users within 150 feet to connect to the LinkNYC gigabit\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi network. The kiosks are powered by an all-new, purpose-built fiber optic network that will deliver speeds up to 100 times faster than average public Wi-Fi, LinkNYC said.\nCityBridge, the consortium of technology firms building LinkNYC, is investing more than $200 million to install hundreds of miles of new fiber optic cable that will deliver gigabit connectivity to Links stations.\nAn Engadget writer who tested the service shortly after it became operations said he was getting 300 megabit/sec Wi-Fi access, much faster speeds than are typically available in coffee shops and most residences.\nThe kiosks\xc2\xa0will contain a built-in tablet allowing users to browse the web and access city services, maps,\xc2\xa0 directions and a 911 emergency call button. People can charge their mobile devices through USB ports, and using the Vonage app on the tablet, can make free phone calls anywhere in the United States, including to 311, 411 and 911. Links kiosks also have two 55\xe2\x80\x9d high-definition digital screens used for public service announcements and advertising, which helps fund the stations.\nAdditional apps and services will be rolled out over the next few months, according to the LinkNYC FAQ.\nLinkNYC has two networks: LinkNYC Free Wi-Fi and LinkNYC Private. The open network relies on web server-based SSL security to protect the information passing between a device and the Link. The private network secures all wireless communications between devices and the Link, regardless of whether a website uses SSL security, the FAQ explained. During the beta phase, the private network requires an iOS device and Hotspot 2.0 technology that lets a device verify the authenticity of the \xe2\x80\x98LinkNYC Private\xe2\x80\x99 network. The network is one of the first in the country to offer an encrypted public network at this scale, according to a post by Intersection on Medium.\nEven so, as the kiosks will be used to browse the web via public Wi-Fi, some are concerned that they pose security risks.\nHackers can \xe2\x80\x9cbreak into them and put information on them to use as a keylogger\xe2\x80\x9d to collect passwords, said Tyler Cohen Wood, a cybersecurity adviser to Inspired eLearning. \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re on the public network and sending sensitive information, you\xe2\x80\x99re on a network with potentially hundreds other people [who] have the ability to really see what you\xe2\x80\x99re doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTo keep the Link stations secure, CityBridge will install cyber protections, including a series of filters and proxies to block anyone who tries to download malware during a browsing session, The Verge reported.\nThe city will also monitor traffic to stop users from receiving data from a command-and-control server. And if malware is installed on a LinkNYC tablet, it would soon be deleted. \xc2\xa0The devices go through a hard reset after 15 seconds of inactivity, according to The Verge\xe2\x80\x99s report.\nFor those who are still uneasy about the security on public networks, Cohen Wood suggested they being wary supplying email addresses or other personal information to access hotspots.\nAbout the Author\nDerek Major is a former reporter for GCN.\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable Format\nRelated Articles\nMarching toward intra-soldier wireless\nFrequent shutdown threats prompt state and local safeguards\nAvoiding a repeat of Hawaii's 'wrong button' mistake\nE-gov vs digital gov: What's the difference?\nVirginia signs on to FirstNet\nGCN\nAdvanced Search\nStay Connected\nSign up for our of\nMadagascar\nMalawi\nMalaysia\nMaldives\nMali\nMalta\nMarshall Islands\nMartinique\nMauritania\nMauritius\nMayotte\nMexico\nMicronesia, Federated States of\nMoldova, Republic aS'New York\'s Free Wi-Fi Is Fast, Free and Super-Secure, But It Comes at a Price\nSubscribeSubscribe to Mic DailyWe\xe2\x80\x99ll send you a rundown of the top five stories every daySign me up Getty ImagesNew York\'s Free Wi-Fi Is Fast, Free and Super-Secure, But It Comes at a PriceBy\xc2\xa0Ruth Reader\xc2\xa0|\xc2\xa0Jan. 25, 2016Last week, New York City started rolling out what is expected to be the largest public Wi-Fi project in the world: new Wi-Fi hubs placed in the antiquated telephone booths scattered around the city.\xc2\xa0The breadth of the program is impressive: It spans all five boroughs and will bring to the city a total of 7,500 Wi-Fi hotspots, the majority of which will be deployed by 2020. The network&aposs speed is enviable; at over 200 Mbps, the download and upload speeds blow your standard Time Warner Cable package out of the water. But the most exciting aspect of the new network isn&apost its power or accessibility \xe2\x80\x94 it&aposs the security. You&aposll have the option to browse the web safely, with end-to-end encryption.Source:\xc2\xa0Spencer Platt/Getty ImagesThe public Wi-Fi problem:\xc2\xa0Public Wi-Fi is notoriously insecure; one 2011 study found\xc2\xa088%\xc2\xa0of public wireless networks\xc2\xa0weren&apost protected with an encryption key.Though connecting to wireless internet at a Starbucks may seem innocuous, it&aposs anything but. That&aposs because most Wi-Fi implementations are open networks. When connecting to the internet through a cafe network, on a bus or in a train, there are no barriers preventing someone from viewing your computer.How? Public Wi-Fi is prime environment for hackers to weasel in between you and the website you&aposre sending information to, allowing them to see all your traffic before it arrives at its intended destination.\xc2\xa0While websites that use encryption protocols like HTTPS (signified by that lock image in your browser bar) provide some protection against threats, there&aposs plenty of opportunity for human error. Simply navigating to your bank&aposs website could inadvertently expose you to a hacker threat. Seemingly legitimate websites can be frauds luring users to enter their login information and effectively hand over their personal data to hackers.Outside of what&aposs called a man-in-the-middle attack, there are more nefarious forms of hacking,\xc2\xa0like malware. For instance, a hacker can launch a pop-up window at the start of a session, invite you to click and then download software automatically onto your computer without you being the wiser. "The interesting thing is, when you do go through these devices, you assume they are secure,"\xc2\xa0Paul Nicholson,\xc2\xa0product marketing director of security firm A10 Networks, told\xc2\xa0Mic. "But there&aposs always the worry that there&aposs something intercepting in the middle."Source:\xc2\xa0Getty ImagesThis is why encryption matters:\xc2\xa0Given that most public Wi-Fi is unsafe, it&aposs particularly interesting that LinkNYC is offering users the opportunity to encrypt sessions end-to-end. End-to-end encryption means that communications can only be decrypted by the person receiving the message using a system of private keys.\xc2\xa0"On a public network, we treat everyone as their own network. No device can see any other device and nothing is shared between devices,"\xc2\xa0Colin O&aposDonnell, chief technology officer of CityBridge, the consortium running LinkNYC,\xc2\xa0told\xc2\xa0Mic.The feature is opt-in, so users have to choose to use it. This is so LinkNYC can download a device-specific key to the phone requesting encryption. That provides a small hurdle for those who may not know what encryption is. But, O&aposDonnell told\xc2\xa0Mic,\xc2\xa0CityBridge will also be deploying street teams near LinkNYC hotspots tasked with teaching the general public how to safely use public Wi-Fi and how to activate encryption. Safety tips include making sure you&aposre actually connecting to LinkNYC and not a spoofed version of the network, avoiding sites that aren&apost secured with HTTPS, and refraining from downloading files from unknown third parties. O&aposDonnell also says that CityBridge has a team monitoring the network around the clock for potential threats and abnormal activity. Given that one of the members of\xc2\xa0CityBridge is telecommunications giant Qualcomm, the security team is likely fairly robust. \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0Source: YouTubeYour data: LinkNYC&aposs\xc2\xa0Wi-Fi system is free, but there is a hidden cost. In order to fund this project, LinkNYC needs to make money. Like many tech platforms, it can do that through ads.\xc2\xa0For now, each station will feature a physical advertisement. LinkNYC will also serve patrons an ad when they first connect to the network. To serve up these ads to the right audience at the right time, the network relies heavily on anonymized user data. But rather than track web behavior, O&aposDonnell told\xc2\xa0Mic,\xc2\xa0LinkNYC uses outside information to know who you are and what you like.Using a device&aposs unique ID, LinkNYC can collect physical data about you that isn&apost tethered to your name, but rather a tokenized number. "We have points all across the city for lengths, and we know which lengths are near Barclays Center and we know when the Nets are playing versus when a Justin Bieber concert is,"\xc2\xa0O&aposDonnell said.\xc2\xa0"So you can start to build profiles about a place and specific time that&aposs really valuable to advertisers."LinkNYC plans to launch 7,500 Wi-Fi hubs in total, with 4,500 coming by 2020.\nLinkNYCLinkNYC does not directly share data with advertisers, O&aposDonnell said;\xc2\xa0it uses the data internally to help brands place ads. However, it will be sharing aggregated and anonymized user data it collects with the city&aposs Open Data Platform.\xc2\xa0It also plans on expanding the kind of data it collects from users. The consortium is partnering with the U.S. Department of Energy, Argonne National Laboratory\xc2\xa0and New York City to develop new ways of using smartphone sensors to collect information.\xc2\xa0For example, vibration detectors can sense how often buses are rumbling by a given location, while cameras can see how many bicycles are on a street or determine the speed of traffic."We think we can do something really special here by creating a really powerful network that generates insights and making those available to the public so that we can have researchers think about how to correlate air quality and populations and how people flow through the city," O&aposDonnell told\xc2\xa0Mic. "A lot of them, frankly, could be about equity and connectivity in the city and where we need to plan future deployments or address digital-divide issues."In taking advantage of these sensors, the CityBridge (and by extension the city) will have to navigate how to access these sensors in a way that doesn&apost violate user privacy. However, if LinkNYC can find a way to gain the public&aposs trust in an appropriate way, the payoff could be\xc2\xa0crucial urban innovation. Share:ShareTweetEmailCopy linkBy Ruth ReaderEmailFollowRecommended videoWhy women\'s rights activists want a "no" vote for Brett KavanaughSept. 18, 2018Most recentSamsung just delayed their foldable phone because of how fast the screens are breakingApril 23, 2019Elon Musk says self-driving \xe2\x80\x9crobo-taxis\xe2\x80\x9d will be here by 2020April 23, 2019Women become financially independent faster than men, according to this studyApril 23, 20198 instagrammable U.S. road trips to take this summerApril 23, 2019This Twitter account tracks every dog you can pet in video gamesApril 23, 2019It\xe2\x80\x99s surprisingly easy to lose your verification on TwitterApril 23, 2019Evan Rachel Wood: Why I\xe2\x80\x99m fighting to change California\xe2\x80\x99s domestic violence lawsApril 23, 2019An AI created a death metal album so even music isn\xe2\x80\x99t safe from robotsApril 22, 2019Elizabeth Warren has a plan to wipe out debt for 75% of Americans with student loansApril 22, 2019The best tablets for drawing, whether you\xe2\x80\x99re a professional artist or just doodlingApril 22, 2019CompanyAboutArchiveCareersCompany NewsContactEditorial StandardsLegalStyle GuideTipsTopicsGet new Mic stories instantly delivered to you.Stay updatedConnect with micConnect with mic\xc2\xa9 2019 Mic Network Inc. All rights reserved.'
p89
aS"ACLU: LinkNYC kiosks need better privacy policy -- GCN\nThe Technology that Drives Government IT\nAI & AutomationCybersecurityCloud & InfrastructureData & AnalyticsSmart Cities & IoTEmerging TechState & LocalMoreEventsResourcesNewslettersContactAdvertiseReprintsList Rental\nACLU: LinkNYC kiosks need better privacy policy\nBy Derek MajorMar 28, 2016\nNew Yorkers who have seen the LinkNYC kiosks popping up on sidewalks may be excited about the idea of free Internet access, but they may appreciate the potential risks involved.\nThe New York chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union has voiced concerns when it comes to the privacy policies for the kiosks, including the amount of information collected on users and how long that information is being stored by CityBridge, the company behind LinkNYC.\nLinkNYC\xe2\x80\x99s fact sheet states that the kiosks do come with an encrypted public Wi-Fi service and a \xe2\x80\x9ccustomer-first privacy policy.\xe2\x80\x9d However, in order to register to use the service, users must submit their email address and agree to allow CityBridge to collect information on devices used to access the service and clickstream data -- what websites users visit as well as where and how long they spend on certain webpages and what links they click on.\nThe ACLU said it believes that the amount of information gathered by the network will attract not only hackers who want to steal information, but also law enforcement agencies looking to track a citizen\xe2\x80\x99s whereabouts.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFree public Wi-Fi can be an invaluable resource for this city, but New Yorkers need to know there are too many strings attached,\xe2\x80\x9d NYCLU Executive Director Donna Lieberman said.\nThe organization also expressed concern over notification policies in the event that the New York Police Department or another government entity wants access to a user\xe2\x80\x99s private information. The current policy states that CityBridge \xe2\x80\x9cwill take reasonable attempts to notify you of such a request, to the extent possible,\xe2\x80\x9d which the NYCLU says fails \xe2\x80\x9cprovide any assurance to users that they will be notified of government requests for information.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAdditionally, CityBridge\xe2\x80\x99s privacy policy only offers to make \xe2\x80\x9creasonable efforts\xe2\x80\x9d to clear out personally identifiable user information, and that will only happen once a user has 12 months of inactivity on the network. That means New Yorkers who use LinkNYC regularly will have their personally identifiable information stored for years and possibly for the rest of their lives, NYCLU said.\nAbout the Author\nDerek Major is a former reporter for GCN.\nE-Mail this page\nPrintable Format\nRelated Articles\nMarching toward intra-soldier wireless\nFrequent shutdown threats prompt state and local safeguards\nSherlock at scale: Law enforcement enters the connected age\nAvoiding a repeat of Hawaii's 'wrong button' mistake\n5 states throw in with FirstNet\nGCN\nAdvanced Search\nStay Connected\nSign up for our a.
